column2: LEAD: At St. James's Episcopal Church in New York, Deborah Anne Norville, a daughter of Zachary Samuel Norville of Dalton, Ga., and the late Merle Olson Norville, was married yesterday to Karl Gert Wellner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gert Wellner of Stockholm. The Rev. J. Seymour Flinn, the senior associate rector of the church, and the Rev.

LEAD: MODERN DANCE HAS been called an art of rugged individualism, and modern-dance choreographers usually go their own creative ways. In contrast, Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis are two choreographers who for 38 years have worked in harmony together, even though each directs a company with its own esthetic personality: Mr.
LEAD: I BRING this up now because Arthur is dead. I heard about his passing thirdhand, which is not surprising if you consider how many years we were out of touch.
LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S independent toll-road authorities will be studied by a legislative committee next year to see if the time has come to bring them under closer state control.

LEAD: Anchors Aweigh Starring Gene Kelly, Frank Sinatra, Dean Stockwell. 1945. MGM/UA Home Video. 146 minutes. $29.95. In ''Anchors Aweigh,'' Gene Kelly and Frank Sinatra play two sailors on the loose in Los Angeles. The breezy duo, who are searching, of course, for a good-looking dame, find instead a precocious lad who wants to join the Navy.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Mets should keep Mookie Wilson. Not only is he a fine fine ballplayer but Len Dykstra has become unreliable, homer-happy, and is not the fielder Wilson is. He should also be kept in an attempt to show that the Mets do not have a racial quota system. THOMAS E. HILTON Brooklyn

LEAD: THERE was a great Preston Sturges movie in 1940 called ''Christmas in July'' - but now it's July in the Christmas season, as the Westchester Chamber Music Festival departs from its summer-only schedule to present two preholiday concerts. What's more, the spirit of cultural brotherhood hovers over the venture, as Saturday's 8:30 P.M.

LEAD: DANCE AND PHOTOGRAPHY. By William A. Ewing. (Holt, $50.) William Ewing's primary interest in photographs of dance lies neither in performance preservation nor in star adulation but in something more profound: the craft, sensuality and intelligence framed within each individual image. The author presents more than 200 full-page exquisitely reproduced images by such artists as Brassai, Genthe, Steichen, Man Ray, Degas, Nadar and Walker Evans, all of them connected by the subject of dance - primitive, avant-garde, spontaneous, classical.

LEAD: Monica L. Smith and Peter J. Unger were married yesterday at the Glitter Bay resort in St. James Parish, Barbados, by Magistrate Haynes Blackman. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. George Prescott Smith of Ridgefield, Conn., and the late Mr. Smith. Mr. Unger is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Michael Unger of

LEAD: Although it has the backing of the Koch administration, a plan to build restaurants in Bryant Park has failed to win endorsement from the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, adding ambivalence to a four-year chronicle of contention.
LEAD: Alexander M. Haig Jr. charged last night that Vice President Bush, as chairman of a study group on drugs, had recommended policies that were ''not working.''

LEAD: AT hearings last month on Canada's free trade agreement with the United States, a member of Parliament from the ruling Conservative Party here offered a sarcastic greeting to Mel Hurtig, the businessman whose name has become synonymous with opposition to the pact.

LEAD: Spurred by growing concern over the social and moral implications of contracts for women to bear children for other women, state legislatures are preparing to confront a spate of bills seeking to regulate the practice.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-27

LEAD: I STILL remember the artful phrase that first enticed us to leave home for Christmas, a habit we have kept up for 25 years. Earlier that year, my father had died suddenly. Bereft of this central figure, how were we - my mother especially -to endure our usual rituals? In the want ad section of the Saturday Review, a wellspring of intriguing possibilities in those days, I found our refuge: ''Tiki, Your Tropic Island Home.

LEAD: With a name like Smucker's, it helps to be male, or so it would seem from Andrew H. Malcolm's article ''Of Jams and a Family'' (Nov. 15). ''Smucker boys absorb the jam business from childhood,'' according to your report. Apparently, Smucker's perpetuates the myth in American business that men are better suited than women for leadership positions.

LEAD: The engagement of Kelly Kathleen Sheridan to Gregg Jones Nowell has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Michael R. Hayes of Rumson, N.J., the stepfather and mother of the future bride. Miss Sheridan is also a daughter of the late John M. Sheridan. Mr. Jones is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Nowell of Fair Haven, N.J.
LEAD: Seoul Hotels Fully Booked
LEAD: A voter-initiated referendum that would give terminally ill patients the right to choose a time to die is being proposed for the California ballot next year.
LEAD: Local government employed 447,000 people, a record number, in New York City during the first nine months of this year, according to Federal labor officials.

LEAD: Should the Mets keep Mookie Wilson? Should the Beatles have kept Ringo Starr, even though there were better drummers around? Do thousands at Shea call ''Moo-kie, Moo-kie'' instead of ''Lenny'' or some other name? Would this Englishman have taken so happily to baseball if Mookie hadn't been there?

LEAD: EVEN IN HIS APRON, Charles Palmer looks like a fullback. The 28-year-old chef is 6 feet 3 inches, 236 pounds, and is clearly more than a match for the sea bass on the cutting board in front of him. Palmer runs a meaty left forefinger along the scales, then, with a few strokes of the knife in his right hand, bones the fish and splits it into two fillets.

LEAD: BIG HERB, my father, never lost the thrill of killing. For him, there was no greater excitement than to be among a covey of quail, on an autumn morning, and to bring down one of their thundering forms with each barrel of his double-barreled Winchester. Or to stand in a blind at sunset, as the mallards lanced in from the exposed waters of the lake, and send one of their speeding bodies plunging into the marsh.
LEAD: As the last of 1,500 formally dressed guests piled into a military hangar here Monday for the grandest black-tie ball in memory, one guest mused about a plan for another kind of party.
LEAD: THE meetings industry records revenues of about $40 billion yearly, the principal beneficiaries being hotels and airlines, according to Mr. Hosansky of Successful Meetings magazine.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To the Editor The ''Time for Temps'' has been a developing, real phenomenon in the marketplace for the last three to four years, not just a recent development caused by the October market collapse (Prospects, Nov. 23).

LEAD: IF YOU ARE PLANNING to eat your hat, the place to go to put yourself in the right mood is the Fashion Institute of Technology at Seventh Avenue and 21st Street. There, in the exhibition gallery, you will find a hat that looks like a serving of French fries and a hat that looks like a strawberry tart; indeed, a whole array of culinary millinery, spread out like a banquet -headgear got up to resemble a salad, a

LEAD: WITH VCR'S RANKING high on countless Christmas lists, an appraising look at some recent models may be in order. Let's, for a change, not start at the top. Sure, it's nice to have the best picture and the latest features. But the latest advances in these respects add greatly to the cost. Viewers who simply want a reliable, basic V

LEAD: Enactment of a bill dealing with Defense Department programs in the 1988 fiscal year has set the stage for an investigation of allegations of censorship at Stars and Stripes, the newspapers published for members of the armed forces stationed overseas.

LEAD: It is curious that when the market experiences a decline, members of the securities industry and the Administration refer to the phenomenon as a ''correction'' (On Language: ''What Happened to the Market?'' by William Safire, Nov. 8). However, when the market goes up, the term ''correction'' is never applied.

LEAD: Rori Lisa Glover, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Glover of North Caldwell, N.J., was married last evening to Richard Edward Berse, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gurson Berse of Westfield, N.J. Rabbi Charles Kroloff performed the ceremony at the Crestmont Country Club in West Orange, N.J. The bride, an account executive at Country Home magazine in New York, graduated from Boston University.
LEAD: Bernard King twisted and turned down the lane tonight the way he used to, leading the Washington Bullets to a 122-107 victory over the Nets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
LEAD: I, too, am divorced and have bought a house into which I've settled very comfortably. It has become my best friend, my security blanket, my haven.

LEAD: KLAUS FUCHS The Man Who Stole the Atom Bomb. By Norman Moss. Illustrated. 216 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95. KLAUS FUCHS, ATOM SPY By Robert Chadwell Williams. Illustrated. 267 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25. THE SECRETS OF THE SERVICE A Story of Soviet Subversion of Western Intelligence.

LEAD: The Long Island Association, the region's largest business and civic organization, wishes to express its deep concern over comments made by Ernest J. Strada, Mayor of the Village of Westbury, in the article regarding the proposed reconstruction of the Meadowbrook Parkway-Northern State Parkway Interchange [ ''Parkway Proposal Draws Opposition,'' Nov.

LEAD: The Daily News reached a tentative agreement with the last of its 10 newspaper unions yesterday after nearly a year of intense labor negotiations that the paper has consistently described as critical to its survival.

LEAD: A conservative coalition led by supporters of Pat Robertson narrowly won a party rules showdown today with forces of Vice President Bush, but the Bush forces denounced the rules changes as illegal.

LEAD: IT'S hard to keep your mind on basketball when your personal problems keep mounting, and for Darryl Dawkins, things finally got to the point that he had no choice. On Friday morning, he called the Detroit Pistons' coach, Chuck Daly, and told him he was tired and needed time to sort out some problems.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about community orchestras misstated the origin of the all-professional Nassau Symphony Orchestra and the status of the Merrick Symphony. The Nassau Symphony is a descendant of the Massapequa Symphony, which has been replaced by the Massapequa Philharmonic, a community orchestra.

LEAD: PSYCHOLOGY and corporate image may play as large a role as budgetary concerns in this year's gift lists, according to Stuart Jacobson, author of ''The Art of Giving.'' ''You have to continue the highbrow giving'' - to the top officers of the company or largest clients, for instance - ''because you don't want it to appear as if the corporation has gone over the brink,'' he said.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Gross National Product III Q'87 II Q'87 Year Ago Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions $3,833.4 $3,795.3 $3,683.3 Real G.N.P. Growth Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in percent 4.1 2.5 2.9 Corporate After-Tax Profits III Q'87 I Q'87 Year Ago In billions, annual rate $141.5 $134.5 $144.0

LEAD: Three years ago, when he was sworn in as the first black Mayor of this old Navy town, James W. Holley 3d said it was ''a city on the verge of greatness.'' Today he is not so sure. True, the dramatic renovation of Portsmouth's once-crumbling downtown proceeds apace, giving the city a spruced-up colonial look and expanding its tax base.

LEAD: By the many hundreds of thousands, South Koreans poured into the streets and broad plazas of their major cities today to protest past repression and affirm their hope for a more democratic future.

LEAD: ONLY a few years ago I used to brag about how the American electronics industry single-handedly kept the United States trade balance positive. Over the past year or so, my little joke soured. Last year, the United States imported $13.5 billion more in electronics products than it exported.

LEAD: Only part of Handel's ''Messiah'' is really suited to Advent, but that is when we do it in this country, and at least five varieties are available this week. My recommendation is a choice between two Baroque-oriented groups. The elegant ''Music Before 1800'' series at Corpus Christi Church on 121st Street is presenting the Amor Artis Chamber Choir and Baroque Ensemble Sunday at 4 P.M.
LEAD: Last week, the American Civil Liberties Union rallied behind the British. Now it is taking up the cause of the Irish.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. George Olmsted of Wayland, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Graves Olmsted, to Kenneth Leroy Wyatt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Wyatt of White Plains. Miss Olmsted and her fiance graduated from Williams College.

LEAD: The Senate approved a $606 billion catch-all appropriation bill this morning that includes $7.6 billion in spending cuts required by the budget compromise between Congress and the White House. It also includes $16 million in nonmilitary aid for the Nicaraguan rebels.
LEAD: THE CORPSE HAD A FAMILIAR FACE Covering Miami, America's Hottest Beat. By Edna Buchanan. 275 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.
LEAD: The 10-member Atlantic City Casino Association has voted unanimously to support a casino official's challenge to New Jersey restrictions on casino participation in the political process.

LEAD: A dance listing today in The Guide, section 2A, gives an incorrect date for the Mark Morris Group at Lehman College in the Bronx. The company will perform at 8 on Saturday, March 19, not next Saturday.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 3 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts creates nightmares in a Maine village. 2 2 8 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel.

LEAD: AT a time when companies are increasingly filing for bankruptcy to shield themselves from litigation, Friday's landmark ruling in the A. H. Robins case may give executives and lawyers second thoughts about such a strategy.

LEAD: THE United States has found itself involved in a program that makes brilliant economic sense. The program helps our industries compete against manufacturers from the Far East, protects, promotes and creates jobs for American workers and contributes to the economic stability of a neighboring nation of vital importance.

LEAD: FABER BIRREN is a colorist, but not in the sense that Matisse is - or Bonnard or even Josef Albers. If anything, his lifelong devotion to the subject comes out of his rejection of art - or perhaps it was his rejection by art.

LEAD: THE VIEW FROM THE KINGDOM: A New England Album. By Richard Brown and Reeve Lindbergh. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $24.95 until Jan. 1; $29.95 thereafter.) The nostalgia of city dwellers for life in the country will be well-fed by this delectable coffeetable book, a collaborative effort by the husband and wife team of Reeve Lindbergh and the photographer Richard Brown.
LEAD: Carl C. Lella, an artist whose murals appeared in several Brooklyn high schools, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital, after a long illness. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: RIVERHEAD town planners want developers to bear more of the public load that their residential developments create, and under a proposal, developers would be compelled to provide for not only the physical structures, like roads, but also the preservation of vast amounts of farmland, the town's most valuable natural resource.
LEAD: The campaign buses and mobile billboards rolled out of their garages in the gray dawn this morning for the last day of activity before yet another Belgian national election.
LEAD: Hundreds of resumes have poured into the offices of Gov.-elect Buddy Roemer in response to advertisements seeking applicants for jobs in his cabinet.

LEAD: Q. I am having a problem removing nonskid bathtub decals I put down five years ago. I had taken up the old ones and put new ones in their place without ever getting all the old adhesive off. Now I would like to remove these decals and the sticky residue left. I have tried benzine, nail-polish remover and Spray 'N' Wash (which was recommended by the manufacturer of these decals), but I have only been able to remove the top layer, not the adhesive.

LEAD: An article from Cambridge, Mass., last Sunday about a dispute between M.I.T. and the City Council incorrectly described the eviction of squatters from a lot owned by the university. Two police dogs that were coincidentally driven past the scene of the disturbance belonged to the city police and were not involved in the eviction.

LEAD: NO GIFT AT CHRIST-mastime reflects better on the giver than the gift of gab. Here are the books about words available this year that will enliven debates, illuminate issues, prop up little kids at the table and prevent doors from slamming shut. New Big Guy THE RANDOM HOUSE DICTIONARY of the English Language: Second Edition-Unabridged is the big book of the year for word mavens.

LEAD: TIME WAS WHEN RECORD COMPANIES established their corporate identities mainly through the artists they held under exclusive contract. Victor, in its heyday, traded on Toscanini; Columbia countered with Bruno Walter. And in pops it was star bands like Benny Goodman and Tommy Dorsey that defined a record label.

LEAD: An American warship today helped rescue the crew of an oil tanker flying the Cypriot flag in the southern Persian Gulf, according to officials aboard the command ship of the United States Navy's gulf fleet.

LEAD: WE eagerly anticipated the holiday season even though we'd be dispersed at divergent global points. Our son would commemorate his 25th birthday with his first trip abroad - destination London. Our daughter would be in Florida with her newly acquired college friends, and we'd be on our inaugural trip to the Orient.
LEAD: FORBIDDEN GAMES Directed by Rene Clement. Embassy Home Entertainment. 85 minutes. $29.95.

LEAD: Virginia Durald Schrum and William Frederick Laporte 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Laporte of New York and Buck Hill Falls, Pa., plan to marry in April, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. John L. Schrum of Charlotte, N.C., have announced.
LEAD: The Town Council here has rejected plans for a five-day open deer season on Block Island, saying fears of an invasion of hunters outweighed complaints that the animals were ravaging shrubs.

LEAD: IN baseball's version of shuttle diplomacy, Sandy Alderson, the Oakland Athletics' vice president for baseball operations, led his entourage to the 19th floor of the Tower at the Loews Anatole Hotel in Dallas at 11 o'clock Thursday night. Armed with a tentative agreement on a trade with the Los Angeles Dodgers, they had a meeting with their counterparts with the Mets.
LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S rising prominence is due in part to the strength of its state government working in response to citizen needs.
LEAD: The war-crimes trial of John Demjanjuk, which began as a dramatic retelling of the Holocaust, has evolved in recent weeks into a detailed study of signatures, ink, paper and even paper clips.

LEAD: The engagement of Katharine Lambard Schwab to Adam Overton Kimmick, the son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Donald W. Kimmick of Mahwah, N.J., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Caspar Schwab of Oyster Bay, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: A condominium apartment building that is the product of a gut rehabilitation is strange enough in the Inwood section of northern Manhattan, where co-ops, rentals and less dramatic renovations are more common. But Academy Twins, with an exercise room, exposed-brick hallways and skylights, is different for another reason.

LEAD: The marriage of Mary McConnell Truitt, a writer and lecturer, to John Lyster Hill, a research analyst at the Center for Naval Analysis in Alexandria, Va., took place in Washington yesterday. The Rev. Charles O'Fallon Mastin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother, Anne Dean

LEAD: Anne Henderson Pollard, serving a five-year term for pleading guilty to charges related to the sale of state secrets to Israel by her husband, Jonathan Jay Pollard, was transferred Friday from a prison hospital in Kentucky to one affiliated with the Mayo Clinic for treatment of a digestive disorder, Government officials and family members said.
LEAD: WHAT is worrying retailers this Christmas season is not so much the number of buyers. It is the number of sellers. And they are going to great lengths in their pursuit of peace of mind.

LEAD: UNTIL the last decade or so, a hefty slab of meat - at lunch, sometimes at breakfast and almost always at dinner - was the staple of the Australian diet. A meat pie, oozing with tomato sauce, was the closest thing to a national dish. Even cafes selling fish and chips still boast signs saying, ''Fish and grills,'' as if to say that fish is too light for the hearty

LEAD: THE HOUSE IN which we live sits under a coffee-bean tree. Had we known about coffee-bean trees before buying the house, we probably would have told the real-estate agent to show us the next place. Because we lived previously in the city, however, we knew almost nothing about the personalities of trees, so we said we would take the house.

LEAD: A GRADUAL but steady re-industrialization is under way through sales of city-owned land in a broad section of East New York and Brownsville designated as the East Brooklyn Industrial Park. Land values are rising, new businesses are moving in, and Lawrence Rose feels vindicated.

LEAD: THERE will be no company Christmas parties at Bear Stearns, Shearson Lehman and some other Wall Street houses this year. Still, judging by the volume of corporate bookings reported by hotels and party planners, most organizations will continue to celebrate the holidays.

LEAD: THERE IS SOMETHING REALLY rather peculiar about the virtual unanimity with which Anselm Kiefer, now 42, has been accepted in the United States as the most important artist to have emerged from Europe in the last quarter of this century. Kiefer's work is like nobody else's. Often daunting in size and undeniably bizarre in its physical structure, it is predicated upon myths and magics, both private and public, that are quite unfamiliar in this country.

LEAD: New York City officials said yesterday that they hoped proposed legislation would give them a year to prepare for a $70 million cutback in Federal subsidies to house homeless people in shelters and welfare hotels.

LEAD: Should India keep the Taj Mahal? Should Egypt keep the pyramids? Of course the Mets should keep Mookie Wilson! At least, until somebody perfects a time machine that would render Willie Mays young again. BOB MURRAY Mt. Kisco, N.Y.
LEAD: IRMA, I know where your satin bridesmaid's dress is. Or rather, I knew where it was on Nov. 11.

LEAD: MAYBE the revivals that the fledgling theater company in nearby Fairfield, Conn., has announced for next year will validate its claim to the name Music Theater of Connecticut; its inaugural attraction, ''Ebenezer!,'' emphatically does not.
LEAD: Coach Walt Hameline being carried off the field after Seahawks defeated Dayton, 19-3, in Division III. Page 3. (AP)
LEAD: When the closing bell rang on Oct. 19, at the end of the worst day in the history of the New York Stock Exchange, a characteristically American era came to an end.
LEAD: AS December holidays lurk on the calendar, people are discovering the joys of visiting their summer homes on weekends.
LEAD: Two Into One

LEAD: MAMA, by Terry McMillan. (Washington Square Press/ Pocket Books, $5.95.) Mildred Peacock, the protagonist of this novel about a poor black family in a decaying suburb of Detroit, finds many ways to transcend poverty -alcohol, prostitution and plain, hard work. ''In its inexorable movement toward economic doom, 'Mama' [ proves ] that dignity can't be carried in a wallet,'' Will Blythe said here earlier this year.

LEAD: Here is the central fact of the recent summit meeting: Mikhail Gorbachev spent only 330 minutes in so-called working sessions with Mr. Reagan (including lunch) but spent 420 minutes in hard-selling the new Soviet line to awe-struck celebrities, ga-ga politicians and businessmen, tongue-tied media executives and a frustrated press corps.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Sara Emily Weiner, the daughter of Jane Brown of New York, and Dr. Jay Weiner of Danbury, Conn., was married yesterday to John Verneuille, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Verneuille of Lindenhurst, L.I. Judge Edward J. Kiley of the Suffolk County District Court officiated at the West Babylon, L.I., home of the bridegroom's brother, Robert Verneuille Jr.

LEAD: At the United Church of Christ in North Hampton, N.H., Kimberly Merin Wood, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin P. Wood of North Hampton, was married yesterday to Dr. Bryan Bruce Fuller, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Wayne E. Fuller of El Paso. The Rev. William McConnell officiated.

LEAD: THE COMPUTER-GENERATED images above represent a human hip. Reading left to right, two rows at a time (the white images illustrate bone structure; the surrounding musculature is in red), the hip appears to be rotating on a vertical axis. It's stop-action photography. Imagine the rotation performed before your eyes on a screen, the illusion of three dimensions, and you envision the accomplishment of innovative hardware and software now being readied for market by Pixar, a computer firm based in San Rafael, Calif.
LEAD: BE-BOP, RE-BOP By Xam Wilson Cartier. 147 pp. New York: Available Press/Ballantine Books. Paper, $4.95.
LEAD: TWELVE New Jerseyans will be honored for their achievements at a black-tie ceremony to be held Jan. 7 at the McCarter Theatre in Princeton.

LEAD: THE winning foursome in the Reisinger Board-a-match Team Championship in Anaheim, Calif., is surely the most remarkable ever to win that famous event. The cosmopolitan victors were Zia Mahmood from Pakistan, Jaggy Shivdasani from India, Ron Smith from Chicago, and Billy Cohen from Santa Ana, Calif.

LEAD: The space agency plans to test a backup Mission Control center to communicate with an orbiting space shuttle in an emergency. The plan will involve the use of portable computers hastily set up at an alternative site.

LEAD: New Rochelle, N.Y. $215,000 57 Monroe Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 81-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, enclosed porch, walk to station; taxes $1,694. Scarsdale, N.Y. $375,000 237 Boulevard 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 59-year-old masonry colonial; eat-in kitchen, den, deck, walk to station; taxes $4,333.

LEAD: East Germany has decided to participate in the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, and is expected to make an official announcement soon, the West German newsmagazine Der Spiegel reported today.
LEAD: A Delta Airlines jet had to turn around shortly after takeoff here because a bird was sucked into an engine, a company spokesman said today.

LEAD: TONY CONZA had dropped out of college and was working as an order clerk for E.F. Hutton when he went to a party in Jersey City. It was 1964. Among the guests were two high school friends - Peter DeCarlo and Angelo Bandassare - whom he hadn't seen in a while. After a few drinks, they began to bat around the idea of starting a business.

LEAD: With the second corruption trial of police officers in two years in progress here, indications are rising that a Federal investigation of the Miami Police Department might eventually affect 100 to 200 officers.

LEAD: The City Council has tabled a resolution to censure the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for ''bad faith dealings'' with a group of homeless people and their supporters who had lived on a lot owned by the university for five weeks.
LEAD: A VIEW FROM THE BENCH By Joseph A. Wapner. 249 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

LEAD: Basking Ridge $430,000 43 Penwood Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; pool, screened porch, 2-car garage, fireplace; taxes $4,078. Livingston $700,000 7 Surrey Lane 5-bedroom, 4-bath, 20-year-old split level; stone fireplace, indoor pool, sauna; taxes $8,256.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Harold Rappaport of Cherry Hill, N.J., and Tucson, Ariz., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Claire Rappaport, to Edward Kevin Flynn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Flynn of New York and Ashaway, R.I. The couple plan to wed Jan. 23.

LEAD: Investigators have ended their examination of a hillside littered with the wreckage of a Pacific Southwest Airlines jetliner that crashed this week, killing all 43 people aboard, officials said today.
LEAD: A weekly column on health and behavior. This week: The urgent need to monitor medication as the body ages.
LEAD: Officials at the New Haven Veterans Memorial Coliseum, after a stabbing death in a melee at a rap concert last month, have stopped selling open floor tickets for rock concerts.

LEAD: IN Budapest these days tourists love to bait their hosts with a single question: Is Hungary still Communist? The tourists' problem is that they cannot see where the system ends in this effulgent greening of ours; the hosts try to explain that under Communism even the grass is Communist.

LEAD: Sled-Dog Race Question: I have always wanted to see the winner of the Iditarod Trail Sled-Dog Race in Alaska. Once in Nome, will it be easy to learn when the winner will arrive and get a front-row look? - E. S., New York, N.Y. Answer: It is not easy, one of the race officials explains, to estimate accurately when the winner and his or her dogs will cross the finish line until the leaders are about 200 miles from Nome.

LEAD: A RIDGEFIELD couple get a kick out of dangling people from a sheer cliff, making them slither through an underground tunnel or hurling them down a roiling river. And they make them feel so good about it that five Connecticut school systems and a university are now sending over troubled students in need of a boost.

LEAD: To the Americans who met him, Mikhail S. Gorbachev emerged variously as a charming, steely and unpredictable Soviet leader - a man who, alternately, ''blew up'' at tough questions, who startled guests with his awareness of American culture, who seemed ''very controlled'' and curiously mysterious.

LEAD: Curbs on imports of Japanese cars were supposed to be temporary. Now almost seven years old, their cost to consumers has been staggering and the benefit to American car makers only marginal. Even so, Detroit has come up with a laughable new argument to make the ceiling lower still.
LEAD: THE HAPPY TIMES STORYBOOK by Phyllis Krasilovsky. Western Publishing Company. 45 pages. $6.95.

LEAD: Participants in the free-wheeling peace camps that have grown up outside American nuclear bases in Western Europe plan to continue their nonviolent protests despite the new treaty between the United States and Soviet Union.
LEAD: It is no wonder that George Pollock is divorced.

LEAD: AS hundreds of Christmas shoppers spill into downtown Stamford during this pre-holiday gift-buying season, a handful of people only yards away are already concentrating their efforts on New Year's Eve.
LEAD: THE WIDOW'S MITE And Other Stories. By Ferrol Sams. 218 pp. Atlanta: Peachtree Publishers. $14.95.

LEAD: WHEN I was faculty representative for athletics at Duke University, I thought I had learned something about college sports and the news media. When I moved to Dallas last summer and became president of Southern Methodist University with a mandate to put behind us the athletic problems of the previous year, I knew that I was about to learn a great deal more.

LEAD: In South Korea, military officers, worried about an opposition victory, talk about blocking this week's elections. In Haiti, the military juggles electoral rules to protect its interests. In the Philippines, the leader of a military reform movement is captured after repeated plotting against the Government.

LEAD: WHEN Gilbert and Sullivan wrote ''The Mikado,'' the English-speaking world's superficial understanding of Japan came largely from exhibitions like the quaint and pretty one underway at Knightsbridge in 1885. Our superficial understandings today are likelier to center on businesslike, technological Tokyo -where Peter Sellars set his ''Mikado'' production a few years ago - or perhaps on the look and sound of Kabuki theater, which were imported into the operetta by the Village Light Opera Group in its current production at the Fashion Institute

LEAD: A man described as emotionally troubled is said to have admitted that he killed a neighbor whose body was found in their apartment building, then barricaded himself in his apartment for six hours before surrendering tonight, the authorities said.

LEAD: OVER the past decade, the term maquiladora has entered the business lexicon. Maquiladoras are American-owned plants along the United States-Mexican border operating under special United States tax treatment and Mexican foreign investment regulations. American-made components are shipped to Mexico and used to assemble products that are sent back to the United States.

LEAD: There were Jews and Hare Krishnas, there were Buddhist monks; Vietnamese exiles mingled with Taiwanese evangelicals; Lithuanians and Ethiopians joined Afghan children, and one lone voice spoke out for Yupic Eskimos.
LEAD: New York City has received a grant of $200,000 for a historic preservation project to restore parts of its first insane asylum, opened in 1839 on what is now Roosevelt Island.

LEAD: THE NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC SOCIETY: 100 Years of Adventure and Discovery. By C. D. B. Bryan. (Abrams, $45.) If any American institution merits a five-and-a-half-pound $45-birthday card celebrating its centennial, it is the National Geographic Society. The society's superbly produced flagship magazine has guided generations of Americans from the benthos to the cosmos and is, I warrant, the only periodical regarded as impossible (if not downright illegal) to throw away; tons of issues are passed down like family heirlooms.

LEAD: As offices encroach upon bedrooms throughout the suburbs, Stamford, Conn., which is dominated by office buildings, is enjoying a spurt of residential construction. First was The Classic, 17 floors and 144 condominiums at the intersection of Forest Avenue and Greyrock Place just north of downtown. Construction began in the summer and is scheduled for completion at the end of next year.
LEAD: A special State Supreme Court panel has issued the mildest sanction possible against a justice of that court who dismissed a state-paid secretary for refusing to baby-sit his son.
LEAD: RESTING ON AN easel, the 15th-century ''Madonna of the Graces'' was lost amid the impatient cameramen and bureaucrats.

LEAD: MORE than three months after they were separated in a dramatic, 22-hour-long operation, two Siamese twins from Ulm, West Germany, remain in stable condition in their private room at the Children's Center of the Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions in Baltimore.
LEAD: MY COMPANIONS IN THE BLEAK HOUSE By Eva Kanturkova. Preface by Vaclav Havel. 314 pp. Woodstock, N.Y.: The Overlook Press. $19.95.

LEAD: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum has charged that a provision was quietly inserted in a House spending bill to allow one company to reap huge profits.

LEAD: To the Editor: Alan Cowell's account of his trip to the Bosporus via zig-zag ferry (Travel, Nov. 8) stirs pleasant memories. From an earlier New York Times piece, my wife and I learned of this commuter run a few years ago. That article directed us to Pier 1 near the Galata Bridge in Istanbul as the launch site.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Polly Rothstein's defense of the tactics that she and the Westchester Coalition for Legal Abortion used against me in the recent election for County Legislature have a hollow ring to them. [ Letters, Nov. 29. ] The newsletter that W.C.L.A. sent out in the waning days of the campaign not only misrepresented my prochoice position on abortion, but resorted to outright character assassination.

LEAD: Design With Plants Morris Video. 57 minutes. $14.95. Ed Hume likes toothpicks. This knowledgeable host, who is an author and radio-TV commentator, uses toothpicks to test whether the soil in a pot is dry and needs water. He also likes to lift a pot to determine its weight; if it is too light, he says the soil is probably dry.

LEAD: For a five-year period in the early 1980's, four marriages and two divorces added up to one wife too many for Vito J. Castellano. Mr. Castellano, the former commanding officer of New York State's militia, who is a prosecution witness in the Wedtech Corporation bribery trial, admitted in court last week that bigamy was among the crimes he committed around the same time he was taking bribes from Wedtech.
LEAD: SUCH WAS THE SEASON By Clarence Major. 213 pp. San Francisco: Mercury House. $16.95.
LEAD: Michael Porter's act may be news to many college basketball fans, but for Jerome (Pooh) Richardson, U.C.L.A.'s backcourt flash, Porter's high-flying acrobatics are old hat.

LEAD: Charles McVey 2d, an American fugitive wanted in the United States in connection with a multimillion dollar plot to sell advanced technology to the Soviet Union, was rearrested in a courthouse here Friday seconds after the judge freed him on an extradition warrant.

LEAD: Nancy Lowd Gleason and James Allen Simms were married yesterday at the Mead Memorial Chapel of Middlebury (Vt.) College. Dr. Olin C. Robison, the president of the college and a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Opponents of the Government and most shopkeepers in Dhaka defied a Government ban and began a dawn-to-dusk general strike today in an effort to overthrow President H. M. Ershad.
LEAD: THE fastest growing sector of Connecticut's agricultural industry is turning to high technology to meet increased demand for its products.
LEAD: The Golden State Warriors acquired Ralph Sampson and Steve Harris from the Houston Rockets tonight in exchange for Joe Barry Carroll and Eric (Sleepy) Floyd.

LEAD: IN the fall of 1937, I got my first job in New York - a rather odd one, and not at all what I had expected when I started looking. Life magazine, which had begun publication under the auspices of Time Inc. the year before, was expanding its staff, and I had heard that the chances of editorial employment for a young man with my background were pretty good.

LEAD: In a city desperate for development, the pricetag on a plan for the new headquarters for a major local corporation is the destruction of a warehouse district that preservationists say is essential to understanding Omaha's role in the growth of the American west.

LEAD: GLITTER, love and pain were the main ingredients in the ''All Ailey Evening'' presented by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Friday at City Center. Mr. Ailey is an eclectic. That the evening proved. But there is a unifying humanity in all his work. And it was danced here in the penetratingly expressive way that is so distinctive a feature of the Ailey dancers and their repertory.
LEAD: The brother of Mayor George Voinovich of Cleveland and the Geauga County Republican leader were indicted Wednesday.

LEAD: AFTER struggling 21 months to obtain a special zoning district, the developers of an apartment building planned on the site of the Olympia Theater on Broadway at West 107th Street say it may still be years before construction begins because a Toronto movie-theater chain has a long-term lease on the theater.

LEAD: An 18-year-old Brooklyn high school student died yesterday from a gunshot wound he received when he was the victim of a street robbery in the borough's Fort Greene section near his school two days earlier, the authorities reported yesterday.

Philip Ewald of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. John Calvin Knox Jackson performed the ceremony at the Basking Ridge Presbyterian Church.

LEAD: The jury in the Howard Beach murder trial, in its third day of deliberations, listened again yesterday to the testimony of a woman who told of hearing a black man plead with a group of white youths who were beating him.

LEAD: Pamela J. arrived in Manhattan in the dead of winter in 1985 on a Greyhound bus, with a sick infant in her arms and five other children trailing behind her, all without warm clothes. She was 22 years old, a single mother of six, nearly penniless, with a ninth-grade education and no marketable skills.

LEAD: An empty white building beside a busy freeway is all that remains of the nation's first private hospital for AIDS patients, which closed Friday after losing $8 million in the 14 months it was in operation.

LEAD: The question of trading Mookie Wilson is basically the battle between the heart and the mind. And nothing bonded Mets fans, total strangers only moments before, more than yelling ''Mooooooooooo-kie!

LEAD: I could not read ''Closed Windows, Good Neighbors'' [ Nov. 22 ] without being grateful that I am not one of Sara Jasper Cook's next-door neighbors. Does she think that the people who have alarm systems are any happier about them than she is? We, too, have to listen to them when they go off, have to worry that someone may be breaking into our homes, and feel like we live in a cage.

LEAD: The signing ceremony for the treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces was a moment filled with potential for the future. Such moments are to be savored, and then we return to the realities of the tough work still to be done.

LEAD: IS ANYBODY WATCHING, AND IF SO, who cares? David Brinkley wondered about it last Sunday on ABC. It's possible, he said, ''there are too many debates - maybe they're becoming a bore.'' Mr. Brinkley didn't specify, but he perhaps had in mind the two-hour, 12-candidate extravaganza on NBC a few nights before.

LEAD: NOT too long ago Miriam Paar, the wife of the television personality Jack Paar, was walking in Manhattan, looking hither and yon, when her eye fell on untied shoe laces flopping from a pair of Reeboks. She didn't give them a second thought until she observed that this was a peculiarity common to a number of teen-agers, all of whom were sporting untied shoe laces that frequently dragged along the pavement.

LEAD: THE roller coaster that the financial markets boarded in the middle of October just won't stop. Stocks went up 100 points last week, their best performance since August, but the dollar was battered. It now will buy less than half as many German marks and Japanese yen as it did at its peak in early 1985.

LEAD: LIFE and death, form and void, symphonic scale and improvisation -Henry Threadgill tackled the big ones in ''Run Silent, Run Deep, Run Loud, Run High.'' The Rev. Charles Ludeking performed the Protestant ceremony.
LEAD: First, vaudeville stopped being funny. Then a fire burned off the top floor. Finally, Jersey City, itself, began to slip. All in all, Florida Flats had hit hard times.

LEAD: A March wedding is planned by Leslie Janice Glick and Dr. Michael Goldberg. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Glick of Liberty, N.Y. Dr. Goldberg is the son of Rosalie Goldberg of East Brunswick, N.J., and the late Max Goldberg. The future bride is a product manager at Lederle International in Wayne, N.J., a division of the American Cyanamid Company.
LEAD: ''This will bring additional downward pressure and we look for this after the first of the year.'' - John Herrington, Secretary of Energy, on oil prices and OPEC impasse. [ 1:5. ]
LEAD: In 1977, President Jimmy Carter sat down with Helmut Schmidt and asked the West German Chancellor how they could work together to bring down the Berlin Wall.

LEAD: Corazon C. Aquino, who has had a trying tenure as president of the Philippines, found something to be ''really overjoyed'' about last week. In a raid on a Manila townhouse, the police captured Col. Gregorio Honasan, the army officer who in August led an attempt to topple the Aquino Government. The authorities said Colonel Honasan would face ''due process of law'' for his part in an attempted coup that left 53 people dead and hundreds wounded, including Mrs.

LEAD: As Leonard Silk's article ''Volcker on the Crash'' (Nov. 8) demonstrated, Paul Volcker is one of the most respected men in this country and throughout the world. I applaud and agree with his statement: ''We can control events if we do the right things.'' And there is, as he believes, time to deal with the underlying problems threatening the American and world economies.

LEAD: I would trade Mookie Wilson because: 1) He can't catch balls hit over his head; 2) he plays so deep, he can't catch flies hit over the infield; 3) he will severely injure another outfielder one day because he lacks basic communication skills when running for a fly ball; 4) he has never learned the strike zone; and 5) he wants to be traded.

LEAD: FOR me, Christmas dinner has to be traditional. That means a serious roast - goose, turkey or suckling pig - and plum pudding brought flaming to the table. Being British, I am used to dishes that might seem unusual to an American, but they are very much part of our repertoire and date back to long before the Revolution.
LEAD: CHAUCER His Life, His Works, His World. By Donald R. Howard. Illustrated. 636 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/ E. P. Dutton. $29.95.

LEAD: BEHIND EVERY WOMAN, there is a closetful of unused makeup - a lipstick that is almost the right shade of red, a pile of slightly garish eye shadows, a foundation that tints the skin an eerie shade of green. You'd think that all of these bungled purchases would help to keep cosmetics companies in business.

LEAD: Four small industrial communities in northern New Jersey with histories of chemically contaminated ground water had elevated levels of leukemia among women and girls from 1979 to 1984, according to a study by the New Jersey Department of Health.

LEAD: Dr. George H. Brown, former executive vice president for research and engineering at the RCA Corporation who led the company's development of color television, died Friday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Princeton.
LEAD: Chris Mullin has entered an alcohol rehabilitation program and will be out of action indefinitely, the Golden State Warriors announced tonight.

LEAD: Troubles in Cambodia In a country short of food, money and expertise, a longer than usual dry season may seriously cut back crops when the chief aid donor, the Soviet Union, is complaining that its assistance is being wasted. LEAD: During a recent swing through Chile's desert north, President Augusto Pinochet strongly criticized a prominent Socialist politician and equated him with the President of Nicaragua.

I have tried benzine, nail-polish remover and Spray 'N' Wash (which was recommended by the manufacturer of these decals), but I have only been able to remove the top layer, not the adhesive.

LEAD: Mike Turk ran for two touchdowns, including a 51-yarder with 1 minute 43 seconds remaining, as Troy State defeated Portland State, 31-17, today to win its second National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II championship in the last four years.

LEAD: HAVING heard the St. Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra's performance of Honegger's ''King David'' on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall, it is not difficult to understand why the work was greeted so favorably at its premiere in 1921. The oratorio tells the grandiose, impassioned story of the Old Testament figure's passage from shepherd to king in music that is both ingratiating and light.

LEAD: THIS SATURDAY EVENING, when listeners gather around their radio sets and tune to their local public-radio station - in New York City, WNYC-FM from 6 to 8 - they will preview a continuing anomaly: a live radio show performed before a live studio audience, featuring music, storytelling and comedy sketches.

LEAD: SEVERAL weeks ago, the Board of Education in New York reported that 55 percent of those who entered city high schools in 1982 did not graduate in 1986. Such numbers have been heard before, in New York and elsewhere, but educators, politicians, business leaders and others are showing new concern about the problem of high school dropouts.

It was cool and cloudy when my wife and I, with the baby in his stroller, joined a crowd gathered on the sidewalk and street outside the funeral home.

LEAD: THE GREATEST OPERA - SO a surprising number of people who dare to nominate one have called it - is 200 years old this season. Whatever its absolute standing among the great, ''Don Giovanni,'' first heard on Oct. 29, 1787, in Prague, can claim one primacy without question. It did something no other opera before it had ever done - it survived its epoch.

LEAD: UNCOMMON THOUGH they may be, Pre-Columbian textiles and feathered garments - boldly graphic, vividly colored and robustly textured - continue to appear in New York art galleries. Currently, for example, the exhibition ''Masterpieces of Ancient Peru: Textiles and Featherwork,'' at the Martin and Ullman Artweave Textile Gallery, 310 Riverside Drive (at 104th Street), presents 16 examples of weaving and stitchery, dating from 400 B.C.
LEAD: DESPITE decades of research costing hundreds of millions of dollars, scientists admit to a profound ignorance about the nature of alcoholism and the effect of drinking on the body.

LEAD: To the Editor: I thought that the article on the Weissensee cemetery gave an excellent description of the cemetery and the history surrounding it. I have been fortunate enough to visit Berlin twice and stay with close friends who live there. I have also toured extensively in East Germany. On my most recent visit to East Berlin, I was taken to the Weissensee cemetery one Sunday afternoon.

And while formal illness exemptions guaranteed his place on the 500-meter and 1,000-meter Olympic teams, Thometz will still have a chance to make the 1,500-meter team.

LEAD: Beyond Therapy Starring Julie Hagerty, Jeff Goldblum, Glenda Jackson, Tom Conti, Christopher Guest. Directed by Robert Altman. 1986. New World Video. 93 minutes. $69.95. This surreal romance is strictly for Robert Altman addicts. Christopher Durang's play has been Altmanized, which is to say that characters have been transported to the director's alternative universe, making ''Beyond Therapy'' a disorienting experience indeed.

LEAD: Outside the mainstream, contemporary art sometimes seems to be turning into a menagerie. So many animals have been invented, depicted and unleashed in painting that they almost seem to be taking over. This need for nature is something of a reaction against the amount of theory in art now. Animals also make it possible for artists to express an affection for living creatures in a way that the human figure, as problematical as it has been in 20th-century art, does not.

There is a sense that no one, not even post-modernists who reject everything he stands for, knows how to cut him down to size.

LEAD: To the Editor: I recently returned from my first and most certainly my only trip to Mexico. While several guidebooks that I purchased before the trip implored me to make sure my car was safeguarded regularly and that bribery of officials is a virtual way of life, I felt that my trip would be restful and enjoyable and that those statements could not apply to a resort town like Puerto Vallarta.

Yes, the newspapers were right: snow was general all over Ireland. It was falling on every part of the dark central plain, on the treeless hills, falling softly upon the Bog of Allen and, farther westward, softly falling into the dark mutinous Shannon waves.

LEAD: ONE thing that you will find out, as we did, when you travel in the Yucatan, is that climbing down those Mayan pyramids is completely terrifying. Unfortunately, you are not going to find this out (and even if you are warned, you won't really believe it) until you are standing on top of one. So there we were at Chichen Itza, and Larry was up on top of the biggest pyramid, and Perri was down at the bottom reading to Benjamin from a favorite book, ''The Cow Who Fell in the Canal,'' and after she had read it through for the seventh time she realized that Larry was not down yet.

LEAD: IN recent months an anonymous phone call helped the Willimantic Police Department find and arrest a suspect in an armed robbery of a convenience store. Another call helped the department make arrests in a drug case.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz issued a plea to NATO nations today to increase spending for conventional weapons.
LEAD: In tribute to the untied tongue, formerly shy people from around the world came here to dance together this evening in a black-tie celebration of gumption.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN JAMES L. BROOKS'S NEW FILM, ''Broadcast News,'' a handsome new anchorman is called into television action during a crisis in the Middle East. As played by William Hurt, the anchorman is, intellectually, way over his head and completely unprepared for the demanding assignment. Jane Craig, the producer of the newscast and the heroine of the movie - a brainy, feisty and extraordinarily self-possessed young woman - speaks to the anchorman through a hidden Telex earpiece, and, while he is on camera, force-feeds him questions, information and direction.

LEAD: FOR 23 years, three four-story factory buildings stood empty and deteriorating on a bluff overlooking the Naugatuck River, persistent reminders of the prosperous manufacturing town that Seymour once was.

LEAD: New York is a city of contrasts - home to the very rich and to the very poor. A city of bright lights and dark corners. New York is home to corporate giants and home to the unemployed. For every success story, we hear another story of disaster.
LEAD: In an unusual meeting, victims of a dishonest lawyer in Rockland County got an apology from the legal profession and a pledge of full restitution from a state agency this week.
LEAD: Wagner College established superiority early today and went on to win the Division III football championship by defeating Dayton, 19-3, in the Amos Alonzo Stagg Bowl.
LEAD: An advertising agency here, worried that Santa Claus has slipped in popularity polls, has decided to repackage him to make him a figure for the 1980's.
LEAD: Defense lawyers have attacked the credibility of a key informer who said two defendants took part in Brink's armored-car robberies for a black revolutionary group.

LEAD: THE New York City transit police have often been branded a second-class force, and the criticism has continued through much of the 1980's - from the death of Michael Stewart after his violent arrest in 1983 to the latest reports of false arrests by officers trying to improve their performance records.

LEAD: ACCORDING to an instructional book entitled ''Basketball Hints,'' those graceful giants in Boston Garden violated common wisdom nearly every time they ran up and down the parquet floor.
LEAD: WHY should Congress elevate the Veterans Administration to Cabinet status? It's simple, to many veterans and legislators: There's no compelling reason for it not to.
LEAD: THE accent was on strong and resonant performing when the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presented a program of four dances on Saturday night at City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

LEAD: Proud tradition once ruled in naming the Navy's ships - battleships for states, cruisers for cities, submarines for creatures of the sea. Those rules no longer hold, partly because the changing design of ships has blurred the distinctions between classes, partly because someone hit upon the idea of lionizing politicians.

LEAD: Released from neutrality by Governor Cuomo last week, many Democratic public and party officials in New York are preparing to take sides in the Presidential contest, with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and Senator Paul Simon of Illinois picking up most of the support.

LEAD: The developer of a controversial office-tower project near Columbus Circle insisted earlier this month, in negotiations with Mayor Koch, on receiving a $5 million reduction in the site's purchase price as well as the equivalent of a short-term loan from New York City in that amount.

LEAD: The Stogel Companies, which has been doing advertising for Adler Royal Business Machines for 22 years, has become the beneficiary of a decision by client management to consolidate. So its assignment, which was in the area of $3 million to $4 million, has now grown to $8 million.

LEAD: During his junior and senior years at St. John's, Chris Mullin, one of the most popular basketball players to come out of New York City, was known as a fun-loving type who enjoyed a beer or two after a game. News yesterday that Mullin is battling a drinking problem and had checked into a treatment program at Centinela Hospital in Inglewood,
LEAD: A renegade engineer whose company helped push Smith International Inc. into the oil service industry big leagues was drafted last week to guide the company from out of its doldrums.

LEAD: Tests of bacteria genetically altered to prevent frost damage to crops were postponed today because of gusty wind, a spokesman for Advanced Genetic Sciences said. The experiment was tentatively rescheduled for Monday, said the spokesman. The Oakland company wants to test the bacteria, which it calls Frostban, on an acre of strawberry plants near here to determine whether Frostban can prevent frost damage to fruit and nut crops.

LEAD: Roger L. Nichols, president and director of the Boston Museum of Science since 1982, died of a heart attack Thursday morning. He was 61 years old. Dr. Nichols supervised a major expansion of the Museum of Science, opening a new wing in March that contains a $14 million Omnimax theater. Under his leadership, the museum began new educational programs, sponsored major exhibits on India and

LEAD: It is beyond Dolby. It is beyond the best efforts of the audio engineers. It is 3,000 people from top to bottom and side to side of a great auditorium, all lustily singing Handel's ''Messiah.'' The performers are the audience, making music together in total wraparound sound.
LEAD: A novel use of an old technique is forcing new attention on one of the most wrenching issues in medicine: the use of babies born without brains as organ donors.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Reagan Administration would no longer insist that Congress accept the Administration's broad interpretation of the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile treaty, which would have allowed an expanded pattern of ''Star Wars'' testing.

LEAD: The Washington Redskins, who struggled all year to win the Eastern Division of the National Football Conference, fulfilled the admonition of their coach, Joe Gibbs, to peak toward the end of the season and played one of their best games of the season today, defeating the Dallas Cowboys, 24-20.
LEAD: Coleco Industries gave layoff notice to 25 workers at its headquarters Friday and the company said there could be further staff cuts throughout the corporation by the end of the month.

LEAD: Julie Ann Lawrence, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Lawrence of Fairfield, Conn., and Oak Bluffs, Mass., was married yesterday to Horace McDonald Barker Jr., the son of Mrs. Lloyd Watson of Grand Terrace, Calif., and Mr. Barker of Dana Point, Calif. The Rev. Peter Floyd, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Rolling Hills Country Club in Wilton,

LEAD: The Soviet Union could pay, in part, for increased imports from the United States by selling Americans inexpensive cars, a top Soviet economist has suggested. Those cars would be intended to compete with low-cost Yugoslav and South Korean models.

LEAD: Bernard E. Epton, a well-to-do Republican insurance lawyer who came close to wrecking Harold Washington's 1983 effort to become the first black Mayor of Chicago, died of an apparent heart attack yesterday in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 66 years old and lived in Chicago, where he was born.

LEAD: At Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I., Beth Jill Landau, a daughter of Muriel Landau of Oceanside, L.I., and the late Sidney Landau, was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel Dancis Benjamin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Benjamin of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Abner Bergman officiated. The bride graduated from Hofstra University and is a candidate for a master's degree in speech pathology and audiology there.
LEAD: What do we really know about Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, the United States Supreme Court nominee?
LEAD: A paper chase through yellowing war crimes archives last week solved the case of the missing Nazi files - a mystery that never was, according to United Nations officials.

LEAD: Trade officials say the Canadian-American free trade agreement is somewhat similar to the treaty on intermediate-range nuclear weapons that was signed last Tuesday by Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev.

LEAD: First of all, the cow imported last year from the ever-receding farmlands is doing well at the zoo - herself a celebration of the progress of this tough and friendly city. For now the sight of such a pastoral creature being milked has been offered to urbane Dubliners as an exotic treat.
LEAD: A GUSTY west wind rattled the bare branches of the hardwoods on the hill above the two blinds where the four of us lurked, awaiting the arrival of mallard ducks bound for a nearby small pond.

LEAD: Last June, Lee Yul Hee took part in her first demonstration, a peaceful protest against the tear gas that choked the streets of Seoul. Today, Mrs. Lee and her friends sat in church and talked of their hopes for democracy - and their fears that the freedoms they helped to win may yet elude them.
LEAD: Clifton Chenier, the Louisiana accordionist and singer whose fans called him ''the king of zydeco,'' died Saturday evening at Lafayette General Hospital in Lafayette, La. He was 62 years old.

LEAD: Most West European Governments appear to be genuinely satisfied that an accord eliminating medium- and shorter-range missiles was signed but relieved that no bold or unsettling superpower initiatives were undertaken.

LEAD: Nearly seven years ago, when a group of mayors met in Washington with officials of the brand-new Reagan Administration, they got a shock whose waves still have not died away in city streets and city halls.

LEAD: After months of searching for a new director for the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, President Reagan has decided to nominate an Army major general who helped negotiate the new treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles.
LEAD: Treasury financings this week include the full cycle of bill issues, starting with today's auctions of three-month and six-month issues and concluding with a one-year offering on Thursday.

LEAD: Capt. Joyce Hardy of the Salvation Army helping Meltris Walker get into his bow tie before a graduation ceremony for 12 homeless men yesterday at the Salvation Army's Central Citadel Corps on East 52d Street. The men, who are homeless, received high school equivalency diplomas with the help of the Salvation Army.
LEAD: So many people contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in memory of loved ones that it would be impossible to cite them all.

LEAD: Clarence Sibert with a 700-pound sow in his pigpen in Lawrenceville, N.J. Mr. Sibert is facing eviction from town-owned property by Lawrence Township officials who contend that his animals are a serious threat to the public. (NYT/William E. Sauro)
LEAD: Jerry Walker of St. Anthony's High School in Jersey City thinks it will be better than the Jersey Shore.

LEAD: Tawana Brawley, a popular 15-year-old high school student, was found Nov. 28 curled in a fetal position inside a plastic bag behind an apartment house in Wappingers Falls, six miles south of here.

LEAD: Faced with conflicting advice and confusing economic projections, Federal Reserve officials are likely to stand pat and leave monetary policy unchanged at this week's meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee, analysts said.
LEAD: It's been a year since Zwelakhe Sisulu, a black editor, was taken from his Soweto home at 3 in the morning to prison. Why? No one knows.

LEAD: An article on Nov. 30 from East Greenville, Pa., about an automobile fatality involving four teenagers on Halloween night, misstated the distance from East Greenville to the nearest McDonald's. It is much less than 20 minutes by car. A map with the article mislocated two communities. The designations for East Greenville and Reading were reversed; East Greenville is east of Reading.

LEAD: SKI boots are probably the oddest footwear worn by modern man. In some ways they're the man-made equivalent to webbed feet: they're not pretty nor particularly comfortable to walk around in, but they're not supposed to be. They've been designed for function. Ski boots have outer shells made of very stiff - almost rigid - plastic that come with buckles, knobs, dials and levers to make them fit tightly.

LEAD: The trade that sent Ralph Sampson to the Golden State Warriors late Saturday night was the culmination of the three uneasy years that it took the Houston Rockets to decide that the 7-foot-4-inch Sampson was never meant to be a power forward but rather a center.

LEAD: A New York City police officer was shot in the leg yesterday while trying to apprehend a suspect in a double homicide in Brooklyn, and a passing motorist was slightly injured in the shooting, the police said.

LEAD: At age 55 and in only eight weeks, an aggressively conservative talk-show host named Sean Morton Downey Jr. has become a kind of cult figure among young, working-class males whom advertisers normally expect to watch hockey games.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Dec. 3 about Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Carl H. Pforzheimer & Com-pany described their business ar-rangement incorrectly. The firms have formed a joint venture.

LEAD: Two hours after it began deliberating at noon on Friday, the Federal District Court jury that is expected to decide Michael K. Deaver's guilt or innocence early this week sent a message to Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. The 12 middle-class Washingtonians wanted a dictionary, and the judge sent it to them.

LEAD: Since last June, at more than 75 galleries ranging from the scruffiest East Village storefronts to the toniest Upper East Side salons, artists and dealers have offered paintings to sell for the benefit of AIDS research.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Philip Greer might have made Archimedes smile.

LEAD: WHAT is popularly known on Wall Street as the ''January effect'' has nothing to do with wintry weather. It is a seasonal phenomenon in which stocks that have been hard hit by selling for tax purposes in December often stage a partial recovery the following month.

LEAD: Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell, President Reagan's national security adviser, said today that the United States would view the introduction of advanced Soviet weapons into Nicaragua as ''a very serious matter.''
LEAD: The Advertising column in Business Day on Nov. 24 misidentified the parent company of Hanes Underwear. It is the Sara Lee Corporation.

LEAD: Skiing Italian Wins Giant Slalom: Alberto Tomba of Italy won the men's giant slalom yesterday at La Villa, Italy, for his third World Cup victory in three races. Tomba, who will be 21 years old Saturday, edged Rudolf Nierlich of Austria, and Joel Gaspoz and Hans Pieren, both of Switzerland.

LEAD: Justin Fiederlein, 13 years old, and his brother Andrew, 9, taking part in TubaChristmas yesterday at Rockefeller Center. About 400 tuba and euphonium players took part in the annual concert of holiday music. (NYT/Vic DeLucia)
LEAD: From the ranks of New York's 200,000 municipal employees, six men and women have been selected to receive awards ''for exemplifying the best in public service.''
LEAD: Tom Lawson, a scrappy former Harvard halfback, has become chief executive of Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson, a relatively small agency that frequently plays against the big boys and wins.

LEAD: Bobby Hebert threw two touchdown passes to Eric Martin and one to Lonzell Hill today to lead the New Orleans Saints to a 24-10 victory over the Houston Oilers. The victory extended the league's longest current winning streak to seven games.

LEAD: Laws requiring the use of seat belts have saved an estimated 1,300 lives in recent years, a new study shows, and the researchers say there is a direct relationship between strong enforcing of the laws and reducing highway fatalities and serious injuries.
LEAD: For years, Clarence Sibert lived alone on a corner of farmland here, with the pigs he raised and the dogs he kept as pets.
LEAD: FOR the serious recreational athlete, one of life's little pleasures is the first day back after a frustrating period of idleness caused by an injury.
