LEAD: Elizabeth Ann Haas, a partner in McKinsey & Company, management consultants, , was married yesterday in New York to Steven Gallen Edersheim, a corporate vice president of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Rabbis Marshall T. Meyer and Irving Block officiated at the Brotherhood Synagogue.

LEAD: The leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, arriving here today for their first summit meeting in more than a decade, face a region and a world that has changed profoundly for them since their organization was founded 20 years ago.

LEAD: Federal investigators, looking into charges of corruption in the awarding of Government telephone contracts, have focused their inquiry on top officials of the General Services Administration, consultants to that agency and representatives of the regional Bell telephone companies, according to individuals close to the investigations.

LEAD: Around the Chrysler Corporation the in-the-know set is calling introductory advertising for the new Jeep/ Eagle mid-size car the ''Big Bang'' because of the large amount being spent in a short period of time. Trade sources said the 1988 budget is $50 million.
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about black children and their doll preferences misattributed results of a Hofstra University study.

LEAD: THE Microsoft Corporation, creator of computer software in Redmond, Wash., recently received a letter from an ad agency that purportedly offered its services on the ground that a couple of its creative people had worked for a Microsoft competitor and were willing to share its secrets.

LEAD: James Colgate is a handsome, 19-year-old private first class in the Army, stationed at Fort Carson, Colo. Classified as an elite athlete, however, Colgate is allowed to spend most of his time at the United States Olympic Training Center in Colorado Springs, where he is practicing to become a member of America's

LEAD: NICOLAS SLONIMSKY'S life in music is already so diverse that it would take the space of this review just to list the chapter headings in his career. Mr. Slonimsky, who is 93 years old, has composed, played the piano, conducted, taught and lectured. But we know him best for two other activities: his early support of such composers as Ives, Chavez, Varese, Riegger and

LEAD: JOHN ADAMS is very much the American composer of the moment. Across the river in Brooklyn, his opera ''Nixon in China'' plays to large and approving audiences; his ''Harmonielehre'' is being taken up by many orchestras, and on a smaller scale, there is his ''Tromba Lontana'' - a five-minute fanfare written for the Houston Symphony in 1986.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Dwight McCarthy, a chubby, mild-mannered radio host who has stirred protests here over efforts to lead an incursion into Utah by an Idaho-based group of extremists, brought allies here Saturday to help support his messages of racial discord.

LEAD: At Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville, N.Y., Cynthia Cleveland Hawkins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic H. Hawkins of Bronxville, was married yesterday to John Mitchell Guarino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Guarino of Fairless Hills, Pa. The Rev. Christopher L. Webber performed the ceremony.

LEAD: For almost as far back as Steve Nemeth can remember, he has been on his own. Decisions were his, backed by the family, but shaped exclusively by his instincts, less than developed though they may have been.

LEAD: The Jets today looked like a team that had never been in a big game before. They were jittery, unable to count to 11 and bamboozled by a 34-year-old quarterback who has neck, shoulder, elbow and knee problems.

LEAD: The jury in the Howard Beach trial deliberated for five hours yesterday without reaching a verdict in the case of four white teen-agers charged with taking part in what has been described as a racial attack on three black men in Queens last December.

LEAD: The oil minister of Iran, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, said tonight that he was leaving a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to consult with his Government about a potential agreement that would allow its enemy, Iraq, the freedom to produce as much oil as it wishes.
LEAD: To accommodate as many as 5,000 more patients in drug treatment programs run by New York State, Mayor Koch has offered 10 city-owned buildings and space in municipal hospitals and clinics.

LEAD: Katie Wolfe and her father, Fred, looking for a Christmas tree in Denver after two inches of snow fell there yesterday. Up to 16 inches had fallen by last night in Colorado's southern mountains, and 18 more was forecast. In New Mexico, where the storm caused the closing of Interstate 40 and other highways, 19 inches fell in Ruidoso and 18 inches at Escancia.
LEAD: Three railroad tank cars burst sporadically into flame today after a derailment Saturday that forced the evacuation of some 5,000 people because of a threat of toxic fumes.

LEAD: With his support among American officials eroded, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military strongman, has begun more openly courting the Soviet Union, the Salvadoran guerrillas and others hostile to the United States, according to Administration officials and a Nicaraguan defector.

LEAD: Anthony Kennedy, President Reagan's third choice for the Supreme Court vacancy, can expect a friendlier reception than his defeated forerunners when he meets today with the Senate Judiciary Committee. That's not because he's a closet liberal, as some senators on the right seem to suspect. Judge Kennedy may prove just as ''conservative'' as Robert Bork or Douglas Ginsburg.

LEAD: Pity the poor play-by-play announcer who comes to a National Basketball Association game unprepared. Imagine the contortions of his tongue as Uwe Blab of the Dallas Mavericks blocks a shot by Larry Krystkowiak of the Milwaukee Bucks. Envision his consternation at a Boston-Seattle game when Jerry Sichting of the Celtics fouls Russ Schoene of the SuperSonics, or at a Sacramento-Utah game when Joe Arlaukas of the Kings dribbles between Mark Iavaroni and Bart Kofoed of the

LEAD: President Daniel arap Moi has released from detention a well-known Nairobi lawyer who was detained nine months ago as he was preparing to represent political prisoners in a suit against the Government charging that police engaged in brutal methods of torture.

LEAD: THERE is an annual ritual among sailboat owners who face winter's onslaught of cold and snow. They haul the boat out of the water, throw a canvas cloth across its deck, and store it somewhere until the next boating season. But it doesn't have to be that way.
LEAD: When John Leftridge and his teammates on the Wagner College football team stepped off their chartered flight at Newark Airport Saturday night, they were not received by an enthusiastic throng.
LEAD: A man shot and killed his former wife, two of their children and two other adults and wounded another of his children before killing himself early today, the police said.

LEAD: John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday that he would not allow instruction about condoms in AIDS education programs in the schools, hospitals and youth programs of the Archdiocese of New York despite the qualified approval of such an approach by his fellow bishops.

LEAD: The Nets, with an 11-game losing streak and a 2-15 record, will be without Buck Williams, the heart of the team, for the next 10 days to two weeks, according to Dr. John Sanzoni, the team doctor.

LEAD: Judith Ann Kramer, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert S. Kramer of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, L.I. to Stephen A. Kovach, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Kovach of Fairview Park, Ohio. Rabbi Neil Kurshan officiated. The bride is a product manager for the Progressive Corporation, an insurance holding company in Mayfield Village, Ohio.
LEAD: The Pennzoil Company will more than double in value if Texaco Inc. pays it $3 billion in cash to settle their legal dispute, according to analysts.

LEAD: Jack C. Carsten, one of the Intel Corporation's highest-ranking executives and the leader of the company's move into an important new market, is leaving the semiconductor company to become a venture capitalist.

LEAD: When Dr. Robert C. Gallo, the Government's top expert on the AIDS virus, began hinting in recent months that he might resign to help found a private research institute, a collective shudder passed through the top officials of the National Institutes of Health, where Dr. Gallo has his laboratory.

LEAD: Despite vocal opposition from some institutional investors, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange is likely to set permanent daily price limits on its popular Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures and options contracts in coming weeks, officials said.

LEAD: Joyce Purnick, City Hall bureau chief of The New York Times, has been named by the Fund for the City of New York as the recipient of its fourth annual Peter Kihss award ''for outstanding reporting on New York City government.''
LEAD: Eleven more state legislatures are considering laws that would encourage American business to fight employment discrimination against Catholics in Northern Ireland.
LEAD: Bernard H. Barnett, past national president of the charity organization United Jewish Appeal, died Thursday at University Hospital here. He was 71 years old.

LEAD: Count Giuseppe Panza di Biumo of Varese, Italy, is a man with a cultural mission. And that is to place his vast, in-depth collection of recent American art in the right hands, even at bargain prices.

LEAD: With memories still fresh of the President and the Soviet general secretary calling each other ''Ron'' and ''Mikhail,'' denizens of the capital are pondering the duration of the new thaw in U.S.-Soviet relations.

LEAD: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles didn't get all of the business of the Bahamas Ministry of Tourism. When D.M.B.&B. landed the $13 million account last week, there was still some left over for Caroline Jones Advertising.

LEAD: It may be only a coincidence that the man chosen Friday in Brussels as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization wrote his doctoral dissertation on ''The Stationing of Foreign Forces in Friendly Countries.''
LEAD: When his telephone rang at 6 A.M. on June 1, Robert C. Wright, the president of NBC, was jolted awake. On the line was Mayor Koch.
LEAD: Kenneth Davis ran 7 yards for a touchdown with 1 minute 9 seconds to play today to cap a 72-yard drive that gave the Green Bay Packers a 16-10 victory over the Minnesota Vikings.

LEAD: MIHAI TETEL, a Rumanian cellist trained in Canada and now resident in New York, gave a debut recital of Haydn, Beethoven, Schumann, Debussy and Sarasate Saturday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall. Mr. Tetel is capable of making good musical sense, and he avoids many of the exaggerations of vibrato and phrasing that often cling to this repertory.

LEAD: The 11 words in gold along the bottom of Eugene Savage's mosaic mural at the courthouse on Queens Boulevard chronicle an idealized vision of crime and punishment: ''Truth, Error, Transgression, Plea, Inquiry, Evidence, Correction, Exoneration, Rehabilitation, Faith, Security.''

LEAD: ''Although people asked for democracy, I didn't know that democracy was going to be this chaotic and bring about so much worry. We cannot vote for the ruling party if we want democracy, but we cannot vote for the opposition because we fear chaos.'' - Chun Hae Sun, a Seoul restaurateur,

LEAD: QUESTION: What quarterback holds the N.C.A.A. record for passing yardage in a game and whose record did he break?

LEAD: A 51-year-old clothing designer was found fatally stabbed at his East Village apartment Saturday, and a man who described himself as the victim's lover was arrested last night after admitting to the slaying when the designer told him he had AIDS, the police said.

LEAD: Someone pushed over two decorative brick pillers in front of Gov. Evan Mecham's home Tuesday evening, the police said. Mr. Mecham, who faces a drive to remove him from office, and his wife, Florence, were in Washington at the time. Last Dec. 21 when Mr. Mecham was Governor-elect, prowlers entered through a hole they cut in the roof and walked about while the Mechams were asleep, the police said.

LEAD: Albert Innaurato, author of the play ''Gemini,'' is among seven playwrights who are to receive this year's Drama League Playwrights Assistance Awards. The awards, given annually by the Drama League, allow for a cash stipend of up to $1,000 for each recipient and the opportunity for a staged reading of the playwright's recent works.

LEAD: The president of E. F. Hutton & Company said yesterday that, contrary to widespread fears among professional employees, the firm would pay bonuses to those who were eligible and who had earned them. ''We're paying them,'' Robert P. Rittereiser said.

LEAD: Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo arriving to celebrate Mass in Managua. The Cardinal, a mediator in Nicaragua's civil war, had been scheduled to meet today in the Dominican Republic with representatives of the contras and the Sandinista Government, but the talks were postponed after the Government asked for more time to prepare.

LEAD: The apparent failure of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to agree on halting overproduction and ending price discounts may cause a drop in the world oil market, putting pressure on the cartel to accept Iranian proposals for a price increase, oil industry analysts said yesterday.

LEAD: IN a gesture rare among recitalists today, Jeffrey Kahane invited two colleagues, Arleen Auger, the soprano, and Gary Hoffman, a cellist, to join him during his performance at the 92d Street Y on Saturday evening. As it happened, the pianist found himself being upstaged at one moment by Ms. Auger, who contributed the evening's only inspired passage - her still and gentle version of the opening lines from Brahms's ''Unbewegte, laue Luft'' (''Mild, unagitated air'').

LEAD: The year's big shopping season is also the season for the book publishing industry's annual fall sales conference - the time to trot out next spring's and summer's books for the company sales force, which will then try to get them into bookstores.
LEAD: The question whether South Korea's presidential vote this week will be seen as fair or rigged emerged clearly today as the issue with the greatest potential to touch off post-election disorder.

LEAD: Jim Kelly threw touchdown passes of 12 yards to Ronnie Harmon and 8 yards to Trumaine Johnson as Buffalo beat Indianapolis, 27-3, today to move into a first-place tie at 7-6 with the Colts and Miami Dolphins in the American Conference East.

LEAD: The Giants put it all together today. Their running game was ineffective, their celebrated defense fell asleep in the first half and their special teams made one costly error after another.

LEAD: Only four years ago, corporate efforts to enlist university researchers in the drive to make American industry more competitive seemed to face major difficulties. But the problems - which mainly involved fears that these alliances would compromise basic academic freedoms - have proved relatively easy to resolve, and many research projects are not only flourishing but producing tangible results.

LEAD: LARRY BAZZELL scores in ''The Signal Season of Dummy Hoy,'' but the play never makes it to first base. This is purportedly the story of how hand signals came to professional baseball in 1886. They were devised, according to the script by Allen Meyer and Michael Nowak, to meet the needs of William Ellsworth (Dummy) Hoy, a good center fielder who could not hear or speak.

LEAD: The nation's health care and foster care systems are overburdened and ill-equipped to deal with an expected increase in pediatric AIDS cases by the year 1991, according to a Congressional report to be released Monday.

LEAD: Never mind that there is no snow here or that Rudolph, lounging in his stall in the reindeer barn, has a broad, black nose. Forget the two-hour wait for two minutes on Santa Claus's lap. Don't worry about the frigid temperatures.

LEAD: The New York State Banking Board has approved a merger of Norstar Bancorp and the Fleet Financial Group of Providence, R.I. The new company, to be called Fleet-Norstar Financial Group Inc., will have $25 billion in assets and will be among the 25 largest bank holding companies in the country. Its headquarters will be in Albany and Providence.

LEAD: Whether to unload stocks, mutual funds and other investments before year-end should depend on more than tax considerations. But taken strictly from a tax perspective, whether the sale occurs in 1987 or 1988 can make a significant difference in an investor's income tax bill.

LEAD: Maurice Lucas is one of the few survivors of an era when teams often traveled by bus and players were surprised when their paychecks cleared the bank. LEAD: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, President Reagan's third choice to fill a seven-month-old Supreme Court vacancy, goes before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Monday, his first step on what appears to be an easy road to confirmation.

LEAD: Elevating the Veterans Administration to cabinet status is an idea that doesn't improve with age. So the case made for it last Wednesday in the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee was no more persuasive than that made last month in the House. But the legislators don't need any persuasion, it seems.

LEAD: PROBLEMS of communication were examined in ''Assimil,'' the fascinating dance-theater event presented by the Danspace Project Saturday night at St. Mark's Church. LEAD: THE title role in ''Turandot'' requires at minimum a soprano voice able to give out the imperious cries of the cruel Chinese Princess with trumpet-like power. But penetrating power is the first requisite, the one upon which renowned Turandots of the past have built.

LEAD: When Giorgio Ronchi was a high school student in Milan, Italy, he spent his senior year in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, as a foreign exchange student. That began a close association with things American.
LEAD: Diana Sheean, an author and the widow of Vincent Sheean, died of a stroke complicated by pneumonia at St. Stephen's Hospital in London last Wednesday. She was 72 years old.

LEAD: Three new varieties of oranges have been developed in a 25-year research project. They should deliver brighter juice to American consumers and help domestic growers compete against imports, the Agriculture Department recently announced.
LEAD: After being imprisoned 26 months as a convicted rapist, Marion Coakley heard himself declared an innocent man yesterday by a judge and prosecutors in a brief hearing in a Bronx courtroom.
LEAD: IN official Washington, where and with whom you eat is usually more important than what you eat. But there are exceptions.

LEAD: Dr. Robert J. Adrian, associate professor of educational and community programs in the department of education at Queens College, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Syosset, L.I. He was 66 years old.

LEAD: Maria-Theresa Duncan, a dancer who was the last of Isadora Duncan's adopted daughters, died at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan Monday. She was 92 years old.

LEAD: A woman pleading for the return of her 2-year-old daughter was fatally stabbed and shot in a struggle with an unidentified man who then shot and killed himself inside a Harlem stationery store yesterday afternoon, the police and witnesses said.

LEAD: The worldwide bull market made global securities dealing a hot investment concept in the 1980's. But with the October collapse of markets worldwide, professional and individual investors are pulling back from what they now fear has become a ''globalization of insecurities.''
LEAD: Israeli troops backed by tanks and helicopter gunships attacked guerrilla bases in southeast Lebanon today.

LEAD: Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers, whose views have commanded a wide following, is considering a new position at Shearson that, some sources at the firm say, may resemble an independent consulting arrangement.

LEAD: What did people do yesterday when they heard that Gary Hart had re-entered the Democratic Presidential race? Again and again, they laughed. Sometimes the laughter was nervous, incredulous: Is this some kind of practical joke? Or it was cynical: He must be after Federal matching funds to reduce his campaign debt.

LEAD: AT the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Cleveland, several people whose legs are paralyzed have been able to walk and even to climb and descend stairs. Throughout the world, about 2,000 profoundly deaf people have had some of their hearing restored, in some cases well enough to allow them to talk on the telephone.
LEAD: Ray Malavasi, who coached the Los Angeles Rams to their only Super Bowl appearance, died today of a heart attack, a spokesman for Western Medical Center said. Mr. Malavasi was 57 years old.
LEAD: Governor Kean brought this depressed city a big Christmas present today, signing legislation for a $42 million aquarium to be built on the bank of the Delaware River.

LEAD: J. David Hann, a communications and computer executive, yesterday was named president and chief executive of Quotron Systems Inc., the stock quotation service acquired by Citicorp in 1986 for $680 million.
LEAD: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 81.7 percent of capacity in November, the highest level in more than three years, the Government said today.
LEAD: President Reagan today signed a five-year extension of the independent counsel law, despite what he said were ''my very strong doubts about its constitutionality.''
LEAD: To celebrate the holiday season and the 100th birthday of the Browning School, the boys in the fourth grade got together and sent $317.15 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

LEAD: Congressional leaders said today that a Nicaraguan defector's assertion that Managua intends to enlarge its military appeared to be turning Congress in favor of renewing non-arms aid for the contras.

LEAD: Zubin Mehta said yesterday that he would retire as music director of the New York Philharmonic at the end of the 1990-91 season. Then he said he couldn't entirely preclude the possibility that he might change his mind. Then, after a nervous telephone call from Philharmonic officials, he said he really hadn't come to any decision at all.

LEAD: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that its board had approved a reorganization that will establish a parent company and divide its operations into three independent subsidiaries.
LEAD: Pinky Tomlin, who wrote the 1930's hit ''The Object of My Affection'' and dozens of other tunes, died of a heart attack at a medical center in North Hollywood Saturday. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: Golden State officially ushered in the Ralph Sampson era this afternoon. The 7-foot-4-inch center joined the team for the first time since being traded by Houston, along with Steve Harris, for Joe Barry Carroll and Eric (Sleepy) Floyd.

LEAD: Jefferies & Company said Alan C. Clore, a longtime customer, and companies he controls had failed to pay for $17 million of Kaisertech Ltd. stock that it had placed orders for in October. Mr. Clore is chairman of Kaisertech, an Oakland, Calif., holding company for the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation.
LEAD: Larry Bird scored 27 points and had 7 assists tonight in leading the Boston Celtics to a 122-102 victory over the Washington Bullets.

LEAD: The New York City Human Rights Commission said yesterday that it has found that the New York Athletic Club discriminates against women in violation of a city law, and must develop a plan to end the discrimination or face a judge's order to do so.

LEAD: The Mexican Government is struggling to regain control of an economic crisis that has unleashed a new round of record inflation, caused Mexicans to shun the peso and send their savings abroad, and stirred up labor discontent.
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that a strong nuclear arsenal was crucial for Western security after intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe are destroyed.

LEAD: Caspar W. Weinberger, who as Secretary of Defense faced big frustrations in the public furor over the Air Force's $7,400 beverage unit, the Navy's $435 claw hammer and a $640 military toilet cover, is in trouble again with contractors. This time it is not those overcharging military contractors but contractors who promised to finish an extension on his retirement home in Maine by mid-November.

LEAD: Governor Kean's plans for the state to take over failing school districts have been blocked in the Legislature again, but he has vowed to move against those districts in court, and this city is at the top of his list.

FOR many dancegoers, Mura Dehn is known, a little vaguely, as a woman who had something to do with film and black dancers. But the Film Forum is doing something about that, with a double feature consisting of ''In a Jazz Way,'' a short film on Miss Dehn by Louise Ghertler and Pamela Katz, and a two-hour excerpt from ''The Spirit Moves: A History of Black Social Dance on Film,'' a documentary by Miss Dehn. The program opens today for a two-week run at Film Forum 1. ''In a Jazz Way,'' shot in 1985, offers a tantalizing look at Miss Dehn. It has the look of a documentary that originally had more ambitious things on its mind, but Miss Ghertler and Miss Katz do give us an undiluted dose of Miss Dehn, who died in February. We see her at her kitchen table, in her apartment in Washington Heights, reminiscing about her youth in Vienna and about her work recording and preserving the artistry of some of the great known and anonymous dancers of the Savoy Ballroom in Harlem.

LEAD: EVER since its founding in 1873, the Oratorio Society of New York has performed Handel's ''Messiah'' each holiday season, all but the first 18 of those years in Carnegie Hall. The group sang the oratorio there on Monday evening, with Lyndon Woodside, its music director, conducting a version full of vigor and buoyed by the presence of several able soloists.
LEAD: Security Council Meets at 3:30 P.M. Trusteeship Council Meets at 10:30 A.M.

LEAD: Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, the head of the provisional Government, has disavowed all responsibility for the massacre that disrupted Haiti's presidential elections two weeks ago and disparaged the Roman Catholic Church, Haitian political leaders and the civilians who organized the election.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: West Virginia officials said today that they hoped to have enough money by Wednesday to cover paychecks this week for 40,000 state workers.
LEAD: Hart's decision to re-enter the Democratic Presidential race today threw the contest into confusion, stunned his party's leaders and left Republicans gleeful over the Democratic disarray.

LEAD: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks totaled 299,262 units in early December, up 7.1 percent from the corresponding period a year ago, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.
LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former leader of Cambodia, announced another about-face today and said he would meet with the Prime Minister of Cambodia's Vietnam-backed Government after all.
LEAD: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in a seesaw session. The Dow Jones industrial average ended 8.62 points higher at 1,941.48, bringing its advance in the last two days to nearly 75 points.

LEAD: Rabbi Stuart Saposh lighting the first candle of the Hanukkah menorah at a day-care center in Commack, L.I. The Jewish festival began at sundown yesterday and ends at sundown next Wednesday. (NYT/Barton Silverman)
LEAD: ''WHAT is this stuff,'' said a shopper to no one in particular - a fairly common occurence in the supermarket.
LEAD: ALMOST unnoticed, garlic has become a significant part of the food scene, both in this country and abroad. It is a delightful development.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Boston Properties, the development company at the center of a plan to erect a double-towered skyscraper at Columbus Circle, will hire a new architect to redesign the project, according to officials of the developer.
LEAD: Mildred S. Simon, a founder of a chain of self-service discount stores, died of lung cancer Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old.

LEAD: HOW do you grapple with the traditional in a world that puts a premium on novelty? Television takes a scattershot approach when it comes to Christmas specials, mixing a few new shows with repeats of others that have been around for years. Many of the so-called classics are not only popular, they're also cheap to rerun.

LEAD: When Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev of the Soviet Union marched into the Pentagon last week to meet with Adm. William J. Crowe Jr. and other members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, almost everything he said and did was shrouded in secrecy.

LEAD: The jury at the Howard Beach trial deliberated for a sixth day yesterday without reaching a verdict in the case of four white teen-agers charged with murder or manslaughter stemming from the death of a black man in the Queens neighborhood a year ago.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would allow continued use of the herbicide alachlor with some restrictions. After four years of study, the agency has decided that the chemical does not pose an ''unreasonable'' risk of cancer in humans.

LEAD: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York, Joan Springler Streit of New York and Edgerton Grant North Jr. of New York and Scarborough, N.Y., were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Herbert Anderson.

LEAD: Ulfert Wilke, a painter and calligrapher who was founding director of the University of Iowa Art Museum, died of complications from a stroke at his home in Anahola, Kauai, Hawaii, on Dec. 7. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: The Wickes Companies said it planned to sell its lumber division to a group of former managers. It was the first sale announced of the three businesses that the company put on the block in October. Terms were not disclosed, but an analyst estimated the price for Wickes Lumber at around $200 million.

LEAD: William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, is a severe critic of many American schools, but he has finally found one that he really likes. It is James Madison High School and it exists entirely in his mind.

LEAD: An unusual independent human rights seminar ended today with some of its leaders, united by experience in Soviet prisons and labor camps, parting ways over how to coexist with the Government that imprisoned and freed them.

LEAD: Hunt-and-peck typists who feel inadequate because they are not proficient at touch typing may now have something to be smug about. After studying touch typists, who use all fingers instead of just one or two, a Tucson, Ariz., group has concluded that they must cock their left wrists slightly to type and could be damaging tendons and nerves.

LEAD: IT is a Christmas Eve ritual handed down from mother to son. Every year, Ed Giobbi, the artist and cookbook author, serves a holiday feast of seven fish dishes (seven for the seven sacraments). Each dish is cooked in a different manner -broiled, fried, baked and so on - or uses a different main ingredient.

LEAD: Chun Doo Hwan, the outgoing President, and his wife, Lee Soon Ja, casting their ballots yesterday in Seoul. Millions of Koreans voted in their first chance in 16 years to elect a president. Page A14. (Reuters)

LEAD: MOST of us are suckers for warm desserts. Whether it's homemade apple pie, a sophisticated souffle or that seldom-seen classic crepes, we are almost powerless to resist a still-warm-from-the-oven or stove-top sweet at the end of a meal.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: About 150 members of this city's Indian community demonstrated on the steps of the Hudson County Courthouse today, demanding that four youths charged with fatally beating an Indian man be tried as adults.

LEAD: The great chefs of France share various faults, but excess modesty has never been one of them. Eagerly do they lend their names to cookbooks, videotapes, canned foie gras, nonstick pans, Beaujolais and, in one extreme case, tennis togs. And who is to say them nay? After long years in the kitchen it's hard to resist a little easy money and fame, even if it does tend to look commercial.
LEAD: Although the typical college athlete in the last generation has grown about 3 inches and added 20 pounds, there is still a place for the smaller performer in hockey.

LEAD: A member of the Jack Kemp for President staff was flattered but suspicious when a caller, identifying herself as a student, asked for statements from the Republican contender on the Strategic Defense Initiative. The address she gave, 733 15th Street, sounded familiar; it turned out to be the George Bush for President
LEAD: An article yesterday about Mexico's devaluation of the peso on the official market inaccurately described the action. The move pushed the peso's value against the dollar down by 18 percent.
LEAD: They have names like ''playing the piano'' and ''relay voting,'' but they are simply colorful descriptions for the possible ways to cheat in the presidential election Wednesday.

LEAD: The San Francisco 49ers' euphoria over a 41-0 victory Monday night against the Chicago Bears, gave way to mild depression yesterday when it was announced Joe Montana may miss the remaining two regular-season games and the top linebacker, Keena Turner, was undergoing knee surgery. Montana has a torn hamstring that definitely will keep him out of Sunday's game against the Atlanta Falcons, and there's ''a good chance'' he'll miss the final game against the Los Angeles Rams, Coach Bill Walsh said.

LEAD: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy completed his testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee today to the congratulations of both Democrats and Republicans who predicted that he would easily be confirmed to the Supreme Court.

LEAD: Marc Sullivan, a catcher for the Boston Red Sox the last three years, with more skill behind the plate than at it, has been traded to Houston. One of the co-owners of the Red Sox is the former major-league catcher Haywood Sullivan, Marc's father. . . . Lonnie Smith, the veteran outfielder who returned to the team last season after failing to attract interest on the free-agent market, was released by the Kansas City Royals.

LEAD: Senate negotiators working on a compromise tax increase package tonight rejected a bid by House conferees to water down - but not abandon - a proposal to limit interest deductions in corporate takeovers.

LEAD: THE House of Beauty and Culture is outre not just in terms of the styles it sells. It is also near the fringe in terms of London geography, situated as it is at 34-36 Stamford Road in the neighborhood known as Hackney.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Dr. Martin R. Katz, a New York cardiologist, died of leiomyo sarcoma of the lung last Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 54 years old.

LEAD: Bronx prosecutors and at least three city agencies are investigating the death of a 28-year-old Bronx woman who, according to her companion and lawyers for her family, was severely beaten earlier this month in a confrontation with the police. The police deny those allegations.
LEAD: MEXICAN food is a serious subject in this part of the world: witness the debate over whether the true Mexican salsa is red or green.

LEAD: A New York City transit police officer was convicted of misdemeanor charges yesterday in the off-duty shooting of a Brooklyn man last year, which prosecutors characterized as a racial incident. However, the officer was acquitted of more serious felony assault charges.

LEAD: After a visit in a cold, driving rain to inspect ''Tilted Arc,'' the Richard Serra sculpture that sweeps across 26 Federal Plaza in downtown Manhattan, a committee of art experts and public officials from around the United States decided yesterday that the work could not be removed or relocated without destroying its artistic value.
LEAD: A blast destroyed a building at an explosives plant today, the authorities said. Three workers were missing and presumed dead.

LEAD: In some offices at the Pentagon, the State Department and the White House, a television set is tuned to Cable News Network most of the time. A British reporter used CNN to help cover President Reagan's summit with Mikhail S. Gorbachev. And Nancy Reagan sent CNN's chief Washington anchor a complimentary note about the summit coverage last week.

LEAD: With Buck Williams missing from the lineup for the first time in seven years and with Mike Gminski missing his beard for the first time in two years, the Nets ended their losing streak at 11 games tonight with a 104-98 victory over the San Antonio Spurs at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
LEAD: David S. Ruder, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that it would probably be months before the agency would bring any new insider trading cases.
LEAD: Peter Birch, a dancer, choreographer and television director, died of a heart attack Sunday at White Plains Hospital, White Plains, N.Y. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: HIS head down, his blood pressure up, Mike Ditka was striding toward the Chicago Bears' locker room at halftime with turnovers on his mind. His quarterback, Mike Tomczak, had thrown four passes that were intercepted and the San Francisco 49ers had recovered two fumbles for a 20-0 jump in what would be a 41-0 rout.

LEAD: The broadest measure of the nation's foreign trade showed a record $43.4 billion quarterly deficit last summer, as the United States ran a deficit with the rest of the world in investment earnings for the first time in 29 years.

LEAD: It tastes sweet and looks like juice, but a popular apple drink sold in supermarkets contains only 10 percent real fruit juice. The rest is sugar and water. Consumers have a right to accurate information about the content of diluted fruit ''punches,'' ''ades'' and ''cocktails'' that compete on store shelves with real juice.
LEAD: 'Tis the season of gift-giving, a joyous thing - except when public-relations gimmicks come disguised as gifts. The 1987 booby prize in this category goes to the YMCA of Greater New York.

LEAD: American officials have developed tentative plans to carry out inspections in the Soviet Union next week of several old radars that the Reagan Administration charges are a technical violation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

LEAD: The Armonia Chamber Ensemble will give a free concert Dec. 30 at 4 P.M. in the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at West 65th Street. The program will feature excerpts from Handel's ''Messiah'' and works by Telemann, Vivaldi, Faure, Beethoven and Mozart. Tickets will be available at the library one hour before the performance.

LEAD: One of Schembechler's foremost Big Ten rivals, former Ohio State coach Earle Bruce has turned down the head-coaching position at Kansas, university officials said yesterday. The Kansas athletic director, Bob Frederick, said Bruce decided against accepting the offer to succeed Bob Valesente at the Big Eight Conference school because ''we could not resolve certain contractual issues surrounding Bruce's previous contract settlement and aren't able, therefore, to pursue the matter further.
LEAD: AT the age of 23, Markus Farbinger, the pastry chef at Le Cirque in New York, is acclaimed as among the most daring and gifted patissiers to arrive on the American restaurant scene in years.
LEAD: Larry Holmes, the former heavyweight champion, was at ringside when Mike Tyson knocked out Tyrell Biggs in October. After seeing the bout, he now says that Tyson is a dirty fighter.

LEAD: In a warehouse of the District of Columbia Public Works Department on a small side street in the Northeast section of the capital, amid spare street lights, signs, posts and paint, is a giant steel cage containing thousands of flags from nations throughout the world.

LEAD: WHOM or what do conservative Baptists serve -God or right-wing causes, or both? LEAD: Alabama must forfeit more than $250,000 in basketball receipts for using two ineligible players in the 1987 N.C.A.A. Tournament, the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today.

LEAD: The Molina family of the Bronx greeting relatives in San Juan, P.R., via ''Project: Video Visit,'' a video-teleconferencing system introduced yesterday by Contel ASC and the Puerto Rico Telephone Company.

LEAD: Since 1932, a White Castle restaurant has been on the northwest corner of Northern and Bell Boulevards in the Bayside section of Queens. Today, two of the restaurant chain's unmistakable white porcelain and notched-roof buildings are squeezed onto that site.
LEAD: House leaders said today that they would push for a two-day stopgap appropriation bill to keep the Government running through Friday.

LEAD: The Boeing Company said today that it was continuing to cut back the manpower being assigned to develop its futuristic 7J7 aircraft and said it was no longer predicting when the aircraft would be available.
LEAD: The Economic Scene column last Wednesday and an article in Business Day on Monday about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's top economics adviser misidentified him. He is Abel G. Aganbegyan.

LEAD: Treasury bond prices rose for the second consecutive day, following the lead set by declining oil prices.

LEAD: THE moon hits your eye like a big pizza pie in ''Moonstruck,'' and a lot of other things do too. ''Moonstruck'' is so heavily ethnic that it begins with Dean Martin's rendition of ''That's Amore,'' and there's plenty more where that came from. With its accordion music, its bits of dialect and its love of opera (a key segment of the story unfolds at a Metropolitan Opera performance of ''La Boheme''), ''Moonstruck'' clearly means to celebrate all things Italian.

LEAD: Six of the seven candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination debated tonight in one of the poorest areas of the country and agreed that a range of new Federal programs was needed to help the economy on both sides of the Mexican border.

LEAD: Doctors at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich., said last night that Bo Schembechler's prognosis for recovery was good after the Michigan football coach had undergone his second quadruple heart bypass operation. Schembechler, 58, was listed in satisfactory condition in the intensive-care unit, where he underwent the seven-hour procedure.

LEAD: I. William Fishkind, an executive with the National Association of Securities Dealers in Washington, the regulatory organization for the securities industry, died of cancer Friday at his home in Burke, Va. He was 53 years old.

LEAD: THE title role in ''Turandot'' requires at minimum a soprano voice able to give out the imperious cries of the cruel Chinese Princess with trumpet-like power. If the two-dimensional character of Turandot can somehow, in addition, be projected with more than a bulldozer's nuances, all the better. But penetrating power is the first requisite, the one upon which renowned Turandots of the past have built.
LEAD: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about the Giants' problems incorrectly named the team's next opponent. The Giants play the Green Bay Packers on Saturday.
LEAD: Robert S. Taft, a New York tax lawyer, died Thursday in Hollywood, Fla., after being struck by an automobile. He was 53 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.
LEAD: Oil prices fell again on world markets yesterday after OPEC decided to extend its current production and pricing levels through the middle of next year.

LEAD: The Amoco Corporation's board approved a $3.8 billion capital and exploration budget for 1988, a 17 percent increase over the company's $3.25 billion budget in 1987. Richard M. Morrow, Amoco's chairman, said in a prepared statement that the company's ability to carry out 1988 spending plans depend on price levels for crude oil, natural gas and refined petroleum products.

LEAD: TWO months after the stock market's deep dive, the economy is holding up remarkably well. The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that American industry was operating at 81.7 percent of capacity in November, two-tenths of 1 percent higher than in October. Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities was up four-tenths in November, after a nine-tenths gain in October.

LEAD: This nation's students, aflame with idealism and self-righteousness, are preparing to move back to center stage.
LEAD: The city's first black mayor was removed from office today in a recall election prompted by charges he sent racist hate mail to community leaders.

LEAD: The United States will cut its 1988 sugar imports by 25 percent, to the lowest level in more than 100 years, the Reagan Administration announced today. The action is expected to increase prices for consumers and hurt the debt-burdened economies of some of America's trading partners among developing nations.

LEAD: Judge M. W. Deo said today that he would announce on Thursday whether the Union Carbide Corporation should pay interim relief to victims of the Dec. 3, 1984, gas disaster at Bhopal, the world's worst industrial accident.

LEAD: ''OVERBOARD'' is an apt title for a comedy that tries to show how the hard, brittle, thoroughly horrible exterior of an heiress named Joanna Stayton (Goldie Hawn) actually conceals a sweet, spunky, hard-working little homemaker and mom. All Joanna needs is a bout of amnesia to bring the better person within her to the fore.

Macy's will also cook the bird for $15; call 212-967-4930 to order.

LEAD: Among the best ways to sabotage the frail process of Soviet-American summitry is for participants to say one thing in private and another in public. Another is to pass over tough subjects in private and then explode them publicly. With Mikhail Gorbachev's jetstream barely dissipated, President Reagan has done both.
LEAD: Seven Pistons and two Knicks were fined a total of $8,500 yesterday for their parts in a fight Saturday night at the Silverdome in Pontiac, Mich.

LEAD: THERE once was a time when big news events had the power to stun and, sometimes, to cause a certain amount of anxiety. Wars, earthquakes, airplane crashes, stock market busts, mass-murder sprees, kidnappings, duplicity in positions of public trust, political assassinations. These things could upset daily routine.

LEAD: Dr. Arthur J. Antenucci, an internist, died of Hodgkin's disease Monday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Van Ellis Huff, inventor of the jalousie window, died at home here last Thursday. He was 93 years old.

LEAD: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia put into words today the relief felt at the uneventful end of a two-day meeting of six Southeast Asian leaders, a gathering held reluctantly and with unusually tight security in this volatile capital.

LEAD: Michael Fay, a banker from New Zealand, gave up his demand for a multinational America's Cup regatta and agreed today to the San Diego Yacht Club's condition that it race only against Fay's boat for the cup next year.

LEAD: Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth made no commitments on expansion at a meeting in Washington yesterday with a group of Senators interested in securing major league teams. Following a meeting with 10 Senators representing Colorado, Arizona, Ohio, Indiana and Florida, as well as the delegate from the District of Columbia, Ueberroth said that baseball wanted to expand, but that it had no timetable and had made no commitments to any city.
LEAD: The course at Brown University had a reputation as being undemanding, a ''gut,'' in campus argot. But it nearly became a college student's nightmare.

LEAD: OVER the years, cities have tried all manner of methods to dispose of sludge, the end product of the typical sewage treatment plant. They have burned it, buried it, dumped it in the ocean, spread it on farms and even made bricks of it.

LEAD: William Lewis Greene, an aeronautical and civil engineer whose security clearance was denied in the early 1950's, resulting in two important Supreme Court decisions, died of a heart attack Dec. 9 at his home in Bath, Me. He was 71 years old. Mr. Greene was an executive with a Navy contractor until 1951 when, as a result of the denial of his security clearance by the Defense Department, he was forced to leave.

LEAD: Sears, Roebuck & Company has agreed to acquire Pinstripes Petites, a women's specialty-store chain based in Minneapolis, for an undisclosed sum. It is Sears's second specialty-store acquisition in recent months - the first was Eye-Care Centers of America Inc., a 41-store chain based in San Antonio.

LEAD: The Governors of Maryland, Pennsylvania and Virginia, along with the Mayor of Washington and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, signed an agreement today on to a regional effort to clean up and protect the Chesapeake Bay, one of the largest and most polluted ecosystems in the country.

LEAD: A high school senior shot his friend to death in an attempt to cure his hiccups by scaring him, the police said Monday. The 19-year-old senior, David E. Duquette, of Glocester, told the police the gun he was holding on Nicholas Lovell, 16, went off accidentally. Mr. Duquette was charged with murder.

LEAD: Iranian war vessels raked the 102,088-ton Greek tanker Ariadne with grenades and machine-gun fire today, forcing most of the crew to abandon ship, and in a second attack tore it nearly in half with a missile.

LEAD: William Edgar Park, retired president of Simmons College, died Dec. 7 at Falmouth Hospital in Falmouth, Mass. He was 78 years old. Mr. Park, who lived in Cotuit, Mass., was president of the Simmons from 1955 to 1970. As president he oversaw a self-study curriculum that expanded the number of departments from 9 to 18 and changed the college into a predominantly residential campus by adding three dormitories.

LEAD: The nation's first permanent underground nuclear waste repository has developed water leaks that some scientists contend will make it useless. The facility is designed to demonstrate how to store millions of cubic feet of radioactive material that will be dangerous for thousands of years.

LEAD: Vice President Bush has made loyalty to President Reagan the foundation of his Presidential bid, and he displayed that quality again Tuesday night at his Christmas Party.

LEAD: Mark Gastineau, once the premier defensive lineman in pro football, received a promotion and a pat on the back today from his coach, Joe Walton.

LEAD: The brokerage community came under intense criticism today from state securities regulators, who contended that nearly half the losses to investors during the October stock market plunge resulted from of shoddy brokerage practices and irresponsible investment advice, not falling stock prices.

LEAD: A building under construction in downtown Marrakesh collapsed today, killing 20 people and injuring eight others, the Moroccan news agency reported. LEAD: Burdeshaw Associates Ltd., a small concern, differs from the 100 other consultants' offices that dot the Beltway, the highway circling Washington.

LEAD: When the first artificial pacemakers for the human heart were developed about 30 years ago, the sole objective was to save the patient from unpredictable sudden death. LEAD: Dennis A. Volman, a reporter for The Christian Science Monitor, died of cancer Monday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 37 years old and lived in Washington.

LEAD: Jack Keiler's father opened his first movie theater in Paducah, Ky., at a time when Charlie Chaplin and Mary Pickford were stars and films were still silent. After more than 60 years in the business, Mr. Keiler sold his last two theaters in February, unable to compete with a new 10-screen complex in a nearby shopping mall.

LEAD: The House ethics committee determined today that Representative Austin J. Murphy, Democrat of Pennsylvania, violated House rules by diverting Congressional property to his former law firm and twice allowing someone else to cast votes for him.

LEAD: Mayor Koch offers to take responsibility for the New York City school system with a restructured Board of Education. Governor Cuomo recently convened a summit meeting, bringing together the Mayor, leading educators, legislators, borough presidents and business representatives to seek consensus on school reform.

LEAD: New York City's Board of Estimate will vote today on four homeless shelter proposals already approved by the Planning Commission. Neighborhood opponents of the shelters argue that they fall short of perfection. Such opposition makes the best the enemy of the better. The proposals deserve support.

LEAD: A 15-year-old high school student took out a gun and fatally shot himself in the head today as his classmates watched, officials said. The name of the student was not immediately released and no motive was known, said Garland McMeans, the Katy School District superintendent. The incident occurred about 10 A.M.

LEAD: An Air Force colonel criticized as putting pressure on wives of senior officers at Grissom Air Force Base to quit work so they would be available for social activities will retire next month. LEAD: Eight years after California led a widespread revolt against taxes and government spending, Californians are growing unhappy with some of the consequences, and they soon will have the opportunity to relax those restrictions. Today a million signatures were filed to place an amendment on next June's ballot that would ease the spending limit.

LEAD: There is a common thread connecting many strong people who decide to seek psychiatric counsel. It is the realization that they are acting repeatedly in a way harmful to them, without knowing quite why. So they spend time, often painful time, with somebody who can make them see themselves more clearly, discover what it is that makes them act out the same mistake - and by knowing, change.

LEAD: Keith Asmussen, the block of the young chip, won his first race ever in New York yesterday, something his son, Cash, used to do regularly. Cash Asmussen was New York's leading rider in 1979, then began riding in Europe in 1980 and has since become the only non-French jockey to win the French riding title, doing so in 1985 and 1986.
