LEAD: Under interrogation in Senate hearings this week on his nomination to the Supreme Court, Judge Anthony M. Kennedy demonstrated a knack for coming up with apt quotations to underscore his philosophical points.

LEAD: Phil Niekro, winner of 318 major-league games, has turned down offers to work in the Atlanta Braves minor-league system and will apparently enter private business. Niekro spent 25 years in the Braves' organization and ended his pitching career with a farewell appearance in the last home game of the 1987 season.

LEAD: Cece Zorinsky is throwing her hat into the ring. Mrs. Zorinsky, whose husband, Edward, a Democrat from Nebraska, served in the Senate for 10 years until his death last March, has decided to run for the House of Representatives in Nebraska's second Congressional district. The incumbent, Representative Hal Daub, a Republican, is running for the Senate seat once held by Mr.

LEAD: Old images of New York's subways live, carried back to Boise and Biloxi: graffiti-plastered, urine-soaked, crime-infested and suffused with noise and danger. Visiting friends are horrified at the idea of taking the train, either for convenience or to beat the street traffic.

LEAD: Prosecutors investigating the death in city custody of a 28-year-old Bronx woman are faced with conflicting reports from witnesses about her struggles with the police and with problems in determining the origin of a fatal blood clot in her leg.

LEAD: As the 35-foot superstretch limo wheeled along Route 46, Melissa Motichka kept trying to find herself on the limo's TV. But there's always so much blab on the noon news. South Korea was picking a president. And Donna Rice's old boyfriend had changed his mind again and was running for President, too.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Milos Jakes, a member of the ruling presidium, after he was elected to head the Czechoslovak Communist Party. Page A7. (Agence France-Presse)

LEAD: THE title of the exhibition ''Antiquities From the Collection of Christos G. Bastis'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is displayed in letters at least a foot tall painted high on the wall in the first of the show's two galleries. These letters threaten to dwarf the objects on view, most of which range from small to tiny, and create the momentary impression that the show's contents are being hyped.

LEAD: A lifelong collection of basketball memorabilia was lost Wednesday when the four-bedroom house in Columbia, S.C., built 23 years ago for Frank McGuire, a Hall of Fame basketball coach, burned to the ground. McGuire and his wife, Jane, barely escaped serious injury from a blaze that fire officials said probably had been caused by a gas leak ignited by a spark after Mrs.

LEAD: The trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie is leading a quintet tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 1:30 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

LEAD: EARLY in his novel ''Ironweed,'' William Kennedy describes a visit made to a cemetery by the aging derelict Francis Phelan, whose mother and father and infant son are buried there. It is Halloween, and they are watching him, interested and bemused, from beyond the grave.

LEAD: $ Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 8.75 8.75 7.50 DISCOUNT RATE 6.00 6.00 5.50 FEDERAL FUNDS 6.64 5.52 6.44 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 5.92 5.93 5.60 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 6.42 6.40 5.58 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 8.83 8.80 6.96 30-YR.
LEAD: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a compromise that would designate Yucca Mountain in Nevada as the only site for disposal of the nation's most dangerous nuclear waste.
LEAD: A Koch administration plan to turn an East Harlem school building into a shelter for homeless families was soundly defeated last night by the Board of Estimate.

LEAD: The play began last night where the endline and baseline meet near the Knick bench. After giving Sidney Green, who was guarding him, a head fake, Charles Barkley made his move to the basket. Patrick Ewing, coming over to cut off the Philadelphia 76ers' power forward, missed the block. Barkley drove round him, dribbled the ball once, took a step and half and then jammed the ball through the basket - in the face of the Knick center.

LEAD: HAUTE Lapland cuisine? Fasten your snowshoes and clomp over to Aquavit at 13 West 54th Street for what is being billed as New York City's first major Scandinavian restaurant to open in several decades. Based on a visit last week, it promises to be one of the most original new spots of the season.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Traffic fatalities on rural interstate highways soared by more than 50 percent in states that increased their speed limit to 65 miles per hour last spring, according to Transportation Department figures.

LEAD: William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, has dismissed two field operatives and disciplined three senior officials for improper actions during the Iran-contra affair, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo read ''A Visit From St. Nicholas'' (''Twas the Night Before Christmas'') to 125 media-mobbed children yesterday, but when the press turned its attention to the Governor, there arose such a clatter that he gave, as a sort of encore, a fair impersonation of the Grinch.
LEAD: A Soviet diplomat accredited to the United Nations was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today on suspicion of espionage, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said tonight.
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company flexed its financial muscle today by completing an old stock buyback program and announcing a new stamping plant.
LEAD: The Cabot Corporation is offering two note issues totaling $250 million through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
LEAD: In April 1975, when the Republic of South Vietnam was on the edge of collapse, Nguyen Huu Co, a retired general and former Defense Minister, took stock of his options.

LEAD: Will R. Sparks, a speech writer for President Lyndon B. Johnson and a retired director of public affairs for Citicorp, died of a brain tumor Wednesday at Long Island College Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Brooklyn.
LEAD: The United States has ended an 18-year moratorium on producing chemical weapons and is filling canisters for an artillery shell that would spread toxic nerve gas, the Pentagon said today.

LEAD: Stunned by their decisive defeat in the presidential election, rival opposition leaders declared Thursday that the results were void because of what they called widespread fraud, and pledged to step up their anti-Government resistance.

LEAD: South Korea's opposition fought a long, brave fight for direct elections in order to have the chance to vote an unpopular Government out of power. Instead, because of its deep division, the opposition appears to have handed victory to Roh Tae Woo, the ruling party candidate whose official anointment last spring touched off national unrest.

LEAD: The Winter Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association begin today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, at 36th Street and 11th Avenue in Manhattan, with this schedule: Today - Men's pairs, women's pairs and senior pairs, 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.; knockout teams, 49er pairs and newcomer pairs, 8 P.M.
LEAD: The Economy
LEAD: The name Schrafft's, which has a bright and shining image to a certain age group of New Yorkers, is barely known to the up-and-coming generation.
LEAD: ''We congratulate Mr. Roh on his victory and look forward to working closely with him.''
LEAD: With just a week to go in the holiday season, Christmas shopping appears to have lost much of its steam, some retailers say.

LEAD: Pier A on the Battery, a century-old landmark that commands an uninterrupted, almost seaborne, vista of New York Harbor, would be turned into a high-priced restaurant - with a visitors' center and fast-food dining, too -under a new plan by the Koch administration.

LEAD: A Federal prosecutor argued today that Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. saw himself as the only man smart enough to save the Western world and that his supporters committed fraud after buckling under intense pressure to finance his 1984 Presidential bid.

LEAD: An 8-year-old girl was found dead Wednesday and her parents and young brother unconscious in the family's apartment, according to the authorities, who said they believed carbon monoxide from a heater was responsible. The girl, Roseanne Keefe, was pronounced dead at the scene while her parents, David and Rosario Keefe, were reported in fair condition today in the hospital.

LEAD: The unemployment rate in Britain fell to 9.5 percent in November, the 17th consecutive monthly decline, the Government said today. The Employment Secretary, Norman Fowler, said 1987 had seen ''the largest sustained fall in unemployment on record.'' On a seasonally adjusted basis, the number of jobless in November was 2.69 million, down 63,500 from October, when the unemployment rate was 9.8 percent.

LEAD: Michael Jordan had a season-high 52 points and began a 12-0 spurt during a 2-minute-53-second span in the final quarter to give the Chicago Bulls a 111-100 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

LEAD: Whether it was seductive wild hope or just a miscalculation, Gary Kasparov blundered yesterday with an incorrect combination and was smartly smashed by Anatoly Karpov in the adjournment session of their 23d world chess championship game in Seville, Spain.

LEAD: More than 20 theatrical organizations, most of which are in the New York area, are the recipients this year of grants and scholarships from the American Theater Wing. The grants, which total more than $30,000, were awarded at a luncheon yesterday. Among the recipients are the AMAS Repertory Company, the Equity Library Theater, Negro Ensemble Company, Theaterwork-U.S.A., the Drama League of New York and the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center.

LEAD: The judge accused by the Brooklyn District Attorney of humiliating a complainant in a sexual-misconduct trial has been accused by jurors in another case of demeaning witnesses, of falling asleep on the bench and of intimidating the defense and prosecuting attorneys.

LEAD: Congressional negotiators have decided to allow the Reagan Administration to proceed with tough new abortion restrictions on family planning groups, handing a victory to the White House and its anti-abortion allies.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The 326-foot-long piershed at Pier A on the Battery, which would be converted into restaurants and a visitors' center under a new plan. Page B3. (NYT/Barton Silverman)

LEAD: Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, stood beside President Reagan today to announce his support for the treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles, but said the pact would probably be amended in the Senate.
LEAD: BASEBALL

LEAD: A $3 billion settlement of the bitter four-year-old battle between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company appeared imminent last night, several people involved in negotiations said. The settlement would be the key part of a reorganization plan that would bring Texaco out of bankruptcy.

LEAD: The West Side Madrigalists are to perform early American madrigals on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Fraunces Tavern Museum, at 54 Pearl Street. Suggested contributions to the museum are $2.50, $1 for students and the elderly. Information: 425-1778.
LEAD: Debating 'Tilted Arc'
LEAD: Within the next two years 882 free- market rental apartments will be created on an 8.5-acre waterfront tract on the northern portion of Roosevelt Island.

LEAD: Nancy Reagan said today that she and President Reagan had been advised by counsel to suspend their personal relationship with Michael K. Deaver as long as appeals of his conviction were pending.
LEAD: The national Democratic chairman said today that Gary Hart had placed personal goals above the good of his party by re-entering the Presidential race this week.

LEAD: An investment group led by the Pritzker family of Chicago said it had purchased a 6 percent stake in Ramada Inc., a hotel, casino and restaurant company based in Phoenix. The Pritzker family controls the Hyatt Corporation and Braniff Airways Inc.

LEAD: For Mark Bavaro, this has been a season of mixed success. The bad parts have been the Giants' 4-9 record and his painful toe injury. The good parts have been his consistently strong games that have kept him ranked as pro football's best tight end.

LEAD: Youngsters watching yesterday as a gargoyle caricaturing a ''caveman,'' right, was hoisted to the top of the north tower at the National Cathedral. The setting of the last gargoyle brought the cathedral one step closer to completion. Only the pinnacles on the twin west towers remain to be raised.

LEAD: A special state panel proposed yesterday that construction of new schools in New York City be taken away from the Board of Education and placed in the hands of a new agency that could do it faster.
LEAD: A report in the Currents column of The Home Section on Thursday gave an incorrect address for the Rein-hold-Brown Gallery. It is at 26 East 78th Street in Manhattan.

LEAD: IT'S the season for warm sentiments and heavy artillery, the time when Hollywood traditionally rolls out its biggest guns. And it's especially true, in a moviegoing year that got off to an exceptionally poor start, that the best has been saved for last. But Christmas moviegoing can be as overwhelming as
LEAD: House and Senate negotiators approved late tonight a package of individual and corporate tax law changes intended to raise $9 billion in new taxes in 1988 and $14 billion more in 1989.

LEAD: With oil prices sliding again and stock markets around the world remaining fragile, it seems an unlikely time for a multibillion-dollar buying spree of oil company stock, but that is precisely what is unfolding in London.
LEAD: Gremlins have invaded I.B.M.'s computers. Worse yet, they reproduce.
LEAD: A Pakistani-born Canadian businessman was convicted today of conspiring to ship material to Pakistan that could be used to produce nuclear weapons.
LEAD: The Census Bureau reported today that the preschool population increased more than 10 percent in the 1980's, with the fastest growth in Sun Belt states and Alaska.

LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said it expected record revenues and earnings for its first fiscal quarter, which ends Jan. 1. Analysts have estimated the earnings at between 65 and 85 cents a share, with revenues between $925 million and $980 million. In the comparable period last year, Apple earned 45.5 cents a share, after an adjustment for a 2-for-1 split, on revenues of $662.3 million.

LEAD: The New York State Department of Health cited Good Samaritan Hospital with deficiencies in eight major areas today, saying that the hospital's quality-assurance system was so badly flawed that hospital officials are not able to quickly detect if an employee deliberately harmed patients.
LEAD: There will be no Christmas party for employees of the First Boston Corporation's Manhattan headquarters this year.

LEAD: Hockey Team U.S.A. Wins:Chris Terreri made 19 first-period saves and Corey Millen scored his second goal of the game during a five-goal second period last night for Team USA in the 7-3 exhibition victory over the Soviet Selects in Bloomington, Minn. Team U.S.A. leads the eight-game series, 4-1.

LEAD: In a move that was expected by analysts, the Marine Midland Bank said that Geoffrey A. Thompson, its president, would take on the additional role of chief executive. Mr. Thompson, 47 years old, replaces John R. Petty, 57, who will continue as chairman of the bank and the chairman and chief executive of its holding company.
LEAD: * Price Stern Sloan to Rubin Postaer & Associates, Los Angeles, for its Questron toy.

LEAD: THE third gastronomic cornerstone has been wedged into place at the Equitable Center on Seventh Avenue at 52d Street, this one an all-American grill backed by that all-American girl of the big screen, Mariel Hemingway. Called Sam's (Ms. Hemingway's moniker among friends), it is the sport-shirt alternative to its very proper neighbors, Le Bernardin and

LEAD: What President Reagan once said in defense of his former deputy chief of staff wholly missed the point. Michael Deaver, he said, ''never put the arm on me, or sought anything or any influence from me since he has been out of government.'' What Mr. Deaver did, with unseemly haste after leaving the White House in 1985, was to put the arm on the rest of the Reagan
LEAD: It seemed almost too good to be true when a local donor came up with $175,000 for a desperately needed home for AIDS patients here. It was.

LEAD: A world premiere of a cantata by Gunther Schuller is to be presented tonight at 8 at St. Thomas More's Roman Catholic Church, 65 East 89th Street. The work, ''Thou Art the Son of God,'' is to be performed by the Horace Mann Glee Club and the Amor Artis Orchestra, conducted by Johannes Somary. Also on the program are Mozart's Coronation Mass and Britten's ''Ceremony of Carols.

LEAD: Whitney North Seymour Jr., the special prosecutor in the Michael K. Deaver case, accused the Reagan Administration today of undermining public confidence in Government by condoning ''influence peddling'' by former senior Government officials.

LEAD: When the Maxwell Football Club in Philadelphia selected Don McPherson of Syracuse for its 1987 award yesterday, it marked the 27th time in 51 years and the fourth in the last 10 that the Heisman Trophy and the Maxwell Award honoring the outstanding college football player of the year went to different players.

LEAD: ''Broadcast News,'' James L. Brooks's romantic comedy about three ambitious young professionals working in television news, was voted the best film of 1987 by the New York Film Critics' Circle yesterday.

LEAD: Dave Righetti, who seems to be the most aggressively pursued free agent in the last three years, last night rejected an offer to pitch in Japan. But that decision did little to clarify his status. With the Yankees, Los Angeles and California among the teams seeking his services, Righetti must take the next step by tomorrow midnight and decide if he will accept the Yankees' offer of salary arbitration.

LEAD: When National Football League players finally capitulated after a 24-day strike this fall, team owners couldn't resist rubbing salt into their wounds. Now, if a preliminary ruling from the National Labor Relations Board holds up, the owners will have to pay for their nastiness.
LEAD: An article on Monday about a Nicaraguan Army officer who defected in October said the proposed peace accord for Central America calls for limiting national armies in the region.

LEAD: LARRY BIRD recently came up with an interesting explanation for the Boston Celtics' slump. The Celtics' bench was too passive, he said. Maybe it was time to bring back M. L. Carr and let him wave his towel again.

LEAD: A silver urn and two gold perfume bottles given to the United Nations by the sultanate of Oman as gifts were stolen Tuesday from display cases only yards from the Security Council chamber, United Nations officials said today.

LEAD: At first glance, Ettore Scola, Bertrand Tavernier and Krzysztof Zanussi seem an odd trio of film makers for the joint retrospective that begins today at the Museum of Modern Art, but Stephen Harvey, an assistant curator of film, explained the logic of the combination this way:
LEAD: An obituary of Alan Mitosky yesterday listed his survivors incompletely.

LEAD: Jed Harris: the Movie Frederic Raphael, who won an Academy Award for the screenplay for ''Darling'' and dissected marriage to a fare-thee-well in ''Two for the Road,'' is turning his attention to the legendary Broadway producer Jed Harris.
LEAD: Representative Charles E. Schumer of New York charged today that homelessness had ''skyrocketed'' in American cities largely because of cuts in Federal housing aid.

LEAD: AT the entrance to ''Nancy Graves: A Sculpture Retrospective'' is the 1969 ''Mongolian Bactrian (To Harvey Brennan),'' a main character in the shaggy camel story that helped establish Ms. Graves's reputation. A camel is an eccentric animal, and this is an eccentric work. It looks like an actual camel, but it was assembled, constructed and pieced together.

LEAD: WITH Christmas just a week away, television is grinding away furiously to take advantage of the season while it lasts. The results are decidedly mixed, as can be seen on three specials this weekend - two public-broadcasting music specials this evening, the other a made-for-television movie Sunday on C
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: In an attempt to pressure Lieut. Gen. Henry Namphy to step down, four leading presidential candidates have announced agreement on a coalition government that would replace him if he yields.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 412 money market mutual funds decreased $174.2 million, to $262.31 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 111 institutional funds were up $75.5 million, to $73.27 billion. Assets of the 206 general purpose funds were down $87.6 million, to $79.81 billion.

LEAD: Ever since Mikhail S. Gorbachev left town a week ago, some White House officials have been practicing the Washington art of ''spin control,'' the technique of delivering information to the press and the public with just the right twist to suit the purposes of the purveyor.

LEAD: PSYCHOLOGY TODAY, owned for the last two years by the American Psychological Association, is taking a new tack at the direction of its recently arrived publisher, Sherwood (Woody) Katsoff, formerly of Science Digest and Penthouse/Omni.

LEAD: The New York State Medical Facilities Finance Agency is tentatively offering $131.5 million of revenue bonds for the Catholic Medical Center, with a maximum yield of 8.315 percent for an issue due in 2022, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.
LEAD: The United States today officially congratulated Roh Tae Woo, the declared victor in the South Korean presidential elections, despite opposition complaints of widespread electoral fraud.

LEAD: Rejecting opposing motions from the National Basketball Association and the players' union, a Federal judge yesterday ordered both sides to prepare for a trial on the union's lawsuit charging that the league is in violation of antitrust laws.

LEAD: Paul W. Lowden, the investor who controls the Sahara Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev., has purchased 7.3 percent of Showboat Inc. and has said he might seek control of the casino company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Lowden said he planned to discuss the acquisition of Showboat's Las Vegas Casino Hotel and other properties with the company.

LEAD: In its most systematic attempt to help people assess the quality of health care, the Government today issued data showing mortality rates at nearly 6,000 hospitals, including 146 where deaths exceeded Federal predictions.

LEAD: Robert Maxwell, head of a multibillion dollar British communications empire and a chief rival to Rupert Murdoch, said yesterday in London that he was interested in ''seriously looking'' into acquiring Mr. Murdoch's New York Post.
LEAD: Israeli soldiers killed six Lebanese guerrillas in southern Lebanon today in a further escalation of violence in the area.

LEAD: The president of the Inter-American Development Bank, Antonio Ortiz Mena, said yesterday that he would quit rather than accept a Reagan Administration appointee as his No. 2, according to officials of the bank, a major lender to Latin America.

LEAD: The Congressional Iran-contra committees made public a newly discovered White House memo today that describes Vice President Bush as being ''solid'' in his support of the arms shipments to Iran as of February 1986.
LEAD: International A3-15

LEAD: The World Saxophone Quartet -Julius Hemphill, David Murray, Oliver Lake and Hamiet Bluiett - are to perform tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

LEAD: WHILE Hugh Whitemore's ''Breaking the Code'' continues on Broadway, another play about Alan Turing, ''A Most Secret War'' by Kevin Patterson, opened this week at the Harold Clurman Theater. Both plays focus on the same aspect of Turing's life - his homosexuality -and neither amply investigates the mathematician's breaking of the German secret code during World War II.
LEAD: Successful Season
LEAD: Ralph Sampson made his debut as a Golden State Warrior tonight, and although the 7-foot-4-inch center could not halt the team's dismal decline, his performance kindled hope for brighter days.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The nation's economy was expanding at a robust annual rate of 4.3 percent immediately before the October stock market collapse, the Commerce Department said today.

LEAD: A former employee of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military leader, has told Congressional investigators that the general authorized arms shipments to the Salvadoran rebels in the early 1980's when the Reagan Administration was trying to keep Nicaragua and other nations from arming them.

LEAD: ABOARD U.S.S. LA SALLE, in the Persian Gulf, Dec. 17 - Iranian gunboats attacked and set afire a cargo ship flying the Maldivian flag in the Persian Gulf today. An American warship nearby sent observation craft to the scene but did not otherwise become involved in the episode.

LEAD: George Cunningham, a lawyer who is a South Dakota state chairman for Senator Paul Simon's Presidential campaign, got a pressing call today from the local campaign manager. It was about Gary Hart's lunchtime stop at Minerva's Restaurant here.
LEAD: A special Federal grant of $4 million that was to have gone toward establishing a permanent record of the choreography of Martha Graham was killed today in Congress.
LEAD: For 80 years - the last 74 in Madison Square Garden - the Millrose Games have provided sparkle, grace and world records in track.
LEAD: A senior official in the Defense Department acknowledged today that evidence provided by a Sandinista defector of a Nicaraguan plan to invade other nations was ''speculative.''

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would recall 203,000 automobiles and light trucks to correct possible safety defects. The company said it knew of no accidents related to the defects.

LEAD: Mox Arthur Weber, retired chairman of the department of physical education at Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., died Dec. 5 at the North Hill retirement home in Needham, Mass. He was 85 years old and lived in Needham.
LEAD: Street battles broke out here today as students and workers vented their anger at the electoral defeat of this city's favorite son, Kim Dae Jung.

LEAD: The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that Willis J. Price would become president of Chevron U.S.A. Inc., its domestic operating subsidiary, and a member of the parent company's executive committee, effective immediately.
LEAD: It was bad enough that this city's Senator Q was indicted. After all, he is thought of here more as a neighbor than as a politician, much less a corrupt one.

LEAD: There does seem to be a serious chance to end the war in Nicaragua and cut off all Soviet military support for the Sandinistas. That was the message the Russians tried to deliver during the Gorbachev visit.
LEAD: * Boeing Helicopter Co., a unit of Boeing Co., has received a $198.9 million contract from the Army for production of 48 CH-47D helicopters.

LEAD: Tom Paxton, a songwriter, is to perform tonight and Sunday at the Bottom Line, 14 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Tonight, the bill also includes Schooner Fare and John McCutcheon; on Sunday, Mr. Paxton shares a double bill with the Carolling Carollers led by Suzzy Roche. Shows begin at 7:30 and 10:30 P.M.

LEAD: Israeli troops kept a tight lid on the occupied Gaza Strip today, but scattered demonstrations broke out in Palestinian refugee districts and towns in the West Bank and the Arab sector of East Jerusalem.

LEAD: ''SEPTEMBER'' is Woody Allen's riskiest film yet. It's a small, tightly disciplined drama about love, friendship and family, set entirely within a Vermont summer house at the end of the season. People come and go to destinations elsewhere, but the movie remains inside the cottage, like a possibly hypochondriacal, invalid ghost.
LEAD: Keith Hughes, a sophomore reserve forward, scored a career-high 19 points tonight as Syracuse took control early in a 111-68 victory over St. Bonaventure.

LEAD: Citing the rising number of AIDS patients crowding New York City hospitals, state health officials yesterday increased the overall capacity of hospital beds by as much as 500 beds. The move reverses 10 years of reductions stemming from efforts to control costs.

LEAD: A divided appeals court panel in Manhattan ruled yesterday that Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones had acted within his power in ordering a Bronx junior high school closed because of poor test scores and attendance.

LEAD: An alternate juror dismissed by the judge in the Howard Beach trial predicted yesterday that the jury would decide the case on the evidence presented and would disregard the broader racial and social questions that have been discussed again and again in the courtroom.

LEAD: The counsel to the House Ethics Committee recommended today that Represenative Mario Biaggi be expelled from Congress, while Mr. Biaggi's lawyers recommended a reprimand, according to the committee's chairman.

LEAD: A $5 million settlement has been reached between T. Cullen Davis, the bankrupt oil heir, and his former wife, Priscilla Davis, in a suit stemming from a 1976 shooting at the Davis mansion, lawyers report. A jury failed to reach a verdict in the case earlier this year.

LEAD: ''A guy has fallen in love with another woman. And the other woman has fallen in love with him. And it got all mixed up. He got on a ship, and the first woman he loved was going to get married to some Duke and he didn't want her to. And then gangsters gave him a ticket and he became the most wanted man in the United States.

LEAD: The Mets tied up a loose end yesterday when they signed Lee Mazzilli to a two-year contract, but negotiations with their two frontline pitchers -Dwight Gooden and Ron Darling -may not be so orderly.

LEAD: SEIJI OZAWA'S program for the Boston Symphony concerts Wednesday night and last night at Carnegie Hall amounted to a reminder not only of Igor Stravinsky's great gifts, but of Serge Koussevitzky. The Boston Symphony is hardly remiss about honoring Koussevitzky's memory, but in this era of erratic, halfhearted support for new music by so many of our leading orchestras (that was true in

LEAD: Grande Bande, an original-instrument ensemble, is to present a program of 17th-century Christmas music tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $14 and $17.50. Information: (212) 874-6770.

LEAD: BASEBALL

LEAD: Traverse the iron doors on the first floor, meander past the broken water fountains and the newspapers strewn on the second floor and step into the home of the Prospect Heights High School boys' basketball team.

LEAD: MILTON SUSMAN has bought convertible securities for more than two decades with considerable success. So despite the stock market collapse in October, the 81-year-old Palm Beach investor intends to continue buying them when they seem appropriate for his portfolio.

LEAD: Lynn Caine, a former publicity agent for a publishing house who became a best-selling author, died of cancer Wednesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Officials of the Defense Department said today that military personnel infected with the AIDS virus were being removed from sensitive, stressful jobs because of new evidence that the virus could impair mental function, even in people who show no overt symptoms of the disease.

LEAD: The Rev. David Rhinelander King, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church in Elizabeth, N.J., died of a heart attack Monday at St. Elizabeth Hospital in Elizabeth, N.J. He was 58 years old and lived in Hillside, N.J. He was a Princeton University graduate and was ordained in 1954. He is survived by his wife, Mary Sue Griffith; a son, Nicholas, of Hillside; two daughters, Elizabeth, of Dallas, and Melissa, of Hillside, and a twin, Canon Jonathan LeRoy King of Bergenfield, N.J.

At the Embassy 3, where ''Eddie Murphy Raw'' opened yesterday, even the ushers were laughing. And they, like everyone else in the place, had good reasons not to. The profanity is persistent, parts of Mr. Murphy's act are filthier than anything Richard Pryor ever attempted (like his adolescent impression of Mr. Pryor doing bathroom jokes), and when it comes to women and homosexuals, Mr. Murphy is clearly proud of his prejudices. Nonetheless, this feature-length concert film is hilarious, putting Mr. Murphy on a par with Mr. Pryor at his best. The generation between the two is readily apparent, both in the routine that has Mr. Murphy mimicking his idol and in his long, scathing anecdote about a telephone call from Bill Cosby, who complained about the obscenity of Mr. Murphy's show. First of all, Mr. Murphy is a terrific parodist, doing a lethal Cosby imitation complete with long pauses and sententious phrasings. Second, he caps this brilliantly by reporting his own subsequent call to Mr. Pryor, who said he himself had receivd a similar dressing down. Do people like you? Mr. Pryor asked. Do you get paid? ''Well, tell Bill I said have a Coke and a smile and shut up.''

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Congress is about to send the President one gigantic, take-it-or-leave-it appropriations bill for fiscal 1988. It's bad enough that the bill isn't even arriving until the fiscal year is almost three months gone. Worse, it's loaded with trivia, fakery and irrelevant controversy, and forces on President Reagan a $600 billion choice: He must accept every detail of this bill, or, if he wants to block a single one, must veto the whole thing.

LEAD: Crude oil cash and futures prices fell yesterday for the fifth day in a row after an early rally found little support. Futures prices of heating oil and unleaded gasoline also declined.

LEAD: A series of five concerts devoted to the Beethoven string quartets, featuring the Tokyo String Quartet, will begin Jan. 20 at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The first program includes the Opus 18 quartets. Other concerts will be on Feb. 10, March 30, April 27 and May 11. Single tickets range from $13 to $17.50; subscriptions are also available for $60 to $75.

LEAD: A brief report by Reuters on Wednesday about Donna Rice's loss of her job as a spokeswoman for a jeans manufacturer misstated what she and Gary Hart have said about a visit she paid to Washington last May.
LEAD: The House overwhelmingly approved legislation today to inject $4 billion into the Farm Credit System. The bailout would be one of the largest ever approved by the Government.

LEAD: The New York City Human Rights Commission yesterday accused two Upper East Side boutiques of discriminating against black men by denying them entrance or by treating them differently from white men.

LEAD: The jury in the Howard Beach murder case deliberated yesterday for a ninth day without reaching a verdict, amid mounting tensions at the Queens courthouse where four white teen-agers are on trial in the death of a black man.

LEAD: Vice President Bush today sought to limit the damage caused to his Presidential campaign by a White House memorandum showing that he supported secret arms sales to Iran last year. He said the memorandum's political effect would be ''absolutely nothing.''

LEAD: A tumultuous four-year legal battle that pitted the Pennzoil Company against the giant Texaco Inc. was brought to a conclusion last night when Texaco agreed in principle to give Pennzoil $3 billion, a lawyer for Texaco said.

LEAD: A striking theory proposed in 1980 ascribed the sudden demise of dinosaurs some 65 million years ago to the fiery impact of an outsize asteroid. Another explanation, duller and less often discussed, rejects catastrophes from the heavens and points to gradual processes on earth, like changes in climate and sea level, as the likely agents of extinction.

LEAD: Boxing Foreman Stops Sekorski: George Foreman stopped Rocky Sekorski in the third round last night in Las Vegas, Nev., for his fifth straight knockout since starting a comeback last March at the age of 39. Foreman, who held the heavyweight championship from January 1973 to October 1974, methodically pounded Sekorski with jabs and savage right hands before Referee Richard Steele stopped the bout at 2:48.

LEAD: The Giants snapped out of their lethargy today and beat a hard-playing team by playing harder. Their offense was efficient and their defense was tough except for a few shaky moments late in the game, and the result was a 20-10 victory over the Green Bay Packers.

LEAD: IT is early evening on one of the last Saturdays before Christmas, and customers at the Hermes shop here on the rue Faubourg St. Honore are standing two and three deep at the scarf counter. Salesgirls in dark blazers tirelessly unfurl square after square of brilliantly colored silk, patterned with peonies, toucans, and bold geometric shapes.

LEAD: ''OUR TOWN'' MAY BE the most misunderstood and misinterpreted of American plays. It is not, as is often assumed, a hymn to small-town life at the turn of the century. Nor is it the American equivalent of Dylan Thomas's ''Under Milk Wood,'' a poetic memory piece suffused with character and atmosphere.

LEAD: INDOCHINE. By Christie Dickason. (Villard, $18.95.) A vivid sense of place and a thorough knowledge of Vietnamese culture distinguish this colorful if flawed first novel by an American-born director and choreographer who lived in Indochina in the 1950's. Christie Dickason's heroine, Nina Luoc, is the daughter of a Frenchwoman and a wealthy Vietnamese who sees her privileged life shattered in 1954 when her mother is killed and her father disappears in the wake of an explosion at their home.

LEAD: Yes, but I think a more appropriate question should be whether or not Bo Jackson can succeed in the situation he has given himself. Playing baseball for the Kansas City Royals, whose fans are predominantly Chiefs football fans and haters of Jackson's football team, the Raiders, presents a much more challenging climb to stardom in both sports.

LEAD: IT began as a pilgrimage, a sentimental voyage to Africa's northernmost cape to complement earlier voyages that had led to another cape, far to the south, at a continent's tip. But it ended more as uncharted meandering along Tunisia's less beaten tracks, beach and forest and antiquity, a journey freckled with surprise and discovery: how, for instance, to prepare and cook a brik; or how they hunt wild boar in the winter with dogs, beaters and shotguns in the uplands back from the coast.

LEAD: THE provocative idea of giving drug addicts clean needles to help slow the spread of AIDS was first broached two years ago, and New York officials have been fighting over it ever since. This month the issue arose at the national level, as the President's advisory commission on AIDS said it would consider such a proposal.

LEAD: ''SORRELL AND SON,'' THE BRITISH period drama currently on public television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' (locally, on Channels 13 and 49 on Sunday evenings at 9), has a way of telling us something about ourselves today. The mini-series stands as a refreshing reminder of what used to be called the eternal verities - kindness, compassion, self-sacrifice and the like - the very commodities employed so astutely by, among others, Thornton Wilder in ''Our Town'' and Sherwood Anderson in ''Winesburg, Ohio.
LEAD: After losing two Grand Slam finals and the Masters title match earlier this year, Mats Wilander won a big one today as Sweden regained the Davis Cup title.

LEAD: THE Los Angeles Raiders' Bo Jackson, who has an ankle injury, will miss today's game against the Cleveland Browns. . . . LEAD: Deep in the mountains of northern Honduras, 500 American National Guardsmen and Army reservists from New York, Pennsylvania and West Virginia are building a road that will help farmers in the fertile but isolated Yoro Valley bring their produce to market.
LEAD: Joseph Marion Haggar, who founded and developed the Haggar Apparel Company, a major producer of men's slacks, sports coats and suits, died of heart failure Tuesday. He was 94 years old.

LEAD: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica says he is deeply troubled by Nicaragua's plans for a military buildup, calling them a clear breach of the spirit of the peace agreement that he, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra and three other Central American leaders signed last summer.

LEAD: Sylvia Lewis, former director of the 92d Street Y Nursery School, died Friday after a long illness at her home in Manhattan. She was 81 years old.

LEAD: A North American bald eagle that flew across the Atlantic and landed exhausted in Ireland will return home, but not under its own power, officials here say.

LEAD: SPURRED by rising disposal and liability costs, Connecticut companies have reduced the hazardous waste they generate by about 15 percent in the last four years, according to an advisory panel appointed by Governor O'Neill.

LEAD: MORE than half a century after his last home run and nearly four decades after his death, Babe Ruth is still making headlines, still creating debate. Just as his 714 homers and his 94-46 record with a 2.28 earned run average as a left-handed pitcher certify him as the best player in baseball history, his enduring esteem as a newsmaker is another reason why he remains the most celebrated baseball player in history.
LEAD: CRATCHITT was walking down Fifth Avenue, looking harried, dodging holiday shoppers.

LEAD: New York City enjoyed a phenomenal seven-year economic boom before the stock market collapse. But these prosperous times did not benefit the people on the fringes of the economy. The number of poor people increased dramatically from 1.3 million to 1.7 million during that period, including unprecedented numbers of families and children.

LEAD: THIS season has its own seductive scents. In our house, the perfume of pomanders replaces the lighter, sweeter fragrance of flowers. A combination of fruit and spice, pomanders have always seemed the perfect treasure or the perfect gift. They are as traditional as the tree, but far more lasting.

LEAD: For more than a decade Penn & Teller, ''two eccentric guys who have learned to do a few cool things,'' as they like to say, have been refining their own curious exhibition of comedy, magic and menace. Now their show is back in New York - on Broadway no less, in the Ritz Theater at 219 West 48th Street.

LEAD: Oscar Schmidt, who led Brazil to a stunning upset of the United States by scoring 46 points in the Pan American Games basketball final last summer, said he is awed by the National Basketball Association but prefers to play in Italy.

LEAD: It came as a shock to read (''Tradition Inspires Illuminator,'' Dec. 6) that Queen Esther, heroine of the Purim story, was ''the only non-Jew revered in Hebraic history.'' If Esther (a descendant of King Saul) is not Jewish, the whole point of the story is lost: She is willing to lay her life on the line by revealing her religion to her husband to save her people.

LEAD: MAYBE restaurant entrepreneurs know something the stock market experts don't. How else to explain the optimism that has given Fairfield County so many restaurant openings in the last few months?

LEAD: After losing the 23d game of the world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, on Thursday, and falling behind in the series, Gary Kasparov made an amazing, determined comeback to win the final game yesterday, level the score and keep his title.
LEAD: THERE ARE A LOT of good things about Christmas. One of the best is Christmas talk. At Christmas you can say words you'd be embarrassed to utter on, say, Columbus Day.

LEAD: ILAN RECHTMAN is a 24-year-old Israeli-born pianist and composer whose New York debut on Thursday evening at the 92d Street Y left one feeling more positive about his playing as the evening progressed. His recital began with a version of Bach's G-major Partita that included moments of inventive playing - the slow opening to the minuet, for instance, and a buoyant gigue - but that failed to sustain interest over more than short stretches.
LEAD: Charles W. Ferguson, a former senior editor of Reader's Digest, died Dec. 11 at Briar Crest Nursing Home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

LEAD: HARDLY had the tragic images of famine in Africa that gripped the world barely three years ago finally begun to flicker than new events seemed to propel their return. A crippling drought, with blood-draining civil strife its dark ally, threatens once again to produce fresh scenes of horror.

LEAD: A district commander of the New York City transit police has been relieved of his command for ignoring a departmental policy forbidding the use of arrest quotas, a department spokesman said yesterday.

LEAD: As the repeated Senate hearings on Supreme Court nominees have demonstrated, the Constitution lives. LEAD: For years, the Nassau County Executive submitted an annual budget and the Board of Supervisors routinely approved it after a one-day hearing. The board had revised only one budget request since 1979.

LEAD: ECONOMIC forecasters have been attacked in recent years for their apparent inability to predict many of the things that matter most - the continued growth in the trade deficit, say, or the stock-market plunge. Some businesses have closed their economics departments, partly for such failures.

LEAD: ADD a note of holiday cheer to food prepared for family and friends by paying attention to the color scheme. Red and green are all it takes. Peppers remain abundantly in the market in red and green. Green herbs such as parsley and even greenhouse-grown fresh basil can be combined with red peppers for colorful accents.

LEAD: To the Editor: We enjoyed ''Gifts of Gear and Gadgets'' (Travel, Nov. 22). As frequent travelers we have availed ourselves of most of them. However, one item that might seem superfluous, in the United States and some parts of Europe, is not mentioned. It is a traveling smoke detector. It may be purchased with traveling case for between $10 and $15.

LEAD: The military-dominated Government today published a new election law that bars independent observers but not soldiers from polling stations, and lets the authorities examine every voter's ballot.

LEAD: WHEN people think of Christmas trees, they don't generally think of electric fences. But for the County Forester, Ted Kozlowski, the electric fence is the only thing standing between the first Christmas tree nursery on public land in New York State and the hungry deer population of northern Westchester.

LEAD: A FEW weeks after the Israeli Government discovered a pretext for expelling Palestinian-American Muburak Awak, the nonviolent disciple of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., another darkly imaginative Palestinian wafted in over the Lebanese border in a hang glider. Before he could be dispatched, six Israeli soldiers were dead.

LEAD: The United States and China, after a year of often contentious negotiations, concluded an agreement early today that will drastically curb China's shipments of textiles and apparel to the United States through 1991. It starts Jan. 1.

LEAD: IF you've completed your last-minute Christmas shopping, why not reward yourself with some last-minute Christmas listening? This afternoon, for instance, you can choose between two editions of the centuries-old Festival of Lessons and Carols, both scheduled at 4 o'clock.

LEAD: Calling all VCR's - to tape ''A Christmas Carol'' (1951) for family enjoyment on Christmas Day. This year the definitive British filming of Dickens is slotted late on Thursday - 12:30 A.M. on Channel 5 - with most children already tucked in bed awaiting Santa. So a taped run-off should make perfect family fare for Christmas Day.

LEAD: A DECLINE in reports of child abuse or neglect during the holiday season, despite a steady increase in such complaints the rest of the year, is worrying sociologists and state officials.

LEAD: MOST of the great restaurants are chef-owned. Long Island's are no exception. Often, it's husband in the kitchen, wife in the dining room and satisfied diners at the tables. Judge Francis M. Arnold of Howard County District Court placed Ms. Hann, 41 years old, of Warfordsburg, Pa., on probation Wednesday and ordered that she be given medical treatment.

LEAD: THERE'S a delicious scariness about skirting the fringes of a great desert. When an unwary visitor or downed aviator is truly snared in the death grip of a major desert, of course, survival is no joke.

LEAD: Arthur C. Clarke's ''2061: ODYSSEY THREE'' (Del Rey/Ballantine, $17.95) is a pallid sequel to ''2010: Odyssey Two,'' which was a pallid sequel to Mr. Clarke's splendid ''2001.'' The new novel has no characters of interest, generates virtually no narrative tension and barely touches on the enigmatic monoliths that figured so prominently in the previous books; rather than resolving anything, the ending is a shameless come-on for ''Odyssey Four.

LEAD: An article in The Times Magazine on Nov. 8 about the political style of Senator Bob Dole misstated conditions under which Dr. William R. Roy, a political rival of Senator Dole's in a 1984 campaign, had performed therapeutic abortions. Only one took place at a Roman Catholic hospital; the reference should not have been plural.

LEAD: FOR centuries the common denominator of every household in Ireland - from a stone cottage perched on a Kerry cliff to a big house reigning over a Longford village - has been the daily use of baskets, especially to hold two staples of Irish life, potatoes and peat clods, or turf, for fuel. Today, in an age dominated by plastics, professional basket makers supply a growing home and international market for willow and rush baskets made in the traditional way.

LEAD: I do not question Lloyd Richards's esteemed place in the American theater (''Leaving His Imprint on Broadway,'' by Samuel G. Freedman, Nov. 22). LEAD: ALL around me at 9,500 feet that sunny winter morning were the spectacular snow-coated Rocky Mountains, with the Continental Divide looming like a thick band of vanilla ice cream across the horizon. Because of the arcane and convoluted laws passed by legislators, most of whom are lawyers, his client and his client's opponent are at the mercy of their lawyers who do not always want their clients to ''compromise'' and ''settle.

LEAD: 'Pravda does not carry cigarette advertising, or indeed any advertising. Government control of information is typical of totalitarian regimes and dictatorships. Those who favor such a ban hope to control the behavior of Americans by limiting their access to information. Ad bans represent censorship and idea control.
LEAD: Among affluent and well-educated Bostonians, the Christmas gift of favor this year is also a potentially dangerous one: gift-certificates for skydiving lessons.

LEAD: Ivan F. Boesky was sentenced to three years in prison for his part in Wall Street's biggest insider trading scandal. Mr. Boesky, once a leading arbitrager who amassed a fortune speculating in corporate takeovers, had pleaded guilty in April to one count of conspiracy to make false statements to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

On Dec. 8, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York City, his family and friends gathered at his funeral to grieve, to remember and to celebrate. LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: Your focus on ''character'' issues typically overlooked the significance of the Jackson campaign to the American people.

LEAD: EITHER way you look at it, a Christmas tree is an expense. If a cut tree is chosen and trimmed with colorful trinkets and lights, its days of glory are brief. All too soon, the tree is tossed on a trash heap to be carted away or cut up to protect a perennial border from spring frosts.

LEAD: Fifty years after Japanese troops in China killed more than 300,000 men, women and children in Nanking, Chinese-American artists have mounted an exhibition of works depicting the deaths to keep their memory alive.

LEAD: IF LOOKS COULD KILL, TOM GRUNICK'S DASHING good looks would surely do it, because they're killing the business he's in. In ''Broadcast News,'' Tom has been hired as a correspondent for a television network's Washington bureau solely on the strength of his telegenic qualities. His presence is a reproach to the more serious, less glamorous journalists who surround him.
LEAD: WRITING ABOUT A fascinating wine region that few others are likely to see is like writing about rare wines that no one else can drink: it's just not fair.

LEAD: I CAN smell it coming. Moisture is woven through the air in thin threads.

LEAD: Employers should not be held responsible for their workers' drunken driving if the employer had nothing to do with the drinking, even if the employer provided the alcohol, the state's highest court ruled this week.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Alabama's black political caucus today gave unanimous endorsement to the Democratic Presidential campaign of the Rev. Jesse Jackson but hedged its bets by naming Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee as its alternative choice.

LEAD: Susan Squire deserves congratulations for her clear article on electroconvulsive therapy (''Shock Therapy's Return to Respectability,'' Nov. 22). ECT is the treatment of choice for certain severe forms of depression. Like other treatments, it has potential side effects, and patients should explore with their physicians the risks and benefits of treatment alternatives.

Her reward was to be held without charges in a fetid Lagos jail for 10 months in a dispute over alleged illegal exporting. When she was threatened with execution in 1985, the resulting international uproar forced her release.

LEAD: To the Editor: From a Manhattan-born U.S. and Swiss citizen, a first prize to Anthony Burgess for his fine article on Switzerland as viewed from Lugano. How delightfully he shares with us his good fortune at living there, and his penetrating observations not only about that Italian-speaking one-sixth of the country but also about the polyglot remainder.

LEAD: At the Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Washington, Elizabeth Diane Spurgeon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Spurgeon of Lansing, Mich., was married yesterday to Karl Edward Bushman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard L. Bushman of Newark, Del.
LEAD: A man, lonely in old age, his eyesight dimmed, still holds on to the dignity of his spare room. But he needs help at the grocery store, as well as a break in the loneliness.

LEAD: Opinion polls consistently show that Americans not only fear, but despise lawyers -ranking them with used-car salesmen and politicians. We don't trust lawyers because they have destroyed the nation's sense of right and wrong. Most Americans are convinced that our courts do not find in favor of the innocent party, but of the better lawyer.

LEAD: Congressional leaders and top Administration officials reached ''agreement in principle'' late tonight on a proposal to continue nonmilitary aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, removing a major obstacle to approval of legislation that would carry out the 1988 budget compromise.
LEAD: Kathleen Mary Byrne, a teacher, and Petrus Cornelis Hendrik Martens, an astrophysicist, were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in New York by the Rev. Neil Connolly.
LEAD: Kent K. Curtis, chief scientist of the National Science Foundation, died Thursday of cancer at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington, D.C. He was 60 years old and lived in Washington.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: SOME CALL THEM ''RADICALS,'' ''REVISION-ists'' or simply troublemakers. But to others -and to themselves - they are challenging the traditional insularity of art history. Energetic, contentious and often controversial, they are a loose-knit community of scholars in universities throughout the country who use methods derived from outside the field to study the visual arts as more than a purely esthetic phenomenon.
LEAD: While the number of Americans living below the poverty line has risen steadily in recent years, new research is finding a much faster rate of growth among the most severely disadvantaged.

LEAD: WHEN state and Federal transportation officials last year withdrew a $12 million plan to build three bridges over the Saw Mill River Parkway, opponents of the project in Westchester County were jubilant.

LEAD: IN LA-LA LAND WE TRUST, by Robert Campbell. (Mysterious Press, $3.95.) La-La Land is Los Angeles, where the discovery of a headless corpse helps a private investigator named Whistler uncover a pornography ring run by a seemingly respectable businessman with a voyeuristic taste for murder. ''Whistler is in many ways a very modern reincarnation of Hammett's Continental Op,'' Newgate Callendar said in The Book Review last year.

LEAD: ONE really disagreeable way to ruin a vacation in the sun is to plunge into the surf and get stung, stuck or bitten by a sea creature. In one case we know of, a vacationer had such an acute allergic reaction to sea urchin spines that he became ill and his traveling companions could not enjoy themselves for worry.

LEAD: Rows of tin cans and glass jars once lined the window sills of her cramped apartment in a city housing project on the Lower East Side, a poor woman's burglar alarm. Bands of youths looted her building frequently, and she had been mugged three times, attacks that left a deep fear that one day she would be irreparably harmed.

LEAD: TEN YEARS AGO, PHOTOGRAPHS made to be seen as art were for the most part sharp, clear and descriptive. While not everyone subscribed to the Modernist notion that it is the nature of the medium to describe the world in exacting detail, most photographers would have agreed that photography's advantage over painting rested with its verisimilitude.

LEAD: LAST year, two owners of an Australian mail-order firm known as Subdivision Art bought a 1959 Picasso linocut print entitled ''Trois Femmes.'' The purpose was to cut it into 500 pieces, each one inch square, and sell them for $135 apiece - complete with a certificate of authenticity and a 30-day money-back guarantee.

He then added two baskets in an 8-2 Washington run that gave the Bullets a 99-84 lead with 6:31 to play.

LEAD: Minorities - blacks, Hispanics and Asians - are on the verge of becoming a majority in New York City's resident labor force, the United States Department of Labor announced last week. The change reflects a shift in the city's population: the exodus of non-Hispanic whites and the influx of blacks, Hispanics and newer ethnic groups, such as Asians.

Griffin's ''Brotherhood of War'' series brings back many of the same characters whose military careers have been delineated in the first six. The series is in the platoon-movie genre - one of everything. LEAD: Back in his days at St. John's University, when Chris Mullin wasn't putting the ball through the hoop, he was putting away a few beers - quite a few beers, in fact, according to acquaintances. LEAD: THE NEWSPAPER OF CLAREMONT STREET. By Elizabeth Jolley. (Viking, $14.95.) In this small, richly peculiar novel, Elizabeth Jolley writes about money the way others write about love - lyrically, longingly, sensually. Money is the obsession of Margarite Morris, known as ''the Newspaper of Claremont Street'' or ''Weekly'' because of the petty gossip she picks up and passes along on her rounds cleaning houses in a small Australian town.

LEAD: WHEREVER olive oil is produced in Italy, it's traditional to celebrate the olive harvest and the pungent new oil with a feast of bruschetta. This is the original garlic bread, made with thick slices toasted over a fire, rubbed with fresh garlic and saturated with intense green olive oil. This simple yet superb dish is known by various names all over Italy - bruschetta, fett'unta, soma d'aj - depending on the region.
