LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Prof. and Mrs. Sidney Feshbach of Leonia, N.J., and Amherst, Mass., have announced the engagement of his daughter Devra S. Feshbach to Paul E. Meriney, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David K. Meriney of Upper Montclair, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: THESE days, don't expect to find a Santa's workshop close to home. Most of the country's 800 toymakers are producing their wares overseas in places like South Korea. Yet there are the exceptions; companies like Bantam Collections Inc., a leading manufacturer of stuffed toys in the infant field. In a 90-year-old building in Port Chester, the company's 47-year-old factory is still turning out 6,000 lambs and bunnies, puppies and elephants, clowns and bears a week, not only at

LEAD: For some employees of Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, the season of giving will mean a computer instead of Christmas cards. What has touched their hearts is the plight of Ann Carina McBean, a 15-year-old Mount Vernon girl who has had sickle cell anemia since she was an infant.

LEAD: A table last Sunday listing changes in the securities industry since September misstated the status of three companies. Carl H. Pforzheimer & Company has formed a joint venture with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. W. Damm, M. Frank & Company was an American Stock Exchange specialist firm that has been purchased by Bear, Stearns & Company.
LEAD: ''ANYTHING can start with a practical idea, but when you deal with an object you forget the practical part. Then the esthetic idea comes into place.''

LEAD: IN AN INDUSTRY FOND OF promotional fanfare, it is surprising that an important new trend in recording remains largely unheralded. This unusual reticence may reflect the fact that the new recording method is still something of a minority cult practiced mainly by smaller companies. But what they have accomplished seems to please many critical listeners.

LEAD: THE State Department of Transportation has mapped plans for a $3 million project to alleviate flooding on the Saw Mill River Parkway south of Dobbs Ferry - a problem that has become so severe that accidents on that road are actually decreasing.

LEAD: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 6 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $4.95.) Nightmarish experiences befall a woman appointed Ambassador to Rumania. 2 7 GARDEN OF SHADOWS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The beginnings of the evil that beset the Dollanganger family in previous novels.
LEAD: EDDY DECO'S LAST CAPER An Illustrated Mystery. By Gahan Wilson. 213 pp. New York: Times Books. $14.95.
LEAD: Chris Chandler threw for 234 yards and two touchdowns tonight, leading Washington to a 24-12 victory over Tulane in the Independence Bowl.

LEAD: The Cuomo administration is prepared to take a leadership role in garbage disposal in New York, including the lending of technical and management help, but it will not help pay local trash disposal costs, the state's Conservation Commissioner, Thomas C. Jorling, said today.
LEAD: The Prague Government, which in the past has been persuaded to lean whichever way the wind from Moscow was blowing, may now be responding to gusts of glasnost.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Kidney Pond Camps, the last privately owned sporting camp in Baxter State Park, will be converted to a more primitive facility next spring despite pleas from patrons that there should be one place in the park with electricity, flush toilets and fine food.

LEAD: Jesse Jackson may ''aim for the mainstream,'' but he remains a divisive force in American life, in spite of all his new appeals and continued efforts to paint himself as a ''rainbow'' man. His being a preacher makes me as uncomfortable with his candidacy as I am with Pat Robertson's. Their respective backgrounds and activities as adults were both partisan and religiously oriented, and I question whether such personalities would serve the country's best interests.

LEAD: HARD times on Wall Street are dragging down an emerging office market across the Hudson River, according to real estate analysts. They expect millions of square feet of new construction to be postponed along the New Jersey waterfront.
LEAD: Fourteen thousand needy children in New York City have warm coats to wear for the winter, thanks to a undertaking involving the Salvation Army and businesses.

LEAD: Although I have always been a great lover of diners, I thoroughly enjoyed Barbara Klaus's hilarious ''Therapy at the Diner'' [ Long Island Sound, Oct. 25 ] . It is a shame that Erich Rosenthal, as expressed in his Nov. 15 letter to the Long Island editor, took this article so seriously, seeing it as an attempt ''to malign the diner,'' which, he is right, is truly an
LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission came under renewed Congressional attack today in a sharply critical year-end report by the House subcommittee assigned to oversee its operations.

LEAD: The ''shebab,'' hot-eyed, desperate, angry young men, were gathered outside the tiny cinderblock dwelling - it would be hard to call it a house - mourning Abdul Salam Fteihah, who had been shot dead by the Israeli Army.
LEAD: Two months after black Monday and in the midst of its holiday fund-raising drive, the Salvation Army says collections in the New York area are running far behind last year's.

LEAD: Defying official recommendations, a growing number of doctors who treat carriers of the AIDS virus are prescribing a powerful, potentially toxic drug even before the patients develop serious signs of disease.

LEAD: The judge presiding over the long-running legal battle between the Intel Corporation and the NEC Corporation of Japan has disqualified himself from the case and vacated an earlier ruling that was considered favorable to the American semiconductor industry.

LEAD: Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo with children Saturday during a visit to Laguna de Venecia. Cardinal Obando, mediator in cease-fire talks between the Sandinista Government and the contras, said he might withdraw if the two sides did not show more flexibility in the talks, which are scheduled to resume today in the Dominican Republic.

LEAD: Israel's relations with Egypt, the only Arab country with which it has signed a peace treaty, have become increasingly strained as a result of the violence that has left at least 16 Palestinians dead in the last 12 days.

LEAD: His name had come to cover the statistics sheet, filling most of the blanks in almost all of the categories. Having thus authored what amounted to a miserably lost weekend for the Rangers, it was slightly sad that Mario Lemieux could not put his signature on its conclusion.

LEAD: Engineers for the space agency and Morton Thiokol Inc. worked today to unravel a frustrating series of breakdowns that forced postponement of the second full-scale test-firing Saturday of the redesigned booster rocket for the space shuttle.
LEAD: Senator David Pryor, a Democrat from Arkansas, acknowledges that the Senate can be sluggish, unpredictable, inefficient and at times unproductive. But he is decidedly fond of the institution.
LEAD: Stan Humphries, the Northeast Louisiana quarterback, said the key to success against Marshall University was simple.

LEAD: It is unlikely that Johann Klepper, a German who invented the folding sea kayak in 1907, could have imagined its future. What would he think if he could see it with a sailing rig on a trans-Atlantic crossing nearly 50 years later? Or as a sabotage craft during World War II? Or in the 1980's as standard equipment for a weekend excursion on the water?

LEAD: The veil of secrecy surrounding trading in the Treasury and agency securities market ought to be lifted, at least partly, according to a report to be published today by the General Accounting Office.

LEAD: A Government agency that helps finance American exports is incurring such losses that its capital will be wiped out within nine months, and it will ask Congress for a $3 billion bailout next month, its chief executive says.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company's divisions in three South American countries that retained offices of J. Walter Thompson have completed their review of their advertising and here is the final score: Thompson 1 - Visitors 2.

LEAD: An article in The Home Section on Dec. 10 about companies that assist employees caring for elderly relatives misidentified a sponsor of an information and referral service for working people. It is J. P. Morgan & Company, not Morgan Stanley.
LEAD: Anemona Maria Hartocollis, a reporter for Newsday, and Joshua Steven Barbanel, a reporter for The New York Times, were married at a Manhattan loft yesterday by Rabbi Rolando Matalon.

LEAD: What many regard as Europe's most effective scientific collaboration, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, known by the French acroynym CERN, survived a critical test last week when Britain conditionally agreed to continue its membership.

LEAD: Rena Bartos, one of the stars of advertising research, is moving from the J. Walter Thompson phase of her life, where she has spent 21 years, to the consultant phase. Mail can reach her at 3 East 54th Street in New York.

LEAD: A year ago, Phil Simms was leading the Giants to the best record in the National Football League and a Super Bowl victory. Now, the 14-2 record of last season has turned into 5-9 this season, and Simms is trying to hold the Giants' offense together by doing things differently.
LEAD: Harold Kern was grim and haggard as he stood in the small vestibule of the courtroom where the Howard Beach jury was deliberating.

LEAD: TALLEY BEATTY took the title of ''The Stack-Up'' from a phrase that can mean freeway congestion. Nevertheless, his work, which the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performed Saturday afternoon at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street, and will repeat on Tuesday evening, concerns emotional, rather than highway, traffic.

LEAD: It seemed like intermission in a play that already had lasted too long, and while few people milling about the lobby felt certain of the final outcome, many were willing to predict on what basis the critics would render their reviews.

LEAD: Walter Payton bid a bittersweet goodbye today to the Soldier Field crowds that watched his career unfold for the Chicago Bears, turning in a 79-yard, two-touchdown effort that was his best so far in a sometimes-trying final season.

LEAD: WHEN the Grande Bande was founded 10 years ago, the period-instrument movement was hardly new, but neither was it squarely within the mainstream of concert life. As a reminder of how all that has changed, the ensemble's performance Saturday evening in Alice Tully Hall drew a full house to hear 17th-century Christmas music.

LEAD: The treaty eliminating land-based intermediate-range nuclear forces will probably pass the Senate when it comes up for a vote next spring. First will come a prolonged debate that will raise the question of whether the treaty has left America and its allies more vulnerable in Europe. As a result, the treaty's most significant contribution may not be the nuclear arms it eliminates but the new phase of concern and action on conventional arms it stimulates.
LEAD: As Jean Kirby made gravy for a lamb roast dinner, her hand grazed the Uzi submachinegun resting amid a clutter of herbs and vegetables on the kitchen counter.
LEAD: Robert B. Horton, the Briton who abruptly assumed command of Standard Oil for the British Petroleum Company in 1986, is returning to a B.P. position in London in April.
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about new cookbooks misstated a title. The book is ''Reading Between the Recipes,'' by Leslie Land (Yankee Books, $15.95).
LEAD: Two immigrants to the United States, one English and the other French, have capitalized on America's love of fast cars and motorsports.

LEAD: The combined pressures of a superpower arms accord and maneuvering for a presidential campaign here have quickened the evolution of French strategic doctrine toward an automatic commitment to defend West Germany at its eastern frontiers in case of a Warsaw Pact attack.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The deepest change in the Soviet Union is not in politics. As Americans who see the current Soviet film ''Repentance'' are finding out, it's in the arts.

LEAD: Jennifer Christman, a daughter of Naomi Sacks Christman of Brooklyn Heights and Robert A. Christman of New York, was married yesterday to Jay Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Cohen of Brooklyn. Rabbi Balfour Brickner officiated at the Americas Society in New York.

LEAD: SINKING oil prices customarily translate into a curb on inflation, and last week this interpretation sent stock and bond prices bounding ahead. Wall Street took its cue from recent meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries after it became apparent that the group was unable to stem overproduction and price discounting.

LEAD: Rabbi Leo Jung, a prominent Orthodox Jewish leader, and for 65 years the spiritual leader of the Jewish Center of New York, died at St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center Saturday, where he had been hospitalized after suffering a heart attack two weeks ago. Dr. Jung was 95 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Mark Acres, a rookie, and Larry Bird and Kevin McHale sparked a 73-point first half, and the Boston Celtics breezed to a 124-87 victory over Philadelphia tonight, foiling the 76ers' bid to take over first place in the Atlantic Division.

LEAD: AT last month's New York City Marathon, all eyes were fixed on 27-year-old Pat Petersen of Ronkonkoma, L.I., who boldly took the lead and held it for 14 miles before finishing fourth in 2 hours 12 minutes 3 seconds. But it was not just Peterson's aggressive racing that commanded attention. It was his running form as well.

LEAD: In the latest struggle to enable Pan American World Airways Inc. to survive another winter when traffic is low and cash is short, some managers and union leaders have put their hopes in being taken over by Jay A. Pritzker, the chairman of Braniff Inc. and wealthy Chicago industrialist.

LEAD: SKIING Tomba Leads Sweep: Alberto Tomba of Italy, who threw away his birthday cake after his four-race World Cup winning streak was broken, began a new streak yesterday, leading a 1-2 Italian sweep in a men's slalom in Kranjska Gora, Yugoslavia, and improving his lead in the World Cup ski standing.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Ida and Joseph Gabay may forgo a vacation and otherwise scrimp because of the money they lost when the stock market plunged. But the Gabays have no intention of playing Scrooge when it comes to their grandchildren.

LEAD: * James Aaby, William Chororos, Philip Guthrie, Richard Mahan and Howard Stein have been named executive vice presidents on the creative side of Backer Spielvogel Bates, where James Keller and J. Edmund Keating have been made senior vice presidents.

LEAD: On a weekend that many feared would be filled with tear gas and thousands in the streets, a group of women sat in a beauty salon, resigned to a new President most had voted against but determined that his new Government would be accountable to them.

LEAD: DON DELILLO is one of the most esteemed novelists in the country, so when ''The Day Room,'' his first play, unfolds at the Manhattan Theater Club, one keeps hoping against hope it is not what it seems to be: ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' as it might be rewritten by a pretentious undergraduate who has just completed the midterm, if not all the required reading, for a survey course in the works of Pirandello, Beckett and
LEAD: Syracuse University will be sending two football teams to the Sugar Bowl.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Singer Company said late last night that it had notified Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor, that he could complete his pending tender offer for the company if he could arrange the necessary financing and promptly complete the deal.
LEAD: Foote, Cone & Belding in San Francisco has taken over the Holland America Line account from Elgin Syferd, a Seattle agency. Billings have been reported to be more than $10 million.
LEAD: QUESTION: Has the same ball park ever been the site of a perfect game and of a batter hitting for the cycle during the same season?
LEAD: A district commander of the New York City transit police has been relieved of his command for ignoring a departmental policy forbidding the use of arrest quotas.
LEAD: Kelly Hrudey, the repeated victim of a Philadelphia Flyer tactic he termed ''crease-bashing,'' scowled when asked about the difficulties of withstanding the proximity favored by Flyer forwards.

LEAD: Early this month Senator Jake Garn entered a meeting of the Banking Committee and told the banking regulators, lobbyists and reporters in the packed chamber that he was fed up with them and the legislative process they were part of.
LEAD: By major college standards, Tony Dawson of Florida State is neither a particularly quick basketball player nor an impressive jumper. But by any measure, Dawson is truly a remarkable athlete.
LEAD: A study conducted for the House Armed Services Committee said today that at least 29 Air Force cruise missiles had guidance systems with an improperly tested component.
LEAD: Gary Kasparov is departing this city in southern Spain in the same manner as he arrived in October, triumphant and controversial, his world chess title firmly in hand.

LEAD: Sitting on a stool pitched against his shanty on a hill overlooking this threadbare capital, Jean Delarouche sniffed and spat as he watched a group of children kicking a soccer ball along the half-paved street.
LEAD: Standing among stacks of wooden ammunition crates Sgt. Antonio Francisco da Silva offered tips for shooting down South African warplanes.

LEAD: The exploding star that flashed to life over the Southern Hemisphere early this year has inspired a clever approach to one of the most baffling questions of modern astronomy: how much of the universe is made of the type of matter found on earth, and how much consists of a rare, mysterious substance that scientists call antimatter.

LEAD: Decades after they began in the United States, mutual funds have arrived in India -lacking the versatility, specialization and experience of the American funds but strongly backed by the national Government here as a safe investment.

LEAD: When the United States Commission on Civil Rights recently approved a proposal to study legal issues surrounding the AIDS epidemic, including the rights of people infected with the deadly virus, it said that victims suffer a ''tremendous stigma'' because ''those acts generally responsible for transmitting the virus are often illegal and have traditionally been morally proscribed.

LEAD: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Karin Jette Schattman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Rains Schattman Jr. of Hewlett Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Ethan Tanenbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Tanenbaum of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Mordecai Waxman and Cantor David Benedict.
LEAD: Attention in the bond market shifted last week from the dangers of inflation stemming from a weak dollar to the prospects of low inflation stemming from lower oil prices.
LEAD: For Brooklyn youngsters (and parents) who have time on their hands, a free guide to activities in the borough for children is now available.
LEAD: AFTER more than six months of speculation and debate, a committee of Delaware's bar association is on the verge of approving new rules governing corporate takeovers, lawyers say.
LEAD: Caspar Weinberger spent more and supervised less than any other Secretary of Defense. His successor, Frank Carlucci, is reaping the fruit of this indiscipline.

LEAD: Here's a tale of the criminal justice system that begins in Maryland a quarter-century ago with a ''murder'' that may not even have been committed. The shooting victim's insurance company was sure that he committed suicide - so sure that it refused to pay off on the dead man's policy until the murder conviction of Nick Donald Bagley, an 18-year-old black man, in October 1962.
LEAD: With passion, anger and calls for unity, Michael Griffith was mourned on the first anniversary of his death yesterday at a crowded memorial service and Mass in a Brooklyn church.

LEAD: John F. Fleming, a rare-book dealer and collector who for 30 years dominated the antiquarian manuscript market, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

LEAD: Despite its legal and financial woes, Texaco Inc. has continued throughout the Pennzoil affair to sponsor Saturday afternoon radio broadcasts of the Metropolitan Opera, a tradition at Texaco since 1940.

LEAD: THE news spread quickly on that cool autumn evening in October 1976. The New York Nets, as they were known then, were on the West Coast, beginning their first season in the National Basketball Association. It was supposed to be a time for celebration for the team from a maligned league that played with a ball that critics said belonged on a beach, not a basketball court.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''You do the best you can do under the circumstances.'' - House Speaker Jim Wright, on an agreement to provide $8.1 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. [ A1:6. ]

LEAD: Among the lesser-known byproducts of the recent meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev is an agreement involving objects of a conspicuously peaceable sort. While the summit meeting was being arranged, United States and Soviet officials hastily drew up a plan to exchange paintings.

LEAD: It's hardly surprising that the faltering Dallas Cowboys have been displaced as ''America's Team,'' but it may come as something of a shock to learn which team has claimed the No. 1 spot in the hearts and minds -or at least the pocketbooks - of the American public.
LEAD: The election last week in South Korea appears to have had a favorable result for the International Olympic Committee and the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul.

LEAD: Mario Conde, a 39-year-old lawyer, became Spain's youngest bank chairman and chief executive last week. Banco Espanol de Credito, which is known as Banesto and is Spain's second-largest bank, named him chairman at the height of its battle with Banco de Bilbao, Spain's third-largest bank, which had launched a hostile takeover bid for Banesto on Nov.

LEAD: A poll published today shows Gary Hart has jumped to the head of the Democratic Presidential field in Iowa and knocked away half the support for previous poll leader, Senator Paul Simon of Illinois.
LEAD: Every weekday morning, Lee-Ann Messina takes the 7 A.M. ferry from New London, Conn., where she lives, to the tiny school on this island off the Connecticut coast.
LEAD: WINTER: A Novel of a Berlin Family. By Len Deighton. 571 pages. Knopf. $19.95.

LEAD: The White House and Congressional leaders reached agreement tonight on a compromise that would give $8.1 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels and sets up a possible showdown vote on American policy toward the contras in early February.

LEAD: Carrying candles and protest signs, several thousand people marched through midtown Manhattan yesterday, criticizing city, state and Federal policies that they said had contributed to homelessness in New York City.

LEAD: Also in the spirit of the season, the United States Geological Survey over at the Department of the Interior has ginned up a computer search of its Geographic Names Information System to document the jolly prevalence of holiday-related names all over this great land.
LEAD: In the spirit of the season, the National Zoological Park received 10 Japanese spider crabs, notable for their bright red and white shells, as a gift from All Nippon Airways over the weekend.
LEAD: Meeting in a rare Sunday session, Congress late today approved an emergency spending bill designed to keep the Federal Government in business through midnight on Monday.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: International A3-16

LEAD: An article on Nov. 28 about the retirement of Thomas L. Sheer, assistant director in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's New York office, misidentified the private company he will join in January. It is Tillinghast, a Towers Perrin Company.
LEAD: A new immigration law has failed to stem the flow of illegal aliens from El Salvador to the United States, according to a confidential cable from the American Embassy there.

LEAD: THE exercise stress test, long a medical standard for detecting heart disease, is frequently ordered for those in their mid-30's or older who follow sound advice and see a doctor before they begin to work out.

LEAD: The marriage of Peggy Duke Kutzen, the daughter of Jerome L. Kutzen of Purchase, N.Y., and the late Carol T. Kutzen, to Gerold Mosher Wunderlich, a son of Eleanor B. Wunderlich of Ossining, N.Y., and Rudolph Wunderlich of Chicago, took place yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in White Plains.

LEAD: The Clorox Company, whose line of packaged goods runs from bleach to cat litter, has retained the San Francisco office of Wunderman Worldwide to ascertain how effective direct marketing would be for its brands. Wunderman is the direct-marketing subsidiary of Young & Rubicam.

LEAD: Dr. Lienhard Bergel, a retired professor of comparative literature at the graduate school of City University of New York, died Dec. 14 at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after being struck by an automobile in Port Washington, L.I., where he lived. He was 82 years old.
LEAD: In bidding to take control of the A. H. Robins Company, Sanofi, France's second-largest pharmaceutical firm, is flexing its young muscles.

LEAD: Sean Elliott scored 18 points and seven other Wildcats scored in double digits as Arizona beat Washington in their Pacific-10 Conference opener tonight, 110-71. The Wildcats rolled up the biggest score ever against the Huskies.

LEAD: The Chicago office of Grey Advertising, which has been acquired by GGK Holding, a European company, will be retitled HFC & Lois/GGK, getting its name from its three top people; its sister company, Lois Pitts Gershon Ponn/GGK, and its new parent company.

LEAD: The Democratic Presidential candidates agree that the Federal budget deficit portends economic disaster, that President Reagan is to blame because of his tax cuts and increased military spending, and that among the pressing tasks for the next President will be to control the deficit.
LEAD: * C. R. Bard Inc., Murray Hill, N.J., a maker of surgical products, elected George A. Davis executive vice president and Terence C. Brady Jr. senior vice president.

LEAD: Facing a host of shareholder lawsuits stemming from its dispute with Pennzoil, Texaco executives have sought to protect themselves in two provisions of a reorganization plan that will be filed today in a Federal bankruptcy court.

LEAD: The E. F. Hutton Group's efforts in the last two years to turn around the fortunes of the battered investment house by hiring away talent from other companies have turned out to be an expensive gamble that failed.
LEAD: No Cherokee Indians live here now, nor did they ever, but their history marks this town forever.

LEAD: Howard Kaminsky, ousted as executive vice president from Random House two months ago in a power struggle that stunned the book publishing industry, is to become president of the Hearst Corporation's trade book group - a unit that includes William Morrow, predominantly a publisher of hardcover books, and Avon

LEAD: Facing losses of more than $75 million this year and operating under new management, the Dravo Corporation said Friday that it was selling its engineering, construction and energy businesses to concentrate on limestone mining and other quarrying.

LEAD: Chinese students at many colleges and universities across the United States have signed a petition to their Government on behalf of an American-educated molecular biologist who was arrested nearly a year ago in Shanghai during a crackdown on political dissent.
LEAD: Jerry Rice set two National Football League receiving records today and scored three touchdowns to lead the San Francisco 49ers to a 35-7 victory over the Atlanta Falcons.

LEAD: ''L'Amico Fritz'' is the second of Mascagni's 17 operas, and, as far as I know them, also the second best. In some ways its craftsmanship and tangy harmonies may even make it preferable to ''Cavalleria Rusticana,'' which made the young composer's fame in 1890. ''Fritz'' is a treasurable piece, completely different from its predecessor: the trailblazer of verismo took Bellini's pastoral ''Sonnambula'' as his model here, and made something touching and memorable.

LEAD: The last knockout team championship to be played at the Jacob Javits Convention Center was won Saturday night by Greg Woods, Jeff Bayone, Ron Felton, Jon Greenspan, Steve Nellissen, all of Manhattan, and Lapt Chan, Woodside, Queens.
LEAD: The Jets' season lasted just long enough to tantalize and confound everyone again - players, their coach and their fans.

LEAD: Laws making 21 the legal drinking age, intended to combat drunken driving among young people, are having little effect on limiting drinking among college students, according to recent studies and interviews with university officials and students.
LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 21, 1987: MONDAY Bunker Hill Inc Secs NBD Bancorp Horizon Bancorp TUESDAY Signet Banking Corp WEDNESDAY Boston Edison

LEAD: A spokesman for the Nicaraguan rebels said today that the contras opened their biggest offensive in the seven-year-old war against the Sandinista Government today, on the eve of truce talks here.
LEAD: The New England Patriots used a wind-blown touchdown, a wind-induced interception and an aggressive defense that limited Buffalo to only 148 net yards today to beat the Bills, 13-7.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WHAT is ''the black tradition''? A program devoted to it, presented by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Wednesday at City Center, suggested that the tradition or heritage is one of strong women and playfully spirited men, of profound suffering and equally profound hope - and of the capacity to celebrate each in vital, entertaining theater and dance.

LEAD: Gifts I would unwrap each Christmas are bound in twine I cannot always cut in time to join the caroling; twine tough as mindless dread - or wisteria that chokes the tree it climbs - it must be slashed away each season.

LEAD: Skip Novak remembers the incident clearly. It was a day in August two years ago when the keel fell off the 77-foot maxi-yacht he was sailing near the southwestern coast of England. Water came rushing through the hatches as the boat turned belly up.

LEAD: With the long-sought settlement pact with Texaco Inc. set to be filed Monday, J. Hugh Liedtke stands at the twilight of a remarkable career of oil patch dealings with a challenge few industrialists could face in their wildest dreams: What to do with $3 billion.

LEAD: Wade Wilson passed for one touchdown and ran for another today as the Minnesota Vikings snapped a two-game losing streak and kept their playoff hopes alive with a 17-14 victory over the bumbling Detroit Lions.

LEAD: Daniel Rich is worried about the homeless and especially the children of the homeless in Manhattan and tried to help out by volunteering his services over the school holidays. The neighborhood charitable organizations, however, said they thought there was not very much the 13-year-old boy could do.
LEAD: A Soyuz TM-4 spacecraft and a booster rocket will be launched Monday to carry a new crew to the Soviet space station Mir, Tass, the official Government press agency, said today.

LEAD: The marriage of Maura Anne Riccobene to Jonathan Brereton Bulkeley took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan. The Rev. Raymond A. Nolan, the bride's great-uncle, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Venerable Robert A. Bryan, the Archdeacon of the North Shore Anglican Diocese of

LEAD: GIVEN a set-up situation that has only one way to go and the playwright's determination to get there, ''Acts of Faith'' maintains a surprisingly high level of tension for much of the way, before collapsing into a lesson in Human Relations. Marilyn Felt's play, which opened yesterday at the Mosaic Theater, takes place in the small upper cabin of a hijacked jet, where Barbara, a light-traveling California psychologist in her 30's, who has been separated from the other passengers because she is the only Jew on board, is being guarded by young Ahmed, a devout Moslem who kisses his gun a lot.

LEAD: Joanna Kudisch Weinberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Kudisch of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday in Berkeley, Calif., to David I. Levine, a son of Dr. Murray Levine and Dr. Adeline G. Levine of Buffalo. Rabbi Michael Monson officiated at Gramma's Inn.

LEAD: With the long-sought settlement pact with Texaco Inc. set to be filed Monday, J. Hugh Liedtke stands at the twilight of a remarkable career of oil patch dealings with a challenge few industrialists could face in their wildest dreams: What to do with $3 billion.
LEAD: About 1,000 youths surging out of a rap concert panicked in a narrow, winding hallway, trampling to death two teen-age girls and injuring at least 29 people, the police said today.

LEAD: Iraq and Iran reported a border attack by Iranian soldiers, but the relatively small number of combatants said to have been involved indicated that this was not the major offensive that Iran has been reported planning for months.

LEAD: With inflation again roaring out of control here, Luiz Carlos Bresser Pereira's job early last week was to play St. George to that perennial dragon. He picked ''fiscal shock'' as his weapon and prepared to do battle.
LEAD: For many suspicious South Koreans, the Battle of Kuro will long linger as the prime example that the presidential election last week was stolen by the Government.
LEAD: It has survived one of the fiercest, most unpredictable and costly legal battles in history. But Texaco Inc.'s problems are by no means over.
LEAD: In the last six years, 30 llamas have graduated from Helen Bodington's obedience school at the top of a hill in this tiny community near San Francisco.
LEAD: The New York top-40 radio station WPLJ, 95.5 FM, has changed its call letters to WWPR, echoing the radio station's logo ''Power 95.''

LEAD: Three days after completing a 25-year jail sentence, Paraguay's longest-serving political prisoner was freed from his cell in Asuncion today and ordered confined to a provincial town for 30 days.
LEAD: Long before the movie was even released, people were talking about Elaine Stritch's performance in Woody Allen's new film, ''September.''

LEAD: In 1945, I wrote a book, ''The Killing of the Peace.'' It was an account of how opponents of the League of Nations, especially Senator Henry Cabot Lodge and former President Theodore Roosevelt, got the Senate to reject the Versailles treaty, which ended World War I. Both politically opposed and personally detested President Woodrow Wilson.

LEAD: America will import no more sugar in 1988 than it did in 1875. The way things are going, it may soon import none at all. That's splendid for a few thousand protected farmers - but a raw deal for everyone else. Hopes of relief have faded what with Congress adjourning, but the Administration and consumers need to keep up the pressure for a reduced support price.

LEAD: Q.Cold air supposedly constricts the capillaries in the skin. Why, then, do your nose and cheeks turn red on a nippy day? A.Oxygen gives blood its bright red color, said Dr. Barbara Gilchrest, chairman of dermatology at the Boston University School of Medicine. Oxygenated blood flows in arteries from the heart to the capillaries, where it gives up oxygen to cells.

LEAD: James Major scored 20 points and hit two 3-point field goals late in the first half tonight to start a 14-point Seton Hall spurt as the Pirates defeated Holy Cross, 98-76.

LEAD: President Jose Sarney of Brazil today signed into law a computer software bill, but he eliminated provisions that would have set tariffs of up to 200 percent on imported software and imposed criminal penalties for using illegal software.
LEAD: When she was a child, Joyce Golden of Manhattan gave part of her allowance to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. She has been making contributions ever since, for about 40 years.

LEAD: Black officials, civil-rights leaders, clergy and citizens expressed qualified approval of the verdicts in the Howard Beach case yesterday, but renewed their criticism of what they see as a deep undercurrent of racism in the city that sprang to the surface again in that violent incident one year ago.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration plans to compile a Governmentwide list of ''irresponsible'' people whose ''seriously improper conduct'' would make them ineligible to receive Federal grants, scholarships, loans, subsidies and other financial aid.

LEAD: Mike O'Koren, after being released by Washington and spurned by Boston, signed a contract with the Nets yesterday and will rejoin New Jersey for the rest of this season. The 29-year-old O'Koren, who played six seasons in New Jersey, was traded by the Nets to the Washington Bullets in 1986. He appeared in only 15 games for the Bullets before he was waived last
LEAD: DEAR DIARY:

LEAD: ''METROLINE'' is of more than passing interest tonight. Channel 13's weekly series on public affairs looks at private organizations in New York that feed the hungry. In 1982, says Mike Shuster, the series host, only 30 organizations did this; now there are almost 500. The program, ''A Million Meals,'' at 8:30, is a model work.

LEAD: The Florida investor Paul A. Bilzerian gave no word about whether his partnership had obtained the financing it needed for his extended $1.06 billion bid to take over the Singer Company. On Monday, Mr. Bilzerian said he had asked Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and the National Westminster Bank USA for financing commitments by today.
LEAD: Our knee-jerk reaction to pictures of soldiers manhandling demonstrators is to regard the soldiers as brutal and the rioters as heroic. That's not always true.
LEAD: DON'T be ashamed; we all do it. Put off holiday shopping as long as possible, that is.
LEAD: FOR decades environmental engineers cleaned up toxic waste in one way: by enclosing and burying it, either in landfills or at the site.

LEAD: France's arms dealings with Iran, which began in 1983 under President Francois Mitterrand, continued as late as this summer under his political rival, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, French newspapers reported today.

LEAD: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe, left, and the opposition leader Joshua Nkomo congratulating one another after signing a ''unity agreement'' yesterday in Harare pledging to merge their parties. Page A3. (Agence France-Presse)

LEAD: Well, friends, neighbors, kin and just plain folks, it looks like it's that time of year again: short days, endless nights, and the slap, slap, slap of plastic on countertops. Time to send out our annual report on what a great year it's been at our house.

LEAD: Eli Lilly & Company completed the previously announced $700 million sale of its Elizabeth Arden Inc. cosmetics subsidiary to Faberge Inc. and announced that its board had approved a plan to repurchase up to $1 billion worth of common stock.

LEAD: After days of quiet and unsuccessful diplomatic appeals to Israeli leaders, the Reagan Administration today issued an unusual public criticism of the ''harsh security measures and excessive use of live ammunition'' by Israeli troops who have been confronting Palestinian demonstrators.
LEAD: ''We began the dawn on a good note, a note of compromise.

LEAD: Jack Powers, the director of athletics at Manhattan College, said yesterday that the school's basketball coach used poor judgment Monday night when he took his team off the court to protest the officiating.
LEAD: Congress, struggling to adjourn for the year, early today approved and sent to President Reagan the first major housing bill in seven years.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday in a holiday message that it was inappropriate to extend Christmas and Hanukkah greetings while the Middle East was ravaged by violence and the Israelis were occupying Arab territory.

LEAD: TO a New Yorker, Bostonian or Philadelphian, seltzer is salt-free carbonated water: club soda without the salt. To a Californian, seltzer is salt-free carbonated water or flavored salt-free carbonated water or sweetened and flavored salt-free carbonated water.

LEAD: TOWARD the end of ''Dynamite Tonight,'' a cabaret-style operetta set in a war-ravaged bunker, a woman bearing word of a cease-fire is shot, to which one soldier sings, ''If peace was declared, killing a girl was not the thing to do.''

LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company and the Matsushita Group of Japan have agreed to create a jointly managed battery factory in the United States. Kodak already sells alkaline batteries made by Matsushita. The new plant, which is scheduled to be built in 1988, would make batteries for both Kodak and the Matshushita Electric Corporation of America, a Kodak spokesman, Henry Kaska, said.
LEAD: Orders to United States manufacturers for durable goods edged up slightly in November, the Government said today.
LEAD: Two weeks of violent Palestinian protests have shaken many Israelis but have had little effect on the domestic political lineup.

LEAD: A special committee of the Delaware Bar Association last night approved, as expected, new rules giving companies incorporated there more protection against takeovers. The rules could have a major impact since many leading companies are incorporated in Delaware.
LEAD: The four leading presidential candidates called on foreign governments today to rule out intervention in Haiti but asked them to help force the military-dominated Government to resign.

LEAD: The authorities here said all five members of a family were killed early today when a lighted Christmas tree was ignited by an electrical short, destroying their home. The Eatonton Police Chief, Kent Lawrence, identified the victims as Floyd Paynter, 30 years old, his wife, Pamela Sue, 24, and their children, Shawn, 5, Brandon, 3, and Kristen, 1.
LEAD: John Lucas scored a season-high 25 points, and Randy Breuer added 24 tonight, leading the Milwaukee Bucks to a 122-105 victory over the Knicks.

LEAD: IT is true, as has often been observed, that a terrine is nothing more than a meat loaf with a French accent. But it is equally true that one of the most welcome presentations on the holiday table could be a well-made terrine maison, a savory mixture of rough-textured chopped pork, pork fat and liver that has been flavored with warm aromatics like cinnamon and allspice.
LEAD: Zimbabwe's main opposition group agreed today to merge with Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's ruling party in a move that is expected to reduce the country's ethnic divisions and rebel violence.
LEAD: A lot of agencies would like to be in the shoes of HBM/Creamer of Boston, because those shoes are Kinney's and Kinney will be spending at least $12 million to advertise them.

LEAD: Even procrastinators can now send ''photocards'' -photographs with holiday messages printed on them -which undoubtedly explains why so many people seem to be doing it this year.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday named Lawrence Iason, a New York lawyer, as administrator for its key New York regional office, ending a temporary situation in which two S.E.C. officials from Washington ran the office.
LEAD: The 74-year-old host of West Germany's longest-running television talk show resigned today, a week after a magazine reopened his past as a Nazi journalist.

LEAD: With the unrest in Israel over Palestinian protests and a general strike joined by hundreds of thousands, the State Department sought Monday to offer assistance to Americans planning to go there over the holidays.
LEAD: After decades as a major player in the tire business, the B. F. Goodrich Company said yesterday that it was getting out.

LEAD: A former state senator who disappeared two years ago after a staged scuba-diving death off Grand Bahama Island has been seized on the island of Male in the Indian Ocean, Federal authorities said today.
LEAD: With the United States abstaining, the Security Council adopted a resolution today strongly deploring Israel's handling of the disturbances in the occupied territories.

LEAD: Negotiations over the new Columbus Circle project failed to meet a deadline of Monday at midnight, went past a second deadline of early last night and are now facing yet a third deadline of tomorrow at 2 P.M.

LEAD: In a sign of the decline in the securities industry this year, John H. Gutfreund, the chairman and chief executive of Salomon Inc., will take a $2 million pay cut for 1987, he has told executives at the Wall Street firm.

LEAD: Rosetta Buggs, the granddaughter of a black Jewish slave, embracing Johanna Ross after the lighting of the final candle on the Hanukkah menorah at the Helen R. Scheur residence for the eld-erly in Flushing, Queens. The festival, which began at sundown last Tuesday and ends at sundown today, was celebrated by prayer, singing and dancing by the residents of the center.

LEAD: Halfway around the world from their American campuses, professors from several United States universities are trying to re-create the essence of American college life, from Coke machines to computers.

LEAD: Scientists have discovered the specific muscle defect that causes Duchenne muscular dystrophy, the most common and one of the most devastating of all inherited muscle diseases.

LEAD: Between 400 and 500 etchings and lithographs have been stolen from the Upper West Side studio of the late Raphael Soyer, according to the police and art experts.

LEAD: Lawyers for most of the seven defendants in the second trial in the Howard Beach case will move to have charges against their clients dismissed on the basis of the verdict Monday night in the first trial, several of the lawyers said yesterday.
LEAD: A committee studying problems in Georgia's virtually all-white Forsyth County divided sharply along racial lines today on the issues that led to two violent confrontations last January.

LEAD: A juror in the Howard Beach trial said yesterday that the jurors, in emotional proceedings, discounted the testimony of the prosecution's key witness but found the testimony of other prosecution witnesses compelling enough to convict three of the defendants of manslaughter.

LEAD: Muscovites who came to the Luzhniki Arena in recent days expecting to savor the power and perfection of the Soviet hockey team returned home wondering if they had instead witnessed the demise of a dynasty.
LEAD: An international team of scientists has discovered what appears to be a single gene that determines whether a human embryo will grow into a male or a female.

LEAD: A recent report by the National School Boards Association in Alexandria, Va., says a lack of progress in integrating technology into the nation's public schools puts most students at risk of remaining technologically backward while a privileged few gain from high-technology education. LEAD: A special prosecutor announced today that he had no current plans to prosecute Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d as a result of an investigation of the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor.
LEAD: Four apparent gunshots were heard in the cockpit of Pacific Southwest Airlines Flight 1771 before it crashed on Dec. 7, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

LEAD: Animal rights advocates have been active in the Washington area over the last several years. Some of them even went so far as to steal 11 cats last August from a Department of Agriculture research center where they were being used to study cellular parasites.

LEAD: Mikhail Vasiljev scored on a breakaway with less than three minutes left in the third period tonight to give the Soviet Union Select team a 3-3 tie against the United States Olympic team in the finale of their eight-game exhibition series.

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote early today by which the House approved, 209 to 208, a compromise $600 billion spending bill to keep the Government running through the rest of fiscal year 1988, which began Oct. 1. A ''yes'' vote is to approve the bill; xxx denotes those not voting. Voting ''yes'' were 116 Democrats and 93 Republicans.

LEAD: It's all over but a little counting. Come Friday, people here will observe Noel's 100th Christmas, and a few days later, with a New Year's Eve celebration at the Community Center, they will close Noel's centennial, the 100th year of being the Christmas City of Missouri.
LEAD: Michael Pirone, 18 years old, stood next to a sleeping cat on the steps of his family's house in Howard Beach, Queens, yesterday and said he felt like he had just lost a year of his life.
LEAD: Smoking on the Long Island Rail Road may soon be a thing of the past.

LEAD: AT Palmer Station, the American base on the Antarctic Peninsula, Christmas came a few days early last year. As Nancy Pellerin, a research technologist in microbiology, recalled, she and 34 other scientists performing research at the station were awaiting a supply ship, due around Christmas Day.

LEAD: THE popularity of the ''point and shoot'' 35-millimeter camera has significantly affected the photography business in recent years. The automatic cameras - like the Canon Sure Shot, Minolta Freedom and Nikon One-Touch - make it easy for a beginner to take good photographs, buoying interest in conventional still photography and revitalizing the industry.
LEAD: Stock prices gave ground yesterday as profit taking and nervousness about developments in the Middle East were blamed for the trades.
LEAD: Nebraska's primary does not come until May 10, but campaign money is already being spent here, to help Presidential candidates in neighboring Iowa where caucuses will be held Feb. 8.

LEAD: A Brooklyn judge was cleared yesterday of an allegation that he humiliated a complainant by ordering her to re-enact a rape. At the same time, the state's Chief Administrative Judge recommended that the Brooklyn District Attorney be investigated for making the allegation.

LEAD: As a Christmas gift, Maria DeJuan's boyfriend asked for the new Belinda Carlisle record, ''Heaven on Earth.'' He's in for a surprise. He is getting a cassette of the top 10 single. But it is not Ms. Carlisle's version. The soft pop accompaniment may sound the same, but the singer is Ms. DeJuan. The picture on the slick package?

LEAD: Federal prosecutors say there will be no more arrests of county supervisors on corruption charges in Mississippi until after Christmas, because the 50 charged so far have left them snowed under with work.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Two reputed leaders in the Gambino organized-crime family, including the man described as the group's new underboss, were convicted last night of taking part in a racketeering conspiracy and of other Federal charges.

LEAD: Environmental, consumer and public health groups joined the United Farm Workers today in urging support for the union's boycott of table grapes sprayed with pesticides.

LEAD: SILAS L. GRIFFITH, a 19th-century lumber baron, gave much to the town of Danby, including the municipal water system, the public library, the orphans' fund and money for the beautification of the Congregational church. But of all the gifts Mr. Griffith gave, none is so cherished as his Christmas tree.

LEAD: The Navy brass owe the Marines and the country an explanation. After almost three months of grilling and polygraphing the one suspect it knew to be guilty, the Naval Investigative Service apparently is satisfied that Marine security guards at the U.S. Embassy in Moscow didn't give away the store to Soviet spies.
LEAD: RESTAURATEURS say that it might cost you almost as much not to dine out New Year's Eve as it will to honor your reservations.

LEAD: IN his lifetime, Bil Baird practiced creative puppetry in his Barrow Street marionette theater and also through his work on Broadway, in films and on television. Affirming his father's legacy, the puppeteer's son, Peter B. Baird, has returned to New York with a revival of one of the family's favorites, ''Davy Jones's Locker.
LEAD: Gretchen Uppercu Hill died of a stroke Monday in Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

LEAD: The musical ''Chess'' will open on Broadway in late April or May -earlier than previously anticipated and without an out-of-town tryout, according to Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, which is a co-producer of the show .

LEAD: A markedly altered image of Stephen Crane that changes the familiar view of him as a dashing war correspondent is to appear next year in a new edition of his correspondence. The work adds 170 newly discovered letters by Crane and 20 by his wife, Cora, to the standard edition of his letters that came out three decades ago.

LEAD: JAPAN is starting to rejuggle its economy in an effort to attain faster domestic growth and slower external growth. Prime Minister Noburo Takeshita and his Cabinet accepted a plan yesterday, prepared by the Economic Planning Agency, for transforming the country from a supercompetitive export machine to a more balanced and affluent society ready to play a larger role in stabilizing the world economy.

LEAD: NEW WOMAN magazine, doing well in circulation and advertising, will begin its first TV advertising campaign tomorrow, and it should benefit both those profit centers. The agency is Wyse Advertising, whose president, Lois Wyse, is a bit of a new woman herself.

LEAD: The Rev. Allan Boesak of South Africa, a leading opponent of apartheid, has established a tradition of preaching a sermon at Christmas time at Bethel Baptist Church in central Washington. The pastor of the church is Walter E. Fauntroy, the nonvoting Congressman from the District of Columbia.

LEAD: ONE could understand the advantages of sharing a season when the Nikolais Dance Theater and the Murray Louis Dance Company once again appeared together on Monday night as part of the companies' engagement at the Joyce Theater. The well-balanced program contained two pieces by Alwin Nikolais and two by Murray Louis.

LEAD: Following is the statement from the New York State Chief Administrative Judge, Albert M. Rosenblatt, on the investigation of the charges against Judge Irving W. Levine.
LEAD: The mile or two that separate the glittering hotels of Manila from the garbage-strewn North Harbor docks of the Sulpicio Shipping Lines measure the distance between two Filipino nations.
LEAD: An independent panel appointed by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it had found no evidence that the futures markets accelerated the stock market's huge plunge on Oct. 19.

LEAD: The New York-based Citibank and Japan's Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank said they would link their automatic teller machine systems beginning in January, allowing customers to use the automatic tellers of both banks. Citibank is the largest commercial bank in the United States, while Dai-Ichi Kangyo is the largest in the world in terms of assets.

LEAD: MY most enduring and exalted memory of Christmas is an odd one, tied to neither home nor family. It is the memory of singing in the elementary school Christmas concert each year. We were rehearsed mercilessly from Halloween on, our consonants honed to a cutting edge, our tight little mouths coaxed into generous ovals.
LEAD: The United States and its principal economic allies said today that they had agreed to ''cooperate closely'' on averting further ''excessive'' changes in the dollar's value.

LEAD: Robert W. Blankshine, an American dancer and teacher and a former featured member of the Joffrey Ballet, died of a heart attack Sunday at a friend's home in New York City, according to his mother, Serene Blankshine. He was 42 years old.

LEAD: Interest rates fell yesterday for the first time in more than a month at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 7.4395 percent, down from 7.9691 percent the previous week.

LEAD: Buried in the spending bill that became law today are sanctions expected to deprive Japanese companies of several hundred million dollars a year of business in the United States.

LEAD: The Westchester County Board of Legislators today approved an $846.9 million budget for next year, after trimming $3.4 million from the spending plan that County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke had presented.

LEAD: Hold the Salad Recent prices for commonplace lettuce varieties like iceberg and romaine seem more suited for imported endive. Bad weather in southern California and Arizona beginning in October has caused the prices for common lettuces to rise to $2 a head or more in many stores.

LEAD: Andrea Hart, daughter of Gary Hart, who is back in the running for the Democratic Presidential nomination, using a stack of phone books as a desk at headquarters in Denver. Furniture and other office accouterments are expected to be in place next week for the renewed campaign. (AP)

LEAD: In one wrenching year, the Howard Beach case dramatized the vulnerability of black New Yorkers, divided the city and, finally, achieved a result that already seems to have restored a measure of faith in the criminal-justice system for many black people.

LEAD: ARCO, moving quickly to increase its stake in Britoil P.L.C., which is also the target of a takeover bid by the British Petroleum Company, said today that it had raised its stake in Britoil to 19.25 percent. On Friday, it held 14.7 percent.
LEAD: Peace talks between the Nicaraguan Government and the rebels were suspended indefinitely today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A smoker feels harassed when asked to put out a cigarette. But nonsmokers feel harassed, and subjected to health risk, by having to breathe in the smoker's smoke. How, then, to keep both happy? By making it very clear where smoking will and will not be allowed.

LEAD: Casper Yost Offutt, a former diplomat who served in Chile and Panama, died Sunday. He was 93 years old. From 1917 to 1919, Mr. Offutt was second secretary of the United States Embassy in Chile and first secretary and charge d'affaires in Panama.
LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service announced today that it would not penalize Americans who had too little withheld from their paychecks this year.

LEAD: IT has been more than 60 years since the ornate department stores just south of 23d Street on what was then Sixth Avenue closed for good as the department store owners followed the retail migration uptown.
LEAD: President-elect Roh Tae Woo said today that he would give up the presidency if he lost a public vote of confidence that he has pledged to seek after the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul.

LEAD: With his spectacular knockout of Edwin Rosario for the World Boxing Association lightweight title last month, Julio Cesar Chavez has emerged as a future star attraction. But just how Chavez will cash in on his new prominence remains to be seen.

LEAD: An unexpected surge in oil prices eroded bond prices yesterday, causing intermediate and longer-term interest rates to rise. The rebound in oil prices also stirred some fears of an increase in inflation next year.
LEAD: A Federal judge in New York gave 55 retailers an early Christmas present yesterday, listing them as the classiest stores in the country.
LEAD: Larry Bird scored 9 of his 31 points in the final 5 minutes as the Celtics defeated the 76ers, 118-115, tonight, Boston's first victory in Philadelphia in two years.

LEAD: Proponents of legislation to require television and radio stations to broadcast varying views on controversial matters pledged today to push for the measure next year, after Congress deleted it from the spending bill early this morning.
LEAD: Arnold Bernhard, the founder and chief executive officer of Value Line Inc., the world's largest investment advisory service, died yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.

LEAD: A civil suit filed today contends that Andrew Cuomo, the son of Governor Cuomo of New York, and a group of business associates violated Federal regulations in an attempt to take over two southern Florida savings institutions and drain their assests.

LEAD: Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Inc. said it had called off its $620 million buyout of Argonaut Group Inc. because the Los Angeles-based life insurer had refused to agree to two changes proposed by Gibbons, Green.

LEAD: Raoul D. Edwards, the editor of United States Banker magazine since 1983, died of a heart attack Thursday after a staff meeting at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y. He was 59 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.
LEAD: One of America's most respected veteran players, 87-year-old Simon Becker, died Dec. 12 after an auto accident in Philadelphia, where he lived.

LEAD: Penn State officials said they would wait until the last minute to decide whether Blair Thomas, the junior tailback who was the team's leading rusher and scorer this season, will be fit to play in the Citrus Bowl New Year's Day.
LEAD: President Reagan today signed a catch-all spending measure and a bill to hold down the Federal deficit, allowing a battle-weary Congress to call it quits at last for 1987.
LEAD: Worlds of Wonder Inc., the toy maker that only last year set a record as one of the fastest-growing companies in history, has filed for protection under the bankruptcy laws.

LEAD: THE world's largest Champagne bottle, called a sovereign, will be used Jan. 15 in Miami by Rosalynn Carter, the former First Lady, to christen the Sovereign of the Seas. The vessel will carry 2,690 passengers, more than any other passenger ship ever built.
LEAD: David Dworkin is moving from one big-name retail chain to another -from the presidency of Neiman-Marcus in Dallas to a similar post with Bonwit Teller in New York.
LEAD: Andrew McBain and Gilles Hamel each scored twice, and Dave Ellett had three assists as the Winnipeg Jets beat the Islanders, 5-2, tonight.

LEAD: ''THE Lonely Passion of Judith Hearne'' is a solemn film about a spinster whose only excess is the wearing of mildly flamboyant bonnets, a woman who declares ''It's only me!'' when she enters a room and who asks for ''just a soupcon of milk'' with her tea.

LEAD: A recent financial disclosure form submitted by Frank C. Carlucci, President Reagan's new Secretary of Defense, raises a question about some of Washington's top bureaucrats that, on the surface, seems baffling.
LEAD: Reports of OPEC production cutbacks and of military actions in the Persian Gulf, as well as technical factors, contributed to a sharp jump in oil prices yesterday, analysts said.
LEAD: John Shiel, an electrical engineer and historian, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Glen Head, L.I. He was 87 years old.

LEAD: Four Soviet-made WAZ jeeps pulled out of Lubango's airport, ferrying visiting United Nations military observers to a hotel.

LEAD: The Nippondenso Company, a Japanese manufacturer of automotive components, will build a $200 million plant that will make starters and alternators in this East Tennessee city. LEAD: It used to be that if what students had to say about their professors was unprintable, it remained that way. No longer.

LEAD: Although the Giants this season fell deeper in the standing than any other Super Bowl defender ever had, it will not take a lot to make the team right again.

LEAD: The Yankees were prepared to announce a three-year, $4.3 million agreement with Dave Righetti yesterday, but they postponed the news until today because they came up with another announcement. This one was a five-player trade that sent Steve Trout and Henry Cotto to Seattle for Lee Guetterman, a left-handed pitcher, and two minor-league pitchers.

LEAD: The MLX Corporation, a distributor of cooling equipment based in Troy, Mich., said the agreement it had reached in September to acquire Pace Industries, the New York-based parent company of the Rheem Manufacturing Company, which makes heating and cooling equipment, had been terminated by Pace. MLX had earlier announced that its lender had not been able to provide it with the subordinated debt that it needed to finance the $825 million deal.

LEAD: Hundreds of civil-rights demonstrators, most of them black, transformed the vast, columned lobby of the Brooklyn Criminal Courthouse into a tumultuous speakers' forum yesterday, shouting support for 69 people arrested in a coordinated series of rush-hour protests against racism Monday night.
LEAD: Shoppers and others on Fifth Avenue yesterday paused to listen to a choir from Daytop Village singing Christmas carols on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral. (NYT/Jim Wilson)

LEAD: As Stan Lundine flew north into the Adirondacks recently, he knew he was returning to friendly territory, a place where he could feel safe without bodyguards.

LEAD: * Berkey Inc., Greenwich, Conn., a diversified photographic equipment concern, said it had sold certain assets of its Berkey Marketing Cos. division and would be negotiating the disposition of several product lines.

LEAD: Highlighting its intention to stake a claim at the leading edge of computer technology, the International Business Machines Corporation today announced plans for an ambitious joint development project with a tiny, three-month-old company led by one of the world's leading supercomputer scientists.

LEAD: The patterns are becoming so patented as to lack even the semblance of drama. For the second straight game and the third time in their last eight, the Rangers gained an early lead and then forsook it, folding before the Philadelphia Flyers, 6-4, at Madison Square Garden last night. For the third consecutive game, they outshot their opponent in prodigious fashion (34-23 this time), but lost.

LEAD: It takes a special sort of guy with a special sort of dedication - or greed - to desert Tampa, Fla., for Rochester as the winter begins to bare its icy talons. Just that sort of man is Edmond C. Froehlich, 41 years old, who has left behind Young & Rubicam/ Zemp, where he was president and chief executive, to join Blair Advertising, one of the Omnicom Group, as president and chief operating officer.

LEAD: I HAVE always been interested by the natural liaisons of foods whose flavors complete each other like well-made harmonies. Some of the most obvious that come to mind are port and Roquefort cheese; a genuine Sauternes and fresh foie gras, and roast lamb with flageolets.

LEAD: Joseph A. Kanon, formerly president and publisher of E. P. Dutton Inc., will become director of the Houghton Mifflin Company's trade and reference division on Jan. 1. He succeeds Austin G. Olney, who will remain a member of the board through next April.

LEAD: The measures enacted by Congress in the year-end rush to adjourn contain a wide range of provisions affecting American policy in South Africa, Central America and the Middle East, as well as the operations of the State Department.
LEAD: A Federal judge today approved a plan to reorganize the PTL that allows the troubled television ministry to retain tax-exempt status.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Governor Cuomo summoned Charles J. Hynes to the State Capitol today to praise his successful prosecution of the Howard Beach case, saying that Mr. Hynes's work proved there was no need to create a new special prosecutor's post for handling race-related cases.
LEAD: New York City's housing agency is seeking to demolish a century-old Brooklyn apartment building that is under the protection of the City Landmarks Preservation Commission.
LEAD: Scott Secules ran for one touchdown and passed for another as Virginia, in a rare postseason appearance, defeated Brigham Young, 22-16, tonight in the All-American Bowl.
LEAD: To The Home Section:
LEAD: The Federal Government plans to build two office buildings in the Foley Square area of Manhattan to ease congestion in the United States Court House and other Government buildings nearby.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The Administration sharply lowered its growth forecast for next year but predicted that 1988 would become the sixth consecutive year without a recession. It estimated that the G.N.P. would rise by 2.4 percent after adjusting for inflation - more than a full percentage point lower than the 3.5 percent projection for next year that it made in August.
LEAD: Hob Broun, a writer, died of asphyxiation Dec. 16 when his respirator broke down in his home in Portland, Ore. He was 37 years old.

LEAD: Robert Paige, an Emmy Award-winning actor who starred in such movies as ''Bye Bye Birdie'' with Janet Leigh and ''Can't Help Singing'' with Deanna Durbin, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack. The Orange County Coroner's office listed his age as 76, but biographies put his age at 77.

LEAD: The view from Rose Malakeng's balcony, across Wanderers Street to the railroad station, is not the stuff of which postcards are made. But it is special to Mrs. Malakeng, who has the kind of home that many blacks in South Africa have hankered after for a lifetime.

LEAD: THERE will always be those for whom the Christmas and New Year season is synonymous with city lights. For them, there is joy in hustle, bustle and bundles. For them, a tinseled tree in an apartment-house lobby, alongside a taped-up poster of Kermit the frog in a Santa outfit, is holiday enough.

LEAD: WHILE gold has always been a mark of opulence in traditional interiors -18th-century palaces and late 19th-century parlors were not shy about flaunting gilded accoutrements - gold has been out of fashion in contemporary interiors for decades.

LEAD: Shirley Peters's holiday spirit was put to the test yesterday under a battered umbrella that provided only slight protection against the snow as she did some last-minute shopping in Denver. (AP)

LEAD: Q. Some years ago during a water shortage I reduced water used by my flush toilets by twisting the bowl refill tube to one side so that instead of directing water through the overflow tube and into the bowl it sent the water into the tank. I have operated two toilets this way for years with no noticeable decrease in flushing efficiency.

Pritzker, the financier who controls Braniff Airways Inc., in his unsuccessful bid to purchase the airline.

LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering three- and six-month bonds totaling $2.38 billion through various securities dealers.

LEAD: The J. C. Penney Company expects to complete its move from New York by July 1, several months ahead of schedule. The retailing company's chairman, William Howell, said on Tuesday that he expected about 60 percent of Penney's 2,200 top managers and a smaller percentage of the 1,600 New York-based non-managers to move in the headquarters shift to the Dallas suburb of Plano.

LEAD: Harry Carson made National Football League history today when he was voted a Pro Bowl linebacker for the ninth time. Lawrence Taylor made history of sorts when he failed to be named a Pro Bowl starter, although he did make the team.
LEAD: Disguising a word by spelling it backwards is an old conception. In ''Erewhon,'' more than a century ago, Samuel Butler did not quite succeed in palindroming ''nowhere.''
LEAD: A former Federal prosecutor will continue to supervise the operation of Umberto's Clam House under a court order issued yesterday in Manhattan.
LEAD: Gary Pallack, a clothing manufacturer, died of a heart attack Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Senator Claiborne Pell, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, has agreed to be the pioneer in trying out a state-of-the-art hearing room that was recently completed in the Hart Senate Office Building.

LEAD: Until recently, Dr. Edward Scott Valentine of Manhattan had assumed that taxes took care of the poor people. ''The increasing numbers of homeless and destitute that I see every day on the streets indicate how thoughtless I have been,'' Dr. Valentine wrote.

LEAD: Chicago has surrendered its public housing projects to heavily armed street gangs. Their bloody encounters terrorize the dilapidated high-rise communities that are home to thousands of poor families. Children are particularly at risk. Some, even while in grade school, are dragooned by the gangs for training in drug dealing.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: President Reagan has signed legislation that will prevent immigration officials from barring foreigners because of their political beliefs for at least the next 14 months.

LEAD: Secrecy in government has a thousand fathers: a thousand excuses. But Frank Carlucci, the new Secretary of Defense, came up with a particular gem last week. LEAD: After three months as the new standard in measuring who watches what on television, the ''people-meter'' ratings device seems to be a network nightmare coming true.
LEAD: The chairman of the governing United National Party and three of his aides were killed by gunmen today, the authorities said. Ethnic Sinhalese extremists were blamed for the attack.
LEAD: The Department of Transportation has put into use a computerized system that will permit airline passengers to select a flight on the basis of on-time performance.

LEAD: AS the last and one of the best known of Elsie de Wolfe's proteges, Tony Duquette is often asked to describe his mentor. What would Mrs. de Wolfe think of such and such? Which of her talents were the greatest? What was it like when she walked into a room? What was her darkest secret?

LEAD: Bond prices rebounded yesterday after finance ministers of seven major industrialized Western countries stated that they opposed further declines in the dollar's value.

LEAD: Lakeside Pharmaceuticals is switching advertising responsibility for its Nicorette gum to Gross Townsend Frank Hoffman, from Medicus Consumer. The chewing gum, sold by prescription only, contains nicotine that is said to help people break the smoking habit.

LEAD: After years of effort, the New York City Council yesterday overwhelmingly approved the city's first comprehensive anti-smoking bill. It would restrict smoking in places of business and most enclosed public places, including stores, restaurants, schools, indoor sports arenas and taxicabs.

LEAD: Paul E. Levine, a partner in a Manhattan law firm, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Manhattan. He was 38 years old.

LEAD: The marriage of Deborah Kaback, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kaback of New York, to Alvin H. Korn, the son of Ann Korn of New York and the late David Korn, took place yesterday at the bride's home in New York. Rabbi Gordon Tucker officiated.
LEAD: Charles Barkley sat on the training table, bags of ice on each knee, as he answered reporters' questions. Despite a slow start, he took care to have the last word.

LEAD: Shares of the Phillips Petroleum Company, which eluded separate takeover attempts three years ago by T. Boone Pickens and by Carl C. Icahn rose sharply today on rumors that a new hostile bid may be pending.

LEAD: Patrick Ewing's driving basket past Dave Corzine with 15 seconds remaining last night provided the Knicks with a 90-89 victory over the Chicago Bulls at Madison Square Garden. Ewing was fouled on the play by Corzine, but he missed the free throw.

LEAD: Jurgen Hingsen of West Germany, who was a silver medalist at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics in the decathalon, is under investigation for suspected purchases of cocaine, a prosecutor in Essen, West Germany, said yesterday. The prosecutor, Hermann Kerl, said an investigation was opened against Hingsen and Rolf Milser, an Olympic weight lifting champion.

LEAD: Counting the Pages Now that President Reagan has signed the two huge bills that Congress passed in the final hours of the 1987 session, Government officials are holding their breath, hoping there will not be a repetition of last year's debacle.

LEAD: Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme, who is serving a life sentence for the attempted assassination of President Ford in 1975, was reported missing last night from the Alderson Federal Prison for Women in West Virginia, the authorities said early today.
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a rollcall listing yesterday on the Senate's vote on a $600 billion spending bill misidentified Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee. He is a Democrat.

''This is an extremely unfortunate situation,'' Mike Storen, the C.B.A.

LEAD: The dollar firmed slightly yesterday in very light trading, as dealers shrugged off the latest affirmation by the United States and its trading partners that they would seek to check a further decline in its value.

LEAD: Gaston Green, the U.C.L.A. tailback, will be unable to play in the Aloha Bowl against Florida Friday because of a pulled thigh muscle.

Most modern power tools are surprisingly light and easy to handle, thanks to new technologies and to tool manufacturers' strong interest in satisfying the needs of amateurs. If you don't own any power tools, or are confused by the variations available, here are some basic choices to consider.

LEAD: America's space agency keeps looking at the heavens through bizarre bifocals. At a time when the paramount need is to reduce the Federal deficit, NASA's top goal is to build a $32 billion space station that has no clear purpose. Congress knows that, yet is willing only to cut in half NASA's request for $770 million in start-up funds.

LEAD: School Basketball St. Anthony's Holds On in Honolulu: Bob Hurley Jr. scored 29 points, including four free throws in the final 11 seconds as St. Anthony's of Jersey City held on to defeat St. Nicholas of Tolentine, 62-58, in the championship game of the McDonald's-Iolani Prep Classic Tuesday night in Honolulu.

LEAD: Angelo and Alice Cangialosi with their quintuplets yesterday at Long Island Jewish Medical Center before the babies, who were born Oct. 15, were released. From the left are Angelo, Nicholas, Ellen, Allison and Jennifer. Mrs. Cangialosi had been taking a fertility drug. (NYT/Sara Krulwich)

LEAD: The first 25 homeless families moved this week into an imaginative prefabricated housing project in Brooklyn called Help I. If it succeeds and can be replicated elsewhere in the region, then helped, too, will be Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's 30-year-old son, who conceived the project nearly two years ago and had the gumption to get it built.

LEAD: Directors of the Tribune Company, trying to make the diversified publishing and broadcasting conglomerate a less attractive takeover target, have approved a more bitter ''poison pill'' contingency plan.
LEAD: An Iranian vessel attacked a loaded Norwegian tanker in the southern Persian Gulf shortly before midnight tonight, starting a fire aboard, maritime executives reported.

LEAD: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks fell 11.7 percent in the second 10 days of December from the comparable period a year ago, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.
