LEAD: Beginning next June, the armed forces will be required under a new law to test all recruits for drug abuse before they enter the service.

LEAD: On winter nights 119th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues looks much like a turn-of-the-century photograph, with its low buildings and brownstone facades. Bathed in the amber of the street lamps, the street is sepia-toned, serene. The doorway of one of the grander homes is draped with wreaths and the tiny white lights that mark the holiday season.
LEAD: Max Blank, a junior center, scored a career-high 27 points as George Washington defeated Rutgers, 72-46, tonight in an Atlantic 10 Conference game.

LEAD: Claus von Bulow, the Danish-born aristocrat who was convicted and then, in a retrial, acquitted of twice trying to murder his wife with insulin injections, confirmed yesterday that he has agreed to renounce all claims to his wife's fortune, to divorce her and to leave the country.
LEAD: Kelly Tripucka came off the bench, scoring 13 of his 15 points in the final 5 minutes 33 seconds, to lead the Utah Jazz to a 91-83 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

LEAD: THE role of the Sugar Plum Fairy in ''The Nutcracker'' is a peculiar one. The part, a focal point of the ballet, is usually danced by a ballerina of artistic stature, but she appears for a very short time on the stage and then only at the end in the ballet's culminating pas de deux. Almost everything in the fairy-tale ballet - Christmas parties, warring mice and toy soldiers and dancing sweets and snowflakes - upstages those final moments of pure classicism.

LEAD: Facing a Thursday deadline to accept a $95 million takeover bid from a New York investor group, the Holly Sugar Corporation said today that it had received a rival offer from the Imperial Sugar Company.

LEAD: If Mohsen Moharerzadeh, a 26-year-old Iranian photographer, had secretly waded across the Rio Grande into the United States, he would probably be free, working here and pursuing an application for political asylum.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In a highly unusual move, a Federal judge yesterday offered to release Joseph Armone, the reputed underboss of the Gambino crime family, on $1 million bond pending his sentencing if he publicly renounced any connection he might have had with the organization and resigned any position he might hold.

LEAD: An article in some editions yesterday about indictments involving the Wedtech Corporation misstated the activity of W. Franklyn Chinn, one of those indicted. Mr. Chinn managed investments for Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, but there is no evidence the investments included Wedtech.

LEAD: Despite the split among Roman Catholic bishops in the United States over their recent statement on AIDS education and the use of condoms, officials at four major Catholic colleges say they welcome the statement as an endorsement of their AIDS policies.

LEAD: A Roman Catholic nun, above, comforting relative of victim killed Sunday when a passenger liner collided with an oil tanker off Mindoro Island, killing at least 1,600 people. At left, Filipinos removing bodies of passengers from the ocean yesterday. Reports that a 4-year-old boy had been found alive Tuesday were called erroneous by officials yesterday.

LEAD: At Checkpoint Charlie, the border crossing in West Berlin, a small museum honors the courage and ingenuity of the many refugees from Communism who have tunneled, flown, swum or sneaked to freedom from behind what the West used to call the Iron Curtain.
LEAD: Engineers at a snowy, remote Utah site today successfully conducted the second full-scale test firing of the redesigned rocket booster for the space shuttle.

LEAD: BACH'S ''Christmas Oratorio,'' all six cantatas of it, was performed with lightness, precision and some virtuosity Tuesday evening in Alice Tully Hall by the 26-voice choir and 39-member orchestra (modern instruments) of Thomas Wikman's Music of the Baroque ensemble from Chicago.

LEAD: Manute Bol, the Washington Bullet center, said that Kevin Mackey, the Cleveland State basketball coach, never did him any favors. The National Collegiate Athletic Association last week charged the Cleveland State basketball program with recruiting violations, primarily concerning Bol, and placed the program on three years' probation.

LEAD: That uproar between Alexander M. Haig Jr. and the United States Marines over a joke that the Republican Presidential contender made at the expense of The Few and The Proud is not over yet, despite his insistence that the joke be treated as a joke.

LEAD: Dave Poulin scored two goals tonight as the Flyers extended their unbeaten streak to 13 games by defeating the Minnesota North Stars, 5-3. Philadelphia also moved past the Islanders into first place in the Patrick Division.
LEAD: The State Department urged Israeli leaders again today to adopt nonlethal techniques to control rioting in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

LEAD: The implications of Dave Righetti's three-year, $4.3 million deal with the Yankees are potentially so far reaching that General Manager Lou Piniella didn't think he could make the official announcement yesterday without making sure he added a quick disclaimer.

LEAD: FROM the 17th to the 19th centuries, the Latin American regions that are now Argentina, Bolivia and Peru produced a treasury of silver objects. A selection is currently on view at a show called ''Southern Splendor'' at the Americas Society, Park Avenue at 68th Street.

LEAD: A judge today ordered the Georgia Bar to halt disciplinary proceedings against the State Attorney General on charges that he violated an ethics code by suing a state agency over a closed meeting.
LEAD: In reassuming the positions of president and chief executive, Fred M. Gibbons, the co-founder of the Software Publishing Corporation, said he hoped to lead the company through two transitions.
LEAD: A pediatrician whose practice collapsed after he filed a lawsuit that revealed he had tested positive for the AIDS virus has agreed to settle the suit against his former roommate.

LEAD: Now that President Reagan has signed the two huge bills that Congress passed in the final hours of the 1987 session, Government officials are holding their breath, hoping there will not be a repetition of last year's debacle.

LEAD: A broad group of nations is ready to contribute about $8 billion to a new fund to aid the poorest and most indebted developing countries, mainly in sub-Saharan Africa, according to involved officials.

LEAD: Soviet and Government troops have killed or wounded more than 1,500 Afghan guerrillas in the first two days of a drive to lift the siege of Khost, a major garrison city southeast of Kabul, the Kremlin said today.

LEAD: Russ Francis, a former first-round draft choice of New England, has agreed to rejoin the Patriots for the remainder of the season and may sign a contract for next year, team officials said. Francis, who was waived by the San Francisco 49ers last week, made the decision to rejoin the Patriots Tuesday after being told by Coach Bill Walsh of San Francisco that the 49ers had no intention of re-signing him.

LEAD: The Navy announced today that a team of the General Dynamics Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation had been selected to build an advanced attack aircraft in a program that could be worth $45 billion.

LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that over-the-counter ''short interest'' - the number of shares sold short, and not yet covered - fell 17 million shares, or 8.2 percent, to 190.6 million shares in the month ended Dec. 15. That was down from a revised 207.6 million shares in the period ending Nov.

LEAD: Let's face it. Except for the odd dramatic event, like Gary Hart's departure and return, the country has been sleeping through the Presidential primary season. LEAD: Communist rebels said today that they would refrain from military attacks on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Reagan Administration is struggling to find a way to avoid closing the Palestine Liberation Organization observer mission to the United Nations, even though a new law requires that it be shut, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: A commuter plane carrying eight people lost power in one of its two engines after takeoff today and crashed into a house, killing five passengers and the pilot, officials said.

LEAD: According to the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, advertising spending in the nation's dailies in October rose 5.5 percent over the same month in 1986, to $2.66 billion. The biggest category gainer was classified, which was up 14.7 percent, to $969 million, while retail rose 1.7 percent, to $1.37 billion.

LEAD: By putting up millions of dollars of their own capital, Wall Street's largest brokerage firms have long made the difference between an orderly market for giant institutional stock trades and one that bounces around wildly.

LEAD: Entries for the 112th annual Westminster Kennel Club show at Madison Square Garden Feb. 8-9 have closed with 2,636 dogs, representing 140 breeds or varieties. ''It's the earliest close in the long history of Westminster,'' said Chet Collier, the show chairman.
LEAD: Libya is building a plant that Reagan Administration officials strongly suspect will be used to make chemical weapons.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WHAT does the well-dressed Munchkin wear at this magical time of year? To find out we stalked Fifth Avenue, that thoroughfare of good taste, for several days.

LEAD: Should New York City's next schools chancellor be more an educator or an administrator? A search committee finally presents New York's Board of Education with an answer: three candidates, all accomplished educators now serving in other cities. It's a defensible choice but more needs to be said. In New York, effectiveness depends heavily on the ability to understand a gritty political system and make it respond.

LEAD: Many post offices will be closed for at least the next two Saturdays and half of the new construction projects will be canceled as part of a package of budget-slashing measures, the Postal Service announced today.

LEAD: The American Home Products Corporation yesterday joined a fast-developing bidding war for the troubled A. H. Robins Company, offering stock valued at $550 million and a commitment to provide $2.48 billion in cash over seven years to compensate women who say they suffered injuries from Robins's Dalkon Shield birth control device.

LEAD: Ferdinand Bachmann, a 30-year veteran of the Salvation Army, had an insider's explanation for why the Christmas shoppers sliding by him in front of Galeries Lafayette were plunking fewer francs into his metal drum this year. It was too warm. ''The colder it is,'' he said, an idle bell dangling in his left hand, ''the more they give.

LEAD: AS they say, better late than never. At the august age of 78, Blanche Moyse finally made her Carnegie Hall debut Monday evening, leading the Orchestra of St. Luke's and the Blanche Moyse Chorale in an absolutely glorious rendition of Bach's ''Christmas Oratorio.'' Even after three hours on stage the conductor seemed vigorous enough to start over again.

LEAD: The Transamerica Occidental Life Insurance Company said it had agreed to provide part of the financing in a $10 million laboratory and plans to enter the growing market for AIDS testing by insurers.
LEAD: This year some top insurance executives, who usually help protect policyholders against risk, are helping to underwrite Senator Bob Dole's effort to win the Republican Presidential nomination.
LEAD: From Food to Fashion: Mr. Chow's New Project

LEAD: Computer Security Change President Reagan is expected to sign a bill shifting from military to civilian hands the control over standards for safeguarding information stored in the nation's computers. Page A10. Slower U.S. Growth Seen The Reagan Administration predicted lower economic growth in 1988, but expects a steady employment rate and lower inflation.

LEAD: THERE'S a satisfying aura of dependability about the double bill at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, through Sunday. The Jimmy McGriff-Hank Crawford quartet and the Houston Person-Etta Jones quintet deliver ballads, steaming uptempo tunes and maybe even a bop or Latin number, but they never stray far from the blues.

LEAD: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said that the Internal Revenue Service intends to rule that most of the $320 million in cash distributed to its shareholders in a restructuring this year will be taxed as a dividend. The percentage of the cash payout that will be considered taxable depends on the year-end earnings and retained profits of the Los Angeles-based retailer, a spokesman said.

LEAD: More than 200 people crowded into a tiny Bronx funeral home where a 28-year-old black woman was mourned yesterday by public officials and ministers as a symbol of what they termed the continuing struggle to stamp out racism in New York City.
LEAD: THE news came in a plain white envelope marked ''personal and confidential.''

LEAD: Despite their preoccupation with last-minute work on catch-all spending legislation and a bill to reduce the Federal deficit, members of Congress still found time to spread holiday cheer among themselves.

LEAD: The lawyer for a convicted teen-ager in the Howard Beach case said yesterday that he would ask the judge for a hearing to determine if, before the verdict, the jury foreman had authorized a television news producer to try to sell her story to newspapers.
LEAD: Blake Stern, an oratorio singer and a professor emeritus of music at Yale University, died Tuesday in Logan, Iowa. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: WHEN we say we can't make love without love, I think, it's intimacy that we mean we can't make love, can't make out, can't live very well without. Intimacy, I think, is what those who live alone in their beds, and those who live with someone without the habitual touch of flesh or mind want to weep for the lack of.

LEAD: A former army colonel whose allegations of high-level corruption touched off a summer of unrest has been sentenced to five years in prison for crimes against state security, a court official said today.

LEAD: An effort to sell a juror's account of the Howard Beach trial to three newspapers has focused attention on an ethical and legal quandary that many journalists and lawyers describe as extremely troubling.
LEAD: ''Raw,'' Eddie Murphy's verbally explicit comedy concert film, took in $9 million in its first week to top the box office receipts.

LEAD: The West Women's Hotel, a run-down building on Skid Row here, is an outpost in the difficult battle being waged around the country to save the spirits of homeless children. It is a place where it can take a month of cuddling and comfort in a locked playroom to coax a 3-year-old girl to smile at her own reflection in a mirror.

LEAD: Reggie Sutton, a cornerback, rejoined the New Orleans Saints yesterday after a month during which he underwent treatment for substance abuse. ''I'm just trying to get my life together,'' Sutton said. . . . Dennis Harrah, the Los Angeles Rams guard, has announced his retirement after 13 seasons. His announcement came after the league announced that he had been selected to the Pro Bowl for the sixth time.

LEAD: Britain's independent Takeover Panel ruled today that the British Petroleum Company's multibillion-dollar bid for Britoil P.L.C. could go ahead, despite the Government's intention to use its ''golden share'' to prevent any bidder from gaining control of Britain's largest independent oil company.

LEAD: A Taiwan citizen who is an American resident has been ordered to leave China for belonging to a ''reactionary organization,'' Chinese newspapers reported today. The man, Qian Ga, was said to belong to the Chinese Alliance for Democracy, a New York-based Chinese dissident group with underground cells in
LEAD: Taiwan is making some progress but has quite a way to go to live up to its stated commitment to human rights and greater democracy, according to the rights group Asia Watch.
LEAD: Israeli officials today rejected the Reagan Administration's assertion that Israeli troops had used excessive force in quelling Palestinian riots.
LEAD: The special teams, which had been the main reason for the recent slide by the Devils, proved very effective tonight against the Penguins.

LEAD: The Turkish Government has filed legal papers responding to a motion by the Metropolitan Museum of Art to dismiss a suit in which Turkey has demanded the return of artifacts it contends were illegally exported in the 1960's, Harry I. Rand, an attorney representing Turkey, said yesterday.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Tuesday, about the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, misstated the arrangement under which banks make payments in the New York Cash Exchange system, a network of automatic tellers. When the cash machine used does not belong to the customer's own bank, the customer's bank pays the owning bank a fee of 20 cents for a balance inquiry or 38 cents for a cash withdrawal; another fee of 13 to 19 cents is paid to the exchange.

LEAD: The Boys Choir of Harlem has sung to critical acclaim all over the United States, in Japan and in major cathedrals and churches of Europe, including St. Paul's in London and St. Germain des Pres in Paris. Yet, says the director, the group has an image problem.
LEAD: A judge in Manhattan has been charged by state disciplinary officials with misusing his judicial powers in a series of cases involving a friend, according to state officials and court records.
LEAD: Navy engineers are checking 300 jet engines throughout the world after discovering that an error-prone mechanic was incorrectly assembling gearboxes, a Navy spokesman said today.

LEAD: THAT was a nice gesture on the part of Dave Righetti, giving himself to George Steinbrenner for the holidays. In an era when athletes are depicted as mercenaries, the Yankees reliever put friendship and loyalty ahead of money, and decided to remain in New York. In a big business like baseball, some may say that Righetti was foolish to let sentiment override the profit motive.

LEAD: * Boeing Co., Seattle, has received an order from Canadian Airlines International, which was formed last March with the merger of Pacific Western and Canadian Pacific airlines, for two 767-300 extended-range jets, plus options on eight more, worth a total of $660 million if all the options are exercised.

LEAD: Egypt is laying the groundwork for a significant expansion of its military presence in the Arab countries of the Persian Gulf, taking a more conspicuous role in a widening Arab military confrontation with Iran.

LEAD: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company yesterday raised its estimates of the amount that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will lose as a result of bad loans transferred to it under the rescue plan that was adopted in 1984.

LEAD: A national campaign to reduce the death and suffering from alcohol abuse seems to be working for adults, with consumption dropping, drinking-related traffic fatalities decreasing and more people becoming aware that alcohol and pregnancy don't mix.

LEAD: An unarmed teen-ager who said he had a bomb hijacked a KLM airliner with 97 people aboard today, forced it to land in Rome and demanded $1 million, airline officials said. The police overpowered him four hours later, and all hostages were released unharmed.

LEAD: The marriage of Nancy Elizabeth Wright, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Madison B. LEAD: Pre-Christmas sales are not working, retailers say.

LEAD: Some may think the meaning of the Howard Beach trial is that racial violence no longer will be tolerated. Others may think the manslaughter convictions of three young white men demonstrate the power of black political pressures. But the clearer ''message'' comes not from the verdict - reached only after 12 days of jury deliberation - but in the reaction of all too many blacks and whites.

LEAD: FREQUENTLY in the land of television, the line between an entertainment and a commercial can get curiously thin. LEAD: An article yesterday about the adjournment of Congress misstated the amount of aid voted for rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government. It is $8.1 million, not $8.1 billion.

LEAD: WE know that Joan Miro had a formative impact on the most venturesome American painters from the 1930's and 40's. LEAD: Henry Cotton, the most distinguished British golfer of his generation, died Tuesday. He was 80 years old. Cotton, who turned professional in 1924, won the British Open in 1934, ending a long run of American victories and again in 1937 and 1948. He played many times in the United States and was captain of the Ryder Cup team in 1939, 1947 and 1953.

LEAD: Mary Decker Slaney, the nation's top female middle-distance runner but also the most injury-prone, will miss the 1988 indoor track season because of an injured right calf, her coach said yesterday. LEAD: This Christmas seems notable for the carol that hasn't been sung - that hymn to materialism, ''The Twelve Days of Christmas.'' Like the dog that didn't bark, could the carol not sung reveal something profound?

LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, the Op-Ed page was omitted in some copies yesterday. Any reader wishing a copy of the page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.

LEAD: WHEN Latin music aficionados are discussing players like Yomo Toro, the Puerto Rican virtuoso of the 10-stringed mini-guitar called the cuatro, they often resort to a term that sounds out-of-place amid the streams of voluble, rapid-fire Spanish: hillbilly. The ''jibaro'' music that is Mr. Toro's specialty actually is folk music from the Puerto Rican hill country - buoyant, driving string-band music that can be compared to American hillbilly and bluegrass styles without stretching the point.

LEAD: The vote by Congress to deny tax credits to American companies for taxes paid by their subsidiaries in South Africa is being viewed here as potentially one of the most damaging economic measures taken by the United States against apartheid.

LEAD: The property room of the Miami Police Department has become a kind of museum reflecting the problems of South Florida: overcrowded, understaffed, besieged by drugs, guns and cash, and strangled in red tape.

LEAD: Until he disappeared while scuba diving in the Bahamas two years ago, David J. Friedland was just a New Jersey politician with a swindling conviction on his record. Subsequently the former State Senator was known as a nimble international fugitive, and was spotted in Paris and Hong Kong among other places, traveling first class and moving a little faster than the law.

LEAD: Parts of the main branch of the Salt Lake City Library were flooded Friday when temperatures near zero caused a water pipe to freeze and rupture, a fire official said. Up to 300 books were damaged. Firefighters believe the rupture occurred in the sprinkler system because it triggered an alarm at the Fire Department.
LEAD: A wonder drug for heart-attack victims. A book of zany but thought-provoking questions. Exciting advances in superconductivity. Buying postage stamps by phone.

LEAD: IT'S A CHILLING SUMMARY. After 40 years of manufacturing waterproofing materials for the textiles industry, the Arkansas Chemical Company went bankrupt in 1983 and abandoned its facilities in Newark, N.J. Under the provisions of the so-called Superfund Act of 1980, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency was ultimately called in to begin a cleanup.
LEAD: Camp Powderhorn could easily be mistaken for a military encampment in the Rockies on a hot July day.

LEAD: Julia Hope Arnsten, a second-year medical student at New York University, and Adam R. Spilka, an associate in the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, plan to be married in June, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Arnsten of New York, have announced.
LEAD: WHEN the Westchester County Legislature approved a major expansion of the county-owned airport last week, alarm bells rang across the state border in Greenwich, Conn.

LEAD: ALEXIS LICHINE'S NEW ENCYCLOPEDIA OF WINES & SPIRITS. Fifth Edition, Revised. By Alexis Lichine with William Fifield. (Knopf, $45.) New Year's Eve celebrants who seek Alexis Lichine's advice on serving Champagne will also learn that Art Buchwald likes bubbly ''because it always tastes as though my foot's asleep.

LEAD: THE BUILDING ON SANTA MONICA BOULEVARD in Beverly Hills, just over the Los Angeles city line, bears no resemblance to the West Coast headquarters of a world-class tycoon with bold new plans of conquest in the Pacific. A scant three stories tall, muted post-modern in design, set in a row of nondescript shops facing the Hilton and the back of Robertson's department store, the World Trade Bank resembles the showroom of a moderately prosperous Chevrolet dealer.

LEAD: The most infamous and significant insider-trading case in the nation's history was concluded when Federal District Judge Morris E. Lasker sentenced Ivan S. Boesky to three years in jail for conspiracy to file false trading records. The prosecutor spoke at sentencing of ''rampant criminal misconduct'' that appears to have involved not only Mr.

LEAD: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. deserves praise for the one-line amendment he wrote for a $16 billion energy and water bill that prevents the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission from conducting an expedited review of the proposed Iroquois natural gas pipeline project. The Senate recently passed the appropriation bill by a vote of 86 to 9.

LEAD: This year's top sports story is, and continues to be, the pollution of the athletic environment by moneyed interests. Big-time college campuses have been infected by agents offering illegal financial assistance, coaches motivated by personal avarice rather than the desire to educate, administrations dedicated to the pursuit of television revenues, and athletes hoping to use school as a way station to the pros.
LEAD: THE SHOP AROUND THE CORNER With James Stewart (in photo), Margaret Sullavan (in photo) and Frank Morgan. 1939. MGM/UA Home Video. 99 minutes. $24.95.

LEAD: JOHN THEODORACOPULOS, a 22-year-old apprentice with a merchant bank, was talking about New Year's Eve recently with a group of friends and, he said, they all agreed. It is a hyped-up evening, anticlimactic, and one that often ends with everyone a bit depressed.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James J. McLaughlin of Plandome Manor, L.I., and Amagansett, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Elizabeth McLaughlin, to Michael Francis Costello, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Costello of Plandome, L.I. A January wedding is planned.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 5 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts creates nightmares in a Maine village. 2 2 10 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel.

LEAD: WHEN a Venetian blind requires repair or becomes so grimy that ordinary dusting or sponging won't suffice, disassembling the blind may be the only answer. Though the job takes patience, it is not difficult.

LEAD: IF Bill Bradley were to declare his candidacy for the Presidency, he would sweep through the 1988 Democratic primaries and convention, win a landslide victory in November and on Jan. 20, 1989, become the next man to live in the White House.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Mrs. Nicholas Biddle Wainwright of Gwynedd, Pa., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Christine Wainwright, to Douglas Fernald Stone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl H. Stone of Greenwich, Conn., and Paris. A May wedding is planned. Miss Wainwright, the daughter also of the late Mr. Wainwright, is a vice president in institutional corporate bond sales at Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Olivia G. Bayard of Pennington, N.J., and Nicholas H. Bayard of New York of the engagement of their daughter Sarah Hathaway Bayard to Peter John Southam, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Southam of Pomfret, Conn. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: A Rumanian woman arrested in Bucharest after an interview for a French television documentary was released Thursday, the League for the Defense of Human Rights in Rumania said Friday.

LEAD: AT the moment, Yale University Art Gallery has not one but two graphic art exhibitions going for it - ''From Mannerism to Classicism: Printmaking in France, 1600 to 1660'' and ''Prints by Contemporary American Women.'' Both come with substantial catalogues and both, curiously enough, are dedicated to the parents of their respective organizers.

LEAD: Charles J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor, has been put in a politically and personally sensitive position with his assignment to determine if there were any criminal or ethical violations by the Brooklyn District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman, in her accusations of judicial misconduct toward a sex attack victim.

LEAD: It's been almost a year since the 700-pound moose who courted a Hereford cow named Jessica in Shrewsbury, Vt., lost his antlers and walked away from the 76-day love affair, but the story of their romance is now popular in hardcover.
LEAD: Four black men were killed Friday and the police twice fired at crowds in a district where more than 230 people have died in factional fighting this year, the police said today.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: ON the moonless night of Dec. 20, most of the passengers on the overcrowded Dona Paz were asleep, either in steel bunks or on outside decks, as the ferry made for Manila. Many of them were going to the Philippine capital for the Christmas holidays. Then the 2,215-ton ferry collided with the 629-ton tanker Victor, with a crew of 13.

LEAD: HOUSING COSTS/N.Y.-Northeast N.J. area* $ % change from % change from Nov. Oct. Nov. 86 Rents[1] 133.7 -0.1 5.6 Homeowner's costs[1] 138.2 0.3 9.9 Fuel and utilities[2] 364.9 0.4 0.7 Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics
LEAD: Personal Flag nosed out two horses by photo-finish today to win the $200,000 Widener Handicap.

LEAD: I only wish that before writing her article, Peggy McCarthy had interviewed those of us merchants in SoNo who are not only doing very well, but are also enjoying our choice of South Norwalk. [ ''SoNo Merchants Are Still Waiting for Prosperity,'' Nov. 8 ] .

LEAD: Almost four years after Queens College won a fierce political battle to recreate a famous high school for intellectually gifted youngsters, the college finds itself in a dispute over where the elite school should be housed.
LEAD: Mayor Koch is seeking ways to break what he says is organized crime's 30-year hold on much of New York City's commercial hauling industry.

LEAD: A female student at Harvard University has filed a legal complaint against one of the campus's nine all-male social clubs, renewing a debate here over whether the clubs, which admit no women and very few men, should retain their single-sex status.

LEAD: THE old two-story brick building in Corona, Queens, at the southwest corner of 43d Avenue and 97th Place, looks no different from many other industrial structures: It is functional, but worn, and surrounded by cars. But the flaking letters of a huge old painted sign just barely coalesce into a magic name: ''Tiffany Studios.

LEAD: Botswana, a peaceful, relatively prosperous democracy surrounded by southern African countries in turmoil, has enjoyed a swift development since independence from Britain in 1966. Now, however, it faces a series of new challenges complicated by its rapid growth.
LEAD: STATE education funds to bring artists into the classroom have caused a blossoming of poetry and other arts programs in Long Island schools over the last three years.

LEAD: The engagement of Charlotte Amalie Feng to William E. Ford 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ford Jr. of Summit, N.J., has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Louis T. Feng of Creve Coeur, Mo. A June 25 wedding is planned.

LEAD: THIS HAS BEEN CALLED an age of dancers. Virtuoso whiz kids dart, spin and soar through choreography whose challenges would once have been considered almost impossible. Then there are the performers who fill the stage with their very presence. Every so often, however, a dancer is endowed with both superb technical facilities and a commanding stage personality.

LEAD: ENTERTAINING at home slumped during the last 10 years. People were so busy working that business functions overshadowed more traditional pleasures. Occasionally, friends would meet for dinner, but this usually took place in restaurants, not at home.
LEAD: Ilkka Sinisalo scored with 2 minutes 25 seconds left in the game to give Philadelphia a 3-2 victory over the Washington Capitals tonight and extend the Flyers' unbeaten streak to 14 games.

LEAD: Recently I saw two young people, husband and wife, in consultation. They were both intravenous drug users, addicted to an illegal synthetic opiate. I tried to detoxify them as outpatients without success. I then tried to arrange for them to get help through a methadone program elsewhere because no such program is locally available.

LEAD: At St. James' Episcopal Church in Woodstock, Vt., Amy Forsythe Waring was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Dunsmore Stevens, a resident in internal medicine at the Presbyterian Hospital in New York. The Rev. Donald Boyer officiated. The bride is a student at the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, from which her husband graduated.

LEAD: THE County Board of Legislators approved an $846.9 million budget for 1988 last week, trimming $3.4 million from the proposed spending plan presented in mid-November by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke. The final version will require a 15 percent increase in the county tax levy, or the amount raised from real estate taxes.

LEAD: STAGING ''Arms and the Man'' is a tricky thing. All excess and extravagance on the surface, it is filled with more operetta-like outbursts than the musical it inspired, ''The Chocolate Soldier'' with its signature song, ''My Hero.'' It is, after all, a play by George Bernard Shaw - and that isn't romantic.
LEAD: An army bomb disposal expert was killed and four others were injured today in the second explosion in two days at an army ammunition depot near Athens, the Defense Ministry said.

LEAD: THE FACE OF ROCK, 1987, WAS the face of U2's lead singer, Bono Vox. Unglamorous, unsmiling, contorted with emotion, imploring attention for the songs rather than himself, he acts not like an overgrown bad boy or a high-living hedonist but an everyman about to explode with hopes and fears. It is the face of popular music feeling its power and its global reach, and taking them very seriously.

LEAD: STAMFORD GALA First Night Stamford, a New Year's Eve revel that has taken a year to prepare, will fill the downtown streets of the nearby Connecticut city from 3 P.M. New Year's Eve to just after midnight on New Year's Day. The experimental gala, based on successful prototypes in Boston, Charleston, San

LEAD: OVER the last 20 years, a million New Jerseyans have attended the state's 19 two-year county community colleges, and for many it has been the start of a career that leads to further study at a four-year college.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John Duer Moores Jr. of Convent Station, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lauren Stewart Moores to Blake Leay Auchincloss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis S. Auchincloss of New York and Bedford, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: THE poet exhorts the ninth graders to take life and make mythology out of it, not to worry about the facts for one half-hour in their day of revolving classes at Harborfields High School in Greenlawn.

LEAD: For the Cleveland Browns, clinching their third straight American Football Conference Central Division championship meant that the Three Rivers Stadium jinx may have been simply a matter of ability.

LEAD: THE MOST IMPORTANT MOVIE news this year wasn't movies but business. More movies than ever went into release this year than at any time in recent memory. Distributors of video cassettes became an important source of production money. Box offices boomed, but often with movies that were interchangeable (''Robocop,'' ''Stakeout,'' ''Lethal Weapon,'' ''Extreme Prejudice'').
LEAD: On the rolling plains of northeast Nebraska, the Federal Government manages the nation's largest wild horse ranch with 3,000 mares, colts and stallions confined in pens across 74 acres.
LEAD: Reese Badman's Christmas present from his grandfather had to find its own way to Pennsylvania from California.

LEAD: Elizabeth Bryan Hufstader and John Michael Balay, graduates of Yale University, are planning to be married in June, the parents of the future bride, Mrs. Walter Steele of Edgartown, Mass., and Peter Hufstader of Providence, R.I., have announced.

LEAD: The engagement of Dana Elise Kohnken to Bradley Douglas Cole has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Kohnken of Westport, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of David M. Cole and Samina R. Cole, both of Annapolis, Md. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: ROY D. WOODRUFF, the scientist who became an outcast after challenging Edward Teller, has returned to an important position at the nation's largest laboratory for the design of nuclear weapons. His comeback, after two years in a humble job at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, may cause new problems for a controversial weapon in President Reagan's Strategic Defense

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Bryan Webb of New York and Amagansett, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Webb, to Matthew Brayton Dawson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Dawson of Dover, Mass., and Little Compton, R.I. The couple plan to marry in May.
LEAD: THE FRANCO REGIME 1936-1975. By Stanley G. Payne. Illustrated. 677 pp. Madison: University of Wisconsin Press. $30.
LEAD: VIEWS OF INDIAN HERITAGE

LEAD: THE tomato is a symbol of the triumphs and disappointments of American agriculture. Over the last 50 years, breeders have crossed one variety with another to produce hybrids with large yields, long shelf lives and the ruggedness to survive a long trek to market. At the same time, the store-bought tomato has become pale, hard, thick-skinned and increasingly tasteless.

LEAD: Humor and art are not always allies, especially when it comes to photographs of dogs. But William Wegman's new color pictures at Pace/ MacGill Gallery (11 East 57th Street, through Jan. 16) manage to make us laugh and think at the same time. In ''Hatched,'' for example, we see the artist's new pet Weimaraner, Fay Ray, wrapped in red-faced aluminum foil, looking somewhat like a Christmas gift and somewhat like a half-opened bonbon.

LEAD: AFTER they reactivated him last week and put him throught several workouts, the Cleveland Cavaliers hoped Ron Harper would be ready to play in last night's game against the Portland Trail Blazers. But now it appears that Coach Lenny Wilkens will have to make do without last season's runner-up for the National Basketball
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE CHALLENGE PUT TO George Bernard Shaw by his friend Arthur Bingham Walkley was to write a Don Juan play; as Shaw saw it, the challenge required by the society he lived in was to create a drama about sexual attraction while forbidden by the strictures of the era to show any incidents actually illustrating such attraction - or even to discuss it onstage.

LEAD: IN the Armenian capital of Yerevan, angry citizens have forced local officials to promise that a chemical plant blamed for high rates of cancer and birth defects will be relocated. In the town of Kirishi, in western Russia, a band of citizens led by a local postman shut down a plant manufacturing synthetic additives for livestock feed.

LEAD: Year round, there are plenty of statistics produced to chart the steadily rising prosperity of Southeast Asia's ''little dragon'' economies. But when Christmas comes, the affluence is measured in happy human faces.
LEAD: Construction took 50 workers seven weeks to complete. And that was just for the pop-up magazine advertisement.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: IN the labor wars that flared up again this fall in the National Football League and the National Basketball Association, the players never seemed to have a chance.
LEAD: THE headline said, ''AIDS Training in Kindergarten.'' Was I reading correctly? Surely they meant ''aides.''

LEAD: The Joffrey Ballet brings its new production of ''The Nutcracker'' to New York this week, for a week only, opening on Wednesday at City Center (131 West 55th Street). A long-cherished project of Robert Joffrey's, the ballet is based on the traditional story with a few differences: For example, the setting of the ballet is Victorian American, andhuman characters from the first act reappear in the second in other guises.

LEAD: IN A QUIET, LOW-KEYED AND civilized way, this was a very distinguished year in the international museum world. In show after show, serious matters were discussed in a serious way. One or two absurd errors were made - notably the welcome accorded at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and elsewhere, to the so-called Helga paintings by Andrew
LEAD: THE SOCRATIC METHOD By Michael Levin. 304 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

LEAD: When the Rev. Peter Larom, pastor of the Grace Episcopal Church in White Plains, heard that Harry A. Halpern planned an office project on the same block as his church building, he briefly considered fighting it. Instead, he decided upon an option being exercised by an increasing number of nonprofit institutions that are situated on valuable, downtown property: He agreed to sell church land to the developer.

LEAD: To the Editor: A friend and I visited Caracas in July. We agreed with Anthony Austin's observation (Travel, Oct. 25) that instead of providing architecture, Venezuelean money could have eased the plight of the poor. As prominent as the modern skyscrapers are, the shanties spilling down three sides of the surrounding mountains paint a rusty stain that ends flush against the high-rise fences.

LEAD: ON A WARM NOVEMBER AF-ternoon, four friends gather to talk in a windowless upper room of an old office complex in downtown Buenos Aires. One is a medical student; two have undergraduate degrees in anthropology and another is working toward one. Although they speak with measured dispassion, their subject is death, violent death - the kind only state terrorism can produce.
LEAD: THE New York Legislature, after 12 years of inconclusive debate, now seems poised - or perhaps obliged - to confront the issue of statewide restrictions on smoking in public places.

LEAD: WITH its unbeatable track record of such musical revues as ''Ain't Misbehavin','' ''Eubie,'' ''Bubbling Brown Sugar'' and ''One Mo' Time,'' all in effervescent stagings, one has come to look upon the Crossroads Theatre Company as the state's premiere showplace for musical tributes to black composers and the eras they represent.

LEAD: Brooklyn District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman has been accused of misjudging a judge. Earlier this month, Ms. Holtzman asserted that Judge Irving W. Levine had humiliated a woman by ordering her to re-enact a rape.

LEAD: ONE DAY IN OCTOBER 1983, Wu Tianming walked onto the stage of the Xian Film Studio auditorium and looked out over the 4,000 faces that he was to manage as the new studio chief. This is what he told them:
LEAD: CLOONEY IN MILLBURN

LEAD: Will the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission run out of landmarks to designate? Or will it be swamped first by its regulatory duties? Should residents of historic districts have more of a say in administering their areas?

LEAD: ''It's not a shoe factory,'' Andrew Leider said to emphasize what he and his partner had done to the former Grossman Shoe Factory at 372 DeKalb Avenue in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn. It is now Clinton Mews, a 78-unit co-op.

LEAD: ''NEVER make forecasts,'' said Samuel Goldwyn, ''especially about the future.'' Well, we at the Smoot-Hawley Institute of Economic Growth and Political Cooperation beg to differ. Of course, at this time of year hundreds of charlatans hang out their shingles, dust off their crystal balls and spew out a lot of hot air about what's coming up.

LEAD: MAINTAINING the stable purchasing power of a currency is the key policy objective of any central bank. Recently, Secretary of the Treasury James A. Baker 3d called for the use of a broad commodity basket, including gold, as an indicator to be used in the monetary policy formulation process.

LEAD: WHEN a Venetian blind requires repair or becomes so grimy that ordinary dusting or sponging won't suffice, disassembling the blind may be the only answer. Though the job takes patience, it is not difficult.

LEAD: THEY are part mechanized cow pony, part military personnel carrier. You see them hauling groceries in Hastings-on-Hudson, toting Turf Builder in Tuckahoe, riding high above the station traffic in Rye. They are not exactly trucks, but they sure aren't cars; they're the new Family Four-by-Fours.

LEAD: A 13-year-old girl from Forest Hills, Queens, kidnapped and held by captors demanding $15,000 in ransom, was found unharmed Christmas night by detectives who tracked her kidnappers to their Brooklyn home, the police said yesterday.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: Two million New Yorkers are eligible to vote but not registered. In October, Mayor Koch announced an ambitious campaign to sign them up with a late-November mailing of registration forms to every household in the city. Senators Moynihan and D'Amato agreed to contribute $300,000 worth of their Congressional franking privilege.

LEAD: THREE men, one black, one white and one Hispanic, are pictured above the line ''We Want to Collar a Few Good Men.'' A young man strolls down a darkened hospital corridor puzzling over his career while a narrator says, ''The work is hard but the rewards are infinite.'' At first glance they seem like just another series of recruitment ads for the armed forces.

LEAD: WHEN a Venetian blind requires repair or becomes so grimy that ordinary dusting or sponging won't suffice, disassembling the blind may be the only answer. Though the job takes patience, it is not difficult.

LEAD: I MET this nice, shy, clean-shaven young man in 1984. At the end of a friendly chat, we exchanged business cards. His name was printed under the colorful logo of a major television network. Below the name, his position: ''Long Island news reporter.''

LEAD: The engagement of Joan Caren Danziger to Dr. Daniel Herz Hechtman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Hechtman of Chestnut Hill and Truro, Mass., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Danziger of West Newton, Mass., and Hartford, Vt. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Bertram A. Portin of Amherst, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Carol Portin, to Jeffrey Nathan Gladstein, the son of Dr. Freyda Gladstein and Nison Gladstein of Philadelphia. The couple plan to marry in June. Miss Portin is an associate in the Philadelphia law firm of Pepper, Hamilton & Scheetz.
LEAD: Lee Stoliar, a sculptor, and Leonard Dufresne, a painter, were married in a civil ceremony yesterday in Las Vegas, Nev.
LEAD: TAKING stock at the end of his seventh year as the 84th Governor of Connecticut, William A. O'Neill generally likes what he sees.

LEAD: THE concert season runs from fall through spring and so, naturally enough, do most subscription series. For some reason, though, the Stamford Center for the Arts decided to crowd all but a handful of its many events into the first five months of 1988, so there's still time to take advantage of reduced subscription rates to five different cycles at the Palace

LEAD: IN a gesture of frustration as well as pride, Giovanni Evangelisti of Italy said yesterday that, because of doubts cast upon his performance, he was renouncing the bronze medal he won in the long jump at the world track and field championships in Rome last summer.

LEAD: Afghan Protest in Moscow Policemen in Moscow and Leningrad reportedly detained 16 people protesting Soviet military involvement in Afghanistan on the eve of the eighth anniversary of the Soviet military sweep into that country. Page 3. War's Toll in Angola Twelve years of civil war in Angola has reduced Government-controlled areas to an archipelago of urban islands strung over a nation twice the size of France.
LEAD: Increased Federal testing of what American schoolchildren have learned is the subject of a debate in Congress and among educators and the outcome will affect American education for decades.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ROMANTIC COMEDY In Hollywood, From Lubitsch to Sturges. By James Harvey. Illustrated. 716 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

LEAD: Six weeks after the political opposition opened a campaign of protests to force the resignation of President H. M. Ershad, there is no sign that the Government and its opposition will come to a settlement soon.

LEAD: A producer hired to film a documentary on the city's celebration of the Constitution's bicentennial has failed to complete the project and never contacted prominent people he had planned to interview, a newspaper here reported Tuesday.

LEAD: THE Grace Episcopal Church has flourished - at least, most of the time - on a site at Church and Main Streets in White Plains, where it was built during the Civil War, when White Plains had only 1,500 residents.

LEAD: Israel's crackdown on Palestinian protesters has sharpened the quandaries and frustrations facing Egypt, the only Arab nation to have made peace with Israel, according to analysts and officials here.

LEAD: George Mira Jr., a linebacker suspended after failing to pass a drug test administered by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, will not practice with Miami for its Orange Bowl game against Oklahoma next Friday night, despite a court ruling that permits him to do so, Coach Jimmy Johnson said today.

LEAD: One of Shaeffer-Eton's two manufacturing plants here has been sold to the owners of the Miller Newspapers chain for $2.2 million, according to company officials. Edward E. Byrnes, vice president of Shaeffer-Eton Inc., said Thursday that the pen and stationery manufacturer planned to lease back a portion of the building for its headquarters staff.

LEAD: Because of a transmission error, an article about child abuse in the New Jersey Weekly last week gave the wrong first name of the chairman of the sociology department at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. He is Dr. Allan V. Horwitz.

LEAD: IS IT TOO MUCH OF A GOOD THING, OR a sign of a new mood? In either case, the acknowledged modern masters of photography failed to command the lion's share of attention in terms of 1987's major exhibitions. Some have been overexposed to the point that their images have begun to pale. This might explain the generally lukewarm response to the Edward Weston centennial exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and to the International Center of Photography's show, ''Andre Kertesz: Diary of Light.

LEAD: About 20 members of Poland's draft resistance group huddled in a small flat in the Polish capital this week, in the middle of a hunger strike to protest the detention of about 100 youths who they say were jailed for refusing military service.
LEAD: Dorothy Hamill trudged up the steps from the Capital Centre rink, ice skates half-laced but with that familiar haircut intact.
LEAD: ON THE wall opposite Representative James J. Florio's desk is a plaque given to him in 1985 by the Consumer Federation of America for ''outstanding service to consumers.''
LEAD: A 66-year-old disabled woman says she was just doing her duty when she hobbled to the scene of a rape and beat her neighbor's assailant with her cane.
LEAD: An unusual partnership of private and public concerns is creating a day care center for 100 children in an inner-city neighborhood here.

LEAD: HARRIET LOVE has been a source for quality vintage clothing since 1965. Now she's added new clothes, mixing them with the old at her redesigned boutique at 412 West Broadway, between Spring and Prince Streets. The new styles seem to be inspired by originals from the 1930's, 40's and 50's.

LEAD: DID IT GO TOO FAST? DID PICTURES JOIN, voices mingle and stories swoosh round in a blender? Why, of course; they had to. There was no other way. Ollie North gave way to Presidential candidates, who disappeared in the Persian Gulf, which evaporated when the stock market tumbled. Red neckties - Washington correspondents now favor solid scarlet - remained the only constant.
LEAD: Make this one for the Staggering Rights. Or the Good Riddance Game. Or the Wait-Till-Next-Year Affair.

LEAD: EARLY next year, the Justice Department will make good on a promise that helped end last month's prison riots in Atlanta and Oakdale, La., when it begins holding special administrative proceedings for Cubans who have been in legal limbo for more than seven years. In the eyes of the law, they and some others who came to the United States with the Mariel boatlift never actually entered the country.

LEAD: A FUNDAMENTAL change is under way in the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino. As she feels pressure from extremists on both sides, but particularly from the right wing, the open debate and broad political participation - the ''democratic space,'' as it was called - have narrowed.

LEAD: The time for getting away from it all -the damp and chill of the northern winter - has arrived. In the following articles, 11 foreign correspondents of The New York Times describe their favorite out-of-the-way refuges of sun, sand and sea. The choices range from the sites of ancient ruins along the Nile to New Caledonia, a Gallicized group of islands in the South Pacific.

LEAD: THE decade was the 1970's and public-sector unions were hurting. City and state governments, reeling from tight budgets, were keeping tight reins on hiring and wages. As workers in the private sector were enjoying steady wage gains, many state and municipal employees saw even their cost-of-living adjustment clauses disappear.

LEAD: The Israeli Army is preparing to begin military trials for nearly a thousand Palestinians rounded up after two weeks of disturbances in the occupied territories, Israeli military officials and lawyers said today.

LEAD: Dula, the first member of the primitive Tasaday tribe known to have visited a big city, has spent much of her time here sitting on her bed waiting to go home again, her belongings packed and ready.

The choices range from the sites of ancient ruins along the Nile to New Caledonia, a Gallicized group of islands in the South Pacific.

LEAD: TOP-RANKED chess players have often played bridge as a recreation, perhaps with more enthusiasm than skill. When in 1941 Samuel Reshevsky beat back a challenge for the United States Chess Championship by the late Al Horowitz, long the chess columnist for this newspaper, the standard of play was not as high as might have been expected.

LEAD: Constance Ann Ix, an assistant vice president of Chemical Bank in New York, and Andrew Soren Pedersen, an assistant treasurer at Chemical Bank, plan to be married Feb. 13.

LEAD: Five months after the United States began to expand its military operations in the Persian Gulf, the Navy continues to grope for the formula that would let it escort ships through the war zone with maximum safety and minimum force.
LEAD: There's no doubting Mikhail Gorbachev's determination to breathe new life into the wheezing Soviet economy. But there are already reasons to think that his first round of reforms will fail.

LEAD: STAGING ''Arms and the Man'' is a tricky thing. All excess and extravagance on the surface, it is filled with more operetta-like outbursts than the musical it inspired, ''The Chocolate Soldier'' with its signature song, ''My Hero.'' It is, after all, a play by George Bernard Shaw - and that isn't romantic.
LEAD: IT WAS the best and worst of news for schoolchildren in New York State, uplifting for their health but a blow to their morale.
LEAD: Soccer officials in the United States have turned to a leading executive in England for help in their bid to stage the 1994 World Cup, a British newspaper reported today.

LEAD: LIKE most stores that have reached the century mark (and they're not exactly rare in London), Smythson of Bond Street, which celebrated its 100th birthday in September, has few qualms about trading on its past. The store's decor is traditional, understated and a bit intimidating, with somber wood cases, carved balcony rail and wall-to-wall carpets in Bond Street blue, as it has come to be known.

LEAD: THE Christmas party for nearly 100 children at Overlook Hospital here was like many others at similar institutions. Parents talked of their hopes for their sons and daughters, and Santa Claus passed out wrapped gifts that were torn open in seconds.

LEAD: THE FLOOD. By John Broderick. (Marion Boyars/ Kampmann, $22.95.) Forget about plot. John Broderick's latest novel, ''The Flood,'' which is set during the 1930's in Bridgeford, Ireland (population 8,767), boasts such a colorful jumble of characters and voices one barely notices that its story is thin and inconsequential.
LEAD: Rhode Island's new mandatory recycling program has created a new crime: theft of garbage.

LEAD: ELEVEN years ago the paramount public issue in the West 40's of Manhattan was massage parlors. There were plans to convert the building at 121 West 46th Street, once the home of the celebrated Luxor Baths, ''secretly and illegally into one of the most lavish 'massage parlors' in the country,'' as one account had it.

LEAD: What to do with $3 billion was the question Penzoil was pondering as a settlement plan was filed in its historic feud with Texaco. Texaco's plan to emerge from bankruptcy calls for a $3 billion payment to settle Pennzoil's claim that Texaco' acquisition of Getty Oil wrongfully interfered with a Pennzoil takeover of the company.

LEAD: Carla Petra Pavone and Morris Allan Stockburger, who both received M.B.A. degrees in 1982 from Harvard University, plan to be married in April.

LEAD: BOUND by place and time, the dapper side streets and avenues of Manhattan's Upper West Side evoke so strong a sense of the city's past that preservationists want to lay the protective veil of historic designation over most of the neighborhood.

LEAD: The developers of Lake Joseph Estates had an ideal opportunity to build a vacation home community, but it did not work out that way. All of 250-acre lake was theirs, as well as over 1,000 acres of forest surrounding it. The only previous activity this Catskill Mountain retreat five miles south of Monticello, N.Y., on Route 42 saw was a Catholic youth camp, closed years ago.

LEAD: Battery Park City plans to contribute $1 billion to develop housing in New York City, $600 million more than originally agreed to. That means the development is to finance one-quarter of Mayor Koch's 10-year plan to build low- and middle-income housing.

LEAD: The Angolan civil war, 12 years old and with no end in sight, continues to stunt this potentially rich land.

LEAD: Track and Field Two Golds for Foderingham: Winsome Foderingham captured two gold medals yesterday in women's events at the Reebok Christmas Classic track and field meet in the West Point field house in West Point, N.Y. The meet was conducted by the Metropolitan Athletics Congress. Foderingham, a Jamaican representing the Bronx International Express Track Club, won the 55-meter dash in 7.14 seconds and the 55-meter hurdles in 8.12 seconds.

LEAD: Celebrating Bird: The Triumph of Charlie Parker Sony Video Software Company. 58 minutes. $29.95. Despite such a handicap, this documentary of a meteoric jazz figure could hardly be bettered.

LEAD: THE PASSING YEAR, AS concerns audio, was marked by a non-event. DAT didn't happen. As most audio fans know, DAT stands for Digital Audio Tape. It is a system of recording and playback that brings digital techniques to tape cassettes and makes them sound just as good as CD's. Listeners accustomed to the latter's sonic excellence had long been hoping for cassettes to catch up and were eagerly expecting DAT's American debut.

LEAD: OUR Boeing 767 took off from Kennedy International Airport at sunset, and the sky was a glorious sight. From my window seat I watched eagerly as we soared through a thin cloud cover over Jamaica Bay. The plane turned smoothly toward the Jersey coast, and I saw the long shoreline that encompasses Atlantic City and Cape May.

LEAD: Syracuse (11-0) arrived here today to begin on-site preparations for Friday's Sugar Bowl game with Auburn (9-1-1), and Coach Dick MacPherson said that he expected his players to enjoy their stay.

LEAD: IN Mexico, its message is admired by millionaires and street peddlers. In Argentina, it is No. 2 on the best-seller list, sandwiched between the latest books from Jackie Collins and Sidney Sheldon. And in Peru, its gospel of ''a new culture'' based on rewarding individual effort was used to fire up thousands of people who rallied against the recent bank nationalization.
LEAD: In some ways, the life of Bart Dobben was like that of everyone else on Amity Street. He mowed the lawn, tinkered with the car and doted on his two young sons.

LEAD: Prison officials were trying to find out today why Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme fled the Federal Correctional Institution for Women on Wednesday after she had rejected parole hearings and quietly served 12 years of her life sentence for trying to kill President Ford.

LEAD: AS we get ready for another round of Auld Lang Syne, the time seems right to think back upon some of the more important musical happenings of 1987. Perhaps we could paraphrase the category system used by so many award-winning ceremonies and cite the:

LEAD: President Reagan paid tribute to ''the spirit of goodwill'' in America today, singling out an engineer in Mississippi, a pensioner in Arizona and a teacher in Arkansas for their charitable work.

Mr. and Mrs. John Robin McNeil of Weston, Mass., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr.

LEAD: Gary Hart's resurrected campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination has picked up two workers, one each from the campaigns of former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri.

LEAD: WITH the new year just before us, it seems appropriate to reminisce about the pleasures of dining out in Connecticut in 1987. There were many, and, in fact, more Excellent-rated restaurants than we remembered: four.
LEAD: When officials here and in other North African countries confront problems that seem to be getting worse, they keep an eye on the volatile issue of Islamic fundamentalism.

LEAD: Ali Haji-Sheikh, who missed a 33-yard field goal with 46 seconds left in regulation, kicked a 26-yarder at 2 minutes 9 seconds into overtime today, as the Washington Redskins temporarily prevented the Minnesota Vikings from earning the final National Football Conference wild-card spot with a 27-24 victory.
LEAD: ''When we're cutting programs for the the poor in this country, should we be feeding excess wild horses?'' - Robert Burford, director of the Bureau of Land Management. [ 1:1. ]

LEAD: Outmoded incinerators in 2,500 New York City apartment buildings pose a serious health risk - particularly in Manhattan where they are surrounded by new, taller buildings - and should be shut down, according to a petition to be sent today to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency by a group of scientists, legislators and environmental organizations.

LEAD: A new study finds that New York State's Medicaid program is one of the best in the country, but it costs New York City plenty. The city's share of the health insurance for the poor now comes to $1.4 billion annually, a figure that has been increasing 11 percent per year, well above the national average.

LEAD: A French hostage has given birth to a girl two months after the woman and seven other Europeans were seized by Palestinian guerrillas while boating off Israel, a guerrilla spokesman said.

The choices range from the sites of ancient ruins along the Nile to New Caledonia, a Gallicized group of islands in the South Pacific.

LEAD: FOR many years, the arts of Japan have exerted a strong influence on Western taste. Ever since the mid-19th century, the Oriental esthetic of simple, elegant design has found increasing favor in the United States, where Japanese prints, pottery and textiles have become ever more popular.

LEAD: King Fahd told a meeting of Arab leaders from the Persian Gulf today that Iran's conditions for ending its war with Iraq are unreasonable and that prolonging the war could drag their nations into it.

LEAD: Gwendolyn Anne Fager, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Fager of New Canaan, Conn., and Paul Raynor Cheek, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd McForrest Cheek of Madison, N.J., plan to marry in April, the future bride's parents have announced.

LEAD: HARDY is a word often used in defining how well a plant grows, but it is a relative term. A plant that is considered hardy in a certain area should survive cold weather and not be subject to frost damage. But the word is not completely accurate, because it does not take into account many factors that affect growth: drought/rainfall, exposure/radiation, soils, summer heat and other environmental constraints.

LEAD: In 1973, fresh from the Manhattan School of Music with a master's degree, Hal Archer scoured Manhattan for a job as a classical flutist. He had anticipated a difficult search, but he never dreamed of the barriers facing a black classical musician in the early 1970's. Through the next decade, his one steady job, and his best reviews, came when he played with the New York City Housing Authority Symphony

LEAD: EVEN IN THE BEST OF artistic climates, the majority of pop music has always been conceived as disposable light commercial entertainment. And in 1987 that climate tended to be more frivolous than usual. From the formulaic metal bombast of Whitesnake to the teen-age triflings of Tiffany, the year offered more than its share of pure fluff.

LEAD: For Marti Stevens the year 1987, which began with her return to New York after an absence of many years, is ending in a special glow. She is not only back in town for her second engagement within the year -this one at Jan Wallman's (49 West 44th Street), for a week starting Monday - but also she is only the second performer to have played a full week in Miss

LEAD: The article about food programs for the needy [ ''Bringing Food and the Hungry Together,'' Nov. 22 ] was very interesting. I would suggest a follow-up listing names of people in charge of the various food programs and their phone numbers. I think many people, like myself, read an article like that and feel we would like to help.

LEAD: UNAUTHORIZED markings on United States stamps, made by the engravers of the dyes, prompted smiles in the world of philately but frowns in the Treasury Department's Bureau of Engraving and Printing earlier this year.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WORLD economic growth has been shrinking and shrinking, but so gradually - and so inexorably - that economists have grown accustomed to the numbers. Yet a stark tale emerges when those numbers are added together year after year and their impact is examined.

LEAD: ROBERT GLENN KETCHUM emerged with a master's degree in fine arts from the California Institute of the Arts in 1974. Since then, apparently, he has been working nonstop - as a curator, consultant, lecturer and, most of all, as a landscape photographer. At the Hudson River Museum it is Mr. Ketchum the photographer and heartfelt environmentalist who is the center of attention.

LEAD: To the Editor: Mr. Austin's portrayal of Caracas might discourage readers from traveling there, except for those who know it to be a cosmopolitan, romantic metropolis that is refreshingly free of the planeloads of Americans found at so many other vacation spots.
LEAD: The Contra War Alternative Media Project of New Haven. Aylmer Press P. O. Box 2735 Madison, Wis. 53701. 58 minutes. $55.

LEAD: Andrea Victoria Cohen and Michael Noah Bresnick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan A. Bresnick of Riverdale, the Bronx, plan to marry in March, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Cohen of Princeton, N.J., and New York, have announced.

LEAD: WHETHER they constitute a late supper on New Year's Eve or brunch on New Year's Day, certain dishes always hit the spot. Blinis, Russian buckwheat pancakes, served with red or black caviar, melted butter and sour cream, are one of my favorites, especially with a glass of champagne or iced vodka.

LEAD: WHEN Gary Fencik announced earlier that this would be his final season of professional football, it appeared that the Chicago Bears' 33-year-old safety, a Yale graduate, would be closing an outstanding 12-year career in an unfamilair manner: riding the bench. But Coach Mike Ditka changed the situation when he announced that, in an effort to shake up the 10-4 Bears, who have lost their last two games, there would be seven new starters for the team's regular-season finale today against the Los Angeles Raiders.

LEAD: Dennis Conner's reclamation of the America's Cup, after losing it to the Aussies in 1983, has to be the sports story of the year. Why else would so many Americans stay up until 4 A.M. just to ''watch grass grow?'' STEWART J. WILEY Westport, Conn.

LEAD: To the Editor: I am writing about an oversight in the article entitled ''A Flourishing of Whirling Dervishes'' (Travel, Dec. 6). My translation of a quatrain by Rumi appeared without crediting the book in which it was originally published and without mentioning my name. The translation first appeared in the book entitled ''Mevlana Celaleddin Rumi and the Whirling Dervishes'' by Talat Sait Halman and Metin And (published in Istanbul in 1983 by Dost).

LEAD: TELEVISION'S CRAVING FOR animation continues to be as ravenous as the appetites of those sinister cats on the film maker Ralph Bakshi's ''Mighty Mouse: The New Adventures,'' Saturday mornings on CBS. While just about all program schedules have currently been offering a cornucopia of animated holiday fare, animators are already busy at their drawing boards crafting colorful fantasies for 1988 and '89.
LEAD: The Army, returning to an age-old strategy used extensively by the Soviet military, is increasing its use of decoys and fake targets in hopes of outsmarting an enemy's modern weapons.

LEAD: NIGHT WITHOUT DAY. By Raphaele Billetdoux. Translated by Derek Mahon. (Viking, $14.95.) In this chronicle of a torturous three-day affair, the lovers' first meeting summons up ''the memory of a bruised pear . . . demanding anew to be eaten or thrown away.'' The burden of their first embrace ''was heavy, but they took the weight of it in their legs, they clung to each other, they concentrated harder, their clenched fingers hurting.

LEAD: Each school day, 24 children roam the Connecticut Hospice in small groups, visiting the kitchen, the offices, the pharmacy, asking doctors, nurses, maintenence people and patients the endless questions of the young.
LEAD: Vern Fleming scored 10 of his 22 points in the third period as the Indiana Pacers opened a 20-point lead and then handed the Chicago Bulls their sixth consecutive road loss, 106-92, today.
LEAD: Massachusetts lawmakers are considering a bill that would require health warnings on every bottle of beer, wine and liquor sold.

LEAD: BEAVER CREEK is a refuge for hawks, elk, whistle pigs (groundhogs), eagles, deer, beaver and skiers fleeing the winter carnival of Vail. Vail, just up the road, is a dazzling place to ski. The Colorado snow is abundant, the temperature rarely cold enough to be uncomfortable, the air dry, the lifts fast; the runs, lined with spruce and aspen, are varied and seemingly endless.

LEAD: SOME people loathe OS/2, some say it is the greatest development in personal computing in many years, and most don't know it from chopped liver. But the new operating system for powerful personal computers is eventually going to affect everyone who uses a PC in business.

LEAD: THE past year was full of innovations in photographic technology, in terms of both cameras and film. We have yet to arrive at a camera so intelligent that it knows where to aim itself, or a film that can switch from color to black-and-white at the press of a button. But photography is definitely marching to the beat of more automation and less fuss.

LEAD: An April wedding is planned by Nina Allison Gelberg and Robert Leland Sobel, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gelberg of Teaneck, N.J., have announced. Mr. Sobel is the son of Mrs. Bernard S. Berkowitz of West Orange, N.J., and the late Martin Sobel.

LEAD: Like many other Jewish scientists in the Soviet Union, Aleksandr Lerner was long denied permission to emigrate because, officials said, he knew too much. Mr. Lerner, a leader in the campaign for Jewish emigration, is a specialist in cybernetics, and Soviet authorities for 17 years denied him an exit visa on the ground that his research had given him access to state secrets.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 7 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $4.95.) Nightmarish experiences befall a woman appointed Ambassador to Rumania. 2 8 GARDEN OF SHADOWS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The beginnings of the evil that beset the Dollanganger family in previous novels.

LEAD: EVER SINCE THE ADVENT OF the compact disk, the record companies' release lists have been filling up with reissues of back catalogue. But their activities heretofore in this regard paled beside the reissue onslaught of 1987. Not that it's surprising, or even bad: the CD has become the format of choice among classical-music record buyers, and naturally one wants as many valuable recordings as possible from the analogue era to remain readily available.
LEAD: The carpenter building a wall of what is to be a new apartment was helping to fulfill a dream for Julia and Sonia Abrew.

LEAD: AFTER a four-year jury trial, probably the longest in United States history, a court in Belleville, Ill., decided in October that 65 citizens of a small Missouri town had not been harmed when a chemical used as a wood preservative was spilled in a 1979 railroad accident. Nevertheless, the jurors awarded the plaintiffs $16 million in punitive damages against the manufacturer, the Monsanto Company, for not ridding its product of dioxin, a potentially dangerous contaminant, and failing to warn the public about it.
LEAD: A wonder drug for heart-attack victims. A book of zany but thought-provoking questions. Exciting advances in superconductivity. Buying postage stamps by phone.

LEAD: Much time has elapsed since the article ''Hempstead Opens Tap on Development''; I've waited weeks for a letter to the Long Island editor to appear such as that of Louise Czajkowski of East Meadow: ''Lawns Turn Brown, Pockets Are Green.'' Right on target, Louise! The Civic Action Council of Nassau County has attempted for some years to persuade our county and town governments to acknowledge that there is a problem relative to preservation of Long Island's fresh drinking water.

LEAD: Li Xiaoyan remembers the day he began working for his master's degree in business administration from an American university.

This was not immediate cause for alarm. To the contrary, what was happening was that a crucial problem that had plagued me since college was being resolved before my ears.

LEAD: AT SOME UNMARKED MO-ment in the departing year, a milestone was passed. The 50 millionth VCR had been sold in the United States. According to demographers who relate such figures to lifestyles, this means video tape has now settled into half of all American households.

LEAD: THE TOXIC CLOUD. By Michael H. Brown. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) Michael Brown is our Paul Revere of toxic pollution. As a reporter who broke the story of the burial of poisonous chemicals beneath a residential community at the Love Canal, and in his subsequent book, ''Laying Waste,'' Mr. Brown was among the first to cry the alarm about toxic waste dumps.

LEAD: PEOPLE buying insurance to cover medical emergencies on a trip are generally less knowledgeable than homeowners buying house insurance. Medical travel insurance is so new that many buyers may not ask all the right questions.

LEAD: In a country with a record for providing refuge to fugitive Nazis, ousted dictators and prominent drug traffickers, the arrival of a well-known former Croatian terrorist here this month caused only a minor stir.

LEAD: Lewis C. Coffin, a former law librarian of the Library of Congress, died of cancer Monday at his home in Washington. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: AFTERrr almost six years of stalled starts and testy sessions, the New York City Council last week passed a comprehensive antismoking bill that is expected to become law in April.

LEAD: Deborah Edmonds with her 20-month-old son Stephen at Washoe Medical Center in Reno on Friday. The child was trapped under water for 24 minutes Monday when a car he was in skidded off a road and into a lake. On Christmas Day the child recognized his mother for the first time since the accident. The child is still listed in serious condition.

LEAD: MOTOR vehicles kill more deer in New York state each year than do hunters in Vermont, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Connecticut and Rhode Island combined, the comparative totals being 30,000 and 28,500.

LEAD: IN 1981, President Reagan persuaded Congress to adopt many of his proposals tightening eligibility and limiting benefits in the main welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children. Emphasizing the importance of the work ethic, Administration officials said A.F.D.C. should be restricted to those who could not work because they were old or disabled or had to care for young children.

LEAD: The Styrofoam box with two compartments keeps the burger hot while the lettuce and tomato stay cool and crisp. But at what cost to the environment? The white plastic packages create hazardous waste. Tons of nonbiodegradable boxes and cups strain the nation's overflowing landfills. Burning can generate toxic emissions.

LEAD: THE EXTRAORDINARY EVENT in architecture in 1987 was surely the building that collapsed before it was ever built: the tower designed by Moshe Safdie for the site of the New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle. What was extraordinary was not the actual design for this building, which was a wretched piece of architecture, but the circumstances surrounding its demise.
