LEAD: WHERE is the stock market headed? That question has been topmost in many minds since the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 22 percent to 1,738.74 on Oct. 19.

LEAD: AS if the onset of gray, endless January were not enough to handle, we are expected, as the new year begins, to make an effort to change our slovenly selves into something more respectable. Resolutions are demanded, those doomed-to-failure promises at self-improvement that we feebly attempt to keep each year.

LEAD: Fourteen years of relentless dictatorship have done little to concentrate Chilean democrats' minds on the future. A recent visit showed the opposition to be as divided today as it was in September 1973. That's when a military coup, supported by centrist and right-wing civilian parties, ended the elected Socialist presidency of Salvador Allende and with it, Chile's democratic political life.
LEAD: Banks and property-and-casualty insurers, their earnings already weak, are furious over a new accounting rule that is likely to depress their earnings further.

LEAD: Although the passage of New York State's $1.45 billion Environmental Quality Bond Act showed strong public support for environmental protection, the State Legislature failed to enact any significant environmental legislation in its last session, a report published recently by the Environmental Planning Lobby asserts.
LEAD: Rewi Alley, a New Zealander who came to China in 1927 and stayed 60 years to help the Communist cause, died Sunday in Beijing, the official New China News Agency reported. He was 90 years old.

LEAD: The mother of one of four teen-agers who committed suicide together in Bergenfield in March has filed suit against a hospital and several employees, charging that they failed to diagnose the youth as suicidal a week before he died.

LEAD: In the last few years under Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, Merck & Company's army of 3,400 research scientists have had the golden touch in developing new drugs. Led by Vasotec, a blood pressure drug, which some analysts say will nudge $1 billion in sales in 1988, 13 of Merck's new products have each registered sales of $100 million or more.
LEAD: Thousands of Afghan refugees gathered at rallies in Pakistan today to mark the eighth anniversary of the Soviet military invervention in Afghanistan.

LEAD: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the leader of Libya, met today with the Iranian Foreign Minister in Tripoli, Libya's official news agency reported. Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati, who arrived in the Libyan capital Saturday, was accompanied by an Iranian delegation, according to the report, which was monitored in Rome.

LEAD: Several weeks ago, Harry Weltman, the Nets' general manager, found little to no interest on the National Basketball Association market for Dwayne (Pearl) Washington. If Weltman were to try to move Washington based on his showing in the last four games, he would likely find a decided change in demand.

LEAD: Four-and-a-half months after Nathan Quinones announced that he was stepping down as New York City's Schools Chancellor, the search for a successor to run the nation's largest public school system is nearing an end.

LEAD: Alexander G. Barmine, a brigadier general in the Soviet Army who defected in 1937 and became an influential journalist and a United States Government official, died Friday at a nursing home in Rockville, Md. He died of complications resulting from a stroke.

LEAD: ''When they arrested all these people last week, they said they were just arresting the 'organizers.' One thousand organizers? In 10 years they will just have to put a wall up around the whole West Bank and Gaza Strip to arrest all of the organizers.'' - Ibrahim Karaeen, a Palestinian in East Jerusalem.

LEAD: A man who was freed from prison after the woman who had accused him of rape recanted was denied bond today on new charges of battery and disorderly conduct. He may have to finish his original 25-to-50-year sentence.

LEAD: A demonstrator hurling a gasoline bomb at a riot police bus protest yesterday in Seoul. About 200 people took part in demonstration protesting suspected voting irregularities. The demonstration followed a peaceful two-hour rally on the grounds of Myongdong Cathedral by about 2,500 people, also protesting sus-pected voting irregularities.

LEAD: Does America need a new ''Nutcracker''? The Joffrey Ballet thinks it does, and on the strength of its conviction it has mounted a new production of the balletic fairy tale that receives its New York premiere on Wednesday at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

LEAD: * Apple Computer Inc., San Francisco, nominated the former astronaut Sally Ride as a director on its six-member board to replace Henry Singleton, chairman of Teledyne Inc. who is not standing for re-election.

LEAD: Twenty-five people or more were believed to have been killed today after ethnic Tamil rebels shot and killed a policeman and then battled policemen and Indian soldiers in a gunfight at a crowded market, witnesses said.
LEAD: The number of bottlenose dolphins found dead on Florida beaches since Thanksgiving has risen to 28, and officials fear that a mysterious disease is moving south along the East Coast.

LEAD: For months, the Y-shaped concrete pillars flanking the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in lower Manhattan resembled a latter-day Stonehenge, akin to the original monoliths in their apparent futility but distinguished by their spray-painted graffiti.
LEAD: Six years ago, a lanky, 6-foot-10-inch Dutch youth named Rik Smits laid his enormous fingers on a basketball for the first time.

LEAD: FOR several minutes after the Giants' 20-7 victory, Joe Walton stood in a corner of the Jets' locker room, providing predictable answers to predictable questions. But when the Jets' coach spoke of how ''there will be a 1988,'' somebody asked him if Jim Kensil, the Jets' president, had assured him that he would return next season.
LEAD: Elizabeth Martin Sanford, mother of Senator Terry Sanford of North Carolina, died Saturday after a heart attack she suffered in a holiday visit to her son's home. She was 99.
LEAD: IT may be just an illusion, but Rony Seikaly says that Coach Jim Boeheim is more relaxed as Syracuse enters the 1987-88 Big East Conference season.

LEAD: Over the centuries, Christian clerics have offered their blessings to everything from the hounds before the hunt to battleships going off to war. Why then should they withhold their blessing from a homosexual couple who have decided to lead a loving, monogamous relationship?
LEAD: The Government of Singapore this weekend restricted the circulation of one of Asia's most influential publications, the weekly Far Eastern Economic Review.
LEAD: The scene is the Oregon State Penitentiary. Several hundred inmates crowd into a steamy gymnasium with a 12-foot ceiling, hoping to see some of their more athletic peers win a basketball game.

LEAD: Despite more than two decades of intensive Federal and state assistance, the depressed coal counties of southwestern Virginia are making little progress in catching up economically with the rest of the state, a major study has found.

LEAD: QUESTION: Don Mattingly set a major-league record with six grand slams this past season. How many did the Yankees hit altogether, and what team holds the mark for bases-filled home runs in a season?
LEAD: In a holiday-shortened week, when activity is normally reduced by the absence of many traders and investors, little new financing is expected in the credit markets.

LEAD: NOBODY knows what 1988 will bring for the stock and bond markets, but James S. Riepe, director of the mutual fund division of T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore, seems sure of one thing. ''It's going to be harder to sell mutual funds than it has been in recent years,'' he said.
LEAD: Sport fishing has come a long way since the days of bamboo poles and twine. Now comes a touch of technological wizardry that may leave even the most tournament-crazed angler wanting.

LEAD: In this season of the strike and the replacement games, with coaches who complain about a certain torpor, and uncertainty taking the field each Sunday, things are still going great in the National Football League.
LEAD: Not long ago, Julie Houston of Brooklyn found $49 on the street and asked her children what treat they would like with the found money.

LEAD: If you haven't yet picked a place for dinner on New Year's Eve, you might consult the Zagat New York City Restaurant Survey. The pocket-size guide lists 740 dining establishments, from Abyssinia to Zucchini, the overwhelming majority of them in Manhattan. Each is rated on food, decor, service and cost.

LEAD: Dr. Cathy Ann Colt, a resident in ophthalmology at the Wills Eye Hospital in Philadelphia, and Dr. Roger James Pomerantz, the chief medical resident at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, were married yesterday at the Harvard Memorial Chapel at Harvard University. Rabbi Albert Ginsberg officiated.

LEAD: New York State will increase the housing allowances of welfare families by an average of 13 percent on Jan. 1. But public officials, community leaders, housing specialists, welfare recipients and landlords assert that the allowances, less than most rents in New York City, will be inadequate to stop an increase in homeless families.

LEAD: Behind the Palestinian riots of the last few weeks is a story about fathers and sons -Palestinian fathers and the sons over whom they may have lost control.
LEAD: Saudi Arabia accused Iran today of seeking to impose alien ideologies on fellow Moslem nations in the Arab world to the detriment of the Arab campaign against Israel.

LEAD: The marriage of Mary Elizabeth Klinger and Dr. Joseph Anthony Salerno took place yesterday at the Rockland Lake Manor in Congers, N.Y. The Rev. Giles Spoonhour, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Palestinian schools in the West Bank, closed by the army as a security measure a week ago, reopened today as combat-equipped soldiers patrolled the main streets and entrances to refugee centers.

LEAD: The beginning was simple enough: on Sept. 12, 1983, a Wells Fargo guard robbed a depot in West Hartford. Getting to the end, however, has turned into what some lawyers are calling one of the lengthiest and most complex criminal cases in Federal court history.
LEAD: Some interesting ideas in bridge organization have come from Sweden, and slowly made an impact on this side of the Atlantic.

LEAD: Economic crises in Brazil, Mexico and Argentina, occurring simultaneously for the first time since Latin America's debt troubles began five years ago, are casting a pall over the region's relations with its foreign creditors.

LEAD: The reports that the conservative leader of Bavaria will visit Moscow next week and the Soviet Foreign Minister will come to Bonn next month appear to signal a revived Soviet diplomatic initiative toward West Germany.

LEAD: Travelers who hauled large, heavy bags aboard planes when they left for their holiday trips may find a surprise on return flights as tighter restrictions on carry-on luggage take effect on New Year's Day.

LEAD: Eric Dickerson ran for 196 yards and two touchdowns today as the Indianapolis Colts won the American Confernce Eastern Division title and gained their first playoff berth in a decade with a 24-6 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.
LEAD: The Government agency that insures almost $2 trillion in deposits at the nation's commercial banks could record the first annual loss in its 54-year history, its chairman says.

LEAD: Looking for some kind of advantage for his struggling Knicks, Coach Rick Pitino mapped a new game plan Saturday night against the Atlanta Hawks, who trail the Detroit Pistons by one-half game in the Central Division.

LEAD: Parking lots at schools are crowded with mothers in mini-vans picking up their children. Young executives park their BMW's and Volvos on weekends to drive their Jeeps to the country club or their vacation homes. The payload in a pickup these days is as likely to be a surfboard as a sheet of plywood.

LEAD: The dramatic disclosures by the Sandinista Defense Minister, Humberto Ortega Saavedra, and by Maj. Roger Miranda Bengoechea, the Sandinista defector, have opponents of aid to the contras grasping at straws.

LEAD: As Congress rushed to adjourn last week, Senator Daniel K. Inouye persuaded colleagues to appropriate $8 million to build Jewish schools in France in a project supported by a campaign contributor but opposed by the State Department.

LEAD: Luxury hotels, with their hot-towel racks, monogrammed robes and perfumed soaps, have proliferated in the capital over the last 10 years, to the point that the market is engaged in a trade war of sorts.
LEAD: One man was killed and four people were injured on Staten Island early yesterday morning when a car racing down Hylan Boulevard spun out of control and burst into flames, the police said.

LEAD: The murder of a Hasidic Jew in a ferocious knife attack in Brooklyn remained a mystery yesterday as detectives sought witnesses and a motive while neighborhood residents held a demonstration and voiced fears that the killing was anti-Semitic.

LEAD: The Year of the Fan Audiences at the World Series, the Super Bowl and many other events this year shared the spotlight with the players. And the athletes, for the most part, appreciated it. LEAD: In a yearend review, the National Organization for Women went beyond well-publicized episodes to recall events that may have escaped public notice. The review, which was compiled by the group's Legal Defense and Education Fund, considered some of the events as progress, others as reverses.
LEAD: The results of this year's Christmas shopping season, reflecting in part the effect of the stock market doldrums and hinting at next year's economy, were disappointing across the nation.

LEAD: For many years, the Federal Government has emulated New York City's pre-1975 spending and borrowing practices. Since 1980, the Government has outdone New York's most financially irresponsible conduct. It has borrowed recklessly, first from ourselves, then from the rest of the world, to finance a huge defense program, significant tax cuts and continuously growing social programs such as Social Security.

LEAD: The search for a twin-engine commuter plane missing since Wednesday night with eight people aboard was called off today, and a newspaper reported that the pilot had been having trouble with his door before the plane vanished.

LEAD: Intense competition among ship and submarine builders is prompting many contractors to submit unrealistically low bids for Navy contracts, leading to huge cost overruns that the Navy must help absorb, a General Accounting Office report concludes.

LEAD: The awful season ended today on the upside for the Giants and with another disappointment for the Jets. The Giants played well on offense and especially well on defense, and won the battle between the metropolitan area's two professional football teams, 20-7.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In an effort to hasten the approval of the new treaty on intermediate range missiles, the Reagan Administration has begun quiet negotiations with Senate Democratic leaders on the politically sensitive issue of how all treaties are made and interpreted.
LEAD: Anthony West, the critic and novelist, died yesterday at his home in Stonington, Conn., after suffering a stroke. He was 73 years old and also kept a home on Fisher's Island, N.Y.

LEAD: IT was nearly 4 P.M. on a damp, overcast winter day when Keith Redrup stopped his group of walkers on a tree-lined country lane here and announced dramatically that they had reached a ''point of no return.'' They could either walk straight to their cars, about two miles away, and bring their Sunday afternoon jaunt to a close after a respectable six-mile distance, or they could add an extra two miles and stop at a nearby farm where the farmer's wife was waiting to serve tea with scones, cream and jam.

LEAD: Summer Tale prompted pace-setting Mugatea to the stretch, then took the lead and raced to an easy 7 1/2-length victory yesterday in the $70,900 Alex M. Robb Stakes for New Yorkbred 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct.

LEAD: THE United States Davis Cup team has played five of its last six home matches indoors, even in the middle of summer when the rest of the tennis-playing world is competing outside. Why? Because indoor tennis removes the natural elements as factors in determining the outcome of a match, and there have been instances in which the United States Tennis Association felt that Mother Nature contributed as much to an American defeat as the opposition.
LEAD: For Richard J. Ferris, the former chairman and chief executive of the Allegis Corporation, 1987 will not be a year of fond memories.

LEAD: Vice President Bush is taking a respite from his political toils with a short vacation in Kennebunkport, Me. On his return trip to Washington next weekend, the Republican Presidential contender will fly over Boston but, being a Yale man, does not plan to drop in at Harvard for a televised interview to which he had been invited.

LEAD: After almost two years as one of the Federal authorities' most wanted fugitives, former New Jersey State Senator David J. Friedland was snared last week by his own success as an operator of a chain of scuba diving shops on an island in the Indian Ocean, a Federal marshal said yesterday.

LEAD: Former Senator Ralph Yarborough, 84 years old, continues to improve after heart surgery Tuesday and probably will be released from Seton Medical Center within a week, a hospital spokeswoman said today. ''The Senator is making steady progress,'' said M. A. Bengston, the hospital's information director.
LEAD: If you are one of those people who think the 1988 Presidential campaign started too soon, you almost certainly aren't ready to contemplate the 1990 census.

LEAD: At the Beth Jacob Congregation in San Diego, June Stacey Cummins, a doctoral candidate in English at Columbia University, was married yesterday to Jonathan David Lewis, a doctoral candidate in physics at Cornell University. Rabbi Eliezer Langer performed the ceremony.
LEAD: An agency that helps crime victims paid $4,140 for a healing ceremony performed by a Navajo medicine man after physicians said they could not remove a bullet from the chest of a wounded Indian.

LEAD: A report on Tuesday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misidentified the assistant editor of Roll Call, a Capitol Hill newspaper.
LEAD: Penn and Teller, the comic co-conspirators, are performing these days on a Broadway stage once trod by Alfred Lunt, Claudette Colbert, Leslie Howard and Dame Sybil Thorndike.
LEAD: Tony Griffin, a starting cornerback for Texas, failed a drug test and has been declared ineligible for the Bluebonnet Bowl game Thursday night, Coach David McWilliams of Texas said today.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission is reviewing a proposal from the American Stock Exchange that would make it easier for sophisticated investors in the United States to trade securities issued by foreign corporations that do not register with the commission.

LEAD: For years, Ibrahima Camara dreamed of opening a carpentry workshop to make wooden chairs to sell to his neighbors. Such a project, however, was prohibited by what was known as the Peoples Revolutionary Republic of Guinea, which restricted chair production to a state-owned furniture factory.
LEAD: At St. John's United Church of Christ in Meadville, Pa., Diane Shafer Strachan was married yesterday to Dr. Larry Allan Graham. The Rev. Donald Engler performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Fire destroyed a hotel today and killed three children in the town of Taneatua, 150 miles south of Auckland, the police said.

LEAD: AFTER months of growing debate over pension laws and how to reduce the mountainous deficit of the Federal agency that insures pension payments, sweeping changes were enacted last week that will significantly affect the payments companies must make and the guidelines under which employers must operate.
LEAD: A Vietnamese military officer writing in an army journal has acknowledged that Hanoi's soldiers are waging ''fierce and complicated'' psychological battles in Cambodia.

LEAD: A chemical-laden freight train derailed Saturday near this east Texas city and burned through the night, causing Federal and state environmental officials to monitor water in the area today for possible contamination.

LEAD: The University of Illinois at Chicago, its sports teams known as the Flames, has 25,000 students and has had for the last six seasons a Division I hockey team. The coach, Val Belmonte, came from Harvard where he was Bill Cleary's assistant for three seasons.

LEAD: A poll indicated today that the Iowa race between Senator Bob Dole and Vice President Bush remains close six weeks before the state's precinct caucuses, a key test of the Republican Presidential campaign.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Holiday sales disappointed retailers across the nation. Although results averaged about 3 percent more than last year, most merchants suffered declines in real terms. A telephone survey indicated that sales varied among types of stores, with those catering to the affluent showing the biggest rises.

LEAD: N. J. Transit will seek a significant increase in state aid to maintain bus and train fares at current levels for the fiscal year beginning next July 1, according to the head of the the state transit agency.

LEAD: An American sailor died today from wounds received Saturday in a bomb attack on a U.S.O. club, the fourth against American targets in Barcelona this year. Rival Catalan separatist groups took responsibility for the bombing, in which nine other sailors were wounded.

LEAD: A glittering new museum overlooking ruins of the Aztecs' Great Temple displays treasures found in the 14th-century ceremonial center that now is the heart of downtown.

LEAD: Donald E. Petersen, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, has every reason to face the coming year with confidence. When financial results for 1987 are reported, Ford is almost certain to be more profitable than the mighty General Motors Corporation - for the second year in a row.
LEAD: Prime Computer Inc., going around the Computervision Corporation's management, is offering shareholders about $400 million for the maker of automated design and manufacturing systems.

LEAD: A former state trooper who was serving two consecutive life terms for murder until his escape two weeks ago has sent a letter of apology to the head of the state's prison system but says he has no plans to return.

LEAD: India has received nine more Mirage 2000 jet fighters from France, the United News of India said today. The Indian Air Force, which relies heavily on Soviet combat aircraft, now has 49 Mirages, the news agency said.

LEAD: Every Wednesday at one of Moscow's most fearsome addresses, 38 Petrovka St., the local police meet the Soviet press to report the latest incidents of exploding television sets, snatchings of fur hats, vodka moonshining and other constabulary notes from all over Moscow.

LEAD: Almost one-quarter of the public schools in New York City have inadequate lighting and more than a quarter need major roof repairs, according to a report released yesterday by the Board of Education's Task Force on Capital Financing and Construction.
LEAD: Israeli officials said today that Israeli soldiers had resorted to using live ammunition against Palestinian demonstrators when their own lives were endangered.

LEAD: As the Democratic candidates plod on to their first event before real voters in Iowa, the public is finally turning its attention from personalities to policies. Even taking the leading non-candidate at his word that he's not running, Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York will open himself to such attention in a few days when he delivers his 1988 State of the State address.

LEAD: This Indian Ocean island-state, a vigorous multiparty democracy with a racially and culturally diverse population, is in the midst of an economic boom that is based in good measure on trade, tourism and investment ties with South Africa.
LEAD: One of the main tasks of the Philippines, according to the new Foreign Secretary, Raul Manglapus, is to deal with ''the American father image.''

LEAD: Diana Melamid and Stephen Bruce Henderson were married yesterday at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough-on-Hudson, N.Y., by Arthur E. Sullivan, the village justice of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

LEAD: Two weeks ago, Walt Poddubny stood on the boardwalk in Rye, N.Y., and stared into the cold afternoon breeze, smiling broadly as his wife and three dogs worked their way toward him along the beach. It was a raw day, he hadn't been home in a week, and he wanted nothing more than an afternoon of solitude.

LEAD: More than 2,000 tour guides and interpreters staged a 24-hour strike in Portugal today, complaining that tour operators were illegally employing foreign guides who were not qualified. About 200 strikers blocked a road leading to Faro Airport on the Algarve coast for 30 minutes.

LEAD: Jascha Heifetz, who died on Dec. 12 at the age of 86, was unforgettable in every way. It was not only that he was the greatest virtuoso after Paganini, and that he set all standards for 20th-century violin playing.

LEAD: MAYBE you won't need a program to tell one character from another in ''Us,'' but it can't hurt. Although there are only two actors in Karen Malpede's play at the Theater for the New City, they take six parts, and the action occurs in three countries over an unchronological period of about 40 years.

LEAD: Early this year, as record trade deficits fueled the drive for trade protectionism in Congress, the name of Representative Richard A. Gephardt became almost synonymous with the issue. His proposal that would require retaliation against Japan and other countries that have trade surpluses with the United States became known as the Gephardt Amendment.
LEAD: The dollar fell to new lows against the yen this morning, dropping as low as 123.30 yen amid pessimism over the prospects for changes in American fiscal policy.

LEAD: The primary defendants in what has become known universally as the Howard Beach case have been convicted in the courts for the tragic death of Michael Griffith, who was struck down by a car while he and two other black men fled an angry mob of neighborhood toughs in all-white Howard Beach a year ago.
LEAD: Charles H. Malik, a former Foreign Minister of Lebanon who was president of the United Nations General Assembly in 1958-59, died today after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

LEAD: A 20-year-old man was found shot dead in a Brooklyn building lobby yesterday with a bolt apparently fired from a crossbow. The building is known as a drug-dealing spot, and the police said the killing appeared to be drug-related.

LEAD: Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a New York brokerage, said it would seek representation on the board of Allegheny International Inc., a diversified manufacturer based in Pittsburgh. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Spear, Leeds also said it had raised its stake in Allegheny's $11.25 convertible preferred stock to 24.6 percent, from 23.4 percent.
LEAD: A judge blocked California from enforcing a new law today requiring women under the age of 18 to get parental consent before obtaining an abortion.

LEAD: MENTION Avon Products Inc. and Wall Street professionals immediately think of the $2 annual dividend rate on the common stock that has been paid regularly since 1983. Most analysts believe Avon's dividend is secure for now, but its safety is like a shadow that keeps lingering over the stock.

LEAD: FREEDOM of the press belongs to those who own one, a remark by the late A. J. Liebling, is line that is practically obligatory in articles about desktop publishing. Proponents see the ability to produce professional-looking publications with a minimum investment as being as important as the development of the automobile; to detractors, it's more like gridlock.

LEAD: As the only former professional athlete among the Presidential candidates, Representative Jack F. Kemp apparently could not resist combining a holiday break in his campaign schedule with a family skiing vacation offering great photo opportunity potential. So the Kemp family assembled the day after Christmas in -where else?

LEAD: THANKS to medical-evacuation methods perfected in the Vietnam War and neurosurgery in specialized hospital trauma centers, tens of thousands of Americans survive brutal highway and other accidents that would have meant certain death only a decade ago.

LEAD: It's that time of year again, Tom Claflin noted the other day as he paid a call on the Citizens State Bank here - time to settle the last of this year's debts and clear the way for a new round of borrowing, planting and harvesting.

LEAD: Tucked away at the end of a narrow winding staircase atop a candy store in a back alley of East Jerusalem is probably the best source of information on the Palestinian rioting of the last few weeks.
LEAD: IN the current issue of The Sporting News, that estimable and indispensable periodical, there is a headline that reads, ''Man of the Year? See Page 4.''

LEAD: Lary J. Mielke, a Los Angeles shopping center developer, took possession last week of his most ambitious project so far. He leads an investor group that bought the historic Huntington Hotel in Pasadena, Calif., from its Japanese owners and promised to spend $40 million to reopen it by 1990.

LEAD: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States last week fell by 23, to 1,145, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today. A year ago, the count totaled 988.

LEAD: Hebe Dorsey, the fashion editor of The International Herald Tribune and a major figure in the fashion world, died of cancer yesterday morning at the American Hospital in Neuilly-sur-Seine, near Paris. She was 62 years old and had been working for the paper for about 40 years.

LEAD: A man wielding two revolvers killed two people, wounded four others and briefly took a hostage before surrendering today, the authorities said. Police officers later found five other people dead at his house, all tentatively identified as his relatives, and were searching for at least six other family members still unaccounted for.

LEAD: An article on Saturday about Cuban-Americans who live in Miami misstated the distance between that city and Havana. It is 230 miles.

LEAD: Q. Many people get a pain below the ribcage when they run. What causes this pain? A. Several things can cause such a ''stitch'' or cramp, said Dr. Averil Ma, a gastroenterology fellow at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. For example, he said, if someone ate a heavy meal and then ''started doing something else that demands blood flow, there would be relative ischemia,'' or a reduction of blood supply to the intestines; this would produce a cramp.
LEAD: Theatrical showmanship lives.

LEAD: Police arresting a demonstrator yesterday in Dhaka during a parade in support of a general strike planned for today. Opponents of Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, the President, have called for the strike to demand his resignation. Police said the parade was broken up because it violated a state of emergency declared after a drive for General Ershad's ouster began in November.

LEAD: These are the final days of a decree mandating desegregation of Louisiana universities, but a dispute has arisen over whether the six-year agreement, signed in 1981, should be extended while the state struggles to overcome a fiscal crisis highlighted by a projected annual deficit of about $300 million.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has apparently moved another step closer to participating in the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul.

LEAD: This city's black community has stepped in to try to pay hundreds of thousands of dollars in hospital bills for Tabatha Foster, a 3-year-old black girl from Kentucky who two months ago received a five-organ transplant at Children's Hospital here.

LEAD: A Federal district judge today scheduled for June 13 the trial of a lawsuit by the trustee for E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. against Marvin Warner intended to recover assets lost during the collapse of E.S.M.

LEAD: Stephen Gordon Glatzer, founder and president of two corporations that design, manufacture and sell aviation search-and-rescue equipment, died Saturday at the hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx after a long illness. He was 51 years old and lived in New Rochelle.
LEAD: A white dove curls toward the sky on a billboard splashed with soft pastels of green and blue. The visual message is made explicit in the words below the affecting scene: ''We want peace.''

LEAD: Joel Benjamin of Brooklyn and Nick DeFirmian of San Francisco tied for first place in the 33d United States Championship in Estes Park, Colo. The two grandmasters scored 8-5, and each was awarded $4,675 in the 14-player round-robin tournament at the Stanley Hotel.

LEAD: Nearly 200 years ago the Founding Fathers drafted a Bill of Rights whose first 16 words insured freedom of worship and separation of church and state to the citizens of the new nation. Now, a Senator, a retired Chief Justice and a British scholar have concluded that that freedom of religion has come on difficult times.

LEAD: * Bruce L. Kelley has joined biIngalls, Quinn & Johnson, Boston, as executive vice president, director of account service.

LEAD: What sort of person rides a Quadrunner LT50, a tiny but muscular four-wheel, all-terrain vehicle that can sprint at 25 miles an hour, pop a weak wheelie and grind its way over small tree stumps? Try a 4-year-old. ''I've even seen 3-year-olds ride it,'' said Craig Gironda, general manager of Stamford Cycle and Sled, an all-terrain-vehicle dealership here.

LEAD: An investigation of a scandal involving contaminated drugs that killed 14 people in a local hospital two years ago has provided a glimpse of the murky world of politics, business and bureaucracy in India.

LEAD: The son of the founder of the Emery Air Freight Corporation announced his retirement as chairman and chief executive yesterday, and he was replaced by a board member who had never worked for the company. No reasons were given for the unexpected moves.
LEAD: The trouble did not spill over here, but the anger did, and so did the futility.

LEAD: The future of one of the nation's most prestigious high school basketball tournaments - the Seagull Classic in Absecon, N.J. - has been jeopardized by a brawl among spectators that the police said was related to a drug ''turf war'' and had nothing to do with the event.

LEAD: ''SCARED SEXLESS'' is glossy, attractive and inane, even if it does warn at the beginning, ''Parental discretion advised.'' Discretion about what, for goodness' sake? The NBC News report, on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock tonight, acts as if it just discovered s-e-x.
LEAD: An article yesterday about a bill in Congress allowing states to raise the speed limit on some highways misstated the origin of the 55-mile limit.

LEAD: If Congress follows through on legislation to set up more systematic national testing of schoolchildren, the country's political and educational leaders will soon find themselves making some important decisions about how to judge the success or failure of American schools.
LEAD: Homeless people packed New York City's shelters and transportation centers last night as temperatures plummeted into the teens and gusty winds created wind chills of below zero.

LEAD: BILL BARRON belongs to a Philadelphia tenor saxophone tradition that has included Jimmy Heath, John Coltrane and, more recently, Odean Pope. If there's any single characteristic that would justify describing a Philadelphia ''school,'' it's the combination of a formidable technical fluency with the tendency for each player to work out his own system of interval permutations - the improviser as comprehensive music theorist.

LEAD: Seeming to mirror the very essence of the capital -confusing directions, stop-and-go policies, swings to the right meeting resistance from the left - a group of idle traffic signals await a return to active duty at Ninth and L Streets N.W., where subway tunnel construction is under way. (NYT/Paul Hosefros)

LEAD: In the suburban igloo of sheet metal and cement that serves as the practice facility for the Philadelphia Flyers, several dozen people had gathered outside the team's locker room one morning this week. They dug their hands deep into their pockets, stomped their feet in the furtherance of renewed circulation and tried to look around their own breath, which plumed visibly into the frigid air.
LEAD: Four black men were arrested yesterday in what the police said was a racially motivated attack on a white taxicab driver in Washington Heights last Wednesday.

LEAD: Hanson Publishing Group of Stamford, Conn., whose titles include Folio: The Magazine for Magazine Management, is coming out with still another publication for the trade. The monthly tabloid, called Publishing News, will cover news in the magazine publishing industry, while Folio comes out with how-to feature articles in the same field.
LEAD: AT the local fish market I have been impressed lately by the supply of ready-to-cook skate, a fish that just a few years ago was rarely found outside seafood restaurants.

LEAD: Now that the season's games have been won and lost (mostly lost), Coach Bill Parcells is about to sit down and figure out how to make the Giants winners again. Although the Giants, one season after winning the Super Bowl, fell to 6-9, they do not seem to need an overhaul. Instead, parts need fixing.

LEAD: The National Basketball Players Association turned down the league's request yesterday to return to the bargaining table. Responding to the request made Monday by Russ Granik, the league's executive vice president and chief negotiator, Larry Fleisher, the union's general counsel, said in a letter:

LEAD: Prices of Treasury issues advanced yesterday, largely because of an unexpected rise in institutional buying that persisted well into the trading session. Dealers said these buyers were encouraged that the central banks in the major industrial nations had intervened to support the dollar.

LEAD: President Reagan's national security adviser made it clear in a letter distributed today that the Soviet Union had reserved the right to abandon a proposed arms-reduction accord if the United States tested ''Star Wars'' components in space.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The headline of the N.B.A. Notebook article in Sports Pages yesterday was incorrect. While the owners have invited the National Basketball Players Association back to the bargaining table, the union has not agreed to talk.
LEAD: Sixteen years of Republican control of Suffolk County ends Friday as a Democrat, Patrick G. Halpin, moves into the County Executive's office.
LEAD: THERE was wonderful junk on stage Monday night at the Joyce Theater.

LEAD: Four former officials of the Interior Ministry, who were convicted of murdering a priest who supported the Solidarity labor movement, have been given shorter prison sentences, Government officials said today.

LEAD: Hundreds of homeless people live in the park behind the sprawling shelter here, where blue tents line the fence and fires flicker all night in steel drums. LEAD: There is no longer any doubt: The party wasn't waning, it was just waiting for a winner.

LEAD: Defenders of Wildlife, a Washington-based conservation and animal welfare group, is something of a lion's den for its chief executives, having gone through three presidents in the last five years.

LEAD: A bowl game is college football's equivalent of a corporate convention, mixing business and pleasure. That mix, however, is not necessarily the same for all teams. While Auburn, under Pat Dye, has become accustomed to receiving postseason invitations, Syracuse is treating the Sugar Bowl as an adventure.

LEAD: ''Le Corsaire'' is a three-act ballet whose title is more famous than its choreography. For the thousands who were dazzled by Rudolf Nureyev and Dame Margot Fonteyn in the 1960's and 1970's, ''Le Corsaire'' meant only the pas de deux that became their celebrated signature piece.
LEAD: Ivan F. Boesky was not there, but many of the 100 or so people could still feel his presence in the Manhattan office where he once conducted billion-dollar deals.

LEAD: How to tell Democrats from Republicans? Some clues are offered in a new work, ''The Dorsey Dictionary of American Government and Politics,'' by Jay M. Shafritz, a professor in the Graduate School of Public and International Affairs at the University of Pittsburgh.

LEAD: South Korea's three main auto companies said today that they plan to increase exports by 23.4 percent next year. The companies' 1988 export targets total 679,000 vehicles, mostly small cars, up from 550,000 vehicles in 1987.
LEAD: On the eve of the New Year, Frances Steloff - one of the most revered booksellers in the United States - turns 100.

LEAD: Dr. Silvia Flores lives near the Atlantic ocean in an upper-middle-class section in the northeastern part of this city, the largest city in Broward County. The Mexico-born pediatrician is president of the socially prominent Broward International Women's Club, which she joined in 1977 when her family came to Florida.

LEAD: Rockets 101, Pistons 91: Joe Barry Carroll scored 25 points as the visiting Rockets outscored the Pistons, 15-7, in the final 5 minutes 41 seconds last night to break the Pistons' 10-game winning streak. The loss prevented the Pistons from setting a franchise record for consecutive victories. They had tied the mark set Feb.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has intensified its surveillance of the copper market while an impending shortage has sent prices soaring, according to agency officials.

LEAD: Sitting at his mother's kitchen table near Los Angeles in 1982, Andy Heyward and a French businessman, Jean Chalopin, developed the idea for a television cartoon series on a crime-solving handyman. After drawing a few sketches, Inspector Gadget was born. The men have since built a powerhouse in television animation.

LEAD: HE'S 73 years old, but his hair is still more the reddish shade of a basketball than gray. And as the new year approaches, Frank McGuire is planning his new home. After it's built among the pine trees of Columbia, S.C., this New York Irishman everybody still calls Coach will sit with his wife, Jane, and his son, Frankie, and watch television or entertain friends.
LEAD: WHEN I was growing up the Italian word melanzana had two meanings.

LEAD: The junta that destroyed an independent election at gunpoint a month ago hopes to legitimize dictatorship in an electoral travesty scheduled for Jan. 17. Gen. Henri Namphy now demands that voters hand their ballots directly to his soldiers. Candidates representing some 90 percent of the electorate have properly declined to participate under these circumstances, refusing to lend legitimacy to a cynical exercise.

LEAD: Kerry Lynch, an American skier living in Denver, has been stripped of his world championship silver medal in the Nordic combined event and has been suspended briefly after admitting he received an improper blood transfusion before competing last February, the United States Ski Association said yesterday.
LEAD: Monroe M. Stearns, a teacher, writer and editor, died Dec. 17, apparently of a respiratory ailment, at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: From the top of the campus, Dallas Hall, a red brick and Georgian building with great stone columns, looks down a long boulevard of greensward and live oaks. It is an honest and imposing piece of architecture, the original building here at Southern Methodist University.

LEAD: Former State Senator David J. Friedland was ordered today to begin serving a seven-year Federal prison sentence for a 1980 extortion conviction that had prompted him to become first a Federal informer and, later, a high-living, globe-trotting fugitive for 27 months.
LEAD: After two seasons of excitement, Providence fans may feel like children who wake up to discover that the circus has left town.

LEAD: What poor prognostication in this space last year; I even predicted the stock market would go down, and of course it has risen a bit since last year-end. LEAD: While singers strive in the rehearsal rooms of the Paris Opera for the fabled honeyed tones, there's a lot of humming-along on the roof, where Jean Pocton's 10,000 worker bees create gallons of honey every year.

LEAD: Should race be a factor in the selection of New York City's next schools chancellor? Of course it should - but it can be only one factor in determining who could function most effectively to rescue the floundering school system.
LEAD: LIKE many other aging cities of the Northeast in the last few decades, Norwalk has seen its downtown wither, primarily as a result of competition from shopping malls and suburban office parks.
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency told Congress today that new Federal regulations governing toxic waste from drilling operations for oil and gas were not needed.
LEAD: LITERAL MADNESS: Kathy Goes to Haiti, My Death My Life by Pier Paolo Pasolini and Florida. By Kathy Acker. 410 pages. Grove Press. $19.95.

LEAD: Tucker Wayne & Company, part of the Atlanta advertising scene for 65 years, and Luckie & Forney Inc., a 34-year-old agency in Birmingham, Ala., have agreed to merge to form Tucker Wayne/Luckie & Company. It will have $125 million in billings, with about two-thirds coming from the Atlanta unit.
LEAD: After Gary Hart admitted having new ideas, several reliable political writers disclosed that all the other Democratic candidates have new ideas, too.

LEAD: TOMORROW night, you have sworn, is the last night of self-indulgence. Beginning Jan. 1, 1988, buerre blanc shall never again pass your lips; you will throw yourself on your sword before tasting a morsel of foie gras, and if you are ever tempted to drink more than a single glass of wine at dinner, you have given your nearest and dearest permission to wrest it from your grasp.

LEAD: Denis Potvin said he did not know what Pat LaFontaine intended to do with the pass he had forwarded, and LaFontaine confirmed that the strategy behind the game-tying goal was simply one of desperation.

LEAD: WITS used to refer to a well-known American literary magazine as The New York Review of Each Other's Books because of the tight coterie of writers, editors and publishers who put it out. The London wine trade is like that.
LEAD: Not long ago, Mickey Duff, the British fight manager and promoter, was recalling the guidance a veteran boxing man gave him when he was just starting out.
LEAD: At least 30 people were injured today in clashes with the police during an eight-hour nationwide strike called by the opposition to demand the removal of President H. M. Ershad, witnesses said.

LEAD: Dorrance Sexton, former chairman and chief executive officer of the international insurance firm Johnson & Higgins, died Saturday in the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Lakeville, Conn.

LEAD: Kenneth Lipper has always been a dues-paying member of many of Wall Street's most venerable institutions. But lately he has been paying dues to an organization of a different sort: the Screen Actors Guild. Oliver Stone, the award-winning director of ''Platoon,'' hired the 46-year-old investment banker and former Deputy Mayor of New York for finance and economic development as the technical adviser on his latest film, ''Wall Street,'' and Mr.
LEAD: Edward Kleban, the Tony Award-winning lyricist of ''A Chorus Line,'' died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 48 years old.
LEAD: Florida has supplanted Pennsylvania as the fourth most populous state, behind California, New York and Texas, the Census Bureau said today.
LEAD: Patrick Bissell, a leading principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, was found dead yesterday morning in his apartment in Hoboken, N.J. He was 30 years old.
LEAD: Donald H. Nathan, a motion picture trade association executive, died yesterday at his home in Wantagh, L.I. He was 62 years old.

LEAD: The Xerox Corporation won a court order today that would seize Federal funds earmarked for Gary Hart's renewed bid for the Presidency. The money would be used to satisfy a debt left over from the Democrat's 1984 campaign.

LEAD: In a few weeks, Haitians are to have another chance to choose a president, but many Haitians say they are not going to vote. It is clear, they say, that a little less than two years after President Jean-Claude Duvalier fled into exile, a new dictatorship is taking shape.

LEAD: Not content to clear Judge Irving W. Levine of the New York State Supreme Court of charges that he participated in the humiliation of an alleged rape victim, the Chief Administrative Judge, Albert M. Rosenblatt, has filed countercharges against the Brooklyn District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman. Her alleged offense: making false accusations against a judge.

LEAD: Some of the people who made news in 1968 and some of the journalists who were covering them will take part in four days of seminars beginning Jan. 12 at the Mark Goodson Auditorium, 2 Columbus Circle.

LEAD: A snow plow maneuvering past an ambulance, a pedestrian and two joggers yesterday on the mall near the band shell in Central Park. The ''Fourth Day of Christmas'' storm left 2 to 4 inches of snow in the metropolitan area. Page B4. (NYT/Jim Wilson)
LEAD: For his 50th birthday, James M. Fox got something he had always wanted - the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

LEAD: Doctors say that Laffit Pincay, who broke vertebrae in a spill at Santa Anita Sunday, will be sidelined at least a month. Pincay was unseated just as he and a 2-year-old filly, May First, left the gate in the third race. . . . Mike Jones, Auburn's leading scorer and rebounder this season with averages of 21.9 and 10.0, has been declared academically inelgible and will concentrate on a pro career in Europe, according to Coach Sonny Smith.
LEAD: Noye Monroe Johnson, a Dartmouth College geology professor who did early research on acid rain, died of cancer at his home here Sunday, school officials said Monday. He was 57 years old.

LEAD: John Kasay, a freshman who had missed two field-goal attempts, connected from 39 yards as time expired tonight to give Georgia a 20-17 come-from-behind victory over Arkansas in the Liberty Bowl.

LEAD: The Pennzoil Company appears to be leaning toward a major acquisition in the oil industry as the best way to use the $3 billion settlement it will receive next year from Texaco Inc., according to a letter that Pennzoil's chairman and chief executive sent to shareholders last week.

LEAD: MOST pop songs end where romance begins, at the moment when partners pair off. The Cucumbers, a Hoboken band that recently released its second album, pick up the story some time later; with a few diversions, they write about friction and affection within longtime couples. In ''My Boyfriend,'' Deena Shoshkes points out, he ''sings me to sleep/Sometimes it's beautiful/ Sometimes it's too loud.
LEAD: Supporters of Gary Hart filed petitions Monday to put his name on the ballot for the Illinois primary, saying they had gathered twice as many signatures as were required.

LEAD: November advertising revenues for the members of the Publishers Information Bureau were the highest for any month in the history of the organization, $619.3 million, a 12.5 percent gain from November 1986. Ad pages for the month were 16,826, a 7.8 percent increase.

LEAD: AFTER a period of stagnation that began in the 1970's and lasted into this decade, the ready-to-eat breakfast cereal industry is enjoying a renaissance aided by consumer interest in nutrition and changing technology.
LEAD: With campus protests having dropped to a murmur, fewer colleges are unloading their stocks in companies with South African operations.

LEAD: A Transit Authority program to revise service on all 200 of New York City's local bus routes, some of which have not been studied for decades, is resulting in schedule reductions averaging about 10 percent.

LEAD: The AIDS epidemic in America is nearing the end of its first phase. The virus is firmly established among homosexual and bisexual men and intravenous drug abusers, and among their regular sexual partners. If, next, it should leak substantially from these groups into the population at large, the epidemic could become self-sustaining.

LEAD: The Apex Oil Company, threatened with foreclosure on a $533 million loan and a liquidation of its assets, has filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

LEAD: After three years of staggering losses, executives in the oilfield service industry thought that the worst was finally over last summer. Oil prices went as high as $22 a barrel and exploration for new oil in the United States began to accelerate, increasing the demand for the drilling rigs, casing, pipe and other equipment and services needed to find and produce new reserves.

LEAD: Richard Koopman, former president of the G. Fox & Company department stores, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Hartford. He was 73 years old and lived in West Hartford, Conn.

LEAD: Mayor Koch yesterday sharply criticized remarks by a Roman Catholic priest at a rally Monday in Brooklyn as anti-Semitic and contended that the priest, along with several political allies, was ''exacerbating racial tensions.''

LEAD: Sabbaticals for college presidents are still a relatively new idea. Michael I. Sovern, who has been president of Columbia University for seven years, was on sabbatical for the fall semester. He and his wife, Joan, a sculptor, have spent most of that time in New York City.

LEAD: WITH 1987 about to exit as a disquieting investment year, market professionals are mulling over their candidates for favored stocks in 1988. One general theme running through these choices is the prospect for increased earnings during the next two years.

LEAD: Prospects for relief in the third-world debt crisis brightened yesterday with an innovative proposal in which banks would forgive billions of dollars of Mexican debt in return for bonds of lesser value issued by Mexico. The bonds would be backed by United States Treasury bonds bought by Mexico.

LEAD: The police discovered nine bodies in a shallow grave and in abandoned cars today outside the rural home of a man who was arrested after a shooting spree here Monday. The bodies brought to 16 the number of slayings linked to the man.

The move was expected because FCB/L.K.P. is also the agency for a bunch of Colgate-Palmolive products. One doesn't have Colgate and Procter under the same roof; the same goes for Lever Brothers.

Forbes, the magazine publisher and hot-air balloon enthusiast, into lending her his Beethoven balloon, a seven-story-high representation of a bust of the composer. She will use it in Washington's Cherry Blossom Parade next spring.

LEAD: Two former Salvadoran national guardsmen imprisoned for the killing of two American agricultural advisers and a Salvadoran Government official have been set free under an amnesty for political prisoners, the Salvadoran Government said today.

LEAD: These days, the mere mention of the U-word - unemployment -sends shivers through the ranks of Moscow's economic reformers. A guaranteed job is viewed as the signal triumph of the Soviet system. Any streamlining that leads to unemployment could derail support for the whole reform movement.

LEAD: Sam LeFrak, the billionaire New York developer, said he just wants to be loved and appreciated.

LEAD: Even before he took the job as general manager of metropolitan Philadelphia's mass transit system last month, William G. Stead of San Francisco was warned that he was entering a political jungle where he might be eaten alive. That is just about how it turned out. And in the aftermath of the messy affair, the reputation of the oft-maligned Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority, owner and operator of the nation's fourth-largest transit system, appears to have sunk to a new low.
LEAD: The Soviet Union has invited an international human rights organization to visit Moscow next month for a week of discussions with top Soviet officials.

LEAD: Harry Green, a retired New Jersey lawyer, died of heart failure Monday at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center. He was 94 years old and lived in Los Angeles, where he moved in 1986.

LEAD: ''Social dynamite'' is one way to define poor children who lack education and sound parental supervision. ''Overwhelmed'' is a way to define poor mothers who lack education and self-esteem. How to help the children and the mothers is a question that can overwhelm, too - so much that it may induce paralysis even among the most well meaning.

LEAD: Friday

LEAD: NO sooner is Willie Nelson released from jail after serving 20 years for trying to rob a train, than he gets together that old gang of his and goes off to try to rob a train again. He knows that an ex-Texas Ranger, Richard Widmark, who stopped him the first time, will be out to get him again, with that old gang of his.
LEAD: Orders to the nation's factories edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent in November, the weakest showing in three months, the Commerce Department said today.

LEAD: Pat Robertson's well-heeled Presidential campaign adjusted its financial course again today by agreeing to accept $4.5 million in Federal matching funds. But it pledged to put the money in escrow while Mr. Robertson decides whether to keep it or try to give it back.

LEAD: It is a night generally remembered for the significant seconds leading up to midnight. For the Rangers, no matter how extravagant their individual New Year's Eve celebrations, it was going to be hard to top the memorable couple of minutes they enjoyed last night slightly after 9 P.M.

LEAD: As evening fell tonight, even amid tropical showers, Copacabana beach came alive with lighted candles as tens of thousands of Brazilians bedecked in white prepared to ask Iemanja, an African goddess of the sea, to guide them safely through the New Year.

LEAD: The drummer Art Blakey is leading the Jazz Messengers tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

LEAD: The atmosphere's protective shield of ozone ebbed rapidly from 1979 through 1986, not just over Antarctica, where the depletion has been sharpest, but over nearly the whole globe, researchers said yesterday.

LEAD: It seems only yesterday that America celebrated its Bicentennial. Yet it was 12 whole years ago, and by the same measure the 21st century is tomorrow - just 12 years hence. Foresighted earthlings will start now to get ready.

LEAD: Sunshine pours in a large picture window of the house. Their beady eyes beneath a tufted crown of bright red feathers dart back and forth, betraying no secrets.
LEAD: Ethnic Tamil militants killed at least 30 Moslems in eastern Sri Lanka on Wednesday in revenge for the deaths of six comrades killed by Moslem fundamentalists, two communities said today.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL The dollar ended a bleak year on a bleak note, falling to new lows against the yen and the mark. Trading was very light. The drop came despite what dealers said was a fourth straight day of buying dollars by the central banks of Japan, West Germany and Switzerland. For the second consecutive year, the dollar recorded the dubious distinction of falling to its lowest levels of the year on the year's last day.

LEAD: THE year 1987 ended on a downbeat. The dollar, on the last day of the year, fell to record lows of about 121 yen and 156 West German marks. In the stock market, by no coincidence, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 11.27 points. Worries about recession were rife, intensified by the sharpest fall in the leading economic indicators since 1981.

LEAD: Art and antiques collectors will long remember 1987 as a banner year for auctions. LEAD: ''IMAGO'' was hailed, on its premiere in 1963, as the last word in the kind of multimedia theater-dance practiced by Alwin Nikolais. The dance started life as a full-evening work that explored ways movement, light and sound affect each other. Subtitled ''The City Curious,'' the piece also seemed to allude to the busy and mysterious pace of urban life.

LEAD: The Holly Sugar Company, which agreed to be acquired by the Imperial Sugar Company on Christmas Eve, said today that Imperial had increased the cash portion of its offer from $105 a share to $108.

LEAD: A FEW centuries ago, Bukhara was a Central Asian hot spot. An ancient city on the silk route between China and the West, just north of present-day Iran and Afghanistan, Bukhara developed a cosmopolitan culture of the Near and Far East. Its traditions drew from Persia, from nomadic Turkic tribes that wandered the steppes, from the bustle of trading cities and the calm of mountain villages; its music was shaped by classical Sufi poets and generations of Jewish court musicians.

LEAD: It was cold, as all but the Sherpas know, and Ted Harris wouldn't come out of his apartment in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, on account of the angina and the stern doctor's orders, and then he thought he would take it one step further: no guests. He could visit by telephone, though, and it was important because he had a load to get off his chest.
LEAD: The board of the A. H. Robins Company last night accepted a sweetened merger bid from Sanofi, a large French drug maker, over competing offers from two American suitors.
LEAD: President Gustav Husak, who was replaced last month as Communist Party chief, praised innovation in Kremlin policies today but indicated that economic change in his country has not even begun.

LEAD: A detailed account of the causes of one of the world's worst nuclear accidents - a fire at a British nuclear plant in 1957 - was suppressed by Prime Minister Harold Macmillan mainly because he feared it would threaten nuclear and defense cooperation with the United States, according to classified documents released today.
LEAD: In a move that may affect the tentative peace process in Cambodia, Prime Minister Hun Sen has also reassumed the position of Foreign Minister.
LEAD: For the first time in six years, the Soviet Union today stopped jamming broadcasts to Poland by the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe, the director of the Voice of America said.

LEAD: The theory was that Big 10 teams had lost six consecutive Rose Bowls, and 12 of the last 13, because the Midwestern kids were dazzled and distracted by Disneyland, Hollywood and the Southern California climate when they came to play the Pac-10 champion.

LEAD: Stock and commodity markets, as well as banks, government offices and most businesses, were closed yesterday in observance of New Year's Day. Most foreign stock markets, including those in Tokyo and London, were also closed.

LEAD: Following are transcripts of New Year's greetings, televised today, by President Reagan to the Soviet people and by Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the American people. The transcripts were supplied by the White House, with the translation from the Russian provided by an official interpreter. MR. REAG
LEAD: It would be wrong to let the holiday season close without acknowledging some of the many people who gave to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund instead of exchanging gifts.

LEAD: DR. CHARLES ALLEN, a physician in Palm Springs, Calif., has been using an options strategy called overwriting for about two years. Even following the enormous market meltdown in October, he has continued to participate in the investment program.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Tim Vesling kicked the 38-yard field goal that put Syracuse ahead before Win Lyle's 30-yard field goal with 1 second remaining salvaged a 16-16 tie for Auburn in the Sugar Bowl today. But now Vesling and five of his Syracuse teammates were being asked in the Superdome's interview area for their reaction to Coach Pat Dye's decision to go for the tie instead of trying for a victory with a last-play pass from the 13-yard line.

LEAD: Rainier National Bank, whose $1.2 billion acquisition by the Security Pacific Corporation became final three months ago, said it had agreed to sell its leasing operation to a unit of the First City Trust Company of Vancouver, British Columbia. Terms were not disclosed. The operation has assets of $160 million and in the first nine months of 1987 earned $2.2 million.

LEAD: When someone suggested recently that Boston College's basketball program was stuck in a downward spiral, Jim O'Brien, the school's second-year coach, insisted that the Eagles' fortunes could change sooner than people thought.

LEAD: A Roman Catholic clergyman says that the South Carolina Republican Party is helping perpetuate a segregated society and that racism should be stamped out on the 125th anniversary of Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation.
LEAD: Chicago's futures exchanges have long had their eyes on the large financial markets of Japan. And now the Japanese are returning that interest.

LEAD: Rabies caused the death of a 13-year-old boy, the first human in San Francisco to die of the rare disease in nearly half a century, health officials have reported. The victim, Michael Ancheta, died Dec. 15 but was not diagnosed as having the rare disease until several days later, according to the city's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control.

LEAD: AMEX VOLUME Total share volume on the American Stock Exchange for 1987. 1987 ........................ 3,505,950,000 1986 .................. 2,978,540,000 1985 ............. 2,100,860,000 1984 ....... 1,545,010,000 1983 ........... 2,081,270,000 MOST-ACTIVE AMEX ISSUES IN 1987 Only common stocks are listed; adjusted for stock splits (s).

LEAD: Scientists at the Argonne National Laboratory have developed what they said today was the first electric motor based on the properties of a material that conducts electricity with minimal resistance.
LEAD: Tim Brown ended his Heisman Trophy season today looking for a towel. A crying towel would have done nicely for his Notre Dame teammates and Coach Lou Holtz.
LEAD: The National Endowment for the Arts has announced awards to three jazz musicians for contributions to ''jazz in the African-American tradition.''

LEAD: Egyptian police with riot sticks charged and beat hundreds of anti-Israeli protesters chanting Islamic fundamentalist slogans today and besieged others at one of Cairo's most eminent mosques, witnesses said.

LEAD: President Kurt Waldheim, who has been accused of involvement in wartime atrocities, today denounced the period of Nazi rule in Austria and urged his countrymen to avoid racial hatred and intolerance.

LEAD: Horse Racing Long Shot Travels by Rail: Key to the Bridge, an 11-to-1 shot, hugged the rail from start to finish and held off Avanti Sassa by a head to win the $113,480 Hialeah Breeders' Cup Handicap yesterday at Hialeah Park in Hialeah, Fla. Natania finished third, 1 1/4 lengths behind the top pair, and Way It Should Be was fourth.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL 3-8, 24 A Salvadoran amnesty law has led to the release of several gunmen accused of killing American and Salvadoran civilians, the United States embassy and human rights activists in that country say. Page 1 Israeli soldiers were on alert in Gaza, Jerusalem and the West Bank to combat Palestinian attempts to commemorate the 23d anniversary of Yasir Arafat's first military operation against Israel.
LEAD: Mexico has agreed to relax its restrictions on imports of steel, beer and wine, Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said in a statement this week.

LEAD: ''Kids America,'' an award-winning nationally syndicated children's radio program, went off the air yesterday after nearly four years of live broadcasts that combined ''Sesame Street''-style teaching with the format of talk radio.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson was treated at a hospital today for back pain and released after a few hours, hospital officials said. A candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Mr. Jackson went to the Franklin Medical Center here at about noon, according to a nursing supervisor at the hospital who refused to give her name.
LEAD: After a year of falling bond prices and volatile interest rates, the sports fans' ''wait till next year'' refrain is echoing through the credit markets.
LEAD: Jimmy Johnson stopped being ''the other guy'' tonight as his University of Miami team swarmed over Barry Switzer's Oklahoma team, 20-14, to lay claim to the unofficial national championship.

LEAD: The Soviet Union today entered a critical phase in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's attempt to resuscitate the economy, in which workers will be asked to change their notion of work radically without yet having enjoyed any great rewards from two years of economic experiments and promises.

LEAD: The trustee for the PTL television ministry will take action to recover what the Internal Revenue Service says is $9.36 million in excessive compensation paid to Jim and Tammy Bakker, an attorney for the trustee said today.

LEAD: A law banning smoking on commercial plane, train and bus trips in California took effect today, but at least two airlines ignored the law, saying superseding Federal regulations allowed smoking sections.
LEAD: A Federal magistrate in Denver has rejected an effort by two major creditors of Gary Hart's 1984 Presidential campaign to lay claim to money held by his 1988 campaign.

LEAD: Kathleen Battle has done more than any guest conductor in recent memory about teaching the New York Philharmonic to play softly -an appreciable achievement, even if her means were somewhat extreme at the New Year's Eve concert in Avery Fisher Hall. One assumes that the microphones improved matters for the telecast, but in the hall it was often hard to hear Miss

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 413 money market mutual funds decreased $3.16 billion, to $258.22 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. Assets of the 112 institutional funds were down $2.11 billion, to $70.99 billion. Assets of the 206 general purpose funds increased $159.8 million, to $79.36 billion.

LEAD: The United States Embassy and human rights advocates are strongly criticizing a blanket amnesty law here that has pardoned several gunmen accused of killing Americans and Salvadorans civilians in recent years.

LEAD: Dorothy Elizabeth Bliss, a retired curator of the American Museum of Natural History, died of cancer last Saturday at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. She was 71 years old and lived in Wakefield, R.I.

LEAD: The steep fall of the dollar has created a catastrophic situation for Airbus Industrie, the European commercial aircraft consortium, the Foreign Trade Minister of France, Michel Noir, said in an interview published this week. Mr. Noir told the newspaper

LEAD: IC Industries plans to spin off the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad into a separate company after it receives a favorable tax ruling from the Internal Revenue Service, a company vice president, Bruce S. Chelberg, said this week.
LEAD: ''Thank heaven for nuclear weapons,'' Prime Minister
LEAD: The party's founding unfolded, amid police harassment, in three acts: the first in a garden house, the second in a cafe, the third in an apartment.
LEAD: It rained on their parade, but five American high school bands and a drill team dazzled their audience during a New Year's Day march through one of London's main shopping districts.
LEAD: Like some earthquakes, the stock market debacle caused aftershocks that hit the over-the-counter market harder than the initial tremor.
LEAD: An Eastern Airlines jet made an unscheduled stop here Thursday so that officials could arrest a New Jersey passenger accused of making sexual advances to two airline attendants.

LEAD: It hasn't been the best of weeks for the front line of the Auburn (7-2) basketball team. On Monday Mike Jones, the leading scorer and rebounder averaging 21.9 points and 10.0 rebounds, was ruled academically ineligible. On Wednesday Jeff Moore, the senior center, suffered a broken hand in an 83-72 defeat to Georgia Tech in the final of the Cotton States Classic.
LEAD: A funny thing happened as the clock at the old Town Hall here struck midnight and ushered in the New Year. There were people on hand, more than 4,000 of them, to watch.

LEAD: The Koch administration, working to keep viable its disputed plan for developing Columbus Circle, has agreed to a new proposal that includes no reference to the height of the project, reduces its purchase price and bulk, and places a new financial constraint on the developer.

LEAD: When Clarissa Davis, top-ranked Texas' all-America basketball player, came crashing down onto the court Tuesday night, badly injuring her left knee in the Orange Bowl Classic in Miami, her mother was listening to the game at a park about an hour south of San Antonio, where she and her husband had driven because that's where the reception was best.

LEAD: STEVE CRAWFORD is a free agent, so he can't extend his record of five times filed and five times settled, but Phil Bradley can try for a third successive victory and Kevin McReynolds and Gary Pettis can try to break their two-year losing streaks. Andre Dawson can try to break the bank. It's salary arbitration time, which means clubs can start cringing because they have come to fear that procedure more than free agency.

LEAD: BEFORE THE STOCK MARKET collapse of all too recent memory, the fashion designers got it wrong: hemlines kept climbing, allegedly a sign of good times to come. But the creative artists of stage, screen and literature got it right: They saw the boom, the big bull market, the age of the yuppies coming to an end, to be brought down by pride, lust, greed and other deadly sins.
LEAD: THE sixth of January. Call it what you will - The Feast of the Three Kings or Epiphany - but at our house it is the day to take down all the holiday trappings.
LEAD: This island state still wishes it could regain sovereignty over the faraway island of Diego Garcia, which the United States has turned into a military base in the Indian Ocean.

LEAD: THE Christmas tree has been hurled out in the back of the property, where it will gradually turn brown and become a haven for birds and other animals braving the blasts of winter.
