LEAD: Making Mr. Right Directed by Susan Seidelman. Starring Ann Magnuson and John Malkovich. 1987. HBO Video. 101 minutes. $79.95.
LEAD: A 28-year-old white woman was forced into a van in Brooklyn by two black men and robbed on Thursday in what the police yesterday called a racially motivated incident.

LEAD: ANN HOROWITZ, 27 years old, traveled across the nation and abroad for several years after college, trying her hand at being a chef but finally deciding she would never be as good as she wanted to be. Instead she turned to graduate school at New York University and discovered that she greatly enjoyed the field of public policy.

LEAD: ECHOES of 1957 reverberated from the Soviet Union last week to a snow-coated rocket test site in Utah. The space age is now 30 years old, moon landings have come and gone and a whole generation has grown up with the reality of space travel. Yet there was something about the triumphant return of a record-setting Soviet astronaut, and another setback to the grounded space shuttle, that was reminiscent of the grim time following the first Sputnik launching in

LEAD: AFTER a series of extensions, the deadline set by Congress for cleaning up the air was to have been New Year's Eve. But more than a decade and a half after passage of the Clean Air Act, the effort is still best described by the words that were used at the beginning: long term. Just before Christmas, Congress approved legislation to extend the deadline to Aug.

LEAD: Anthony V. Barber, a former headmaster of preparatory schools in the New York metropolitan region, died of bronchial pneumonia Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Barber, who had been ill with cancer, was 83 years old and also lived in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

LEAD: The engagement of Jane Marie Flynn, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William F. X. Flynn of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Stanley Randall Silver, a son of Dr. Randall H. Silver of Auburn, Me., and Helen M. Silver of Medford, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents. The couple plan to marry in July.

LEAD: RED HORIZONS: Chronicles of a Communist Spy Chief. By Lieut. Gen. Ion Mihai Pacepa. (Regnery Gateway/ Kampmann, $19.95.) In 1945, Rumanian intelligence officers provided the nascent United States intelligence organization with copious secret files on the Soviet Union - of value in part because they covered Soviet territory occupied by Rumanian forces during World War II.

LEAD: ON the surface, it was a fight about condoms, an unsightly brawl on an unseemly topic for the Princes of the Roman Catholic Church. But at the heart of the matter of last week's debate over the new AIDS policy of the American bishops was a long-simmering struggle between conservative and liberal forces in the

LEAD: ONE of the delights of owning property along a back country road is the appearance of the road itself. Frequently, that road will be framed on either side by hand-built stone walls. It may be narrow and winding, allowing mature shade trees on either side to form a canopy across the middle.
LEAD: THE SAD TRUTH THAT there is no free lunch is about to reassert itself in 1988. Looking ahead into the new year, audio fans are bracing themselves for steep and inevitable price increases.
LEAD: The bankruptcy of United States policy in Nicaragua is worsened by the weakness of Congress in resisting that policy and by the trickery of the State Department in promoting it.

LEAD: Japan's whaling fleet, reconfigured as a ''research expedition,'' steams toward the Antarctic. In defiance of the International Whaling Commission, Japan plans to kill 300 minke whales in the name of science. The meat would be sold, as usual, for profit. The U.S., traditionally the conscience of the treaty that protects whales, can have only one reaction to this brazenness: sanctions.
LEAD: Town officials here say that an adverse court ruling will not keep them from leaving a cross atop a Christmas tree on the courthouse lawn until holiday decorations are dismantled next week.
LEAD: GOING by the numbers, things didn't look so good.

LEAD: DAVID CAMERON: AT THE END of his spring showing, the models led 26-year-old David Cameron across the stage. He had a big smile on his handsome face and for good reason: the audience was clapping, stamping and hollering approval of his highly shaded, sharply styled designs. After two years in business, Cameron is on his way to becoming a major American talent.

LEAD: Hart Complicates Campaign Political professionals think Gary Hart will have a major influence on the Democratic Presidential race even if he does not prevail. Page 16. A Kidnapping Jolts India An abduction that forced India to release prisoners has stirred debate on dealing with extremists and focused attention on leftist radicals.
LEAD: HE'S THE man with no name, the other Senator from New Jersey.

LEAD: FRANCESCO'S is such an improvement over the restaurant that preceded it in its downtown Norwalk location, that one wishes it were doing better. On the nights of our visits, one of which was on a weekend, only a handful of tables were occupied.

LEAD: Federal researchers have reported a substantial increase in tuberculosis in the United States for 1986, the first in more than three decades of record-keeping. They said AIDS was partly to blame. The nation recorded 22,768 cases of tuberculosis in 1986, up 2.6 percent from 22,201 in 1985, the Federal Centers for Disease Control reported

LEAD: Pamela Margaret Davis, an artist, and Steven A. Kivelson, an associate professor and a theoretical physicist at the State University at Stony Brook, L.I., were married in San Francisco yesterday. Rabbi Robert Kirschner performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. S. Marshall
LEAD: A great summation to this crazy football season would be a Colts and Saints matchup in the Super Bowl. GARY M. LEON East Brunswick, N.J.

LEAD: Elizabeth Patterson Murdoch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Murdoch Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Henry Clinton Maguire 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Maguire Jr. of Merion Station, Pa. The Rev. Frank C. Strasburger, the Episcopal chaplain of Princeton University, performed the ceremony at the university chapel.

LEAD: ONE OF THE WORLD'S MOST beautiful exhibition spaces is the one that was confected not so long ago by the English architect Max Gordon for the Saatchi Collection here. It is a mysterious space, in which level is played against level and shape against shape. It is, in fact, something of a thinking man's maze.

LEAD: Rupert Murdoch, who appears to believe he cannot own too many communications companies, has been told that he does. Under temporary waivers from the Federal Communications Commission, the Australian-born publishing magnate has been allowed since 1986 to own The New York Post and The Boston Herald while simultaneously operating television stations in those cities.

LEAD: LAST AUTUMN Junior Scholastic magazine celebrated its 50th year in print - a life that began with reports about a new Supreme Court Justice named Hugo Black and a war between Japan and China. But for the magazine's parent, Scholastic Inc., the anniversary was no time for nostalgia.
LEAD: IN the end, the winner was Overload.

It was also the culmination of a slow, painful process of community building, carried out during 40 years of living in the
LEAD: The Justice Department has filed suit against the Long Branch Housing Authority, charging the agency with discrimination and maintaining segregated apartment projects.

LEAD: At Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church in Bethesda, Md., Tracey Lee Shewmaker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Shewmaker of Bethesda, was married yesterday to Patrick Joseph McCormick 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. McCormick Jr. of New York, East Hampton, L.I., and Buenos Aires. The Rev. H. Vernon
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Feminist literary studies are a new thing on campuses, but they did not spring full-grown from the heads of the recent polemical feminists. For generations, well-read women have developed a chain of favorite authors, passed on by word-of-mouth. My mother was my link to the feminist literary past. She introduced me to such important and then neglected authors as Olive Schreiner, Elizabeth Gaskell and Maria Edgeworth.

LEAD: A STRAIGHT-A high school senior in Connecticut's Fairfield County is caught with crib notes while taking a midyear test in history. Asked to explain himself, he responds, ''If I get a B, I won't get into Princeton.''
LEAD: ''CLAY AND GLASS,'' an exhibition now on view at the Montclair Art Museum, marks the beginning of the second cycle of ''New Jersey Arts Annuals.''

LEAD: REINVENTING EVE Modern Woman in Search of Herself. By Kim Chernin. 191 pp. New York: Times Books. $16.95. ONCE I had a fantasy about the Virgin Mary. When the angel Gabriel announced that Mary would bear a son - a very special boy - she thought it over and said, ''No.'' Gabriel couldn't believe his ears, so Mary repeated, ''No.
LEAD: RED DOLL By Juan Luis Cebrian. Translated by Philip W. Silver. 162 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $15.95.
LEAD: A South Bronx man died after he was stabbed, beaten, handcuffed and then thrown out of an apartment window early yesterday, the police said.

LEAD: Elizabeth Bodne Anspach and Eric David Carlson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. A. David Carlson of Munster, Ind., plan to marry in June, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew A. Anspach of New York and Edgartown, Mass., have announced.

LEAD: CALLING ALL VOICES Those who would like to become ''Messiah'' participants rather than ''Messiah'' spectators by the time Easter rolls around might get in touch with the Westchester Chorale. The community singing group directed by Daniel Paget is enlisting new members. Three evenings of auditions will be held weekly in conjuction with the first rehearsals of the new year, beginning at 7:45 P.M.
LEAD: FROZEN plumbing is easily one of winter's worst household disasters.
LEAD: IN her 80-year career, the whale ship Charles W. Morgan made 37 voyages, visiting every ocean. Soon, small pictures of the historic vessel will be visiting many mailboxes.

LEAD: TO TRADITIONAL educators, the For Spacious Skies program might seem like castles in the air. But for Katie Masselam, a sixth-grader at the Pollard Middle School in Needham, Mass., the program was a new way of seeing - and speaking, writing and drawing about the world around her.

LEAD: I say ''bosh'' to William Boyd, and recommend that he keep his ears open while wandering around London (''Cockney Charisma,'' Dec. 6). LEAD: THERE are several daily fashion parades on the gilded shopping stretch of Madison Avenue between 60th and 96th Streets.

LEAD: A United Airlines jet carrying Representative Richard A. Gephardt suddenly lost cabin pressure today, forcing passengers to use oxygen masks and the pilot to return to O'Hare International Airport here. The Missouri Democrat and several members of his Presidential campaign staff were among the 37 passengers and five crew members on United Flight 401 from Chicago to Omaha.

LEAD: IN Modena, until not long ago, a girl could hope to find a husband only if she could make pasta and if her dowry included a little barrel of balsamic vinegar. Eating well is very important in Modena, hometown of Luciano Pavarotti and Ferrari cars, as it is in next-door Bologna and throughout the region of Emilia-Romagna, the gastronomic heartland of Italy.

LEAD: Gary Hart's sudden decision to re-enter the 1988 Presidential campaign has provoked, at least in public, more wringing of hands than careful calculation, more denunciation than analysis of its impact on the Democratic race.

LEAD: As one scandal after another unfolds, it is clear that President Reagan presides over one of the most corrupt administrations ever. Whether measured by the rank or the sheer numbers of officials who have come under ethical suspicion and criminal investigation, the amount of sleaze is awesome. Precise comparisons to the Grant, Harding and Nixon Administrations aren't possible or necessary.

LEAD: Never one to duck trouble, Ariel Sharon has now set up housekeeping in the middle of it. Recently, in what was criticized by many as a provocative gesture, the pugnacious former general, now Israel's Minister of Industry and Trade, took an apartment in the Moslem quarter of Jerusalem. After Mr. Sharon spent his first night in the apartment last week, insisting he was promoting ''integration'' of Arabs and Jews, Mayor Teddy Kollek said the move was ''counterproductive.

LEAD: The Giants! In a surprise Presidential action under the Football Powers Act, President Reagan decrees all strike games null and void. Computer programs conclude that the Giants would have won all their strike games, making them 9-6 for the year and a playoff qualifier. BRANDON DUNN New York

LEAD: Retailers' Christmas sales were nothing to brag about, but the modest increases were enough to allay the worst fears of merchants. Gains were expected to average out to about 3 percent, which is really no gain at all when an inflation rate of more than 4 percent is factored in. But things could have been a lot worse in a year that saw a dizzying tumble in the stock market, and, in fact, the biggest sales gains came from affluent shoppers.

LEAD: OWL MOON By Jane Yolen. Illustrated by John Schoenherr. Unpaged. New York: Philomel Books. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 9) THE very best books for not-quite-reading children must be written to charm and astonish the adults who will read them aloud: thrill that reader, who will communicate those prickles at the nape of the neck, and you'll have created a desire in the young listener to learn how to read books alone.

LEAD: NORTH OF YESTERDAY: Or, Flowers of Waz. By Thomas McEvilley. (McPherson, Cloth, $20; Paper, $10.) Can we fault the art critic Thomas McEvilley for the preposterous ambition of ''North of Yesterday''? He flings together the quick and the dead, urban derelicts and characters dreamed up (literally) from an anecdote of Herodotus, and indulges in an orgy of mythologizing - not to mention a mythologizing of orgy.

LEAD: Of all the labels that could have been attached to Jimmy Johnson as the football coach at the University of Miami for the past four seasons, the notions of champion and educator have never seemed to stick.

LEAD: In her article, Elizabeth Kolbert refers to a ''classic'' feminist article by Sandra Gilbert, in which Ms. Gilbert attacks the image of Milton, alluding to his ''well-known misogyny'' and his ''antifeminism.''
LEAD: A police officer here has been charged with selling heroin over one of the department's emergency communications telephone lines, which include the 911 emergency number.

LEAD: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.50.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, an evil wizard and a mouse. 2 8 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $4.95.) Nightmarish experiences befall a woman appointed Ambassador to Rumania.

Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, announced his long-awaited response to the Iran-contra affair, most of the public attention focused on the disciplinary action he took against several agency officials. LEAD: CALAMITY JANE With Doris Day (in photo), Howard Keel, Allyn McLerie, Philip Carey, Dick Wesson. 1953. Warner Home Video. 101 minutes. $24.98
LEAD: A Federal court order to improve Louisiana's mostly black universities has been extended to allow more time to decide whether the state has fulfilled its terms.

LEAD: Before the New Year and new attractions overwhelm the past, the opportunity exists in the post-holiday lull to catch up on some movies that arrived amid no great hoopla and boasted no big names but laid their claim to audiences with sheer excellence.
LEAD: The San Francisco 49ers will win easily. Montana and Rice are the best quarterback-receiver duet in the league. JON GELB New York

LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 22 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: In my years of undergraduate and graduate study of literature, I have yet to meet a student or professor who would disagree with the point made in Elizabeth Kolbert's article ''Literary Feminism Comes of Age'' (Dec. 6) that we have a legacy of neglected or forgotten female writers. However, sexual politics has less to do with who makes the course syllabus than do the practical constraints of the academic year.

LEAD: From across this West African seaport, crowds converge daily on a modest tin-roofed house. Stevedores from the docks, smartly dressed office secretaries, market women with babies slung on their backs - they all come seeking medical advice from the ''Yank Yank.''

LEAD: ''THE Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' a very loose musical version of Charles Dickens's unfinished thriller, has a clever gimmick going for it: The ''surprise final denouement,'' as the show's master of ceremonies-chairman puts it, is up to the audience.

LEAD: A sharply divided Federal appeals court has ruled that the Government may in effect prevent defendants from hiring the lawyers of their choice by freezing defendants' assets in racketeering and drug cases.

LEAD: THE Olympic 100-meter champion, Evelyn Ashford, who holds the world record of 10.75 seconds in the event as well as indoor bests of 5.74 for 50 yards and 6.54 for 60 yards, will compete in the United States Olympic Invitational meet at Byrne Meadowlands Arena Feb. 13. The 30-year-old Ashford, who won the United States Olympic Invitational in 1986 after the birth of her daughter but missed most of last year because of an injury, will run in the 55-meter dash against the defending champion, Gwen Torrence, and Merlene Ottey, the bronze medalist in the 100 meters at the 1984 Olympics.
LEAD: CLEOPATRA Directed by Cecil B. DeMille. With Claudette Colbert (in photo), Warren William (in photo) and Henry Wilcoxon. Goodtimes Home Video. 100 minutes. $9.95.

LEAD: Puerto Rican organizations receive negligible philanthropic support from some leading foundations, according to a study conducted for the National Puerto Rican Coalition, a seven-year-old association based in Washington.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Within the Teleport, a 100-acre telecommunications and office project on Staten Island that has faced many skeptics and many setbacks, workers are preparing sites for three office buildings expected to open this year.
LEAD: Flooding caused by torrential rain abated today on the eastern side of the island of Oahu, and most of the 2,800 evacuated residents returned home to clean up at least $29 million in damage.

LEAD: To the Editor: Certainly, you need a travel agent. But Betsy Wade should not insult her readers. She says, ''Unless you enjoy doing jigsaw puzzles in solid colors,'' you should use a travel agent to put together an independent tour.
LEAD: IN most cities the phrase luxury apartment refers to an apartment in a new building. But in New York, increasingly, it is also being used to describe a renovated apartment in a former tenement.
LEAD: Israeli helicopter gunships fired rockets today into two southern Lebanese villages held by guerrillas of the pro-Iranian Party of God, destroying houses, the state-run Beirut radio reported.

LEAD: PUERTO RICO'S beaches, historic fortresses, rain forest and charming old capital have long been lures for visitors. But its newest point of interest isn't new at all. It is a prehistoric network of caves with an underground river running through it, a hidden, wondrous world in the depths of the earth.

LEAD: In Roslyn Village, where residents stubbornly preserve what is old, 25 new homes will be built across the street from the Bryant Library, the proudest symbol of the village's past. The library, on East Broadway, contains the writings and memorabilia of William Cullen Bryant, publisher of The New York Post and the Nassau County port's most famous 19th-century resident.

LEAD: EVER SINCE THE RUDOLF BING ERA ENDED and the Metropolitan Opera was gradually taken over by its board of directors, company administrators have offered a flurry of excuses about their inability to cast as many superstar singers as veteran Met audiences were used to.

LEAD: San Francisco will get it done. The 49ers are the team on a roll. But the playoff structure would be different without the three replacement games. Also, since the draft is determined by final record, the replacement games will change the draft order, in turn affecting future team quality. These unfortunate facts cloud the Niners' run at the title.
LEAD: WHEN Thomas S. Gulotta was appointed Nassau County Executive a year ago, he inherited thorny problems ranging from solid-waste disposal to a dwindling water supply.

Mr. Klausner is a son of Dr. David Klausner of Cleveland and the late Audrey Klausner. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Until Buell Fuller died last week at the age of 80, he and his identical twin, John, were separated only twice in their lives: once when John preceded Buell at birth by two minutes, and a second time two decades later when Buell joined the Air Force for two years.

LEAD: Mary Robinson Parkman, the director of St. Andrew's Nursery School and Kindergarten in Murray Hill, N.J., and the Rev. Alan C. French, the rector of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Murray Hill, plan to be married Feb. 13.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about the new state law governing marine fishing licenses misstated the kind of fishermen to whom it would apply. The $100 annual license fee is required only for commercial fishermen who are state residents. Under the law, commercial fishermen are defined as those who sell one or more fish a year.
LEAD: DON'T worry. You're not the only one who's surprised the Houston Oilers are in the National Football League playoffs.

LEAD: LINDA ADDIS of Clifton made a common mistake several years ago: She assumed that Medicare would take care of her parents in their old age.

LEAD: Armand Therrien, a murderer who escaped from a Massachusetts prison three weeks ago, has apologized for his early departure. But he also said he would not be coming back. The state Correction Commissioner, Michael V. Fair, disclosed last week that he had received the apology in a letter from Mr. Therrien, a former state trooper who in 1975 was sentenced to serve two consecutive life terms for killing his business partner and a Westwood police officer.

LEAD: President Reagan and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada signed a landmark trade agreement yesterday that would eliminate tariffs and lower other barriers to trade and investment before the end of the century.

Fearing the worst, most will simply avoid bathroom scales for a week or two. But some will decide the time has finally come to get serious about physical fitness.

LEAD: To the Editor: With apologies to Regina Schrambling (Fare of the Country, Nov. 15), by far the best flying fish and cou-cou in Barbados is made by Ada Lewis in Carrington Village, St. Michael. I order it ahead of time and have it waiting for me when I arrive.

LEAD: THE DECENT THING TO DO about the year's bad films used to be to let them go quietly. But that was in the days when a movie of no merit could be counted on to disappear into the oblivion from whence it came. Those days are gone, as anyone who regularly visits video stores must surely realize. It is now possible for a terrible film to resurface in a nice package that bears no memory-jogging information, just an indistinct title and the name of a star or two.

LEAD: THE State Commission on Integrity in Government, barely a year old, is beginning a critical period that will very likely determine whether the New York City corruption scandals will prompt genuine reform in the business of politics or just another study to be filed and forgotten.

LEAD: Seven Broadway theaters designed by Herbert J. Krapp were designated New York City landmarks in November. Another Krapp theater, the Boulevard, in Jackson Heights, Queens, was not. Altogether, eight interiors and six exteriors of Mr. Krapp's 15 Broadway palaces have been given landmark status. Meanwhile, the brick exterior of the Boulevard, at 82-28 Northern Boulevard, has been covered with brown tile.

LEAD: Savoyard Sing-Along Jan. 6 -- An opportunity to join in the musical shenanigans of Gilbert and Sullivan will come after a performance of ''the Yeoman of the Guard,'' the spoof of English manners and morals, at symphony space, 2587 Broadway (95th Street). After the 8 P.M. performance there will be a sing-along with the 30-member cast.

LEAD: WHEN WE CONTEMPLATE A WORK OF art, the experience most of us share is of seeing or hearing something with a beginning, a middle and an end. LEAD: An article in The Week in Review on Dec. 20 about New York's Congressional delegation incorrectly traced the history of New Yorkers who have served on the Senate Finance Committee. Daniel Patrick Moynihan is the first Senator from New York to have served on that committee since the 1930's. Calvin Coolidge was from Massachusetts and never served in Congress.

LEAD: Dr. Richard R. Green declared yesterday that his basic goals as the next schools chancellor of New York City would be to raise students' academic performance and to restore public confidence in the nation's largest school system.

LEAD: The military has begun top-secret ground tests of a compact, powerful laser that the Reagan Administration wants launched into space in the early 1990's as part of the effort to build a defense against nuclear missiles.

LEAD: THE GUITAR WAS PRIMARILY A rhythm instrument in jazz until Charlie Christian brought the electric guitar into the jazz mainstream in 1939 when he came out of Oklahoma to join Benny Goodman. In the big bands that dominated the 1920's and 30's, it was difficult for an acoustic guitar to be heard as a solo instrument, which was one reason the banjo was favored over the guitar until electrical recording arrived in the mid-1920's.

LEAD: ONE OF THE very important attractions of the game of golf,'' wrote Bobby Jones, one of the sport's immortals, ''is that it provides a varied assortment of topics for conversation.'' Not least, it seems, the golfer's zany wardrobe, which over the years has encompassed such classical oddities as screaming argyle hose and peaked tartan caps.

LEAD: As many studies have shown, most notably the recent one by the American Physical Society, there is no way either now or in the foreseeable future to build a Star Wars defense that would shift the balance from offensive to defensive weapons. Given the dim military prospects, given the risks in deployment, given that the Russians seem eager to negotiate limits on research, why would anyone want to spend $4 billion a year on Star Wars research?

LEAD: I RECENTLY attended a performance of that hoary chestnut of the American theater, ''Our Town,'' at the Long Wharf in New Haven. The Thornton Wilder play had first performance a half century ago, on Jan. 22, 1938, but it remains a classic because of its timeless emphasis on the values of small-town life.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I became hooked on Hoskins when I saw him in ''Flickers'' on Masterpiece Theater. Bob Hoskins does not have to concern himself unduly with people ''forgetting about him'' in a few years' time. He has been ''flavor-of-the-month'' with my family since 1982, and this predilection shows no sign of abating.

LEAD: Fire swept through the cabaret of the seafront Balmoral Hotel in Blackpool this morning, forcing 102 people from the Balmoral and a neighboring hotel, the Craigy Don, to flee. The police in this resort town on England's northwest coast said two people ill from smoke inhalation were treated at the scene.

LEAD: THE PHOTOGRAPHS IN the recently published book ''Alberto Giacometti'' do something rare: they convey a measure of what we feel when we encounter the sculptor's work in the flesh. The pictures may be missing the sculpture's scale, texture and command of space, but they elicit its essential spirit through the pictorial equivalent of metaphor.
LEAD: Meryl Illene Stone and Michael Howard Cohen, executives at J. P. Morgan & Company in New York, plan to marry next summer.

LEAD: IT will be well into the middle of the month before the concert calendar builds up to anything resembling its usual midseason pace, but music at the New Rochelle Public Library hardly misses a beat. Having last Sunday sponsored one of the final county concerts of 1987, the library this afternoon ushers in the '88 recitals roster.

LEAD: The incident started when a group of high-level local officials was traveling in an unarmed convoy through a heavily forested area in southern India. Suddenly a gang of radicals emerged from the woods and took the travelers hostage.

LEAD: The choice of a new schools chancellor for New York City yesterday brought statements of support from politicians and educators who said they hoped Dr. Richard R. Green could soon begin to revive an ailing schools system.
LEAD: EVERYONE agrees that something has to be done about the bridge between Waterford and East Lyme. Just what is to be done is the question.

LEAD: It was apparent that there had not been any overnight revelations for Dick MacPherson. The Syracuse coach came to a team breakfast this morning, lacking sleep and a satisfactory explanation for why Auburn chose to play for a tie in the Sugar Bowl game the day before. He tried to mask his feelings, engaging in long goodbyes with players heading home for the remainder of the semester break, hugging and kissing members of their families.

LEAD: ''WE take care of our own'' was one of the family mottos I grew up with. And take care they did. My father supported his mother, my mother's parents and her two unmarried sisters. ''I married the whole damn family,'' he once said in a rare expression of feeling. Mother's sister, Bessie, submerged her life in order to care for her parents at home, through Grandma's broken hip and Grandpa's strokes.

LEAD: John Kolesar caught a 20-yard touchdown pass from Demetrius Brown with 50 seconds to play today, and Jamie Morris carried for a career-high 234 yards and three touchdowns, leading Michigan over Alabama, 28-24, in the Hall of Fame Bowl.

LEAD: Inadvertently, and without benefit of a major retrospective, this is an excellent time to view and review the achievement of Alexander Calder. At the Whitney Museum of American Art (945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, through Jan. 17), an exhibition of 14 works focuses on Calder's activities during the early 1930's.

LEAD: FEW labor leaders were surprised last month by a spate of reports that Jackie Presser, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, had resigned. The rumors weren't true, but the fact that they were so widely believed showed how troubled is Mr. Presser's reign over the 1.7 million-member union, the nation's largest.

LEAD: On July 2, 1781, General Comte de Rochambeau chose a 60-acre hillside in Ridgefield, Conn., to encamp his French Army troops aiding the American colonists because it afforded a strategic view of the British camp in New York. John W. Ryan looked over the same border 206 years later, saw the corporate headquarters of Westchester County, and decided that a 17-home development on the same hillside would have a market.

LEAD: THE long-dormant tectonic plates of European politics and economics have shifted again, much to the discomfort of West Germany. The changes have conspired to create pressure on the Government of Helmut Kohl to assume a role in the world commensurate with the country's economic and strategic importance - a position it has long been reluctant to accept.

LEAD: Q. We have a brick patio with a northern exposure, and there is a problem with mold and mildew forming on these bricks. We have to scrub them several times a year with bleach to remove the growth. Do you have any suggestions for preventing this growth?

LEAD: HE won the Hollywood Invitational with Rivlia, the San Juan Capistrano with Rosedale, the Sunset Handicap with Swink, the Laurel Futurity with Antigua, the Flamingo with Talinum, and the Santa Barbara and Santa Ana Handicaps with the 4-year-old mare Reloy. And when the victories were totaled up for the year, Nelson Bunker Hunt's horses had 323 of them, so it was no wonder that he was named the winner of the 1987 Eclipse Award as outstanding breeder.

LEAD: FOR the 250 Indians on the Poospatuck Reservation on the Mastic-Shirley peninsula, clean water is finally on its way. With Federal money through the Clean Water Act of Suffolk County and community development funds from Brookhaven Town, the reservation will be hooked up to public water by spring - a project that will cost $170,000.

LEAD: Merle Evans, the ''Toscanini of the Big Top'' who for 50 years thrilled crowds as he led the blaring band of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, died Thursday in Sarasota, Fla., the winter home of the circus. He was 96 years old.

LEAD: Thank you George Young and Bill Parcells for assembling a scab team that effectively turned the lights out on the Giants' season before the end of the baseball season. With their toughest adversary out of the picture, watch Washington take the whole shootin' match. PETER BLECHMAN Fishkill, N.Y.

LEAD: IF you can't fight City Hall, take it to court. Increasingly, that is the tack being taken by groups frustrated by the normal political process in New York City. And in resorting to litigation, they are winning some victories.

LEAD: Johnny Campo and Jorge Velasquez, who teamed with Pleasant Colony to win the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes seven years ago, won the $250,000 Flamingo Stakes today at Hialeah Park with a son of Pleasant Colony named Cherokee Colony. The style of the colt's victory had the trainer and jockey thinking about the

LEAD: Though not an emigre, I, like Alex Goldfarb, am a biologist who has recently returned from a visit to a U.S.S.R. Academy of Sciences Institute in Moscow, where I lectured and pursued a collaborative research project (financed by the United States National Science Foundation). I, too, went there to measure firsthand the consequences of glasnost.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH a quadruple jump has never been completed in competition, Brian Boitano, who goes after his fourth straight United States Figure Skating championship this week in Denver, has come close and he says he will be trying to come even closer. ''Whether the jump is successful or not on a particular night will not make that much of a difference in the results,'' said Boitano, who won the 1986 world championships then finished second to Brian Orser of Canada last year.

LEAD: WHILE it may not be unusual for directors of regional theaters to call upon the same performers with regularity, it is a rare thing for an actress and a director to establish a working relationship that has the earmarks of a sustained artistic alliance.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: This letter is in response to an article by Elex Ingersoll titled ''How I Was Rescued, Like It or Not'' [ Opinion Page, Nov. 22 ] .

LEAD: Radio station WQXR AM-FM, responding to competition for the New York region's classical music audience, will make major adjustments in its programming this month, reducing the amount of discussion and adding more music on its FM signal, according to station officials.

LEAD: LAURENCE FANON is backstage at the Lido, putting on her face. She's tall and lithe, her eyes are huge and run several depths of blue. Her father worked in the markets in the old Halles, she grew up in Montmartre, and now, lacing up her battered, steel-backed shoes, she's every inch the feisty, self-reliant Parisienne.

LEAD: THIS IS THE ONLY CITY IN America with an entrance. You slide and slither into most downtowns, passing through gradual layers of ever-more-intensely built-up sprawl, and you do not so much enter the center as realize after you are there that it is all around you. Not Pittsburgh. Pittsburgh is entered with glory and drama.

LEAD: Top Dogs WHEN Tony Bullock, the incoming East Hampton Town Supervisor, was still in the Suffolk County Legislature and gave out his Thanksgiving ''Stuffed Turkey Awards'' for waste in county government, he included in the list $125,000 that had been allocated for ''a police dog academy.'' The Suffolk County

LEAD: A HALF-HOUR before a recent game between Georgetown and Florida International in Miami, some fans in back of the Hoyas' bench unfurled a banner exhorting, of all things, the Syracuse University basketball team.

LEAD: ONE of the reasons that color-print films outsell color-slide films is their reproducibility. Take a picture on slide film of the family gathered together round the Yule log and you get back a slide, period. Take the same picture on print film and you get back a print and a negative. With the negative, you can order as many duplicates of the picture as there are family members.
LEAD: Last September, New Jersey's Attorney General received an urgent call from the Superintendent of the state police.

LEAD: WHEN Toyota and General Motors opened their joint-venture auto plant in Fremont, Calif., in 1984, workers began each shift with several minutes of calisthenics accompanied by piped-in music. Today the music remains, but nobody bothers with the calisthenics.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: THE LIFE OF KENNETH TYNAN By Kathleen Tynan. Illustrated. 597 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

LEAD: WINTER CHAMBER SERIES There's nothing like good chamber music to chase away midwinter blues. At least, that's what the programmers at the Islip Arts Council suggest. So once again, the council has put together a series of free concerts for Sunday afternoons through March. This month, the musicians will make music at the Bayard Cutting Arboretum in Oakdale; in February and March, the activity moves to another Oakdale site, Fortunoff Hall on the Dowling

LEAD: ''THE church fights the enemies of yesterday and the friends of tomorrow.'' That enigmatic slogan, a senior Vatican diplomat said, explains how the Roman Catholic Church dealt with the Huns and the French Revolution - and how it now deals with the Soviet Union.

LEAD: A Federal judge awarded temporary custody of the 9-year-old son of a Zimbabwean diplomat to the State Department yesterday, apparently clearing the way for the child's return to Zimbabwe tomorrow.

LEAD: The engagement of Sheila Ann Murphy to Michael Maurice Azarian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Azarian of Andover, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Murphy of Oldwick, N.J., and Groton Long Point, Conn. An April wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor: I enjoyed touring the London record shops vicariously with Mr. Haber. I spend a lot of time in the jazz specialty shops every time I'm in London.

LEAD: THE NATION'S first program that links welfare payments to students' attendance will start in Wisconsin on Feb. 1. The program, known as ''Learnfare,'' was passed at the urging of Gov. Tommy Thompson in what he described as an effort to discourage welfare dependency.

LEAD: WHEN Barbara Boynton and John Odom cook a holiday dinner, it is no slapdash affair. There is a huge goose, sausage- and-chestnut dressing, carrots, brussels sprouts, all kinds of traditional accoutrements. Cookware of every type comes into play - except one. There is not a piece of microwave cookware in sight.
LEAD: Who will win the playoffs? Who cares? BRIAN B. BOEHM Sea Cliff, N.Y.

LEAD: As Eastern Europe enters a period of political and economic fluidity, the United States faces a quandary. If it does nothing, it forfeits an opportunity. If it does too much, it risks fostering an instability that could deliver a severe setback to Soviet-American relations.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Carl London of Bulls Head, S.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sherri Sue London, to Michael Edward Pastolove, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Pastolove of Brookville, L.I. Ms. London, an account representative for the Arts and Entertainment Cable Network in New York, graduated from the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University.
LEAD: THE TENANTS OF TIME By Thomas Flanagan. 824 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/E. P. Dutton. $21.95.
LEAD: Two polls made public this week brought some good news for France's Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, and bad news for its conservative Prime Minister, Jacques Chirac.
LEAD: In the A.F.C., Indianapolis and Houston lack experience. Seattle has the talent but is missing chemistry. Denver and Cleveland will play again for the title, but this time the Browns will win.

LEAD: The number of aliens applying for legal status under the new immigration law has dropped steadily in recent months, raising serious questions about whether the program will reach its envisioned total of two million applicants before it ends May 4.

LEAD: MARIO RESTAURANT on Motor Parkway in Hauppauge is at the epicenter of the fastest-growing business and industrial complex on Long Island. Restaurants have blossomed along the parkway in response to this burgeoning business community. Mario, now seven years old, was one of the first. It has retained its early popularity and tops many a businessman's list of favorite dining spots.

LEAD: Recent insider trading scandals have again focused attention on violations of the law and of the code of business ethics. But which business leaders - and companies - are conducting themselves with the highest level of propriety? Business Forum editor Joel Kurtzman sampled the opinions of seven experts on business and ethics.

LEAD: After a 22-year-old court battle over errant tee shots, the Quaboag Country Club in Monson has agreed to shorten its ninth hole in hopes of keeping golf balls off the property of John and Miriam Fenton.

LEAD: CHOREOGRAPHERS NEED more than ideas. They need time, dancers, rehearsal space - and money. Therefore, any attempt to help choreographers is welcome. Yet, with help may come unwelcome complications.

LEAD: The start of every year invites new resolve about how we will improve ourselves. The start of every fourth year invites new resolve about how we will improve the nation. Soon many of us will go on diets, and many of us will begin listening in earnest to what the Presidential candidates have to say.

LEAD: A new corporation, just a few months old, is poised to play a big role in the New Haven housing boom. Its legal team includes some of the nation's finest tax, finance and real-estate lawyers - a pool of talent that the largest companies in the world would covet. On paper, this is a corporation to watch.

LEAD: ONE Sunday I paid a visit to my fifth-grade teacher, Sister Devota Maria, a nun I had't seen since 1945, when I graduated from St. Pascal Babylon School in St. Albans, New York City. It was the ending to a rather unplanned day.

LEAD: A West German charter plane carrying 16 people crashed in mountainous countryside near the western coast tonight. Everyone aboard was believed to have been killed, the Anatolia news agency reported.

LEAD: The engagement of Patricia A. Gallagher to Gregory A. Ryan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Ryan of Morristown, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mr. Edward F. X. Gallagher of Newburgh, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in June.

LEAD: Gary Jennings's article ''Old and Novel'' (On Language, Nov. 29) is devoted to an impassioned plea for the compilation of a dictionary of ''What People Used to Call Things.'' Such a dictionary is, in fact, being edited at the University of Glasgow - it will be called the Historical Thesaurus of English.

LEAD: An old-world open-air grocery marketplace within blocks of an upscale nightclub; a restaurant with a la carte menus priced to match New York establishments around the corner from a family-owned diner serving more than you can eat for less than half as much and, braving the cold winds off Lake Erie, 80,000 Browns fans regularly packing Cleveland's Municipal
LEAD: CULTURE is alive and well in the Connecticut Berkshires.

LEAD: Investigators looking into an MX missile fire that killed five workers at a Morton Thiokol plant here are examining the possibility that static electricity may have ignited the blaze, a company official said. A 23-foot MX segment containing 100,000 pounds of solid propellant burst into flames Tuesday after the fuel had been poured into the rocket segment, Thiokol said.
LEAD: THE deed is done. Upon the doctor's insistence, we have placed my husband's stepmother in a nursing home near us.

LEAD: THE Joffrey Ballet's new Victorian production of ''The Nutcracker'' is so pretty a spectacle and is performed with such liveliness that it seems almost like splitting hairs to talk of mundane things like role debuts. On Friday at City Center, however, Leslie Carothers and Ashley Wheater danced the Sugar Plum Fairy and the Nutcracker Prince for the first time in New York.

LEAD: The Yonkers City Council today appointed Neil J. DeLuca, a former Yonkers youth services director, as city manager. He is to serve until a nationwide search for a permanent manager is completed.

LEAD: JAZZ CLARINETISTS, A RARE breed since the 1940's, are making a comeback. Two recently released albums, ''Southern Bells'' by the Clarinet Summit and Hamiet Bluiett's ''The Clarinet Family,'' both Polygram imports on the Black Saint label, document the work of no less than 12 contemporary jazz clarinetists.

LEAD: College Basketball Rutgers 77, Arizona 54: Sue Wicks scored 17 points and grabbed 11 rebounds and Rutgers reeled off 14 straight first-half points last night on the way to a victory over Arizona in Piscataway, N.J. The victory was the 35th straight at home for the Lady Knights and raised their record to 6-2.
LEAD: In his article ''Star Wars Is Coming, but Where Is It Going?'' (Dec. 6), William J. Broad repeats a common fallacy: ''nuclear weapons cannot be uninvented.''

LEAD: ZURS is an expert skier's jewel in the crown of the Arlberg, the spectacular range of chalk-stone mountains in western Austria. For skiers whose mission is to find challenging slopes in an intimate European village high above the tree line, it is close to perfection. The main street, which you can walk in 10 minutes, is bordered by chalet-style hotels and a few shops.

LEAD: THE United States Postal Service will release two statehood issues in the next six days. A Georgia statehood commemorative will be released Wednesday, to be followed Saturday by a Connecticut statehood commemorative. Both stamps are part of a series of 13. The series began last July with a Delaware issue to celebrate the bicentennial of that state's ratification of the United States
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: PRESIDENT Reagan now has about a year left to work his will on international events, to shape his legacy. But, as he has certainly seen in the last seven years, the capacity to control world affairs from the Oval Office is sorely limited, and the prospects for dramatic accomplishments in the final period seem slim.
LEAD: The Israeli Army kept a heavy guard on the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip today and only minor disturbances were reported.

LEAD: WHAT MAKES A WORK OF art ''great''? What makes a painting or sculpture more than the sum of its parts, more than a document of a person, period, position or style? What is it about a work that makes people from other periods and places keep returning to it?

LEAD: IT'S a brand new year here at the American Widget Works in Ludd, Tex., a ficticious company that we founded a few minutes ago (even though our motto is ''Serving Luddites Since 1982''). Widget Works is a small but growing company that designs, manufactures and distributes high-quality widgets to fine stores and airport souvenir stands.
LEAD: Earmuff Exalted In Maine's Chill

LEAD: IT was hailed in its time, but now the West Side Improvement is to some an awful blight and to others a magnificent opportunity. The elevated railroad, completed in 1934, snakes around and even through industrial buildings on the Lower West Side of Manhattan. It will either be demolished or returned to service, depending on the outcome of litigation that began in 1985.

LEAD: THE RANDOM HOUSE DICTIONARY OF THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE Second Edition, Unabridged. Edited by Stuart Berg Flexner with Leonore Crary Hauck. Illustrated. 2,478 pp. New York: Random House. $79.95. THIS outsize unabridged dictionary, the first in English in 20-odd years, weighs in at 12-plus pounds. It involved nine years' labor by 340 lexicographers and consultants, and its 2,500 pages contain 50,000 new words; 75,000 fresh definitions; Italian, French, Spanish and German dictionaries; prodigious, encyclopedic information; spankingly updated entries on high-tech jargon, trade names,
LEAD: FILL bird feeders daily. Put gift house plants in a cool, draft free location and keep soil moist. Move tender gesneriads, such as African violets, away from cool windows. From Catalogues

LEAD: WHEN a corporate management decides that a subsidiary no longer fits into its grand design for the future, one solution is to spin off the unit to the company's shareholders. For the company, one advantage of such a transaction is that unlike an outright sale, it would probably not be subject to Federal income taxes.

LEAD: AS HIGH SCHOOL students in California start selecting classes next fall, some will be able to get credit for an unusual language course -American Sign Language. The addition of the language of the deaf as an acceptable alternative to the state's requirement that students complete a course in either a foreign language or visual or performing arts will take effect July 1.
LEAD: WHEN the Soviet Union offered to sell to the public photos of the earth taken by its space satellites, the United States Geological Survey expressed keen interest.

LEAD: Because of mechanical errors, a review of William Duggan's ''Lovers of the African Night'' on Dec. 20 included two incorrect phrases. They should have read: ''Ata Four is a woman of courage; when a vicious Boer sets his dogs loose and three innocent Africans are killed, Ata pays the Boer back with honey-and-mustard goat meat pies laced with rat poison''; and, ''She has a son, Kanye -which means 'enough' - and lives to see him become a hero: In a student demonstration against abuses in education he is shot by the police.

LEAD: Anita Marie Chilen, the president and a co-owner of Charles Sumner Inc., women's clothing stores in Boston and Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married yesterday at St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in Chestnut Hill to Robin S. Lincoln, a stockbroker at Tucker, Anthony & R. L. Day in Boston. The Rev. James

LEAD: SUDDENLY EVERYBODY IS TALKING about greed. It may not be a brand-new topic, but after the chastening experience of the stock market fall in October it seems an all too appropriate one. We virtuously distance ourselves from yesterday's excesses (without necessarily discarding today's); and three works in particular have shown up at just the right time to highlight our concerns - Oliver Stone's movie ''Wall Street,'' Caryl Churchill's play ''Serious Money'' and Tom Wolfe's novel ''The Bonfire of the Vanities.

LEAD: THE questions asked most insistently of this column concern the small ads in newspapers, including this one, that simply list cities in Europe and Asia and then prices. At the bottom of the ad is the name of an organization, a phone number and sometimes an address.

LEAD: DICK ROBERTSON, a senior executive with Lorimar Telepictures in Los Angeles, is the quintessential bicoastal fitness fanatic. Whether at home in Malibu or on his frequent trips to New York, the 6-foot-3, 186-pound executive works out six days a week with trainers. In 1987, Mr. Robertson estimates he spent upwards of $20,000 on instructors, equipment and club memberships.
LEAD: ADULTS WHO decided to forgo undergraduate degrees in earlier years are now pursuing them in record numbers, and a growing number of colleges have stepped up their efforts to accommodate them.

LEAD: Senator Albert Gore Jr., who has staked his Presidential campaign on the support of the South, picked up two political prizes in North Carolina today, winning the endorsements of Senator Terry Sanford and former Gov. Jim Hunt.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH charitable organizations had expected deficits in holiday fund-raising this year because of the uncertain economy, most major charities in New Jersey seem to have raised at least as much as they did last year.

LEAD: Jenifer Frenze, a lawyer in Philadelphia, and J. Philip Donahue, a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at Columbia University, were married yesterday at Old St. Mary's Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. Edwin Sanders performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.
LEAD: I REMEMBER it vividly. The Super Bowl ring that I promised to my father as a senior in high school suddenly appeared on the finger of John Riggins.

LEAD: THE COMPACT DISK REVOLUTION reminds many old-timers of the early days of the LP. Starting around 1950, dozens, then scores, then hundreds of small companies started putting out a kind of product, especially in classical music, that the major companies would not touch. Suddenly we had a plethora of Baroque music.

LEAD: FOR 20 years, Richard Chamberlain did not speak of his experiences as a United States Marine during the Vietnam War. This week, he will preside at the opening of an exhibit of 40 of his paintings that deal with the year he spent in Vietnam.
LEAD: HOCKEY

LEAD: ''THIS HAS COST ME A novel,'' says Chaim Potok. ''I should be working on it right now. I really should. And I will never write it. You have a finite life to live, so that the price I've paid is a novel, and I don't know whether it is or is not worth it. Because I don't have that novel and I will never have that novel.
LEAD: THIS Monmouth County township has a rich legacy waiting to be written about, including the settlement of its westernmost village (Allenwood) and at least two Revolutionary War heroes.
LEAD: ''The Chicago market is a made-for-speculation market, but it leads New York around by the nose.''

LEAD: WHEN a major exhibition of the work of Georgia O'Keeffe, marking the centennial of the artist's birth, opened at Washington's National Gallery of Art two months ago, a big, lavish book entitled ''Georgia O'Keeffe Arts and Letters,'' containing 120 color plates of all the exhibited work, accompanied the exhibition.

LEAD: A CAJUN quarterback from a small town in Louisiana may not evoke the most flattering image in some of the more sophisticated towns around the National Football League. In New Orleans, however, the return of Bobby Hebert in 1985 was a cause for celebration, like discovering another oil field or returning from a fishing trip with the nets bulging.
LEAD: RAISING CHILDREN was easier when I was little.
LEAD: ''THE strategic realities are now changing,'' said the briefing officer at the Training and Doctrine Command here, which does long-range thinking for the Army.
LEAD: A fire ignited by a time bomb that exploded in a Nativity scene in Cambridge is the latest in a series of arson cases at churches and religious settings in eastern Massachusetts.

LEAD: BELOW THE LINE. Living Poor in America. By Eugene Richards. (Consumers Union, Cloth, $32; Paper, $20.) People will be more concerned about poverty in America if they see its face up close. That appears to be the premise that inspired Eugene Richards, an award-winning photographer, to put together this book, a collection of photographs and interviews documenting the hardship endured by 21 of the nation's 32.4 million poor people.

LEAD: Mary Elizabeth Ware, an administrator at the New School for Social Research, and James Howard Rathlesberger, the assistant executive vice president of the National Health Council in New York, were married yesterday at the Congregational-Presbyterian Church in Lewiston, Idaho. The Rev. John Williams performed the ceremony.

LEAD: LISTENING TO MIKHAIL S. Gorbachev's impassioned address in the rococo white-and-gold ballroom of the Soviet Embassy on 16th Street in Washington, on the late afternoon of Dec. 8, in a heterogeneous gathering of some 50 fellow American ''intellectuals'' and ''artists,'' I recalled these cryptic words of Nietzsche's; but wondered if my habitual skepticism, particularly regarding politics in its most public, theatrical mode, might be irrelevant here, unjustified.

LEAD: WAKING AT night, I made my way in the dark to the bathroom without trouble, but when I switched on the light, I was stunned: it wasn't my bathroom at home - or, in fact, any bathroom I'd ever seen. I supposed I must be in a hotel on a business trip - but what trip? What hotel? I had no idea. Panic such as one feels in certain nightmares swept over me, but this was no nightmare; I was definitely awake.
LEAD: Visiting Cyprus
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Randy Sue Caplan, a third-year student at the Fordham University school of Law, and Dr. Michael Hunter Perskin, a resident in internal medicine at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York, plan to be married on Jan. 31.

LEAD: A teen-ager was trapped inside a trash compactor and was crushed to death Friday while workers tried to rescue him. Michael Hucorne, 17 years old, was compacting trash in a large compactor behind a supermarket with another young employee when he became trapped. He was squeezed between the top of the compactor and a lower compacting level, the police said.

LEAD: EARLY ONE brisk autumn morning, just as the school buses were beginning to roll, three members of the Parent Team, part of School District One in New York City, jumped into a four-door sedan and sped off to Public School 188. After stopping briefly to check in with the principal, they charged up five flights of stairs and burst into the computer room where they found exactly what they were looking for: parents and students learning how to run computer programs - together.

LEAD: ENGLISH COMP is the minesweeper of the educational fleet. There's absolutely no status in running such a class, or ship. Yet somehow the whole fleet looks very silly without it. The minesweeper clears away problems everybody else pretends are not there. It's time-consuming, hazardous duty. And if, when I'm done, there are only half as many mines - comma splices, sentence fragments and the like - have I succeeded?
LEAD: BY defeating John Nunn in their tie-break match in Budapest, Lajos Portisch became the 14th qualifier for the elimination matches to pick the 1990 challenger for the world championship.

LEAD: I WANTED to learn something about word processors. ''The Word Processing Book'' by Peter A. McWilliams was recommended to me. It has all sorts of useful information: it tells students how, when they have bought a term paper, they may alter it with a word processor to suit their own ''personal style.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-15

LEAD: A State Assemblyman, joined by environmentalists, has announced the formation of an organization to stop a $48 million Army Corps of Engineers project because it would flood part of Letchworth State Park.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Shafter of New Canaan, Conn., and Peru, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Dunn Shafter to James Thomas Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Sullivan of Bristol and Old Saybrook, Conn.

LEAD: AFTER suffering municipal corruption and a failing economy, New Britain is undergoing a rejuvenation. A highlight was President Reagan's visit to the city last July, in which he cited New Britain as an example of a remarkable economic comeback.

LEAD: Q. We have a brick patio with a northern exposure, and there is a problem with mold and mildew forming on these bricks. We have to scrub them several times a year with bleach to remove the growth. Do you have any suggestions for preventing this growth?
LEAD: The Week in Business column last week misidentified the company from which Steve S. Chen recently resigned. It was Cray Research Inc.

LEAD: IT WAS the typical student scramble: Robert E. Vanasek pulled an all-nighter to finish his midterm in Political Management, went to class, and just half an hour before it was due, packed his knapsack and sneaked out to pick up the paper from the typist, barely making it back to class by the deadline.

LEAD: THERE IS A FELLOW who drives around San Francisco with a bumper sticker that says, Il faut boire du pinot noir: ''Drink pinot noir.'' Who would argue with that? To paraphrase Will Rogers, I've never met a man who didn't like pinot noir.

LEAD: At Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I., Janice Lynn Landis, the daughter of Harriet Landis of Bellmore, L.I., was married last evening to Ira Jason Schacter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Schacter of Merrick, L.I. Rabbi Saul Teplitz performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THERE was never any doubt about what the inside label would say. The clothes and fabrics, with their striking design and splashes of bold color, were clearly Marimekko. But for people of a certain generation - those who came of age in the 1960's - they represented more than just a brand name: They conjured up an image and an era.

LEAD: A simple test for drunkenness while driving, introduced by the Federal Government four years ago, is being praised by police officials across the country. However, a few officers find difficulty in its simplicity, which involves checking the suspect's gaze.

LEAD: A POSITIVE attitude is synonymous with the new year. The two go together like bagels and lox, corned beef and cabbage, toasts and champagne. The only difference is that unlike the other pairings, the positive attitude and the new year don't stay married for long. They separate after the first few days and there's usually a divorce within the month.

LEAD: 'BILOXI BLUES' IN MILLBURN Neil Simon's ''Biloxi Blues,'' which won a Tony award for best play in 1985, opens Wednesday at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn. It is the middle work in Mr. Simon's semi-autobiographical trilogy, which begins with ''Brighton Beach Memoirs'' and ends with ''Broadway Bound.

LEAD: THOUGH I HAD PERENNIALLY felt anxiety during midwinter's failing light, the nadir of my depression came the spring I contemplated killing myself. That was nearly two years ago. Exhausted from insomnia and unable to function, I left my job before noon one day and went home to the suburbs.
LEAD: ALMOST as difficult as the scientific riddle of AIDS is the ethical question of whether doctors are obliged to care for patients infected with the deadly virus.

LEAD: A history of Weston's role in the Revolutionary War notes that the farming town was half a day's carriage ride to Boston and a favorite overnight spot for weary travelers headed for the state capital.
