LEAD: MORE than 144,000 women in Connecticut's cities, suburbs and rural areas have lost their main source of income, state officials say. Five years ago, there were roughly 70,000 of these women, termed displaced homemakers.
LEAD: UNUSUAL COMPANY By Margaret Erhart. 225 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

LEAD: AMONG top-ranked players, not one in a hundred is as active in bridge administration as he, or she, is at the card table. When one of these rare mortals achieves a major success, it is time to cheer for dedicated enthusiasm has received a fitting reward.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: 'The French have a saying that the cemeteries are full of indispensable people. . . . If I come back and function better, it is better for the university.'

LEAD: AMID THE burst of question marks that traditionally rain down on the freshman heading off to college, the dorm room often emerges as the one certainty - reassuringly available, universally inhospitable. Parents in tow, the car trunk a tangle of quilts, extension cords and Impressionist posters, the fresh college student arrives on campus, greeted by an overly cheerful junior who motions toward the new home.

LEAD: Joshua Schulman, project manager for Twin Creeks Village, said the architecture of the East Fishkill, N.Y., development would reflect ''the essence of a New England farmhouse and a more formal colonial home.'' He meant not only the 424 town houses planned for the 110-acre project, but also the 54 condominiums for older people and a 24,000-square-foot office and retail building.
LEAD: Charles Smith scored 30 points and Jerome Lane grabbed 21 rebounds today as Pittsburgh dominated Florida inside for an 80-68 victory.

LEAD: SIXTY years ago, Thomas J. Watson Sr. paced the maple floors in the International Business Machines Corporation's giant plant here in the center of New York State, presiding over the production of time clocks and meat slicers. Now, on those same floors, I.B.M. has spent hundreds of millions of dollars building a state-of-the-art production line that can snap together in minutes its newest, smallest and most price-competitive mini-mainframe computer.
LEAD: Members of the faculty of Boston University have lost another round in their fight to prove they have less power than faculties at other schools.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Livingston $280,000 6 Rale Terrace 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 34-year-old split level; C/A, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $3,354. Millburn $235,000 750 Ridgewood Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 43-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $3,141.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: For residents of Manhattan's East 10th Street, Christmas this year meant turkeys, presents - and the burglar alarm on a fancy European sports car, which blasted off and wailed for four hours.

LEAD: Pro football is no longer a sport but a business; the game has been structurally altered. Society's values are reflected in this uniquely American game. This game is violence, greed and absolutely dull.

LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair is expected to submit questions to Vice President Bush about his role in the sale of American weapons to Iran and is considering requesting an interview with Mr. Bush, according to Reagan Administration officials.

LEAD: THERE'S NOT MUCH GOLD IN them, actually. According to International Olympic Committee regulations, the Olympic bronze medals shall be bronze, the silver medals silver, but each gold medal, weighing 193 grams in all, must contain just six grams of the stuff. Mostly, the golds are made of sterling silver, too.

LEAD: I believe I can aid Gary Jennings with the ancient word for getting ''bucked'' off a horse. I give him instead: equiabiciate. I recalled that reference from my high-school Latin toils with ''Caesar's Gallic Wars,'' wherein that Roman military genius sent a Gallic horseman with a message to Cicero, his general in the field.
LEAD: UNITED STATES diplomats are expected to visit here later this month in a new attempt to break the impasse in Angola's 12-year civil war.

LEAD: WHEN workers ripped up the nine-year-old artificial turf at Riverfront Stadium two weeks ago to clear the way for the installation of a new surface, they were instructed by Cincinnati Reds officials to save one piece of the carpet - and of baseball history. That was the patch where Pete Rose's 4,192d hit landed on Sept.

LEAD: WEARY, forgetful and slow-moving, Penelope, a fairy godmother, is up for retirement. All she needs to reach it is to grant one more wish. But by the time she remembers just who is wishing what - and gets to them - ''they've already gotten what they want.''

LEAD: CONGRESS created the national Office of Education in 1867 and then, not quite sure of what it was supposed to do, ordered its Commissioner to keep an eye on the Federal reindeer herds in Alaska. Commissioners have since been relieved of their reindeer-watching duties, but the tradition of turning to education to deal with everything from driver safety to drug abuse lives on.
LEAD: IN THE INSULAR WORLD OF television comedy, something curious is happening: On a number of new shows, no one is laughing.

LEAD: ANNA DELANEY'S CHILD, by John Thorndike. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) Anna Delaney is grief-stricken by the loss of her son in a car crash; her father, Alex, is depressed over the death of his wife. This ''lyrically powerful'' first novel ''deftly explores the ethics of memory, dramatizing how Anna and Alex learn to forge bonds with the living without betraying their loving memories of the dead,'' Sherie Posesorski said in The Book Review in 1986.
LEAD: J. R. Reid scored 25 points today to lead North Carolina to an 80-73 victory over U.C.L.A.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Covenant House, the shelter for runaway youths that hoped to build its endowment when it bought the Times Square Motor Hotel on West 43d Street three years ago, has sold the hotel to the New York International Hostel Corporation after operating it at a loss.
LEAD: Jessica Lee Stedman and Andrew Joseph Guff Jr. were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan by Msgr. John V. Bartos, an uncle of the bridegroom.
LEAD: In this bizarre season, who else can win but the Saints? CHRIS LEAVEY Jamaica Estates, N.Y.
LEAD: A HALF-CENTURY ago, Edward I. Brown bought a 40-acre tract here in Monmouth County, a onetime gravel pit along the northern fringe of the Pine Barrens.

LEAD: SOMETIME in February, Senator William Proxmire, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, plans to have it take up the next step in bank deregulation - repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act.

LEAD: SINCE the days when burly, bewigged policemen masqueraded as women to catch molesters, police departments around the country have used decoy officers to trap suspected muggers, rapists and other criminals. The technique works, but it has sometimes been abused. Officers have been accused of entrapping suspects by dangling money, flaunting jewelry, planting evidence - a practice sometimes called ''flaking,'' though the origin of the term is uncertain - or tricking a target into picking up a valuable item an officer has purposely dropped.
LEAD: In a brief ceremony made significant by its ordinariness, Emperor Hirohito appeared before thousands of his subjects today to wish them well and to be heartily cheered in turn.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Martha Graham took on the gods and goddesses in her choreography, following which dance entered into a period of relative abstraction. A program this week suggests that myths and the subconscious may be becoming popular once more as a subject for dances. Marjorie Gamso, a postmodernist-era choreographer known for the resonant intensity of her dances, presents ''Her Thousand and One Nights'' at Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street, Friday through next
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In percent Tax-Exempt Bonds 7.86 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index Money Market Funds 6.92 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield Bank Money Market Accounts 5.82 Bank Rate Monitor Home Mortgage 9.82 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum fixed rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 14.50 Continental Illinois, Chicago 14.00 Bank of America, San Francisco 18.25

LEAD: THE NEW SEASON: A Spectator's Guide to the 1988 Election. By George F. Will. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) In this eclectic and engaging smorgasbord of bons mots, statistics, anecdotes and epigrams, one source crashes George F. Will's buffet line twice. ''This ain't a football game. We do this every day,'' Earl Weaver, former manager of the Baltimore Orioles, says about baseball.

LEAD: WHEN Jeanne Lorenz graduated from the Milwaukee High School for the Arts last spring, she had a scholarship to the University of Wisconsin, and she thought she was destined for college in the fall. Because she is the oldest of four children in a single-parent family, her mother was relieved that her daughter's higher education was being paid for.
LEAD: ONCE again this great nation of ours has avoided a major schism. The center has held. E pluribus unum and all that.
LEAD: BRUBECK AND BRUBECK Four years ago, Darius Brubeck joined the music faculty of the University of Natal in South Africa to teach jazz. Since then, Durban has become a mecca for jazz buffs.

LEAD: New technology has made the telephone more versatile. Calls can be dialed by simply pressing one button. People at three or more locations can speak at once. During a conversation, a beep signals that another call is waiting.
LEAD: There is a regular chorus of beeps and bleets emanating from one Mount Vernon home today -sounds reverberating in Bronxville and in New Rochelle.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Gary R. Gruber of Bryn Mawr, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Martha Gruber, to Richard William Wagner, the son of the Rev. and Mrs. William O. Wagner of Southbury, Conn.
LEAD: Time is precious these days as planners for the San Diego Yacht Club scurry to come up with an innovative boat design for its America's Cup defense against New Zealand.

LEAD: ''It is hard to imagine a more positive or more hopeful beginning to 1988.'' - Alexander B. Trowbridge, president, National Association of Manufacturers, on U.S.-Canada trade agreement. [ 12:3. ]

LEAD: Buried deep in the catchall spending bill passed by Congress are two pointed swipes at the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency. One virtually invites the Defense Secretary to slash the agency's personnel budget; the other takes away two aircraft used at embassies around the world to fly ambassadors, military attaches and visitors.
LEAD: The Word-Killer In an encyclopedic novel that was a recent best seller in France, Georges Perec describes an unusual occupation. This is from ''Life: A User's Manual'' (Godine).

LEAD: IN A MOVE to make its liberal arts students more attractive to potential employers, the University of Rochester is spicing up its liberal arts curriculum with a series of ''practical'' business-related courses. The new program is bound to be alluring to students as well - the university is giving the courses away.

LEAD: St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Lynda A. Ceremsak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Ceremsak of Hamilton, Mass., to F. George Davitt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Alan Davitt of Delmar, N.Y. The Rev. John Costello performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A former coroner's investigator has accused some of his former colleagues of stealing money, jewelry and other property from the dead, and a grand jury is investigating the allegations, a newspaper reported Friday.

LEAD: To The Editor: With reference to the Practical Traveler (Nov. 29) concerning travel agents: I am an agent who happily books leisure travel, and I would like to point out a few additional services a good travel agent can offer.
LEAD: I RELEASED trout bigger than I had ever caught before. Then I hooked and lost trout bigger than that. And then I spooked trout still bigger.

LEAD: The marriage of Laura Jeanne Dutzek, the daughter of Henry Dutzek of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and the late Barbara Mae Dutzek, to Jonathan Simons Lichter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Lichter of Larchmont, N.Y., and New York, took place yesterday at Singer's Caterers in Spring Valley, N.Y. Kenneth Rones, a town justice in Clarkstown, N

LEAD: A. WHITNEY BROWN, whose sardonic political commentaries inject a note of ferocious cynicism into the ''Weekend Update'' segments of ''Saturday Night Live,'' brings an air of offended gentility to his analyses of world affairs and governmental mismanagement. An apple-cheeked smoothie, whose deep-set eyes glint with inscrutable comic cool, Mr.

LEAD: A FURTHER decline in the value of the dollar against major foreign currencies would be, on balance, bullish for foreign stocks. However, one risk of investing abroad is that a drop in foreign stock markets could offset the advantage of the currency play. With that caveat in mind, what are some foreign stocks that appear attractive for 1988?

LEAD: Martin Charnin, a Broadway lyricist, is to lead a workshop in lyric writing and directing for the musical theater, during two-hour sessions, Jan. 7, 11, 14 and 21 at 7:30 P.M., at the 92d Street Y School of Music, at 1395 Lexington Avenue.

LEAD: Everyone hears this is a difficult time in Argentina, but it's also a promising one. Fashionable Buenos Aires fills its conversation with the troubles. To discern the positive requires poking beneath the surface of the capital's complex and Italianate political life and venturing into the million-square-mile interior.

LEAD: The October collpase ended what had been an astounding bull market here. This was the year that the Tokyo stock market's capitalization exceeded New York's - at the end of October, the New York Stock Exchange was capitalized at $2.254 trillion, while Tokyo was worth $2.677 trillion, according to Morgan

LEAD: Every Friday night in an old school auditorium tucked back in the southeast Tennessee mountains, a brand of bluegrass music in the tradition of the early days of the Grand Ole Opry takes center stage.

LEAD: Tennis Shriver Overcomes Novotna: Top-seeded Pam Shriver of Lutherville, Md., had to struggle for almost two hours yesterday, but she defeated Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 7-6, in the championship of the Ariadne Classic at the Milton Courts in Brisbane, Australia. Shriver won $25,000.
LEAD: Joseph Sittler, a Lutheran theologian known for his work on religion and ecology, died of cancer Dec. 28 at his home in Chicago. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: On the human rights calendar, 1987 belonged to the brave, especially those who risked their skins monitoring governments. These are freedom's foot soldiers, volunteers who courageously record the names of political prisoners and report on torture and star-chamber justice.
LEAD: One man was fatally shot and another was critically wounded in a sudden burst of gunfire yesterday afternoon as the two men were leaving a restaurant in Elmhurst, Queens, the police said.

LEAD: This year the performance of various segments of the media industry could vary widely. Cable television, for example, is expected to have a very strong year. But the growth of cable is among the key factors that may make it a relatively lackluster year for broadcasters.

LEAD: After two years of heavy losses that turned the plight of the nation's semiconductor industry into an international political issue, chip makers returned to profitability in 1987. Industry officials and analysts generally expect a continuation of the recovery in 1988.

LEAD: The Resident Associate Program of the Smithsonian Institution has for years been enriching the Washington scene with a variety of offerings for people who hold membership in the institution - from lectures, concerts and film programs to courses and seminars on architecture, religion and the arts.
LEAD: Former Gov. Bruce Babbitt may have poor name recognition in Iowa and New Hampshire, but some residents of his home state think his name is too prominent.
LEAD: Chinese organized crime's involvement in extortion, prostitution, loan sharking, gun smuggling and murder is sharply on the rise in the New York area, law-enforcement officials say.

LEAD: In Hong Kong, the stock market underwent a devastating collapse in October that seriously harmed confidence. The market's Hang Seng index started the year at 2,568.30 and finished at 2,302.75, down about 10 percent. Its high for the year was 3,944.24 on Oct. 1.
LEAD: Rarely has the computer industry entered a new year so uncertain whether it would soar or stagnate.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The flow of economic and financial news in 1987 - which seemed dominated by insider trading investigations, questions about international economic cooperation and the stock market plunge - thrust many people into the spotlight.

LEAD: ANN JILLIAN has kept a tight rein on ''The Ann Jillian Story,'' the television movie on NBC at 9 this evening. A year or more of skirmishing took place before Ms. Jillian settled on a teleplay by Audrey Davis Levin. Corey Allen is the director. And Ms. Jillian plays herself. The result is admirable in some ways, puzzling in others.
LEAD: Inauguration Day is more than a year away, but speculation has already begun on candidates for the new President's Cabinet, in particular the person who might become Secretary of the Treasury.
LEAD: MY FIRST LOVES by Ivan Klima. Translated by Ewald Osers. 164 pages. Harper & Row. $14.95.

LEAD: Few things grab the attention of drivers speeding along the icy, six-lane Glenn Highway here quite so quickly as the sight of a 1,000-pound moose with a vast array of antlers, galloping into the beam of their headlights.
LEAD: The New York Mets will go to any lengths to try to return to their championship form of 1986. Even to Australia.

LEAD: For the Mexican stock market, 1987 has been a year straight out of Charles Dickens: the best of times, the worst of times. For the first nine months of the year, the Bolsa de Valores in Mexico City performed more impressively than any other market in the world, rising eightfold in local currency terms.

LEAD: The game of bridge surely generates more apologies than any other activity, unless one counts late arrival as an activity. Millions of them cross the world's card tables every year, and as many again fail to materialize through stubbornness, lack of courtesy or lack of understanding.
LEAD: Twenty-one people were killed and 14 wounded in overnight Israeli air strikes on Palestinian districts and Lebanese militia positions in southern Lebanon, the Lebanese police said today.

LEAD: IN preparing for the Super Bowl playoffs, coaches often talk about how it's just another football game. ''We haven't approached this game,'' Jim Mora of the Saints said before yesterday's wild-card game, ''any differently than any other game.'' But a playoff game is different. And the Minnesota Vikings approached it differently.

LEAD: The world of big banking acknowledged reality last year, largely as the result of moves by two men: John S. Reed, chairman of Citicorp, and Lewis T. Preston, chairman of J.P. Morgan & Company. In a one-two punch of sorts, the two bankers smashed the myth that such big third-world debtors as Mexico and Brazil would ever fully repay their hundreds of billions of dollars in foreign debt.

LEAD: New York City Transit Authority officials are still fuming over Connecticut's unneighborly issuance of 17.5-cent turnpike tokens that also worked in $1 subway turnstiles. Until the turnstiles were rewired in 1986 to reject slugs, the T.A. lost more than 7,000 full fares a day to the Connecticut coin.

LEAD: When Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, requested that insider trading indictments be dropped against three Wall Street professionals, he promised reporters that a new round of broader indictments against the three would be handed up ''in record-breaking time.''

LEAD: Two years after beginning a campaign against sexually explicit and violent lyrics on record albums, Tipper Gore has moderated her tone but expanded her scope to include music videos, television programming and video cassettes.
LEAD: A report on Dec. 25 about charities in the Soviet Union misidentified the chairman of a fund to help Soviet orphans. He is Albert A. Likhanov.
LEAD: A French singer with a pet pigeon lives there. So do a former vaudeville female impersonator, a saxophonist who played with Benny Goodman and a woman who began her theater career as a cat.
LEAD: Sooner or later, all things must change. Winners become losers, the weak become strong, the young become old.
LEAD: The drastic remaking of this old farm town has changed what it means to be a volunteer.
LEAD: For retailers still reeling from one of the most difficult Christmas seasons in years, 1988 offers little hope for improvement - at least in the early months.

LEAD: It seemed nothing more than a colorful bit of hyperbole from a passionate reader of mystery novels when John J. Phelan Jr., the chairman of New York Stock Exchange, began to talk a year ago about the prospect of a stock market ''meltdown.''
LEAD: The Black Book, proclaimed by its sponsors to be the most comprehensive and useful index to the Washington press corps ever produced, is scheduled to appear this month.
LEAD: The steel industry has made one of the great comebacks in American corporate history. The question now is whether it can continue to hold its own against foreign competition.

LEAD: The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, and an attorney for the Municipal Art Society yesterday sharply criticized a new agreement by the Koch administration to keep alive a controversial Columbus Circle development.
LEAD: Two Americans living in Toronto, Alda and Robert Bell, are often homesick and they try to return to the United States, specifically New York City, several times a year.

LEAD: For the last four weeks, 28 Chilean exiles, including 10 children, have been occupying the local offices of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees as part of a campaign to obtain political asylum in a country other than Brazil.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Companies

LEAD: A 41-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged with the slaying of a 12-year-old Coney Island boy who was shot in the head Dec. 30 as he looked through the peephole of his family's apartment door.

LEAD: Even before Oct. 19, traders on the Paris Bourse were suffering through a tough year. The leading French stock index, the index of the Compagnie des Agents de Change, started the year at 397.80 and peaked on March 26 at 460.40.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: What runner hasn't had to contend with yapping dogs, a car that swerves too close, or a dimly lit route? A dentist in Rockville, Md., who is an avid runner, has come up with a device meant to thwart those annoyances.
LEAD: George Steinbrenner has just about everything money can buy, but the one holiday present he has wanted for years still eludes him: a Presidential pardon.
LEAD: International A2-11

LEAD: Officials in the administration of Prime Minister Jacques Chirac said today that they would formally propose legislation later this month that would set limits for the first time on campaign spending and donations.

LEAD: The 10 inches of snow that fell on Chicago this week snarled the city's airports and roads. But down at the Civic Opera House, where the Lyric Opera is halfway through its most successful season, the big winter storm seemed barely a flurry.

LEAD: The shake-up in the nation's banking industry will accelerate this year. Regional banks will continue to consolidate into bigger and bigger institutions, while the traditional behemoths - based in New York, Chicago and California - will remain locked in their struggle to deal with huge loans to deeply troubled third-world countries.

LEAD: Previous forecasts for the agency business might have been too optimistic, according to Greg M. Ostroff, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company, who is reducing his own domestic growth forecast for 1988 to the 6.5 to 7.5 percent range, from 8-plus, and to 4 percent in a worst-case scenerio.
LEAD: At least 20 people were hurt today when policemen charged demonstrators who were demanding that President H. M. Ershad step down, opposition party leaders and witnesses said.

LEAD: Reminiscing about the growing pains of Shearson Lehman Brothers, Peter A. Cohen, who at 41 is possibly the youngest investment chief on Wall Street, recalls what his daughter, Lauren, told him when she was a little girl.

LEAD: The marriage of Ellen G. Schaffer, the international and foreign law librarian at the Georgetown University Law Center, to Sidney A. Bludman, a professor of physics at the University of Pennsylvania, took place yesterday at the Thomas Law House in Washington. Rabbi Mindy Portnoy performed the ceremony.
LEAD: For American companies seeking to sell debt or equity, Europe is looking barren and forbidding.

LEAD: Krystyna's office opens for business at 7 A.M., but the stores open at 6. So the Polish housewife from the edge of Warsaw starts her day early, standing in line ''maybe for 10 or 15 minutes'' for staples like bread, butter and cheese.

LEAD: Vikings' Anthony Carter, left, being congratulated by Jim Gustafson after scoring a touchdown during Vikings' 44-10 rout of Saints in New Orleans. In Houston, Oilers' Tony Zendejas kicked field goal in overtime as Oilers beat Seahawks, 23-20. SportsMonday, page C1. (NYT/Joe Traver)
LEAD: An hour before his team was scheduled to face Virginia on Saturday night, Rollie Massimino sat in a deserted locker room at the John E. duPont Pavilion contemplating the Big East season.
LEAD: The only problem at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow night will be finding someone to show you your seat, because all but a few of the ushers will be performing.

LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 3, 1988: MONDAY Carolina Freight Nevada Power TUESDAY Centerior Energy Puget Sound Pwr & Lt Orange & Rockland Util WEDNESDAY American Water Works Rite Aid Corp Houston Industries THURSDAY General Pub Utilities Pillsbury Co WR GraceSun Co

LEAD: The story of the Toronto Stock Exchange in 1987 was the story of the commodities markets. Creeping inflation and increased economic activity helped raise the prices of such important commodities as gold and copper. That proved a boon for many companies on Canada's resource-oriented exchange.

LEAD: Opposition by the A. H. Robins Company's shareholders and claimants to a merger between Robins and a French drug maker appeared to be mounting yesterday. The $600 million deal was announced this weekend.
LEAD: Business - the Lord be praised - is good thanks to human ineptitude, Said Ead remarked.

LEAD: The nation's industrial economy expanded briskly in December, significantly outshining November in new orders and production, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report scheduled to be released today.

LEAD: Only three weeks into 1987, the year was already shaping up as an historic one on Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had closed out 1986 at 1,895.95, promptly waltzed past 2,000 on Jan. 8 and then 2,100 on Jan. 19.
LEAD: Mayor Koch declared his own ''Day of Outrage'' last week, but almost nobody came.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation, in an obvious effort to divert attention from its recent market-share losses and other woes, is opening a three-day exposition of its advanced technology in New York City beginning Tuesday.

LEAD: Hundreds of people have offered to adopt a dog that was found wandering in the desert with razor-tipped hunting arrows dangling from its head and body, the police say. The dog, a male shepherd mix under a year old, was found by two women on horseback near Sunset Park. Clark County animal control officers took the dog to an animal hospital, where a veterinarian removed the arrows, disinfected the wounds and kept him under observation.

LEAD: America's passion for new transportaton vehicles remains nearly as ardent as ever. Most industry forecasts call for sales of about 10 million cars and 5 million light trucks - roughly the same as last year but down from 1986, when 16.3 million vehicles were sold.

LEAD: American servicemen and government civilians arriving in Panama are given a printed ''fact sheet'' by the United States Embassy warning them of civil unrest and providing a radio frequency to tune to for information and instructions in case of trouble.

LEAD: Despite expressions of good will from top politicans and educators, Dr. Richard R. Green must contend with a widespread sense of skepticism that an outsider can master the intricacies of the job of New York City Schools Chancellor.

LEAD: There is such a thing as official lust in the Federal Government. Among the many little-known provisions tucked deep within the $17.6 billion deficit-reduction bill adopted by Congress just before Christmas is a Senate amendment covering the excise taxes that are levied on diesel and certain other motor fuels sold wholesale to dealers.
LEAD: Many people in Manhasset, L.I., have compared Gus Potter to George Bailey, the character in the classic Frank Capra film ''It's a Wonderful Life.''

LEAD: Toward the end of the withering four-and-a-half-month process of choosing a New York City schools chancellor, a critical moment came when the president of the Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., telephoned Sandra Feldman, the head of the teachers' union, on Thursday morning.

LEAD: Hollywood not only shrugs off economic uncertainty but thrives on it, according to legend. Despite the ripple effects of the stock market collapse, customers keep pouring into movie theaters, even as ticket prices reached $7 in some areas.
LEAD: Fletcher F. Acord, the third-ranking official in the United States Postal Service, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage, a Postal Service spokesman said. He was 56 years old.

LEAD: Miami was voted the No. 1 college football team in the nation yesterday in both The Associated Press and United Press International polls and also finished on top in The New York Times's computer rankings. Florida State and Oklahoma were second and third, respectively, in all three rankings.
LEAD: Lower fuel prices, fewer discounts, more modest additions of new planes, continuing good traffic. All portend a good year for the airlines. The wild card is labor settlements.
LEAD: ''It's a shame we had to pick this week to be terrible.'' - Tony Elliott of the New Orleans Saints. [ C4:1. ]

LEAD: The West German stock market got off to a bad start in 1987. Foreign investors, who had accounted for 60 percent of the turnover, began to pull out amid concern that the market's bull run was ending. The relative stability of the dollar in the spring led to some improvement, but the summer would prove a calm before the storm.

LEAD: Gary Hart said today that his resurrected Presidential campaign would be directed at the task of convincing voters that he really can govern the country despite the scandal that drove him from the race for seven months.

LEAD: A song contest is one method used by Guinea-Bissau to fight AIDS, which has spread in that nation without many visible signs. Page A2. Higher Profits Are Seen Corporate profits will rise a modest 5 to 7 percent this year, economists say. Page D1. The outlook for 11 industries, pages D6.

LEAD: The beleaguered New York State Legislature returns to Albany on Wednesday for what promises to be a rocky 211th legislative session, filled with tough issues and shadowed by pending corruption trials.
LEAD: Treasury financings this week consist of today's regular weekly sale of new three-month and six-month bills, followed on Wednesday by an auction of seven-year notes.

LEAD: Despite the presence of snow, and a forecast of snow, sleet and rain for today, a golfer kept his swing in tune yesterday at the driving range at Eisenhower Park in East Meadow, L.I. for future milder temperatures. (NYT/Barton Silverman)

LEAD: ANY young man thinking of a career as a professional black-bass fisherman would do well to read Nick Taylor's just-published ''Bass Wars,'' (McGraw-Hill) which describes the fierce struggle either to remain in the big money or to get a small bite of it. So forewarned, he might decide to buy a mule and prospect for gold.

LEAD: Payments by the PTL ministry to Jessica Hahn in exchange for her silence about a tryst with Jim Bakker totaled $363,700, nearly $100,000 more than previously reported, according to an Internal Revenue Service report.
LEAD: The Israeli Army announced today that it would permanently expel nine Palestinian nationalists arrested during the riots of the last three weeks.
LEAD: Three teams in the country average more points a game than the University of Oklahoma basketball team, and they all play in the National Basketball Association.
LEAD: When Cherokee Colony rallied to a promising victory in the Flamingo Stakes here Saturday, it marked the emergence of a new Kentucky Derby contender but the return of a familiar team.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Ask a Texas oilman about the outlook for oil prices in 1988 and the answer typically is about $18 a barrel, or a little more than $1 above the spot price last week for American crude.

LEAD: The Senate has shown good sense in voting to expand Federal school testing. Now the opposition is unlimbering its rhetorical guns for an assault in the House. But its arguments against national tests of student achievement still sound mostly vague and self-serving.

LEAD: The fall of the stock market is rewriting the rules of corporate takeovers. Gone are the swashbuckling raiders who used junk bonds to plunder the business landscape. Instead, Wall Street is expecting a return to normalcy: back to the days when corporations merged for strategic business reasons and not for quick financial gain.

LEAD: The vise tightens on the $450 billion health-care industry, which runs the gamut from drug and medical-supply houses to hospital chains and nursing homes. Many costs are soaring, and skilled workers are scarce in the labor-intensive hospitals, where revenues have been cut by insurer-imposed restrictions.
LEAD: IN a year that was crowded with major advertising developments, the ongoing saga of the J. Walter Thompson Company was clearly the dominant news story.
LEAD: A majority of the police officers in this Chicago suburb, one of the poorest in the country, walked off the job this weekend because they have not been paid in more than two weeks.

LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Unemployment... Dec. Consumer Borrowing... Nov.

LEAD: QUESTION: How many players have hit home runs in their first time at bat in the major leagues and which one of the group wound up with the most homers for a career? Have any made it to the Hall of Fame?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The profits of American corporations are likely to rise again this year, aided by growing exports that have been made more competitive by the weak dollar. But, at this point, it looks like consumers will not buy enough in 1988 to give corporations a year of strong income growth.

LEAD: Some of the hundreds of Hasidic Jews who gathered yesterday at Beth Jacob School in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn at a memorial service for Eli Wald, who was stabbed to death as he returned home from work on Christmas morning. The gathering was also intended to protest what the participants called increased violence against residents of the predominantly Jewish neighborhood.

LEAD: A half-dozen years ago, so many American publishers were issuing fiction by Latin American authors that critics dubbed the period the ''Latin boom.'' The boom inevitably subsided, but now it is returning stronger than ever - not just with more titles, but also with books that are already major critical or commercial successes in Latin America and
LEAD: Lacrosse at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, an ancient game in a modern setting, mixed marketing and mild mayhem tonight.

LEAD: Dairy farmers can expect the price processors pay them for their milk to slide to a 10-year low in 1988 as a result of a reduction in Federal price supports that went into effect Friday, an Agriculture Department economist says.

LEAD: The six American journalists, members of a Pentagon-sponsored news pool covering military operations by the Navy in the Persian Gulf, were fed up. They had languished in the sun at their harborside hotel for nearly a week without setting foot aboard a ship.

LEAD: It was also a year of extremes in London. The Financial Times 100-share index closed the year at 1,712.14, up 2 percent from its opening for 1987 at 1,679. But in between, the market soared to new heights.

LEAD: THE building was erected in 1928 as a grand equestrian stable. Ten years later, it was converted to its present form, a skating rink, when the owner felt like watching some hockey. For his horses, he built another stable across the street.

LEAD: SKI instructors call them never-evers. These are people who have never been on skis and usually arrive at a ski school with visions of dashing down racecourses, jumping off cliffs or gliding through waist-deep snow.

LEAD: SINCE September, when Senator William Proxmire announced his intention to repeal the Glass-Steagall Act, the prevailing view has been that any bill to deregulate banking that got through the Senate would hit a brick wall in the House.

LEAD: New evidence of the way chemicals cause cancer is leading the Environmental Protection Agency to reassess the risks of many of the substances it regulates. It is finding some of them less dangerous than it previously believed.

LEAD: Somehow, a page from the past must have been planted in the New Orleans Saints' playbook last week without the Saints' knowledge. How else can anyone explain what happened today to a team that thought it had put 20 years of football follies behind it, stirring the imagination of its fans, who proudly painted their faces when just a few years ago they covered their heads with paper bags?
LEAD: Tom Barrasso made 27 saves tonight as the Buffalo Sabres beat the Quebec Nordiques, 2-1.
LEAD: The following speech, by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, is the first in a series of basic, or stump, speeches that will be published over the coming months in The New York Times.
LEAD: For Henry R. Kravis, the man who perfected the art of the leveraged buyout, it is hard to imagine a better year than 1987.
LEAD: Kevin Loughery, who coached the Washington Bullets to an 8-19 start this season, was dismissed today and replaced by Wes Unseld, a Bullets assistant coach.
LEAD: The Houston Oilers, the team their fans and the rest of the National Football League forgot, produced a rare but spectacular playoff victory today - their first since 1979.
LEAD: What a year.

LEAD: A group of gay Roman Catholics resumed their protests during Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, one month after 11 of them were arrested at the Cathedral when they refused to be seated during the sermon.
LEAD: Fourteen years after six members of a south Georgia family were murdered, the case, which has caused many Georgians to debate the justice of the legal system, is before the courts again.

LEAD: When Alan Greenspan was sworn in as Federal Reserve chairman in August, few doubted his powers as an economic analyst, but whether this lifelong adviser could adequately set policy as head of the nation's central bank remained to be seen.
LEAD: Mortimer B. Zuckerman is at odds with himself.
LEAD: Franklin Torch says he was reading the latest West German census, which shows a declining birth rate, when ''it clicked in my mind that they could use surrogate mothers.''
LEAD: In the Polish city of Cracow recently, Soviet and Polish businessmen drank Crimean champagne to celebrate their countries' first joint venture.

LEAD: GLENN SEIFERT, a Long Island optometrist, tells the story of a top amateur tennis player with a blistering serve who sometimes had difficulty holding up his end on the volley. Someone suggested that a vision problem might be a factor.

LEAD: The 11th New York Philharmonic Radiothon, a three-day broadcast of music, interviews and pledges, will take place in February on WQXR (1560 AM and 96.3 FM). The broadcast, an annual fund-raising event for the orchestra, will begin at noon on Feb. 5 and last until midnight Feb. 7. Included in the 60-hour broadcast will be taped excerpts of performances.

LEAD: In the 16 months since Jennifer Levin was killed in Central Park, the story of her last hours, and how she spent them with Robert E. Chambers Jr., has emerged in patchwork form. Today, in a 13th-floor courtroom in lower Manhattan, where Mr. Chambers stands charged with her murder, a jury is expected to begin hearing the full fabric of the tale - and prosecutors and defense lawyers say many widely held assumptions about the case may fall.

LEAD: ''The Dead,'' the work that marked the extraordinary synthesis of a great literary talent with a great cinematic one, was voted the best film of 1987 by the National Society of Film Critics yesterday.
LEAD: Japan, always a bit self-conscious about its limited size, has taken a giant step to keep itself from shrinking.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Gripping a microphone, Buca Pussick charmed the crowd with the ballad of Maria, a girl with a ''honey-sweet mouth'' and a ''beautiful body.''

LEAD: The collapse of a new storage tank poured an estimated one million gallons of diesel oil into the Monongahela River over the weekend, threatening drinking water for 750,000 residents of suburban Pittsburgh.
LEAD: The dollar rebounded after opening at a record low against the Japanese yen today, while stocks declined sharply in an abbreviated post-holiday session.
LEAD: In the telephone industry the winners of recent years seem likely to lose their momentum in 1988, while losers of the recent past could be the companies to watch.
LEAD: A growing international determination to stop a regional war that actually endangers world peace is reflected in the Soviet Union's abandonment of its opposition to sanctions against Iran.
LEAD: A 59-year-old Queens man was arrested early yesterday in the shooting death of a woman who was described as his girlfriend, the police said.

LEAD: Boris Baryshnikov saw on television that an entrepreneur in Finland was getting rich peddling Mikhail S. Gorbachev souvenirs. Suddenly a light went on over his head - possibly the word ''glasnost'' in marquee lights.

LEAD: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze flew to Kabul today and met with the Afghan leader, Najibullah, as speculation grew that the Soviet Union has increased its efforts to find a way out of the eight-year-old war in Afghanistan.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AT a professional training course for accountants in the Bay Area, there were signs that tax practitioners have not kept up with the sweeping changes of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and thus have failed to give their clients important advice on critical matters.

LEAD: Q. What flesh-and-blood person would be the source of the genetic material used to map, or ''sequence,'' the entire human genetic code? A. Each person has 23 pairs of chromosomes, which together contain about 3 billion bits of DNA. Only one in a thousand differ from person to person, said Dr.
LEAD: Salah Hindawy, a senior Egyptian diplomat who took part in efforts to resolve a border dispute with Israel, died of a heart attack Sunday in Kuwait. He was 48 years old.
LEAD: THE DROWNED AND THE SAVED. By Primo Levi. Translated from the Italian by Raymond Rosenthal. 203 pages.

LEAD: Yasser Seirawan won the $10,000 first prize in the 23d annual American Open Tournament at the Los Angeles International Airport Marriott Hotel. The 27-year-old Seattle grandmaster scored the winning, 7-1, in the eight-round Swiss-System competition sponsored by Software Toolworks and organized by the Santa Monica Bay Chess Club.

LEAD: The investment group that has agreed to acquire the Bell & Howell Company for $64 a share said today that it was considering selling certain ''non-core'' Bell & Howell assets in order to finance the transaction.

LEAD: The Primerica Corporation said the sale of its direct marketing subsidiary, Looart Press Inc., to De Luxe Check Printers Inc. had been completed, resulting in an after-tax gain of about $35 million for the fourth quarter of 1987. The proceeds from the previously announced sale of Looart and its operating subsidiary, Current Inc., totaled about $180 million, or about $150 million after taxes, Primerica said.

LEAD: New outbreaks of citrus canker in Florida have split Federal and state disease experts over the success of efforts to prevent the disease from establishing a permanent foothold in the continental United States.

LEAD: As usual, the behemoth spending bill that Congress passed just before adjourning in December contains tucked-away provisions serving special interests of individual legislators. But, surprisingly, some Capitol Hill analysts suggest that, in a reflection of general budget constraint, the bill may have fewer pork-barrel items than in the past.

LEAD: In an inspired moment, House Speaker Jim Wright drew this portrait of himself yesterday to illustrate how he will wield the gavel when the House of Representatives convenes Jan. 25 in a new session of Congress, the second session of the 100th Congress. (Jim Wright)
LEAD: The Treasury began disbursing $28.7 million today in Federal matching funds to 12 Presidential candidates.
LEAD: ABOUT a year ago, in a small airport in Kentucky, I was alarmed by a sign that read:

LEAD: The New York investor group Plum Associates, which appeared to have lost a takeover bid for the Holly Sugar Corporation to the Imperial Sugar Company, re-emerged as a suitor. In its third proposal in two weeks, Plum Associates, a group headed by Peter R. Harvey of Illinois, is now offering to acquire 60 percent of the company's stock at $92.50 a share, or $61.5 million, instead of the previous cash price of $85 a share, or $56.5 million.

LEAD: Wayne J. Stemmer was snowed in yesterday at his home in Westport, Conn., and he had a cold to boot. But he also had a deal wrapped up to give him some cheer - the $150 million acquisition of the Lincoln Savings Bank.
LEAD: The United States and other leading governments reportedly bought $2 billion to $3 billion in American currency today, helping the dollar to recover from a sharp decline in Asian trading.

LEAD: Dana Goode-Veistrup with her 78-year-old, $14,000 Rodolfo Fredi violin. It was stolen last September and returned on Sunday after a young man bought it from a man in the street for $10, and gave it to the police. She now faces a problem because she bought a replacement last month for nearly the same price.
LEAD: When retailers went to Ronaldus Shamask's showroom to look over his spring fashions for men, the designer was sure his sports jackets and pants in bright red or purple wouldn't sell.

LEAD: Not content with the usual year-end self-congratulations, the Justice Department makes an extravagant prediction about Attorney General Edwin Meese, a frequent grand jury witness and subject of special prosecutor interest.

LEAD: At Williamsport Hospital and Medical Center in Pennsylvania, a special committee is supposed to decide whether the hospital's pharmacy will carry a particular drug, and the process can take several weeks. But when Genentech Inc.'s heart attack drug came out in November, hospital officials eager to get their hands on it bypassed the committee and placed an order immediately.

LEAD: Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, has requested a substantial increase in funds to fight AIDS next year. Budget officials have urged President Reagan to approve most of the request, saying that significant cuts ''would embarrass the Administration.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Steve Scanniello clearing a path in the rose garden at the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens. About 3 inches fell in Manhattan and northern New Jersey and 6 to 7 inches fell on Long Island, in-cluding parts of Brooklyn and Queens. Although driving was hazardous, few major tie-ups were reported as the Sanitation Department mobilized 1,800 pieces of equipment to clear roads.

LEAD: For 60 years, the Reader's Digest Company's sole magazine was the highly successful Reader's Digest. Now George V. Grune, the company's chairman since 1984, is seeking to expand the company's publishing empire.

LEAD: * Allis-Chalmers Corp., Milwaukee, a developer of specialized technology for process control equipment, said it had completed the sale of its mining equipment unit to Boliden A.B. of Sweden for $97.9 million.
LEAD: A West German diplomat was shot and killed here early today, and there were hints and denials that a Kurdish group was responsible.

LEAD: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a basic speech. It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.

LEAD: A NEW song cycle by David MacBride was the main feature of Sunday evening's concert by the Prism Chamber Orchestra at Merkin Concert Hall. ''Nocturnos de la Ventana'' is a setting, in Spanish, of three Garcia Lorca poems for tenor, string quintet, keyboards, percussion and a small wind complement.

LEAD: In the early 1950's, a flock of migrating geese made an alarming appearance on the nation's Distant Early Warning radar screens. Steadily advancing across the DEW line, their formation resembled that of an enemy bomber squadron. Fortunately, the error was discovered and nuclear scenarists lived to think again.
LEAD: An Iranian delegation has arrived in Turkey to begin negotiations on a new oil pipeline, Turkish Government and oil industry officials said today.
LEAD: * Atlas Corp., Princeton, N.J., elected as a director Harry Winters Jr., president of the Winters Co., Tucson, Ariz., a mining industry consulting concern.

LEAD: In a matter of seconds last Tuesday evening, 11 shots from two police revolvers rang out on a Queens street. Moments later a man who the police say had lunged at an officer with a five-inch knife lay dying, struck by at least six bullets.

LEAD: On June 7, 1978, the Washington Bullets' dressing room was filled with the laughter and shouting that go with winning the National Basketball Association championship. But, off to the side, away from the din and the flowing champagne, there were tears.
LEAD: Luciano Liggio, the real-life ''Godfather'' of Corleone, is spending his long hours in prison painting.

LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus in 1988 is expected to exceed $4 billion, down from last year's $6.55 billion, the Trade and Industry Ministry said today. It predicted that exports would grow by 8 to 13 percent, to about $52 billion, despite the rise of the won against the dollar.

LEAD: In an effort to take some of the misery out of mathematics, the Chicago public schools began providing free pocket calculators to students today, but some critics warned that the program could cause learning problems.

LEAD: A 7-year-old East Meadow, L.I., boy, Anthony Accetta, was critically injured yesterday afternoon when he was hit by a Cablevision van in the road in front of his home on Maurice Avenue, according to the police. The driver of the vehicle, James Terry, 34, of West Babylon, L.I., was issued a summons for driving a vehicle with a suspended license.
LEAD: Stock prices staged a powerful year-opening rally yesterday, and traders said a strengthening dollar and program trading were behind the surge.
LEAD: APPLYING advanced X-ray techniques, scientists have for the first time determined the three-dimensional structure of an insect virus in atomic detail.
LEAD: Lily Laskin, a French musician who helped make the harp a featured solo instrument in concert halls, died today in a Paris nursing home. She was 94 years old.

LEAD: Deepening knowledge of the differing ways that chemicals can turn normal cells into runaway masses of malignancy may add new complexity to the effort to regulate cancer-causing substances, many experts say.

Yesterday a large pile of visa papers was spotted at the Soviet consular office in the capital, apparently to permit Ms. Walters and a television entourage to travel to Moscow next week.

There are drive-through florists, drive-through dry cleaners, drive-through liquor stores and drive-through pharmacies. There is even a drive-through pawn shop for those who do not want to leave their cars and expose their hard luck to the world.

LEAD: Jesse Jackson told patients at a drug-rehabilitation center he was briefly dependent on a painkiller more than 25 years ago, but he said in an interview today that the episode lasted less than a day.

LEAD: Plans by the National Science Foundation to recover a airplane used for polar exploration that crashed in 1971 are still on schedule despite the crash last month of a second plane carrying spare parts for the first, officials here say.

LEAD: WRITTEN in the clay, a sunbaked tablet from the 18th century B.C., was a message from one ruler of a city-state of upper Mesopotamia to another. We have released your spies, the ruler said, so where is the money you promised as ransom?

LEAD: Continental Airlines struck a blow at the concept of first-class service yesterday, announcing that passengers who belong to its frequent-flier program and pay the full coach fare could get first-class seats on most flights by making reservations on a first-come, first-serve basis.

LEAD: Emma Gresham, a retired schoolteacher, was chosen mayor and four other blacks were named to the five-member City Council today in the election of the first municipal government in this town of 300 people since 1933.
LEAD: Foreign visitors spent a record $5.7 billion in London in 1987, the London Tourist Board estimated today. There were 8.9 million visitors, and 23 percent of them were Americans.

LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had reached settlements involving a number of lawsuits against its employees and others that will net the company about $28 million in payments from its insurance company, the Employers Insurance of Wausau Mutual Company.

LEAD: Ending an era in which it seemed to be a fountain of untaxed wealth, Saudi Arabia has introduced income taxes on all foreign businesses and foreign workers, increased import duties on many goods, issued its first public debt in a quarter-century and drawn from its foreign currency reserves.

LEAD: TEN years ago Hearst Magazines, which then had eight magazines, began offering a ''corporate buy'' that gave advertisers discounts for running ads in at least three of the magazines at least three times each.

LEAD: In the instantaneous world of foreign exchange trading, no bit of market gossip spreads faster than reports that the Federal Reserve or some other central bank is intervening to buy a particular currency.
LEAD: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States fell by 24 last week, to 1,121, Baker Hughes said today. A year ago the total was 962.
LEAD: The State Department stepped up its protests today over the release from a Colombian prison of a man described as one of the world's leading cocaine smugglers.
LEAD: Gaston Eyskens, a former Prime Minister of Belgium, who led six Governments during a period that spanned 24 years, died at his home in Louvain on Sunday. He was 82 years old.
LEAD: It was Sunday night, so Bill had his ARTS Anonymous meeting in Hicksville.

LEAD: The first housing bill in seven years is on its way to the Oval Office.

LEAD: SURGE suppressors are devices that stand between a computer and its power source, guarding the machine's delicate circuitry against surges and other electrical fluctuations that are normal along AC power lines but potentially disastrous in a computer. I like to think of them as gremlin guards.

LEAD: Natural gas prices climbed to their highest levels in two years on the spot market today amid what experts said was a combination of bitter cold weather and a fresh dispute between pipelines and gas producers over a Government ruling that went into effect last Friday.

LEAD: A coalition of legal and church groups here is trying to prevent the deportation of a handful of Cuban women, detained around the country, so they will not be separated from the children to whom they gave birth in this country.

LEAD: President Reagan will cut the ribbon Friday morning when the Army-Navy Club, a 102-year-old institution, rededicates its clubhouse on Farragut Square after almost four years of remodeling and reconstruction. The light-yellow brick building was dedicated by President Taft in 1912 after a move from a building across the street that President Harrison had dedicated in 1892.

LEAD: California remained the favorite location for motion picture and television filming in 1987, taking in some $6 billion, slightly more than last year, according to early figures made public today by The Hollywood Reporter newspaper.

LEAD: A civil-rights association and a federation of block associations in Queens said yesterday that they had formally asked Governor Cuomo to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the fatal shooting by white police officers of a black man on a residential street in Laurelton, Queens.

LEAD: Armed with pickaxes and jackhammers, a contingent of 40 stagehands worked furiously yesterday to tear apart the set of ''The Mahabharata'' at the Majestic Theater in Brooklyn, barely 10 hours after the last performance of Peter Brook's epic production. Looking more like a muddy contruction site than the scene for this season's most-talked-about theatrical work, the Brooklyn Academy of Music's controversial new performance space was rapidly being transformed.
LEAD: Pledging to protect suburban values threatened by continued growth, Thomas S. Gulotta was inaugurated today as Nassau County Executive.
LEAD: Johnstown, Pa., has had a number of tragic floods, the worst one being almost 100 years ago. Indeed, the Johnstown flood is almost a part of the language.

LEAD: Supporters of Bruce Babbitt yesterday submitted to the New York State Democratic Committee the names of 140 prospective candidates for delegate to the party's national convention. It was the first day such filings were permitted under state party rules.

LEAD: AEROSPACE engineers have hit a dead end in conventional efforts to test designs for the next generation of spaceships, planetary probes and other futuristic flying machines, prompting a rush of new proposals and projects for exotic techniques to help develop 21st-century spacecraft.
LEAD: MANY people keep their distance from personal computers, even those who could find a use for one, because of an impression that only the mathematically inclined can truly understand them.

LEAD: E-II Holdings Inc., a publicly traded spinoff of the Beatrice Company, said today that it plans to nominate six candidates for election to the board of American Brands Inc., the diversified giant whose businesses includes tobacco and numerous consumer products.
LEAD: A 53-year-old unemployed actor shot himself to death last night after having held his former girlfriend hostage for seven hours earlier in the day in her West Side apartment, the police said.

LEAD: LIKE advice to the lovelorn, helpful words for job losers and job seekers are widely available. Now an economist and a forecaster offer some advice for middle managers who have lost their jobs and for people with new M.B.A. degrees who are looking for their first jobs.

LEAD: About one in 10 people receiving cyclosporine to prevent rejection of transplanted organs develops kidney problems, including fatal kidney failure. Now a group at the Albany Medical Center has found experimental evidence that the reason those people develop kidney trouble is that the drug breaks down into poisonous fragments in their bodies.

LEAD: N.H.L. Oilers 2, Bruins 2: Charlie Huddy scored an unassisted goal on a long shot apparently deflected by a Bruin player with 2 minutes 17 seconds left in the third period, giving Edmonton a tie last night. Huddy's 60-foot shot apparently hit Boston's Ken Linseman and spun past the goalie. Edmonton played without the injured Wayne Gretzky.
LEAD: OPERATION BABYLON. By Shlomo Hillel. Translated from the Hebrew by Ina Friedman. Illustrated. 301 pages. Doubleday. $19.95.
LEAD: An Indian court has dealt a severe blow to one of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's sharpest political foes, saying that he had misused his office to benefit his relatives.
LEAD: Rolf Presthus, chairman of the Conservative Party and a former Finance Minister, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Friday, his family said. He was 51 years old.

LEAD: The defense attorney in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. stood before the jurors yesterday and urged them to ask a single question: Why would Mr. Chambers kill Jennifer Levin in Central Park in August 1986?
LEAD: * Donnelley Marketing, Stamford, Conn., a unit of the Dun & Bradstreet Corp., to Marquardt & Roche, Stamford, for Carol Wright's couponing promotion package.

LEAD: In six years as District Attorney of Brooklyn, Elizabeth Holtzman says, she has raised the professional standards of her office, introduced new strategies to deter crime and forged closer ties with the black and Hispanic communities by aggressively investigating complaints of police brutality.
LEAD: Having never finished with a winning record in 13 years as a National Hockey League franchise, the Devils are not accustomed to playing in games they are supposed to win.

LEAD: Washington is unhappy about Spain's insistence on pulling out American warplanes when an existing base agreement runs its course about three years hence. True enough, the Socialist Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, promised in 1986 to cut back U.S. forces if Spain voted to remain in NATO, which it did.
LEAD: A 61-year-old union organizer, reputed to be an organized-crime figure, was found shot dead yesterday afternoon in his automobile parked in front of his home in Brooklyn, the police said.

LEAD: AIDS experts are growing more concerned that results from many trials of experimental drugs against the disease may not be valid for key segments of the population that the epidemic is increasingly hitting: drug users, nonwhites and women.

LEAD: In the first 34 games, Michel Bergeron used at least three goaltending schemes and produced zero solutions. Six games ago, his imagination nearly exhausted and his intentions unclear, Bergeron threw up his hands and told John Vanbiesbrouck to start.
LEAD: An article yesterday about the coming session of the New York State Legislature misidentified State Senator John R. Dunne. He is the deputy majority leader.

LEAD: Margaret Thatcher has become Britain's longest-serving Prime Minister of the century, and the main effect of her new historical status seems to be a broadening of the debate about authoritarianism and the concentration of power in her third term.
LEAD: In Eastern Europe, where for four decades the Soviet leader has represented to millions the main source of their discontent, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has wrought an astonishing transformation.

LEAD: ''Among the people as a whole, as long as she can deliver bread and circuses, as long as the prosperity is there, she can go on and it will be hard to stop her.'' - Robert D. Waller, Conservative Party polltaker, describing Margaret Thatcher. [ A6:4. ]

LEAD: For the first time in New York State, the number of inmates serving time for drug-related offenses has surpassed those imprisoned for any other type of crime, officials of the overcrowded prison system said yesterday.

LEAD: A Soviet crash program to catch up with the West in designing powerful new computers is beginning to pay off, but the Russians still lag far behind, according to industry reports.

LEAD: On the beaches of southern New Jersey, children hunting for seashells came upon broken hypodermic needles and other hospital debris. Off the craggy coast of Connecticut, lobstermen found their catch already dead because of the paucity of oxygen in the water. Biologists in New York, performing autopsies on sea turtles that had washed ashore, discovered plastic shopping bags in their stomachs.

LEAD: For something that has never been performed successfully in competition, the quadruple toe loop gets a lot of attention. It came up again when Brian Boitano, the only American skater with a realistic chance of landing it, said he did not intend to try it during the United States figure-skating championships, which began here today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A man who was convicted of stealing more than $428,000 from his employer was sentenced today by Judge Gerard Goettel of Federal District Court to five years in prison and ordered to return the money. The man, Charles Bates, 41 years old, had pleaded guilty to defrauding the company, Equitable Relocation Management Corporation, during a 10-month period in 1986.

LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that it had found no evidence of price manipulation in the Major Market Index, a stock index futures contract traded on the Chicago Board of Trade, during the October market collapse.
LEAD: Along with writing the nation's laws, members of Congress have shown a 200-year passion for pen and paper by writing everything from college textbooks to boastful biographies to spy novels.

LEAD: William J. Cagney, a brother of James Cagney and the producer of such films as ''The Time of Your Life'' and ''Kiss Tomorrow Goodbye,'' died of a heart attack Sunday at Hoag Memorial Hospital here. He was 82 years old.

LEAD: On his first day in New York City as Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green, displayed confidence, flashes of humor and a certain no-nonsense attitude toward what he clearly thought were fringe issues. And at his baptismal City Hall news conference yesterday he suggested, ever so gently, that he, not Mayor Koch, was the star.

LEAD: Members of the dance and theater worlds gathered yesterday afternoon at the City Center to honor Nora Kaye, the American ballerina who died last year. Known for her dramatic power, Ms. Kaye, who was born in New York City in 1920, was a member of American Ballet Theater from its inception in 1940 until 1951, and again from 1954 to 1959.

LEAD: Sikh militants in Punjab state killed 10 people, one a senior member of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party, in attacks over a 24-hour period Sunday and today, the police and news organizations said.
LEAD: The Villanova Wildcats invaded Alumni Hall last night and, despite a lapse late in the second half, dominated St. John's with a pulverizing inside attack that gave them a 69-62 victory.

LEAD: The Decision Industries Corporation has agreed to pay Econocom International N.V. $1.85 million for certain expenses relating to Econocom's failed takeover offer for the computer concern based in Horsham, Pa.
LEAD: Jack Clark, who led St. Louis to two division titles in the last three seasons but was injured for parts of all three years, will not re-sign with the Cardinals, his agent said yesterday.
LEAD: Murat T. Gadginsky wants to change the way Russians shop.

LEAD: Few issues have so riled old-fashioned Reagan supporters as the plan that Mr. Reagan has endorsed for elevating the Veterans Administration and its 250,000 employees to the status of a department of the Federal Government and its chief to membership in the Cabinet.

LEAD: Marat Gramov, the chairman of the Soviet Union's sports committee, said today that his country intended to participate in the Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, and that an official announcement was expected next week.

LEAD: FOR a while last Friday night I rooted for the University of Miami to be No. 2 because I thought it was a dirtier team than Oklahoma. Why else were so many of its players wearing towels on their belts?

LEAD: At the end of a decathlon the track-and-field computer can normally digest the results of 10 events and produce final standings within five minutes or so. The American Contract Bridge League's computer in Memphis, however, took more than five weeks to digest the results of 10 days of national play, admittedly involving much more data.
LEAD: A Vietnamese investment code governing business and trade with foreigners has been passed by the country's National Assembly.

LEAD: Steven T. Florio, the president of The New Yorker, announced yesterday that Rebecca Wesson Darwin, a long-time associate, had been promoted to publisher of the magazine, a title that he had previously held.

LEAD: ''The Chosen,'' which opens Thursday at the Second Avenue Theater, is the biggest gamble in Off Broadway history. Its $2.5 million capitalization is more than the combined cost of all Off Broadway productions last season, according to Paul Libin, head of the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers, a trade group.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL The U.S. and other governments bought an estimated $2 billion to $3 billion in dollars, helping the currency recover from a sharp decline in Asian trading, dealers said. LEAD: M. Lee Pearce, a doctor and lawyer who is president of a Miami health-care consulting company, wrote out a sobering prescription yesterday for one his clients, American Medical International Inc.

LEAD: Mike Tyson's big deal was sealed yesterday.

LEAD: THE worst performers in the Dow Jones industrial average sometimes turn into winners the following year. LEAD: A cable car loaded with about 50 skiers here started up accidentally with its door open and without its conductor today, and one teen-age skier fell 50 feet to his death, the police said. Two other teen-agers were injured when they also fell to the parking lot below the valley station.
LEAD: The State Department has decided to refrain from further strong public criticism of Israel's handling of Palestinian protesters, a well-placed Administration official said today.

LEAD: When California was known to people in southern China as ''the Golden Mountain'' a century and more ago, Chinese immigrant settlements dotted the rural regions of the state. Chinese communities, born in the Gold Rush of 1849, thrived in the countryside until job opportunities began swelling the Chinatowns of big cities like San Francisco.
LEAD: The dollar rallied yesterday after touching new lows during overnight trading in Tokyo, bolstered by signs that several central banks, including the Federal Reserve, had bought dollars.

LEAD: Representatives of Jay A. Pritzker met with union leaders of Pan American World Airways Inc. in an effort to revive his attempt to take over the airline, sources close to the talks said yesterday.

LEAD: Construction spending shot up 2.2 percent in November, the biggest increase in nine months, as the building industry benefited from widespread gains in both residential and nonresidential construction, the Government reported today.
LEAD: The recent cold snap in Alberta has put snowmaking on Mount Allan back on schedule.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court decided yesterday that the 9-year-old son of a diplomat from Zimbabwe should remain in foster care on Long Island pending a full hearing later this week in a case involving accusations that the boy had been beaten by his father.

LEAD: Treasury bond prices retained moderate gains late yesterday after soaring earlier in the session. While relatively light, trading was described by dealers as somewhat unnerving, as illustrated by the behavior of the key long-term Treasury bond.

LEAD: If you are lucky enough to be heading south you are now confronting the bathing suit problem. The scenario is all too familiar. First comes the debacle of the dressing room. There are few fashion moments as depressing as this one. The bare facts about your body are facing you in the mirror. How to find a suit that will enhance what's all right but also disguise what isn't?

LEAD: WHY does CBS keep conveying the distinct impression that, all things being equal, it would prefer not to have ''Cagney and Lacey'' on its schedule? You may remember that the series was officially canceled a few years ago and then brought back, thanks largely to viewer protests. Since then the show had been doing reasonably well in the ratings on Monday nights, although rumors of its permanent cancellation continued to circulate each year at renewal time.

LEAD: Senator John Melcher of Montana, chairman of the Senate's Special Committee on Aging, is working to convene a ''Silver-Haired Congress'' alongside the regular Congress sometime next year.
LEAD: President Robert Mugabe appointed a new 27-member Cabinet on Saturday, dropping several longtime supporters and giving key posts to former foes, including Joshua Nkomo.

LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today defended the army's decision to order nine Palestinian nationalists deported, saying the Gaza Strip and West Bank residents being thrown out were ''incorrigible.''

LEAD: Arthur J. Lumsden, a former head of the Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce and chairman of the publishing house of Dodd, Mead & Company, died of lung cancer Sunday at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 68 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla., and West Hartford, Conn.

LEAD: Just before Christmas, Congress gave Nevada an expensive present - the Federal repository for highly radioactive waste, now to be tunneled out of Nevada's Yucca Mountain. The gift comes with a special evergreen greeting: $20 million, every year. Yet the Governor of Nevada, Richard Bryan, does not sound grateful.
LEAD: THE yawn is something of a biological mystery.

LEAD: The Philadelphia 76ers suspended Andrew Toney yesterday after the guard failed to complete the team's West Coast tour while complaining of chronic foot problems. Toney, who has appeared in only nine games this season, started and played 29 minutes at Portland Friday, tying his season-high of 13 points and handing out a season-high nine assists.
LEAD: Delaware, which is home to more major corporations than any other state, moved a step closer yesterday to adopting a law that would make unfriendly takeovers more difficult.

LEAD: The Oakland Athletics have signed the free-agent veteran second baseman, Glenn Hubbard, to a contract for the 1988 season, plus an option year, the club announced yesterday. The Athletics did not reveal other terms of the pact.

LEAD: The Brooklyn Lyric Opera's professional workshop, the Opera Stage, is to perform Bizet's ''Carmen'' on Thursday at 8 P.M., Sunday at 3 P.M., Jan. 14 at 8 P.M. and Jan. 17 at 3 P.M. in Hirsch Hall at Temple Ansche Chesed, 251 West 100th Street. Tickets are $7.50. Information: (718) 837-1176.
LEAD: Mayor Raymond L. Flynn, building on a theme he has often sounded in his first four years in office, today pledged his administration to providing jobs for the city's young people.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mieczyslaw Rakowski has been at the leading edge for reform among Polish Communists for over a generation. He never quit the party, as so many did, and his fortunes waxed and waned according to the climate. Along the way he accumulated enemies among party officials who thought him too soft and critics of the party who thought he lacked the courage of his conclusions.
