LEAD: * Gary C. Robert has joined Greenstone & Rabasca Advertising, Melville, L.I., as executive vice president in charge of client services.

LEAD: An internal report by safety experts concludes that two years after the Challenger disaster the space agency still lacks the engineers, guidelines or leadership to ensure the safety of manned spaceflight.

LEAD: Now, it is on to San Francisco, where the Minnesota Vikings fully expect to be regarded as an appetizer on the 49ers' playoff menu. Their one-sided victory Sunday against New Orleans probably will end the talk that they did not deserve to be in the playoffs, but ultimately, the Vikings figure the National Conference wild-card game will be remembered as the day the Saints reverted to their losing ways.
LEAD: The Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden has been given eight major works of modern art from the estates of Gustave Ring, a leading builder in the Washington area, and his wife, Marion.
LEAD: An article yesterday about the appointment of New York City's new Schools Chancellor misidentified Peter F. Vallone. He is the majority leader of the City Council, not its president.

LEAD: The collapse of an oil storage tank near Pittsburgh on Saturday was highly unusual, according to experts in the field, but they said it was also surprising that surrounding dikes did not keep a million gallons of diesel fuel out of the Monongahela River.

LEAD: The French singer and actor Yves Montand will be the recipient of the 1988 tribute by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, April 25 at Avery Fisher Hall. As it has done annually since the first tribute in 1972, the society will show excerpts from several of the honoree's films, including his latest, ''Jean de Florette'' and ''Manon of the Spring.

LEAD: Israeli troops shot and killed at least one stone-throwing Palestinian youth today and wounded seven others while trying to quell another outbreak of rioting in the Gaza Strip. Five Israeli soldiers were slightly wounded by rocks and bottles.

LEAD: The General Services Administration's board of contract appeals said yesterday that it would resume considering a protest by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, ruling in the process that the Government had not provided enough information to justify a continued delay.

LEAD: The suit and countersuit involving the Lotus Development Corporation and the Rossin Greenberg Sereonick & Hill agency and the question of the security of company secrets have been settled out of court, with the agency promising not to solicit business from any Lotus competitor for 10 months, as well as promising in writing not to release any confidental information of
LEAD: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.
LEAD: The Hospital Corporation of America has completed a $564 million stock repurchase plan. The offer for 12 million of common shares at $47 a share expired at midnight Monday.

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission plans to reinstate policies designed to increase ownership of radio and television stations by members of minority groups and by women, according to a commission spokesman.

LEAD: The world's most benign weapons systems are the salts and shots in the arsenal of the United Nations Children's Fund. For a pittance, Unicef confounds common and deadly foes of children: diarrheal diseases, measles, tetanus, whooping cough and polio. A decade ago only 5 percent of the third world's children were vaccinated.

LEAD: Soviet bank said today that it was issuing 100 million Swiss francs ($75 million) of 5 percent bonds, a move bankers said was apparently the first of its kind by an enterprise incorporated in the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Independent film makers have challenged new rules by the United States Information Agency that allow the Government to label documentary films as propaganda when certifying them for duty-free distribution abroad.

LEAD: ''For the past two days the central banks have been like a basketball team that uses fast breaks to keep the opposition off balance. For the past two days they have been buying dollars as the currency has risen in value, an action that has pushed the dollar even higher. For the last year or so they always bought dollars as the currency was sinking.

LEAD: From Maine to California, from Detroit to New Orleans, Governor Cuomo traveled the country 27 times last year, mostly to sound the impassioned theme that has become his trademark: Ronald Reagan is wrong. More money and programs are needed to help the poor and others who do not share in the American dream.
LEAD: The District of Columbia Council declared an emergency today because of sub-freezing temperatures and ordered the Mayor to open government buildings to the homeless.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said that J. T. Battenberg 3d had been promoted to vice president. Mr. Battenberg, who is 44 years old, heads the design and manufacturing of cars for the Flint Automotive division of the Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac Group.

LEAD: Alan Sweetser, founder and president of Compass Inc., which helped corporate managers who lost their jobs find new ones, died of a heart attack Nov. 16 at St. Mary's Hospital in Minneapolis. He was 59 years old and lived in Minneapolis.

LEAD: A Federal district judge in Philadelphia has overturned regulations set by the United States Department of Transportation that he said deprived disabled people of the right to have access to mass transportation.

LEAD: Interest rates fell for the third consecutive week at Citicorp's regular commercial paper auctions yesterday. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.908 percent, down from 7.3946 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.0184 percent, down from 7.2978 percent.

LEAD: A member of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic brain trust today published an unusually strong critique of the country's latest economic innovations, saying the measures introduced throughout most of Soviet industry just four days ago were ''a fiction.''

LEAD: Nobody was gratified by the 3-3 tie that followed three plodding periods and the blizzard of offense both clubs appeared to save for the five-minute overtime. Still, the Islanders and the Minnesota North Stars admitted to feeling a sense of relief about at least being able to emerge unbeaten from a lengthy game whose difficulty grew as it neared its conclusion.

LEAD: Manufacturers of drugs given to animals that are used for food will be required to develop new tests for residues, in order to meet a stricter safety standard proposed by the Food and Drug Administration, officials announced Monday.
LEAD: Bear, Stearns & Company announced Monday that it was acquiring the specialist operations of Asiel & Company, a small brokerage house.

LEAD: The officials of 23 companies - the majority of all the concerns involved in the removal and disposal of asbestos materials in the New York metropolitan region - were arrested yesterday and charged with bribing a Federal environmental protection inspector to overlook violations of Federal rules and regulations.

LEAD: The public schools here will be the focus of a national research center on education being established with the goal of restructuring American education and making the country's work force more competitive with foreign workers.

LEAD: Workers dragging a boom into the Monongahela River to help contain fuel spill near Pittsburgh. Officials called yesterday for renewed efforts at conservation as about 13,000 homes were without water. Page A19. (AP)

LEAD: Congress, attaching special significance to the financial plight of black colleges and universities, has increased the amount of Federal aid for those schools by about 50 percent this year, to $73.1 million.

LEAD: Every year thousands of visitors flock to Marblehead, to its historic harbor, its art and craft galleries and antique shops, its purposely quaint Colonial streets and its six yacht clubs. This winter, a new group of guests are staying unseasonably late: 15 homeless families.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo, in his State of the State message on Wednesday, will propose raising the maximum weekly benefit for unemployed workers in New York by almost 30 percent, aides to the Governor said today.

LEAD: Mayor Koch, seeking to dissuade the State Legislature from approving increases in municipal pensions, said yesterday that New York City would hire 1,548 fewer police officers and sanitation workers over the next two months than had been anticipated.

LEAD: Three ticket agents charged yesterday that Broadway's largest theater owner has a monopoly on theater-party sales of tickets to the musical ''Phantom of the Opera,'' in violation of antitrust law.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It wasn't modesty that caused walkers in midtown to cover their faces yesterday. Chilly winds made it feel decidedly colder than the 23-degree high temperature that was recorded. But if you think that was bad, wait until tonight, when the temperature is expected to drop as low as 8 degrees below zero.

LEAD: There was no need for inspirational speeches by Coach P. J. Carlesimo when his Seton Hall team played Connecticut tonight. All the Pirates had to do for motivation was recall last season, when Connecticut, the last-place team in the Big East Conference, defeated them twice.

LEAD: Too much New Year's food and drink killed 10 people in Belgrade, the newspaper Vecernje Novosti reported today. It quoted doctors as saying the deaths were caused by heart attacks or strokes resulting from overeating or drinking too much alcohol.
LEAD: The New York Observer, a four-month-old weekly serving Manhattan, cut its news staff by 25 percent yesterday to try to reduce costs, said Arthur L. Carter, the owner and publisher.

LEAD: Two Soviet families asked for political asylum in Turkey last week, a Foreign Ministry official said today. The spokesman, Inal Batu, said the Government was reviewing the requests and had not made a decision.
LEAD: John S. Millis, chancellor emeritus of Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, died of cancer Friday at his home in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that New York City officers needed more training in subduing violent people without using guns and in ''overcoming a mindset'' that makes them reluctant to retreat.

LEAD: If you and your partner have ample values for a game contract, and you allow an opponent to play undoubled at the level of one, the result is almost always a disaster. LEAD: They sometimes talk about skating in the Olympics as if it were a hazy dream from childhood, a goal once conjured up that seems, even now, so unrealistic, unreachable and presumptuous.
LEAD: Don't assume anything with the Knicks. Just when it seemed they had taken two major steps forward, they found a way to take a big step back last night.

LEAD: Patricia Powers, a short-story writer and the wife of Bertram A. Powers, president of New York Typographical Union No. 6, died of a heart attack Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. She was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Across Eastern Europe a shadow society has sprung up outside of the control of the ruling Communist parties, tolerated because the authorities have neither the money nor the ability to fulfill Marxism-Leninism's promise to build a better life for working people.

LEAD: By now it seems as if Marvelous Marvin Hagler would have made up his mind about his boxing future.
LEAD: Daniel Walker, a former Democratic Governor of Illinois, began a seven-year sentence Monday for bank fraud and perjury at a minimum-security Federal prison.
LEAD: Castle & Cooke Inc. said that the CSX Corporation had agreed to become a partner in a $200 million project to develop two hotels and 150 homes on the Hawaiian island of Lanai.

LEAD: In the nation's capital nearly everybody who is anybody has a press secretary. Their lot in life is to quash unpleasant rumors, write press releases, schedule interviews with sometimes hostile journalists, fend off attacks from many quarters and, for the most part, entrust their futures to the boss.

LEAD: Saday Courville, who played second fiddle on the first known Cajun record in 1928 and was one of the last links with the ''pure'' sounds of the Acadian heritage, died of heart failure Sunday. He was 82 years old.

LEAD: Vice President Bush, who has been repeatedly attacked by his leading Republican rival, Senator Bob Dole, struck back today, scoffing at Mr. Dole's Senate career and his expertise in foreign policy.

LEAD: THE most vivid images in ''Song of Refuge,'' a kind of environmentalist Punch and Judy show, suggest a high-minded, low-budget theatrical offshoot of the movie ''Robocop.'' Following scenes in which the unpolluted natural environment is depicted in shadow puppetry underscored by ethereal chanting, actors clad in outfits made entirely from metal cans battle one another clumsily in a sequence of clanking duels.
LEAD: ''Three Men and a Baby'' remained the top film at the box office for the first weekend of 1988, earning nearly twice as much as the second-place movie.

LEAD: Nurses picketing yesterday outside Lenox Hill Hospital after contract negotiations broke down. Negotiations have been underway since October for a new two-year contract. The union is seeking salary increases, limitations on mandatory overtime and contractual ''quality of care'' assurances that set limits on patient-nurse ratios.
LEAD: The Federal Election Commission today declared the Rev. Jesse Jackson eligible to receive Federal matching funds for his 1988 Presidential campaign.

LEAD: Do students actually use what they learn in school? Some educators say no, and one of them has started a publicaton, called Think, Inc., aimed at helping children bring what they learn in the classroom to the outside world.

LEAD: Three more Eastern European countries - Poland, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia - have said they will compete in the Seoul Olympics, increasing to 133 the number of nations who have accepted invitations.

LEAD: New York City officials said yesterday that more than 2,700 residents of city shelters had been placed in jobs through work programs since they began in 1982, with almost half the placements since last fall.

LEAD: David J. Friedland, the former New Jersey state senator who was captured on an island in the Indian Ocean last month, pleaded not guilty today in Federal court to charges of conspiracy to defraud a teamsters union pension fund.
LEAD: Police sharpshooters wounded the leader of a prison revolt today, ending a 30-hour uprising that left four inmates and guards dead and eight wounded, officials said.
LEAD: Hinde Taarji and Assia Belghiti consider themselves in the vanguard of change for women's rights in North Africa.

LEAD: President Jose Sarney today named an economist and longtime Government official, Mailson Ferreira da Nobrega, as Brazil's new Finance Minister, succeeding Luiz Carlos Bresser Pereira, who resigned last month in a clash over economic policy.

LEAD: VNU, the United States subsidiary of a Dutch publishing company, has acquired Media Records, a company that keeps track of the advertising content of newspapers, and will add it to its Marketing Services division. Since the division already operates Leading National Advertisers, a major media-measuring service, it means a more complete service for the industry.

LEAD: MILLIONS of adults brought up on breakfast grains that were colored, sugared, flavored and shaped like little O's or chocolate-chip cookies are continuing their lifelong cereal habit. But as they have grown older their tastes have changed. Today, they want something a little less sweet, a lot more sophisticated, with emphasis on nutrition.

LEAD: A swimmer has died after being stung by a Portuguese man-of-war, a bubble-like relative of the jellyfish. Emily H. Small, 67 years old, screamed and lost consciousness when she was bitten about 30 feet from shore, friends who were with her said. She was in a coma for five days before she died Friday.

LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, the Wall Street financier who is the largest Texaco shareholder, has made good his promise to offer an alternative to the company's plan to emerge from Federal bankruptcy protection.

LEAD: FRIENDS are often surprised when I tell them that one of the favorite foods of my childhood in Burgundy was macaroni and cheese taken bubbling from the oven of the wood-burning stove. Their response is conditioned by the thought that macaroni and cheese is as solidly American as Boston baked beans and clam chowder.

LEAD: Rolando Blackman, whose 18.5- point scoring average is second highest on the team, will miss the Dallas Mavericks' next five games after spraining his knee in a 117-107 loss to Houston Monday. The 6-foot-6-inch Blackman was injured when Allen Leavell of the Houston Rockets fell on him after fouling Blackman on a drive to the basket.

LEAD: I HAVE been married almost 10 years to the same person. Sometimes it's hard for me to believe. Neither of us was sure that any human being could be expected to live over the long haul with anyone as stubborn, opinionated and difficult as the other. Somehow it has worked, and it is not a gross exaggeration to say that this is partly because I am a much better cook than he is, and he tells much better jokes than I do.

LEAD: The top-secret Stealth bomber being built by the Northrop Corporation, which is already believed to be hampered by problems that have brought more than $200 million in write-offs, is now experiencing new delays and management problems.

LEAD: Computers are dumb beasts that do exactly what they are told. When told to do something perfectly, they do it perfectly. Inscribe, a Cambridge, Mass., company marketing computerized calligraphy , is finding that the computer is . . . well, not human enough. It doesn't make mistakes.

LEAD: Dr. Denton A. Cooley, one of the nation's foremost heart surgeons, filed for protection Monday under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code, an apparent victim of the foundering real estate market here.

LEAD: Last spring, Representative Tom McMillen, a freshman Democrat from Maryland, took the floor of the House of Representatives to describe an ''internal, high-level Japanese Government memo'' that he said had recently been brought to his attention.

LEAD: Shinya Watanabe was amused at the unlikely sight of his fellow students panicking over a term paper that was almost due. Nearby, students sitting in study carrels with their heads bent over Western classics occasionally looked longingly out the window.

LEAD: Bernard King scored 15 of his 27 points in the fourth quarter, and Moses Malone scored 26 points as Washington snapped a five-game losing streak by defeating the Nets, 101-97, tonight. It was Wes Unseld's debut as the Bullets' head coach.

LEAD: THE first thing you noticed were the eyes, sad eyes, moist eyes, unfulfilled eyes. Bil Keane has made a career of painting sad-eyed clowns, waifs who have seen too much, but Pete Maravich was not merely a Keane painting, he was a man trying to go straight.

LEAD: The Suffolk County Medical Examiner has issued a ruling of homicide in the death of a patient at Good Samaritan Hospital who was treated by a nurse suspected of injecting lethal drugs into patients, a law-enforcement official said today.

LEAD: MAIN STREET, the downtown of Flushing, was weakened but never felt the sharp decline that hit other Queens commercial centers when regional shopping malls began opening in the borough in the 1960's. Since the early 1980's Main Street has evolved from a struggling retail street into a thriving shopping center where retailers have squeezed into almost every square inch of space and where the vacancy rate is less than 1 percent.

LEAD: Less than two weeks before the presidential election scheduled by Haiti's army-dominated Government, the four leading candidates have carried out their threat to call a boycott and the field is dominated by seven former associates of the deposed Duvalier dictatorship.

LEAD: United States crude oil production declined 4.1 percent, to 3.03 billion barrels, in 1987, a year when the oil industry was thought to be showing signs of recovery from its nose dive in the early 1980's, Petroleum Information reported on Monday. Meanwhile, natural gas production, bolstered by increased production from the Gulf of Mexico, increased by 1.7 percent above 1986 to an estimated total of 18.2 trillion cubic feet, according to the Denver-based reporting service for the oil industry.

LEAD: FOUR years ago, De Gustibus discussed useless kitchen gadgets that were collecting dust in the attic: things that were broken, like electric mixers and electric frying pans, and things that were in good working order but served no useful purpose at the time.

LEAD: Robert F. Wagner Jr., his authority as president of New York City's Board of Education imperiled, resolved a sensitive political stalemate over the choice of a new schools chancellor last week with a threat to resign, city and education officials said yesterday.

LEAD: TO discover what Americans eat, 1,870 people nationwide were asked a battery of questions, including the following. To find out how you measure up, compare your responses with those of the survey respondents.
LEAD: After more than 60 years as a Left Bank landmark, the restaurant La Coupole has been sold to a French restaurant chain for about $10 million, the buyer said today.

LEAD: Early Christmas night Loyal Garner Jr. said goodbye to his wife and six children in nearby Florien, La., hopped in his pickup truck and headed with two companions to retrieve a friend's automobile just across the border in Texas.

LEAD: The Broadway production of ''Chess,'' which for the last year has been scheduled, threatened with cancellation and, only last week, postponed indefinitely, is now scheduled to open in April, the producers announced yesterday.

LEAD: The accounting firm Price Waterhouse & Company said yesterday, as expected, that its clients would not be required to write off the value of their loans to Mexico if they participated in the recently announced exchange of Mexican loans for Mexican bonds. The firm gave its position in a ''generic accounting letter'' to clients.
LEAD: Myerson & Kuhn is making its debut in New York City this week, arising from what was recently the nation's fourth-largest law firm.
LEAD: Gene Lees's 'Singers'
LEAD: Closing arguments began here today in the murder trial of two members of a former business and social group that called itself the Billionaire Boys Club.

LEAD: This being Twelfth Night and the end of the Christmas season, it's safe to say that millions of American homes will sport a trail of needles from tree stand to front door tomorrow. But not where the homeowners had the foresight to invest in a tree removal bag.
LEAD: C. Edward Acker's days as chairman and chief executive of the Pan Am Corporation appear numbered.

LEAD: It's always been hard to accept that George Bush could, at the same time, be the most ''completely involved'' Vice President of modern times, as he and President Reagan assert, and still have been disengaged from the Iran-contra affair, as he asserts. And it's getting harder as Mr. Bush still refuses to say more about his role in that disaster.
LEAD: NOTHING is better for you or shows off a microwave oven to better advantage than vegetables, particularly winter vegetables.

LEAD: THERE aren't many French restaurants in the United States where a couple wearing Bermuda shorts, T-shirts and Mickey Mouse ears would be tolerated, much less welcomed. But Chefs de France is no ordinary French restaurant. In this extravaganza at the futuristic Epcot Center at Disney World in Orlando,
LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association is offering today four-year and seven-year debentures totaling $1.35 billion through various securities dealers.
LEAD: In 1912, when Adolph Zukor, founder of Paramount Pictures, exhibited the first full-length feature film in the United States at the Lyceum Theater in New York, he charged $1 for admission.

LEAD: Despite advances in the last two decades, most of the mechanical and chemical tools for cleaning up large oil spills were designed for use in the open ocean or on and near coastlines, and not for spills in rivers.

LEAD: Textile and apparel exports from Mexico to the United States would grow by 6 percent annually in the next four years, compared with a 50 percent increase in 1987 imports, under a pact between the two countries announced today by the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter.
LEAD: At one end of the Washington Redskins' defensive line, there is the sometimes ebullient, sometimes troubled Dexter Manley, one of the better known players in the National Football League.

LEAD: The ''CBS Evening News,'' hoping to capitalize on the allure of its star journalists, will begin next week to schedule regular guest appearances on the newscast by the correspondents from the CBS prime-time program, ''60 Minutes.''

LEAD: The Bell & Howell Company faces seven shareholder lawsuits, contending that the company failed to negotiate fairly with all parties during the bidding that developed between the British publisher Robert Maxwell, the New York publishing company Macmillan Inc. and the Bass family of Texas. Bell & Howell, based in Skokie, Ill., accepted an offer of $64 a share, or $647 million, from the Bass group, which also included several Bell & Howell executives.
LEAD: Alysheba lost to Java Gold the only time they met on the race track last year, but scored a resounding victory yesterday in the Eclipse Award balloting for the champion 3-year-old of 1987.

LEAD: In introducing himself to New York, Richard Green revealed a confident, adroit public figure and passionately concerned educator. To rescue the failing school system, he will need those qualities and more. He will need substantive help from the central Board of Education, which will formally choose him as Chancellor today, and from City Hall and Albany.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Exposure to radon, the odorless radioactive gas that seeps into buildings from underground rocks, appears to be responsible for about 13,000 lung cancer deaths annually, according to new data compiled by the National Academy of Sciences.

LEAD: You know how it is in these parts: you step into a shop and all of a sudden the shopkeeper is your newest best friend. Everybody has a story like that. Everybody has at least one warm song for every three tunes of rudeness, or should. In any event, Pasquale Ursitti answered the door.

LEAD: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. is offering $150 million of 10 percent sinking-fund debentures, due in 2018, at a price of 99.25 to yield 10.079 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

LEAD: John H. Goldsmith, who lost his job as chief executive of a Midwestern brokerage firm in a dispute with the firm's parent, has landed on his feet with a new post in the regional brokerage industry.
LEAD: The 23-year-old daughter of Malcolm X was forced into a car on West 60th Street yesterday afternoon and robbed at gunpoint, the police said.

LEAD: Despite a potential for conflict because of their differing missions, educators and law-enforcement officials said today that they had found a basis for working cooperatively to try to drive drugs out of New Jersey's schools.

LEAD: Stuart Z. Perlman, who with his brother founded Caesars World Inc., a chain of opulent gambling casinos and hotels, and then severed ties with it amid charges of ties to suspected organized-crime figures, died of a heart attack Monday at the North Miami Medical Center in North Miami Beach, Fla. He was 60 years old.

LEAD: Grand Auto Inc., the struggling chain of automobile parts stores based in Oakland, Calif., has agreed to be acquired by Paccar Inc., a manufacturer of trucks and oilfield equipment based in Bellevue, Wash., for $16 a share, or about $49.2 million.

LEAD: Pete Maravich, the leading career and single-season scorer in major college basketball history, died yesterday in Pasadena, Calif., after suffering an apparent heart attack while playing in a pickup game. He was 40 years old.

LEAD: Among dozens of political tout sheets that give the morning line on Presidential and Congressional campaigns, the Cook Political Report is one of the most respected. In its latest edition, Charles E. Cook Jr., editor, finds that ''with every week, the Republican nomination becomes more of a two-way contest'' between Vice President Bush and Senator Bob Dole.
LEAD: Nearly one out of five public water sys-tems tested in the United States has been found to be contaminated by chemicals, a group affiliated with the consumer advocate Ralph Nader said today.

LEAD: RIGHT now, it's tempting enough just to gaze at the cover of ''Tropic Cooking'' by Joyce LaFray Young (Ten Speed Press, $12.95), with its photograph of a turquoise sea lapping at white sand and a grove of palm trees set against an azure sky.
LEAD: The dollar's value rose dramatically in heavy trading yesterday, bolstered by a growing belief that, for now, Washington and other governments are committed to preventing its further decline.

LEAD: ENGINEERS have long dreamed of a near-perfect energy storage system in which a huge current of electricity would circulate indefinitely without resistance, always ready for use. The basis for such power storage would be a superconducting coil, but the cost of the device has prevented its development by utility companies.
LEAD: International
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: With the stacks of unruly paper on his desk, the faded cardigan, the gruff talk and the nostalgia for good old-fashioned reporting, Mert Proctor is the image of the hometown editor.

LEAD: Amid reports of a deepening Egyptian military involvement in the Persian Gulf, President Hosni Mubarak is to embark this week on a tour of gulf Arab nations, sealing Cairo's emergence from ostracism because of its peace with Israel.
LEAD: Guatemala has rejected a request by Nicaraguan rebels that they meet there with the chief mediator before continuing talks on a cease-fire, United States officials said today.
LEAD: Travel Fox sneakers, which created quite a stir last year by running an ad featuring a male and female clad only in sweat socks and the product, have been switched to another agency.
LEAD: Chris Columbus says that it is a privilege to live in New York City and that he ''wanted to give something back to the city I love so much.''

LEAD: The Florida investor Paul A. Bilzerian said he had ended negotiations with an unidentified investor who he said had previously given an oral commitment to purchase $150 million in stock to help Mr. Bilzerian complete his $1 billion bid for the Singer Company. Mr. Bilzerian has already raised $895 million for the bid, but the loans are contingent upon his obtaining the remaining $150 million, now being offered as high-yield bonds.
LEAD: Chefs on the Slopes
LEAD: ''Broadcast News,'' ''The Last Emperor'' and ''Moonstruck'' each received five 1988 Golden Globe nominations today from the Hollywood Foreign Press Association.
LEAD: Presidential contenders in both parties are bringing in reinforcements for their final political offensives before Iowa's important caucuses on Feb. 8.

LEAD: WHEN the Intel Corporation developed the 80286 microprocessor a few years ago, the chip was jammed with 120,000 transistors and took about three and a half years to create. Its successor, the 80386, was more than twice as complex - 275,000 transistors - and was finished in a little under three years.

LEAD: Jose Luis Chea, foreground, Deputy Foreign Minister of Guatemala, and other members of the Central American peace plan's watchdog commission at a meeting yesterday in Managua. It was the second day of the panel's six-day trip through Central America to monitor progress of the pact. The commission is scheduled to visit Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador before presenting the results of its findings at a Central American summit meeting Jan.
LEAD: THE main course was braised beef, the wine a hearty Beaujolais and the occasion a drill in table manners.
LEAD: Herbert G. Kawahara, a longtime executive of E. F. Hutton & Company, has been named president of the Pacific Stock Exchange.
LEAD: * Alliant Computer Systems Corp., Littleton, Mass., said it was restructuring to add 50 new jobs in its international organization and to eliminate 40 positions at its headquarters.
LEAD: The Warsaw Pact has proposed negotiations that could lead to the elimination of the battlefield nuclear missiles deployed in Central Europe and along the border between the Germanys.

LEAD: THE Chinese film ''The Horse Thief'' is best watched as pure spectacle, since it unfolds almost entirely without benefit of dialogue. What little talk there is tends to be plain and to the point (''If only we had stew''). However, from the scenic and ethnographic standpoints the film is often quite arresting.
LEAD: Bond prices rose modestly yesterday for the second consecutive day, following the lead set by the foreign exchange market, where the dollar continued to strengthen.

LEAD: Calculating that each American taxpayer, in theory, could be responsible for $18,569.10 of the debt now on the Federal books, a Republican Congressman from New York is trying to force the Internal Revenue Service to make that more widely known.
LEAD: The executive committee of the Delaware Bar Association, as expected, yesterday endorsed a measure that would limit certain unfriendly corporate takeovers.

LEAD: Harold Matson, a literary agent who represented Evelyn Waugh, C. S. Forester, Arthur Koestler, Malcolm Lowry and William Saroyan, died yesterday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 89 years old.
LEAD: Saying a crisis still existed, Gov. Robert P. Casey called today for renewed efforts to conserve water in suburban areas in the aftermath of the huge oil spill in the Monongahela River.
LEAD: Postmaster General Preston R. Tisch announced today that he would leave office to return to private business in the next few months.

LEAD: A chart in Business Day last Saturday listing Nasdaq stocks with the biggest gains and losses for 1987 misstated the percentage decline for National Bancshares of Texas. The stock fell 81.6 percent. In addition, a chart of the leading underwriters misidentified a top-ranking firm. It was Credit Suisse First Boston, which shared the top spot with First Boston.

LEAD: There was another one of those smoke fights on an airplane the other day. It's always the same: a smoker so desperate for a cigarette he's ready to start screaming in pain. Somebody willing to die rather than be subjected to cigarette smoke. Pandemonium in the sky, police meeting the plane at the gate.

LEAD: Investigators are considering the possibility that the shooting death of a West German Embassy employee was related to a private matter and not terrorism, an Interior Ministry spokesman said today.

LEAD: The United States joined with the rest of the Security Council tonight in unanimously adopting a resolution calling on Israel to drop plans to deport nine Palestinians involved in disturbances in the occupied territories. The Council said such expulsions would violate the Palestinians' human rights.
LEAD: Many college professors around the country are rethinking the very notion of what is literature.

LEAD: Amnesty International issued a survey today on children who are victims of political repression around the world, citing 18 countries in which ''the most basic rights'' of children were violated.

LEAD: Still smarting from criticism that some of its market makers failed to cope with the crush of customer orders in the Oct. 19 stock trading rout, the National Association of Securities Dealers plans further improvements in executing transactions electronically.

LEAD: A firefighter standing near the charred entrance to a two-story house yesterday in Newington. John Quintaglie, his wife, Faith, and their 16-year-old son, John, were killed in the early morning blaze. (AP)

LEAD: THE horizon seems boundless as scanned from many vineyards in eastern Washington, with the snowy Cascade Mountains rising far away across semi-arid deserts. For Simon Siegl, executive director of the Washington Wine Institute, the economic horizon of the state's steadily rising wine industry seems equally expansive.
LEAD: Henrique de Souza Filho, a prominent Brazilian cartoonist better known locally as Henfil, died here from pneumonia and other AIDS-related complications Monday. He was 43 years old.
LEAD: Abbas Ali Hamadei, a dual Lebanese-West German citizen, went on trial here today on kidnapping and other charges.

LEAD: A second flaw in the redesigned shuttle booster rocket has been discovered by engineers from the space agency and Morton Thiokol Inc. Their further examination of last month's test firing showed that hot gases reached an O ring seal in a critical rocket joint.

LEAD: WHAT wine with what food? Insofar as it's possible to predict anything, it's a pretty safe bet to say that this will be the hot topic in wine books for some time to come. And why not? It would be a food book, too. Two for the price of one, you might say.

LEAD: Pro-gun forces in the capital, who have long perceived Senator Edward M. Kennedy and other gun control advocates in Congress as their chief adversaries, are now viewing with alarm a purported threat from an entirely different quarter - the Reagan Administration.
LEAD: John Blair Communications is made up of Blair Television, a national advertising representative for a number of stations, and Blair Entertainment, which produces and syndicates TV programming.
LEAD: THE dramatic nutrition revolution that was going to change the way Americans eat is not happening, judging by a recent nationwide telephone survey conducted by The New York Times.

LEAD: George Grayson Tyler, a former head of the tax department of the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore and a former president of the University Club, died of a heart attack Monday. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan and in West Redding, Conn.
LEAD: President Jose Napoleon Duarte asserted today that Salvadoran leftist guerrillas were responsible for killing a leading human rights official here three months ago.

LEAD: Jack Powers, the Manhattan College athletic director, announced yesterday that school officials had met with the basketball coach, Bob Delle Bovi, and would not take any disciplinary action against him for pulling his team off the court and forfeiting a game against Drexel in a Texas tournament two weeks ago.

LEAD: DRUG stocks took off yesterday in the wake of Hoffmann-La Roche & Company's $72-a-share, or $4.2 billion, hostile takeover bid for Sterling Drug Inc., which makes Bayer aspirin and other products.

LEAD: Business expansion in the New York metropolitan region slowed last year, with its economy showing strain even before the stock market collapse on Oct. 19, according to a Government report released yesterday.

LEAD: Five Palestinians today admitted involvement in the hijacking of a New York-bound Pan Am jumbo jet in 1986. But they blamed Pakistani commandos for the deaths of 21 hostages killed by gunfire and grenades.
LEAD: Solomon Telushkin, an accountant, died of a stroke Dec. 24 in his home in Brooklyn. He was 81 years old.

LEAD: Stephen King's ''Tommyknockers,'' a nightmarish tale set in a Maine village, was the best-selling hard-cover book in the United States in 1987, according to a survey by The New York Times. Even though it went on sale only in October, there are already 1,345,000 copies in print.

LEAD: Protesters throwing stones at Israeli soldiers in Khan Yunis, where one youth was killed and seven wounded. Despite deportation order for nine militants and the arrest of more than 1,000 demonstrators, Israel has been unable to impose order in the Gaza strip or the occupied West Bank. At the U.N., the Security Council, in a unanimous vote, called on Israel to drop deportation orders.

LEAD: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Representative Les Aspin, issued a blistering criticism today of a year-old report from President Reagan on his strategy for achieving national security.

LEAD: Crude oil futures posted modest gains yesterday on carry-over buying from Monday, when prices of all energy contracts soared on reports of a ''squeeze'' in London's cash market for North Sea Brent grade oil.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Rony Seikaly and Derrick Coleman scored 19 points each, and Steve Thompson added 15 tonight as Syracuse scored an 80-67 Big East victory over Boston College.

LEAD: Thirty-two years ago, Allen Ginsberg sent shock waves through the seemingly placid cultural landscape of mid-1950's America with a poem that proclaimed ''the best minds of my generation destroyed by madness.''
LEAD: Dave Christian and Mike Gartner scored first-period goals tonight as the Washington Capitals defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 3-1, and extended their unbeaten streak to five games.

LEAD: Arizona State named defensive coordinator Larry Marmie as its new head football coach last night, just five days after John Cooper resigned to take the job at Ohio State. Although Marmie, who is 45 years old, has no previous head-coaching experience, he had Cooper's support as his successor plus the unanimous approval of the Sun Angel Foundation - the school's main booster group.
LEAD: WHINING chief executives of agencies and magazines, in search of publicity, are fond of saying, ''We are the best-kept secret in the business.'' Few, however, back up that cliche with proof.

LEAD: It is bad enough that Congress openly stuffs favors into appropriations bills - a project here for a Congressman's home district, a grant there to soothe a senator. But doing it in the dark subverts honest government. That's just what Congress has done with its secret stuffing of the new omnibus spending bill.

LEAD: Sugary snacks, soft drinks and french fries are still high on the list of America's favored foods, a nationwide New York Times telephone survey has found. Despite recommendations to decrease sodium, sugar and cholesterol in the diet, and despite greater consumer awareness, the diets of Americans of all age groups are not significantly more nutritious.

''He's undergoing daily treatment but he's definitely not ready to skate,'' Dr. Gordon Cameron, the Edmonton Oilers' team physician, said. Cameron said Gretzky suffered a ''substantial wrench to the knee, and nature dictates that it'll take time to heal.
LEAD: WITH the United States losing share of the world market in manufacturing, mining and agriculture, what is the job outlook for the labor force through the end of the century?

Everyone, it seemed, prefaced their remarks differently, but almost all of the Rangers arrived at the same response.
LEAD: A small girl with a big brush taking part in an annual New Year's calligraphy contest yesterday in Tokyo. Some 7,400 youngsters demonstrated their skill in producing characters. (AP)
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation showed off its technological visions of the future yesterday, even though some of its high-tech efforts have been less than wildly popular with consumers.

LEAD: Jon Miles Kurtis, foreign sales executive with Manley Productions Inc., New York film producers, died in his sleep Sunday at his home in Woodstock, Vt. An autopsy is planned to determine the cause of death. He was 32 years old.

LEAD: The small, impoverished town of Keysville, 120 miles east of here, on Monday re-established a local government that had been dormant for 54 years. The election, seen by many as a symbol of efforts by rural blacks to gain political power, marked a victory for blacks seeking more municipal services over whites who fear higher taxes.

LEAD: Don Sutton, a 300-game winner who spent the first 15 years of his major-league career pitching for the Dodgers, has signed a one-year contract with his old team. ''We are extremely happy to have Don Sutton return to the Dodgers' organization,'' Fred Claire, the team's executive vice president, said.

LEAD: A group of opponents to the appointment of the new Schools Chancellor, Richard R. Green, urged Dr. Green yesterday to oppose proposals to give Mayor Koch more control of nominations to the city's Board of Education.

LEAD: Here in Texas by the Colorado River is a man from Oregon whose story begins in Chicago. He is a mountain man, a lover of Douglas firs, the self-appointed watchman who keeps a summer vigil high on a Pacific peak. It seems strange to encounter him on a cold, leaden day among cinder block and steel. And yet, this is an apt place.

LEAD: Israel said today that a top British diplomat had been taken in by Arab propaganda when he criticized as ''an affront to civilized values'' conditions at a Palestinian district that he toured in Gaza.

LEAD: Skiing Schneider Wins Giant Slalom: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland won a women's World Cup giant slalom yesterday at Tignes, France, holding off challenges from Catherine Quittet and Carole Merle, both of France. Schneider was timed in 2 minutes 33.68 seconds for the two runs. Quittet, who led after the first heat, came in second at 2:33.83.
LEAD: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 -

LEAD: ''THE Politics of Food'' examines worldwide hunger and finds it's the fault of the West. Western creditors and governments, particularly the United States, have joined to choke off world food supplies. The two-hour documentary, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, is provocative, but it doesn't have much breadth.

LEAD: Saying he didn't get a fair shake at Iowa, Dan McGwire, who dropped from starting quarterback for the Hawkeyes in the preseason to No. 3 by the end of the year, said he plans to transfer to San Diego State. ''Very unhappy. Very unhappy. You can underline that,'' McGwire said. ''They built me up to be real big and they didn't give me a chance.

LEAD: Saudi Arabia rescinded a sweeping package of income taxes on foreigners today following protests from foreign workers and Saudi businessmen. The taxes had been instituted by royal decree only a few days ago.

LEAD: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $250 million of 8 3/4 percent noncallable notes, due in 1991, at a price of 99.95 to yield 8.767 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
LEAD: KRAZY KAT. A Novel in Five Panels. By Jay Cantor. 250 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

LEAD: ASK a few friends whether they prefer yams or sweet potatoes and you'll get quite an earful. Of course yams are better, they'll tell you. They're richer, moister, smoother and sweeter. LEAD: Harold M. Lane, former chairman of the Lerner Stores Corporation, died of a stroke Friday at his country home in Byram, Conn. He was 96 years and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Isiah Thomas scored 6 of his 18 points in the final 4 minutes 32 seconds tonight as the Detroit Pistons snapped Atlanta's six-game winning streak with a 90-87 victory over the Hawks.

LEAD: Ahold N.V., a leading Dutch food retailer, said it had bought an 80 percent stake in First National Supermarkets, a chain of 122 supermarkets across the United States, for an undisclosed amount of cash. The Dutch company, which also owns the BI-LO and Giant Food Store chains in the United States, said the present management would continue to direct First National, which is based in Cleveland.
LEAD: A Staten Island man has been charged with killing his infant son by twice dropping the child onto the floor while playing with him after drinking, the police reported yesterday.

LEAD: WOR-AM, caught between its long tradition as the leading talk-radio station in the New York market and the desire to attract a younger audience, next week begins a new program schedule that has already prompted loud cries of protest from some in the station's audience.

LEAD: Lee Alexander, the longtime Mayor of Syracuse and former president of the United States Conference of Mayors, pleaded guilty today to Federal charges that he turned the Syracuse City Hall into a racketeering enterprise that extorted at least $1.2 million over 16 years from city contractors.
LEAD: A 9-year-old boy accidentally shot to death his infant brother today with a pistol he found in the house, the police said.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said today that he was reviewing how many Navy ships were needed in the Persian Gulf region, but reaffirmed the American intention to continue escorting commercial vessels.

LEAD: A New York City police officer who interrupted a robbery at a house in Brooklyn early yesterday was shot in the stomach and seriously wounded in an exchange of gunfire that left one of the suspected thieves dead, the police said.

LEAD: Karl Nelson, the Giants' offensive tackle who missed the 1987 season while being treated for cancer, underwent surgery today to strengthen his left shoulder.

LEAD: The continuing debate over the Columbus Circle project has centered on such weighty matters as price, process, tax abatements and the prospective marring of Central Park by architecturally produced shadows.

LEAD: A $1 billion hostile takeover of the Singer Company seemed assured yesterday as Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor who has offered to buy it for $50 a share, announced that T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, had agreed to provide the last $150 million needed to finance the deal.

LEAD: Judith Price, who presides over the publishing success story known as Avenue magazine, has now made a major decision affecting another of her publications, On the Avenue, which is more of a slick tabloid.
LEAD: The United States Attorney in Colorado has asked President Reagan to withdraw his nomination to the Federal bench after a dispute over the accuracy of the prosecutor's disclosure statements.

LEAD: EVEN among professionals, rollers replaced brushes long ago for painting the major portions of interior walls and ceilings. But a brush is still necessary to reach areas where a roller will not fit. Knowing how to use a paintbrush skillfully makes working with one much easier and less messy, and it gives better-looking results.

LEAD: HELEN SCHNEIDER'S appearances in New York cabarets, which have been widely spaced over the past dozen years, have shown her in constantly changing lights. She has been a blues singer drawing on Muddy Waters and Willie Dixon, a jazz singer leaning on Billie Holiday and Ella Fitzgerald, a singer of rock nostalgia and - after an absence of nine years during which she became a rock star in West Germany and an actress in films and theater - she returned to New York almost two years ago singing pop songs of the 20's in a one-woman revue, ''A Flapper's Folly,'' at the
LEAD: David C. Sutherland, vice president of Home Line Cruises Inc., died of pneumonia Saturday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 63 years old and lived in West Orange, N.J.

LEAD: The Rangers, initially taken aback by the fiesty, forechecking Vancouver Canucks, scored three rapid goals in the second period and held on for a 4-2 decision before 16,814 fans at Madison Square Garden last night.

LEAD: Citicorp said yesterday that it would eliminate 400 of the 2,500 jobs at its North American investment bank within two months. The decision follows an announcement in November that about 1,000 jobs would be cut by the end of 1988 in its retail banking operations because of a centralization process.

LEAD: In response to warnings of stepped-up violence by the Irish Republican Army, British military helicopters in Northern Ireland are being equipped with machine guns and with infrared systems designed to protect aircraft against surface-to-air missiles, military authorities say.
LEAD: A high-stakes feud has erupted here between The Boston Herald, a scrappy tabloid owned by Rupert Murdoch, and the state's senior United States Senator, Edward M. Kennedy.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions of Business Day yesterday about the new law firm of Myerson & Kuhn incorrectly described the financial status of Booth, Marcus & Pierce, a law firm whose partners joined the new firm. Booth, Marcus & Pierce specialized in bankruptcy law; it was not bankrupt.

LEAD: Moderation, which he had lost along with his composure two days before, returned to Doug Carpenter's voice. Perspective, too, was slowly replacing the angry tunnel vision that had overtaken the coach of the Devils. After watching his team's sorry 6-3 surrender Monday night to the Los Angeles Kings,
LEAD: Prostitutes and their customers who are arrested and convicted in Newark would have to submit to tests for the AIDS antibody, under an ordinance passed today by the City Council.
LEAD: President Reagan signed legislation today rescuing the indebted Farm Credit System, saying the bill should help alleviate farmers' financial troubles.

LEAD: BP America Inc., a unit of the British Petroleum Company, offered $250 million of 9 1/2 percent notes yesterday. Due in 1998, they were priced at 99.30 to yield 9.61 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

LEAD: Jose Dedeurwaerder, a top Renault executive who once headed the American Motors Corporation, has resigned after 30 years with the French auto maker, officials said. Renault refused to comment about his departure, but industry sources said this week that Mr. Dedeurwaerder had differences over the direction of the company.

LEAD: The fits-and-starts decline of the dollar that began last fall appears about over, growing numbers of economists and financial market experts say. Few see the dollar keeping all of its new-found strength, but few see it going down much either, although there are caveats.

LEAD: A group of CBS News employees has joined forces and sent a donation of more than $1,200 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The contribution came from more than 200 employees, including maintenance workers, security guards and mailroom employees, as well as newsroom personnel.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE first few times you hear your child say that he doesn't want you, but wants his other parent, it can be crushing. What have you done so wrong that he has rejected you many years before you can blame it on the churning hormones of puberty? Where are the adoring looks, the tiny arms flung around your leg as you return home?
LEAD: The gray-haired gentleman in the middle of the Cleveland Browns' huddle at practice the other day was not an aging quarterback. It was Art Modell, the owner.

LEAD: The State Department, retaliating for Colombia's release of a reputed cocaine smuggler. said today that all travelers from Colombia are now subject to closer inspection on arrival in the United States.

LEAD: As diesel fuel from last week's spill flowed down the Ohio River, the water crisis here eased somewhat today and attention turned to why a storage tank burst.
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about a speech by Vice President Bush at the National Press Club in Washington misidentified the club president. He is Andy Mollison.

LEAD: FOUR months ago the American Craft Museum quietly opened a small shop on the upper level of its galleries at 40 West 53d Street. And for a very small store, it has a surprisingly high concentration of things you didn't know you needed.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: New York City officials announced yesterday an agreement with a company to replace canceled commuter ferry service between Brooklyn and Manhattan. The company, Manhattan Express, will offer three runs between Fulton Landing and Wall Street each rush hour, starting Monday, and will expand service later this month to include the 69th Street pier in Bay Ridge.
LEAD: Following are excerpts from Governor Cuomo's State of the State Address to the Legislature yesterday, as transcribed by The New York Times through the facilities of Channel 13.

LEAD: Cliches flock around Margaret Thatcher as thickly as sparrows in London's East End. She is indeed forceful, divisive, gritty, a quick study, thinks fast on her feet. So are other politicians, yet none in modern Britain have equaled Mrs. Thatcher's longevity. She has served longer than any previous Prime Minister in this century - 3,167 days as of last weekend - and has a fair chance of winning a fourth straight election.

LEAD: Don't relax. There's always something to worry about. Herpes, crack and nuclear holocaust have not gone away but have become passe worries. A trendy era obeys fashion even in its fretting. Here are some worries that have already infected 1988.

LEAD: Kim Young Sam, the South Korean opposition leader, won an overwhelming vote of confidence from his party today after saying he would step down to take responsibility for his defeat in last month's presidential election.
LEAD: REPERTORY has made a glorious comeback at the New York State Theater.
LEAD: When I was in my 30's, a 50-year-old friend told me that you don't know anything until you are 50. I reach 50, and what does he tell me? ''You really don't know anything until you are 60.''
LEAD: The police said today that four blacks had been killed in separate incidents in Pietermaritzburg, where fighting between black political groups has killed 31 people this year.

LEAD: Gunnar Engellau, the Swedish industrialist who built the Volvo company into a major international automobile maker, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Goteborg, where he lived. He was 80 years old.
LEAD: The Pillsbury Company said yesterday that it planned to sell or close about 103 of its fast-food and full-service restaurants to improve sagging corporate profits.

LEAD: A committee of shareholders of Texaco Inc. pressed the company's chairman yesterday to change the board's proposed bankruptcy reorganization to remove bylaws that make unfriendly takeovers difficult.

LEAD: Jules-Francois Crahay, a Belgian designer who began working as a couturier in Paris in the early 1950's, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Monte Carlo. He was 70 years old. Mr. Crahay retired in 1984 from the House of Lanvin, where he had worked for 20 years. Before that, he worked for Nina Ricci from 1952 to 1963.

LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk intends to negotiate a political settlement with the Vietnamese-backed Government in Cambodia with or without the backing of his coalition partners or foreign allies, the Prince's son and spokesman said today.
LEAD: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

LEAD: More than 15 courtroom sketches of those involved in recent trials will be on view through January at the library of the New York Law School, Queens College, Long Island Expressway and Kissena Boulevard. Subjects of the sketches, done by a variety of artists, include David Berkowitz, Mary Beth Whitehead, Cheryl Pierson, Marla Hanson and Eddie Murphy.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WITH the financial markets pursuing the dollar down, up and sideways, the big question remains: What is United States policy on the dollar?

LEAD: Nine paintings found in France in the custody of Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi arms dealer, may actually belong to former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and have been turned over to the Justice Department by the French Government, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

LEAD: Dr. Bern Dibner, a science historian and founder of the Burndy Corporation, manufacturer of electrical and electronic equipment, died in his sleep Tuesday night at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 90 years old.
LEAD: Suria Saint-Denis, consultant director of the drama division of the Juilliard School, died Dec. 29 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. She was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Federal Government filed a lawsuit yesterday charging that the Consolidated Edison Company had removed asbestos from its plants without properly protecting its workers or the public. Asbestos, when dispersed in the air, can cause cancer or other diseases.
LEAD: * Adelphia Communications Corp., Coudersport, Pa., said it had entered into an agreement with Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. to acquire Ultracom Inc. for $78 million.

LEAD: An investigation of the nozzle failure on the space shuttle booster rocket has determined that a key component probably did not fall off in the test firing but immediately after, and so the problem is not considered to be as serious as first thought, industry and space agency officials said yesterday.
LEAD: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -

LEAD: The law school of the City University of New York, a much-lauded experiment in devising a nontraditional curriculum and in preparing law graduates for public service careers, is embroiled in a dispute over tenure.

LEAD: N.H.L. Flyers 6, Blues 4: Rich Tocchet and Brian Propp each scored two goals last night as Philadelphia defeated visiting St. Louis, extending its unbeaten streak against the Blues to 34 games at the Spectrum. The Flyers are 31-0-3 at the Spectrum since Jan. 6, 1972, when the Blues won, 3-2, for their last victory in Philadelphia.

LEAD: The Justice Department has sent additional information about investments by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to the independent prosecutor investigating Mr. Meese in connection with the financially troubled Wedtech Corporation.

LEAD: An 18-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged in an attempted robbery Wednesday that left a police officer wounded and another suspect dead outside a Brooklyn house, the police said.
