LEAD: The seaside condominium where Arturo Cruz now lives in exile is set in a gentle landscape of marinas and country clubs quite unlike his native Nicaragua. But the comfort that surrounds him has done nothing to ease his regrets.

LEAD: Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga of Jamaica said today that the pledge by the army-dominated Government of Haiti to hand over power after a presidential election scheduled for Jan. 17 ''seems to be on course.''
LEAD: When the wind howls and the Hudson freezes and the clouds hang heavy in the sky, a funny thing happens to New York. It turns into Fat City.

LEAD: Life magazine, which raised its circulation rate base by 100,000, to 1.6 million, with its November issue, is now going to increase it another 100,000 with the March issue, Elizabeth P. Valk, its publisher for the last year, has announced.
LEAD: A WOMAN RUN MAD. By John L'Heureux. 258 pages. Viking. $17.95.
LEAD: A group of second graders at Public School 54 on Staten Island held a Jump-a-Thon the other day to raise money for the homeless of New York City.
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had ended its efforts to arrange a sale of the troubled Financial Corporation of America to the Ford Motor Company.
LEAD: BASEBALL

LEAD: A Federal appeals court issued a brief order yesterday allowing the State Department to resume efforts to return a diplomat's 9-year-old son to Zimbabwe in a dispute growing out of accusations that the boy had been beaten by his father.
LEAD: THE TRUE GEN: An Intimate Portrait of Hemingway by Those Who Knew Him. By Denis Brian. 356 pages. Illustrated. Grove Press. $19.95.
LEAD: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation said yesterday that it would withdraw from the institutional money management business, making it one of the few large banks to abandon that field.
LEAD: Trevor Howard, the gravelly-voiced actor who made a career of playing English officers and gentlemen in his more than 70 motion pictures, died yesterday. He was 71 years old.

LEAD: With a stunning performance in his short skating program, earning perfect marks of 6.0 for composition and style from eight of the nine judges, Brian Boitano tonight virtually assured himself of his fourth consecutive national title.

LEAD: ONE of the pleasures of frequent ballet-going is the chance it gives to see dancers step into new roles. On Wednesday, the New York City Ballet offered such an opportunity in a performance at the New York State Theater that boasted four role debuts in Jerome Robbins's ''Piano Pieces.''

LEAD: While the Big East season began a month ago, the bitter battles that distinguish conference play began when Georgetown and Pittsburgh squared off Wednesday night in the season's first true heavyweight bout.
LEAD: There was slightly less than seven minutes left in the third period when Aaron Broten, having been assessed a misconduct penalty, was done for the night.
LEAD: A judge today approved an agreement that will allow new tests of evidence that helped convict Gary Dotson of rape and send him to prison for six years.

LEAD: A picture on Dec. 31 with an article about Sam LeFrak's Newport development in Jersey City was published in error. The photo - showing waterfront strollers - was made at Pier 17 of the South Street Seaport in Manhattan.
LEAD: WHEN thrust into the cold, hot-house plants quickly wither.

LEAD: The White House is casting about for a new candidate to fill a vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board because of a powerful Senator's opposition to the front-runner, Leif H. Olsen, according to officials.

LEAD: THE stock market's October tumble dealt a harsh blow to general equity mutual funds, but an odd thing happened along the way. In the final quarter, these funds managed to outperform the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for the first time since the second quarter of 1983.

LEAD: Central bankers, who acted dramatically to bolster the dollar's value earlier this week, backed up those deeds with strong words yesterday, and nervous currency traders responded by pushing the dollar higher for the fourth straight day.

LEAD: All 138,000 copies of a United Nations report on refugees were ordered burned by the United Nations High Commissioner because he thought it unfairly represented West Germany's policy toward asylum-seekers.

LEAD: The Singer Company said its advisers, Goldman, Sachs & Company and the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, had entered into talks with representatives of Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor, about his $50-a-share bid for Singer.
LEAD: Treasury bond prices rose modestly yesterday, as many market participants waited for the dollar to stop gyrating and for more economic data to provide clues on interest rates.

LEAD: WITH support from one TV commercial for men, one TV commercial for women and one radio commercial that is sexually ambiguous, Fairchild Publications on Monday will be offering its new weekly consumer publication Travel Today to the East Coast reading public.

LEAD: Americans took out about $2.22 billion more in installment credit than they paid off in November, as the growth in consumer borrowing slowed in the first full month after the October stock market plunge, the Government said today.
LEAD: Syria has begun a diplomatic offensive, proposing to be host for a meeting of the Arab countries of the Persian Gulf and Iran, with which they are at odds.

LEAD: Bernard Krauss, former president of Esquire Inc., an educational and music publisher, died of cancer Jan. 4 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 58 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.
LEAD: Pat Robertson, seeking to broaden his support, stumped through western New Hampshire earlier this week, urging voters to judge him on the issues and not on his personal religious beliefs.

LEAD: A Buffalo charter airline formed by a Continental Airlines pilot was charged by Federal authorities yesterday with operating illegally for seven months after its airline license had been revoked.

LEAD: Vineyardmusik, an early music ensemble, is to present ''Gulliver's Travels'' set to music by Telemann and performed on 18th-century instruments tomorrow at 10 A.M. and noon at the Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street. The performances are intended for children. Tickets are $6. Information: 683-0696.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that an agreement on Afghanistan should include not only a withdrawal of Soviet troops and a halt in American arms to Afghan rebels, but also an end to Soviet military aid to the Afghan Army.

LEAD: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said today that it would cut 90 jobs, or nearly 10 percent of its work force, in response to the steep decline in trading volume since the October market collapse.

LEAD: Having failed to find a safe exit from Afghanistan, the Soviet Union may now be bracing itself to settle for a quick exit - even one that leaves the possibility of continued civil warfare on this country's southern border.

LEAD: The housing problems of Long Island came home to Jeff Casey last summer when the 29-year-old assistant business professor moved his family from Boston to take a job at the State University of New York management school.
LEAD: After three months on the job, Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. is preparing to make some major changes in the hierarchy of his department.

LEAD: Americans in four cities will have a chance to voice their concerns on the future of American-Soviet relations this month as part of a project designed to let Presidential candidates know how Americans feel about the Russians.

LEAD: In an attempt to force the issue of giving addicts clean needles to help prevent AIDS infection, a private drug abuse agency has decided to defy New York State law by distributing free needles and syringes in New York City.
LEAD: The high-ceilinged corridor of the Fontainebleau Hotel in Miami Beach was crowded with labor leaders, most of whom had suddenly become publicity shy.

LEAD: George Bernard Shaw subtitled ''Man and Superman'' ''a comedy and a philosophy.'' Shorn of its third act, ''Don Juan in Hell,'' and without the appended ''Revolutionist's Handbook,'' the play accents the comedy rather than the philosophy - a cascade, sometimes a surfeit, of wit and impertinence at the expense of marriage, morality, wealth and social position.

LEAD: Under Stalin, much as in czarist times, a dissenter in the Soviet Union might have been shot in the back of the neck. Under Yuri Andropov's tenure at the K.G.B., the dissenter might instead have been confined to a psychiatric hospital and tortured with psychotropic drugs.

LEAD: Jordan is watching the events in the Israeli-occupied West Bank to see if they might lead to a reopening of Middle East peace talks, but it is wary of a possible resurgence of the Palestine Liberation Organization's influence.
LEAD: * Hans Hansberg and Ann T. O'Hara have been promoted to senior vice presidents at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton.

LEAD: FOR those deeply attracted to modern and contemporary art, the greatest story ever told remains the invention, early in this century, of abstraction. A heroic epic played out on many fronts, both esthetic and geographic, its countless chapters seem to sustain endless scrutiny. As with much of the past, these chapters are in perpetual motion, being continually revised and elaborated upon by succeeding generations of art historians, critics, curators and, in their own way, artists.
LEAD: Survival has always been the first issue for Israel, but it has changed dimension over several periods. In the aftermath of the Holocaust, the goal was creation of the state.

LEAD: Hit or Miss Shops of Stoughton, Mass., a division of the Zayre Corporation, has assigned its advertising account to Mullen Advertising of Wenham, Mass. The budget is $4 million. Hit or Miss operates more than 450 off-price women's apparel shops.
LEAD: FRIDAY FOCUS ON A PRODUCER
LEAD: Old Masters
LEAD: Robert Streetman, a high school dropout who murdered a woman in a $1 burglary, was put to death by injection early today. The execution was delayed three hours by confused state officials.

LEAD: Interest rates on fixed- and adjustable-rate home mortgages fell for the second consecutive month, and although rates on fixed-rate mortgages declined at a faster pace, the share of adjustables continued to rise, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said it had sold 2,012,950 cars and light trucks in the United States in 1987, down 8.1 percent from its own 1986 sales plus those of the American Motors Corporation, which it acquired last year. Its car sales were down 20.9 percent, to 1,096,385, and its truck sales were up 14.1 percent, to 916,565.

LEAD: ''REALISM TODAY,'' an exhibition at the National Academy of Design, pulls together drawings that can be grouped only in the loosest way under the same artistic banner. American artists whose pictures incorporate recognizable images of the world, whether or not these were generated by observations of nature, have been allowed to share the academy's walls.

LEAD: Ex-State Senator Joseph R. Pisani has been out of prison less than a year and he already has his own radio talk show. ''My name is Joe Pisani and welcome to 'Let's Talk with Joe Pisani,' '' he said yesterday as he signed on at WVOX, New Rochelle, for the first time.

LEAD: Facing a partner who is knowledgeable and skillful is just as important in defensive signaling as it is in bidding. It is frustrating to send signals that your partner does not read, or look for signals that are not sent.

LEAD: Three largely unheralded teams remain alive in the National Football League playoffs this weekend. But if the Minnesota Vikings, the Indianapolis Colts and the Houston Oilers are the underdogs, the Chicago Bears, the San Francisco 49ers, the Washington Redskins, the Denver Broncos and the Cleveland Browns are recognizable big names.
LEAD: By halting the purchase of plastic foam cups, plates and other products by New York City agencies, Mayor Koch sets a welcome example.

LEAD: WITH the Nancy Graves sculpture retrospective and the display of Rodin bronzes, the third installation on the fifth floor of the Brooklyn Museum is easy to overlook. It doesn't help that its title, ''The Treasure of San Gennaro: Baroque Silver From Naples,'' suggests luxury items, religious relics and little else.

LEAD: Meade H. Esposito, the 81-year-old former Brooklyn Democratic leader who was convicted last September of giving an illegal gratuity to Representative Mario Biaggi, is under investigation again by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn.
LEAD: Trevor Howard Dies at 71
LEAD: Paine Webber Inc. announced yesterday that John F. Lehman Jr., the former Secretary of the Navy, had joined its investment banking division as a managing director.

LEAD: Severe winter weather over much of the nation bolstered heating and crude oil futures yesterday. Despite a late burst of profit taking, the spot February heating oil contract closed up 0.31 cent a gallon, at 53.79 cents, after soaring to an intraday high of 54.40 cents.

LEAD: ARTURO TOSCANINI. More than 30 years after his death, at the age of 89, the maestro's name remains synonymous with excellence and uncompromising dedication. The reasons are made clear in the documentary ''Toscanini: The Maestro,'' a ''Great Performances'' presentation on Channel 13 at 9 this evening.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mack Lobell, winner of 13 of 16 starts last year, was a landslide choice for Horse of the Year and top trotter of 1987 in balloting conducted by the United States Trotting Association and the United States Harness Writers Association.

LEAD: Articles about the publisher Rupert Murdoch yesterday and on Jan. 1 misstated the circulation of The Boston Herald. It had an average daily circulation of 355,000 and Sunday circulation of 265,000 in the six-month period ended Sept. 30, 1987.

LEAD: Consumers long accustomed to a deluge of sophisticated electronic products that have continually declined in price might be in for a rude awakening this year. For the first time in years, prices of televisions, stereos, compact disk players and video cassette recorders appear to be going up.
LEAD: In these days of fierce competition for legal talent, a law firm in Grand Rapids, Mich., recently came up with a proposal that would have pleased the satirist Jonathan Swift.
LEAD: Russell C. Means, a co-founder of the American Indian Movement, announced his retirement from the group today, proclaiming the organization ''has worked itself out of a job.''

LEAD: The Islanders have assigned the 27-year-old defenseman Ken Leiter to Springfield of the American Hockey League for conditioning. Leiter, who has played in only 18 of the team's 38 games because of chronic abdominal and groin strain, had missed seven of the team's last eight games. 26. . . . Dick MacPherson of Syracuse was honored last night in Atlanta by the 5,500 members of the American Football Coaches Association as this season's major-college coach of the year.
LEAD: Cabaret, an ever-fragile world perpetually on the verge of flickering out, seems to thrive at the coldest time of the year, its intimacy a buffer against the blast of winter.

LEAD: The Year of French Music, a series of performances sponsored by the New York University Chamber Music Society, continues today at 8 P.M. with a concert of piano music by Debussy at the New York University Theater, 35 West Fourth Street. Gregory Haimovsky is the pianist for the concert, which is a benefit for the society.

LEAD: ''The argument that this is going to encourage drug abuse is ridiculous. We're one of only 11 states restricting needles, yet we have the highest rate of drug abuse in the world anyway. And we're not giving needles to anyone who doesn't already have them.'' - Yolanda Serrano, head of a private drug-abuse agency in

LEAD: SOPHOCLES' comedy ''The Searching Satyrs,'' we are notified in the program at the Nat Horne Theater, was ''performed once in 440 B.C. and lost for 2,500 years.'' That should give us a reprieve until 2060, but here it is, as if early confirmation were required that Aristophanes was Greece's great comic poet.

LEAD: The Koch administration says it's serious about protecting New York City workers who blow the whistle on waste, fraud and corruption. But consider the case of Samuel Adams, formerly a $263-a-week Health Department janitor. After a month on the job, Mr. Adams reported to the department's Inspector General that his supervisor was turning back the time clock to protect tardy co-workers.
LEAD: LE REGENCE, the opulent, Old World French restaurant in the Hotel Plaza Athenee, has in a sense been a victim of its own success.
LEAD: Baseball and union officials yesterday debated the impact the Yankees had made on the game by signing Jack Clark, the free-agent slugger from the St. Louis Cardinals.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission and its Canadian counterparts today set up a framework for close cooperation in an effort to stem a broad range of cross-border violations of securities laws.
LEAD: Eight string quartets that are now taking part in the Juilliard String Quartet Seminar Week are to give two free concerts at the school's Michael C. Paul Recital Hall today at 4 and 8 P.M.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Chiat/Day, New York, announced yesterday that by mutual agreement with its client, the Rockport Company, the two are splitting.

LEAD: Donald G. Russell, who has spent much of his career bouncing sound waves beneath the ground as a petroleum engineer for the Shell Oil Company, was named this week to head a small exploration and production company trying to rebuild.

LEAD: WHEN most theater-, concert- or museumgoers come in contact with a creative work, they expect the play, composition or painting to be a finished, polished product. They may pause to reflect on the arduous and perhaps mysterious process that led from the first spark of an idea, through many creative twists and turns, to a completed work with which the artist presumably was more or less satisfied.

LEAD: Roberto Duran, the 36-year-old former champion, will challenge the Continental Americas middleweight champion, Ricky Stackhouse, Feb. 5 as part of a pay-per-view cable-television tripleheader in Atlantic City. The other bouts, previously announced, include a title defense by Marlon Starling, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion, against Fujio Ozaki, and a welterwieght fight matching Mark Breland and Juan Alonzo Villa.
LEAD: FCB/Leber Katz Partners has set up the Targeted Communications Group at 101 Park Avenue with Jon Adams as its president, a staff of 80, and $60 million in billings.

LEAD: A 20-mile oil slick caused by the collapse of a huge oil tank in Pennsylvania on Saturday reached this city on the Ohio River at midnight, prompting officials to start the process of closing the city's water treatment plant.
LEAD: Mayor Koch signed into law yesterday a bill that will greatly restrict smoking in public places in New York City.
LEAD: A betting frenzy surrounding the largest Pick-Six pool in Florida racing history made for a memorable closing afternoon at Hialeah Park today.

LEAD: Sanctimony and hypocrisy attend the great tragedy being played out now over the Palestinians of the Gaza Strip. Any fair look at Gaza, and the West Bank, shows guilt on all sides - Israel, Arab leaders, the United States and the United Nations. They have all stood by while Palestinians have been stripped of any legitimate political voice, and few have worked to rekindle hope through renewed Arab-Israeli negotiations.
LEAD: Bob Eddy, a former editor and publisher of The Hartford Courant, died Monday at his home in Glastonbury, Conn. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: Brian Boitano performing his short program last night at the United States Figure Skating Championships in Denver. He earned eigh perfect marks of 6.0 for composition and style, virtually assuring himself of a fourth straight national title. Page B13. (NYT/Jose R. Lopez)
LEAD: State Senator James H. Donovan, a powerful Republican from Chadwicks and chairman of the Senate Education Committee, uses flashcards.
LEAD: IN her latest film, Emmanuelle Beart goes a very long way on very short speeches.

LEAD: Citing an uncertain investment climate and a soft market for office space in the financial district, the New York Mercantile Exchange announced yesterday that it was withdrawing from a project that would have created the world's largest commodity exchange. The withdrawal appeared to doom the project.
LEAD: GAGE & TOLLNER, the 99-year-old Brooklyn landmark restaurant, may be sold soon, and its future as a business is uncertain, the owners say.
LEAD: An obituary of Harold Matson on Wednesday gave an incorrect date for his death. Mr. Matson, a literary agent, died Monday.
LEAD: Of all the South African political figures likely to pose serious problems for President P. W. Botha, the Rev. Allan Hendrickse has never figured very prominently.

LEAD: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., traveling in Europe, has conferred this week with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and President Francois Mitterand of France. He is scheduled to meet Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in London next week. His main subject: The United States-Soviet treaty banning intermediate missiles in Europe.
LEAD: British 'American Way'
LEAD: It is not only what you say that counts in Washington, it is where and when you say it.
LEAD: One of the seven drivers charged with trying to fix a race at Yonkers Raceway in November said yesterday that he did all he could to win the race but that his horse was outclassed.

LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said yesterday that he would propose legislation that might allow Rupert Murdoch to continue to own both The New York Post and a New York City television station, at least temporarily.
LEAD: President Reagan has chosen Maj. Gen. William F. Burns as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, the White House announced today.

LEAD: Israeli troops wounded at least seven Palestinians today as violent demonstrations broke out again in the occupied Gaza Strip, and there were reports that a 15-year-old youth died of his injuries.

LEAD: A New York family that increased its stake to 7.6 percent of the Cooper Companies' 23 million shares outstanding said it might seek representation on the board of the eye-care concern, based in Palo Alto, Calif. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Bruce, Howard and Wayne Sturman of Mount Vernon said they might present a restructuring proposal to Cooper management that ''could include the sale or disposition of one or more of the company's principal business segments and a restructuring or liquidation of the company.

LEAD: The A. H. Robins Company, which has operated under a bankruptcy court's protection since August 1985, yesterday began an uphill battle to win support for a plan to clear its debts and reorganize itself as a subsidiary of Sanofi, a big French drug company.

LEAD: Erich Honecker, left, with President Francois Mitterrand yesterday after arriving at Orly Airport. Mr. Honecker is the first East German leader to visit any of the three Western powers that have occupied West Berlin since World War II. French officials say there are no plans for signing agreements, but the talks are seen as a step toward overcoming what Mr.

LEAD: The class-action lawsuit, which has its roots in medieval English law, achieved what many consider its finest hour in 1954 when Brown v. Topeka Board of Education desegregated the nation's schools. Then, in the 1970's, class actions became the rage of the legal profession. Now they appear to be dying.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: War strategies were plotted and top secrets discussed in its rooms; journalists gathered scoops here and Presidents lost at bridge.
LEAD: December sales at the nation's top retailers were generally, in some cases surprisingly, improved over the figures from December 1986.
LEAD: While political specialists continue discussing how many debates are too many debates, the second round of the prolonged 1988 Presidential debating competition will start Friday in Des Moines.

LEAD: Sitting alone in a bare prison cell, a man accused of being a guerrilla gunman spent an hour this morning quietly recounting how, he says, he helped kill a human rights official here 10 weeks ago.

LEAD: In a modest frame cottage built on a concrete slab, Willie Mae Porter and Marlin Gingerich looked down at her carpet, ruined by water. ''Tear it out,'' Ms. Porter said. Mr. Gingerich bent to do so.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that after a nationwide search, it had selected a new chief accountant from its own ranks, naming Edmund Coulson to the important financial post.

LEAD: William C. Brennan, a former advertising executive, died of cancer of the colon and liver Tuesday at Fairview Hospital in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 75 years old and lived in Great Barrington.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: International A3-11

LEAD: Bo Jackson, already a professional baseball and football player, has rejected an opportunity from pro basketball. Offered a chance to sign a contract with the Orange County (Calif.) Crush of the new International Basketball Association for players 6 feet 4 inches or shorter, the former Heisman Trophy winner from Auburn said no thanks yesterday and went home to Bessemer, Ala., to pursue hunting, a sport for which he receives no pay.
LEAD: Thousands of Americans have begun buying a new form of health insurance that pays for nursing homes or care in their own homes for chronic illnesses.
LEAD: The Islanders, the unanticipated proprietors of first place in their division for the bulk of the season, aren't sure whether they ought to be pleased with themselves or worried.

LEAD: The folk singer Odetta will be among the speakers tomorrow during a three-day forum for educators and community leaders on the life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Lenox Avenue, at 135th Street.
LEAD: DiFranza Williamson Inc., a 32-year-old New York sales promotion agency, has been acquired by Ketchum Communications, a Pittsburgh-based advertising and public relations company.

LEAD: The San Francisco 49ers will not appeal the National Football League's $50,000 fine for offering playoff bonuses to their players, Coach Bill Walsh said yesterday. Commissioner Pete Rozelle notified the team yesterday that, although he would not rescind the bonuses promised by the 49ers' owner, Edward J.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Scientists wielding million-dollar medical instruments completed a weeklong operation yesterday, the main feature of which was the carefully choreographed dissection of two dead fish.

LEAD: The original manuscript of the Emancipation Proclamation, in the handwriting of President Abraham Lincoln, will go on exhibit tomorrow and Sunday at the State Museum in the Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller Empire State Plaza in Albany.

LEAD: President Reagan's draft budget for the next fiscal year calls for a new policy that would prevent cities with rent control laws from receiving Federal grants for the repair of rental housing, according to confidential budget documents.

LEAD: The Koch administration and the City Council leadership have reached agreement on a key provision that had threatened the Mayor's proposal for public financing of election campaigns, city officials said yesterday.
LEAD: The International Olympic Committee said today that a record 143 countries have signed for the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 413 money market mutual funds increased $5.64 billion, to $263.88 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 112 institutional funds increased $4.32 billion, to $75.31 billion. Assets of the 206 general purpose funds were down $117.0 million, to $79.27 billion.
LEAD: Traveling about India, or suddenly during conversations here in the capital, I find my mind wandering off to a street in a distant town in the Himalayas.

LEAD: The renewed Presidential campaign of Gary Hart has received thousands of small contributions from adiring supporters. Some checks were accompanied by notes to Mr. Hart's wife, Lee, praising her for standing by her husband after disclosures about the weekend he spent with a Miami model.

LEAD: Taiwan had a record trade surplus of $19 billion in 1987, up 22 percent from 1986, the Government reported today. Exports were $53.5 billion; imports were $34.5 billion. Taiwan's surplus in trade with the United States grew 18.5 percent, to $16 billion.
LEAD: A task force appointed by President Reagan to study the stock market crash will call for radical changes in the way stocks, bonds and other financial instruments are traded.
LEAD: Errol and Beverly in Love

LEAD: Yesterday, less than 24 hours after Gary Gaetti had said that there was ''a real good chance'' he would reject a contract offer from Minnesota and seek a better deal, and slightly more than 24 hours before he would lose the chance to return to the Twins until May 1, the free-agent third baseman signed a three-year Twins contract worth $4.3 million.

LEAD: The St. Louis Cardinals, starting an immediate search for power after the loss of Jack Clark, have held preliminary discussions with Bob Horner. ''At this point, we're talking,'' Horner said last night from his home near Dallas. ''Obviously, there's a fit there.'' Clark signed a free-agent contract with the Yankees Wednesday, leaving the Cardinals without their only proven power hitter.
LEAD: Markets

LEAD: A 12-year-old boy was fatally injured Tuesday when he hit a tree while sledding at a park near his home here. The boy, Maximillian Schuberthan, of 447 Park Hill Avenue, died Wednesday at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, the county medical examiner's office said. He was sledding at Pelton Field at about 5 P.M.

LEAD: A woman was shot and killed, and her sister was seriously wounded, when the dead woman's ex-boyfriend approached them on a crowded platform at the Grand Central subway station in the rush hour last night and fired a shotgun before disappearing into the crowd, the police said.

LEAD: The FMC Corporation's Defense Systems Group and a Turkish partner, Nurol Defense Industry, will receive a $1 billion contract from the Turkish Government to build armored combat vehicles, it was announced today. A spokesman for the FMC Defense Systems Group, which is based here and has a manufacturing plant in nearby San Jose, said the deal called for about 1,700 armored vehicles to be made over the next eight years.
LEAD: A. Hawley Peterson, a retired New York investment counselor and stockbroker, died Monday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: The first witness in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. described yesterday finding the body of Jennifer Levin, almost nude and sprawled with her arms and legs askew in Central Park, and seeing a tall man in khaki pants lingering under the trees in the background.

LEAD: At first they excoriated him, but now the other contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination have stifled their attacks on Gary Hart because they found they were only hurting themselves and helping his resurrected campaign.
LEAD: New Sculpture Garden
LEAD: Lawyers for Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, have sharply disputed allegations of wrongdoing leveled against their client in the Congressional Iran-contra report.

LEAD: DENNIS MILLER is one of the youngest and brightest standup comedians to belong to the tradition of urbane scattershot commentary that extends from Bob Hope to Johnny Carson to Chevy Chase. Mr. Miller, who maintains an air of sarcastic deadpan geniality in his role of anchorman for the ''Weekend Update'' segments on ''Saturday Night Live,'' is more vivacious and irreverent in his club act than on television.
LEAD: A bill banning the sale and distribution of irradiated foods was passed by the Assembly today by a 62-to-3 vote and sent to Governor Kean.
LEAD: President Reagan today named James M. Stephens to succeed Donald L. Dotson as chairman of the National Labor Relations Board.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Sean Elliott scored 23 points, and Tom Tolbert had 20 as third-ranked Arizona, which held California to 12 first-half points, cruised to an 80-51 Pacific-10 Conference victory tonight.
LEAD: A late Christmas shopping surge and strong after-Christmas buying helped lift December sales for some big retailers. Page D1.

LEAD: For many Americans who are just now storing their holiday decorations, plastic angels and stocking stuffers may not be at the top of their shopping list. But on a 45-acre site in this community of 3,000 some 80 miles north of Detroit, the selling of seasonal cheer is a year-round business.

LEAD: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas has capitalized on disaffection with President Reagan among Iowa Republicans to build a substantial lead there over Vice President Bush, a New York Times/ CBS News Poll has found.
LEAD: As the dollar strengthened and bond prices recovered, stock prices rose yesterday for the fourth session in a row.

LEAD: A senior Defense Department official made a secret trip to Panama last week to urge the country's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, to withdraw from politics and allow an elected civilian government to take power, State Department and senior Latin American diplomats said Thursday night.

LEAD: A program of show tunes, soul, jazz and gospel music is to be played on Sunday on the vintage organ at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street. James Paulin, who was the organist at Radio City Music Hall during the early 1970's, is to play the theater's 1928 Wurlitzer. The concert is sponsored by the New York Theater Organ Society.

LEAD: The Guarneri String Quartet is to perform an all-Beethoven program tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Grace Rainey Rodgers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Tickets are $16. Information: 570-3949.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II is likely to meet President Kurt Waldheim as many as three times during a papal visit to Austria this June in keeping with protocol, Roman Catholic officials said today.

LEAD: In the first of what is expected to be a series of sanctions resulting from the stock market crash, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that the largest specialist firm on the exchange was giving up its right to make a market in an important stock, that of J.P. Morgan & Company.

LEAD: New Yorkers, however outraged they may be by $7 movie tickets, like to think they are beyond street shock. Nothing is so unusual or outrageous, they imagine, that they haven't seen or heard it already. But a New Yorker visiting Chicago recently found something about which to be surprised.
LEAD: Vice President Bush said today that he knew ''a lot'' about the President Reagan's secret initiative to ship arms to Iran.

LEAD: As part of the Washington Square Contemporary Music Series, a trio -Rolf Schulte, violinist, William Purvis, french hornist and Alan Feinberg, pianist - is to perform works by George Edwards, Robert Helps, Babbitt and Stockhausen on Sunday at 3 P.M. in Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street). Tickets are $8.

LEAD: Three of four adult Americans now know that the AIDS virus can be transmitted through sexual contact, and 81 percent support federally financed research to find a cure for the deadly disease, a new poll shows. In 1986 this fact about transmission of the disease was known by 61 percent.

LEAD: January usually brings a post-holiday lull and, without fail, post-holiday bills. Just when there seems to be no escape, the mailbox swells with sweepstakes letters. The timing is no coincidence, according to direct-mail marketers, who say they get the best response at this time of year.

LEAD: Robert U. Redpath Jr., an advisor to corporations for pension and estate planning, died Dec. 28 at his home in South Orange, N.J., after a long illness. He was 81 years old. Mr. Redpath graduated from Yale College and was associated with several life-insurance companies.

LEAD: A man described as one of the city's major drug dealers was convicted yesterday on charges that will put him in jail at least 15 years, officials said. A jury that deliberated more than A jury that deliberated more than two days found Lorenzo (Fat Cat) Nichols, 29 years old, guilty of three counts of criminal possession of a controlled substance, criminal possession of marijuana, criminal use of drug paraphernalia and six counts of criminal possession of a weapon.

LEAD: ''Tamara,'' a play by John Krizanc at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street, will suspend performances for two weeks, beginning Jan. 18, to make room for the Winter Antique Show. The play will resume on Feb. 2.
LEAD: Israeli officials said today that dozens of Palestinians had been jailed in the last few days under a procedure allowing them to be held without trial for up to six months.
LEAD: Spring is just a few steps away, as close as the cut flowers at the nearest greengrocer or neighborhood florist.

LEAD: David Puttnam, the film producer whose credits include the Oscar winners ''Midnight Express,'' ''Chariots of Fire,'' ''The Killing Fields'' and ''The Mission,'' will receive the 1988 Eastman Second Century Award.

LEAD: Diane Feinstein waving farewell at inauguration ceremony for Art Agnos, center, who succeeded her yesterday as the city's 39th Mayor. At right was Mr. Agnos's wife, Sherry. In his speech, Mr. Agnos stressed people's rights to decent jobs and affordable housing. (AP)
LEAD: The Library of Congress has announced the award of commissions totaling $91,500 to 10 composers to write works under auspices of the Serge Koussevitzky Music Foundation.

LEAD: Tim Brown of Notre Dame, the Heisman Trophy winner, and Don McPherson of Syracuse, the runner-up, will be teamed on the East squad Sunday for the Japan Bowl, an annual college All-Star game to be played at Yokohama.
LEAD: Robert Barrios, a copy editor for The New York Times and former Foreign Service officer, died Thursday at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 33 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Sales of new cars in Italy rose 8.3 percent last year, to a a record 1,976,541, the Italian Association of Auto Makers reported today. Fiat accounted for 43.7 percent of the total.

LEAD: A group of black Baptist ministers voted this week not to invite Mayor Koch to its annual memorial service for the Rev. LEAD: For the Nets, tonight's game began to resemble the temperature: cold, dropping fast, looking as if it would get worse before it got better.

LEAD: Yonkers officials were reported today to have offered to settle at least part of the city's seven-year-old desegregation suit by proposing to build 10 units of public housing on each of 20 sites in white neighborhoods.

LEAD: China agreed today to accept substitutes for some products of the Toshiba Machine Company, partly resolving an eight-month dispute over Japan's decision to bar Toshiba from exporting to Communist states.
LEAD: Because of the snow, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

LEAD: Winter raided the East Coast yesterday with heavy snow and freezing winds that disrupted transportation, government, business and education and recast the landscape into snowbound shapes from the Carolinas to the New York metropolitan area.

LEAD: While William Thomas McKinley cannot strictly be called a Minimalist, the four concertos by the composer that the American Symphony Orchestra performed Thursday evening in Carnegie Hall showed him to rival certain members of that school in his capacity to write seemingly endless stretches of unvaried, uninteresting music.
LEAD: West Germany's unemployment rate rose to 9.2 percent in December from 8.5 percent in November as the number of jobless grew by 175,200, to more than 2 million, the Government reported today.
LEAD: DOROTHY PARKER: What Fresh Hell Is This? By Marion Meade. Illustrated. 459 pages. Villard Books. $22.50.

LEAD: A committee representing the outside shareholders of the A.H. Robins Company yesterday put off a decision on whether to oppose Robins's plan to become a subsidiary of Sanofi, the French drug company.

LEAD: Robert Moresco sits in Jimmy Armstrong's, one of those old Irish saloons on the West Side of Manhattan, and talks about a play he has written, and the reality on which it might or might not be based.
LEAD: Harold T. Shapiro took office as Princeton University's 18th president today and appealed to American higher education to be more mindful of the moral and spiritual needs of college students.

Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who plays a powerful role in overseeing the securities industry, said today that he had begun an investigation into charges that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission used unreliable data in its study of possible manipulative trading involving the Major Market
LEAD: Ruth Wright, a retired theater owner, died of cancer Dec. 31 at her home in Great Neck, L.I. She was 75 years old.
LEAD: When a bullet hit Ceferino Lumanlan in the forehead Wednesday night, it looked as if a sudden gust of wind was blowing back his hair.

LEAD: Painful as it is to experience, there is something cathartic about being humbled. Somehow, the vulnerability it exposes leaves its victims more easily introspective, certainly more engagingly candid.

LEAD: ''Sorry I am late,'' Sophie Gluck of Brooklyn wrote in a note, along with her gift of $15 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. She requested that her contribution go to a needy older person.
LEAD: The Computervision Corporation said yesterday that its board had rejected a $390 million takeover proposal from one of its leading rivals, Prime Computer Inc.

LEAD: After successfully nurturing movements toward democracy in the Philippines and South Korea, the Reagan Administration now appears to have been overcome with a sense of powerlessness as it faces the prospect of failure in Haiti.

LEAD: Oral Roberts, the evangelist, has decided to remove ministry programs from scores of television stations across the country because of sagging donations and a decision by many stations to drop religious programming.

LEAD: The Nissan Motor Corporation is recalling 75,000 four-wheel-drive vehicles for repairs to pollution-control devices and fuel lines. The fuel line problem, involving the potential for leaks, is limited to 1987 and 1988 Pulsar NX models. Nissan said in a statement that it had received no reports of engine fires.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration is considering whether to impose new punitive measures against Panama if Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega moves to consolidate his position as the power behind the scenes, senior Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Almost half the tests for the AIDS virus given at a major United States medical center over a 15-month period were administered without a sound medical reason or the patients' consent, researchers reported today.

LEAD: President Reagan proposes increases for the Education Department, the air traffic control system and the Federal crackdown on drug trafficking and white-collar crime as part of his $1.1 trillion budget for 1989, according to confidential budget documents.

LEAD: Republican officials in Texas asked Federal agencies today to investigate charges that petitions filed for the state's Presidential primary by two Republican candidates, Senator Bob Dole and Alexander M. Haig Jr., contained numerous forgeries.

LEAD: A police sergeant testified yesterday that sometime near or after her death in Central Park, Jennifer Levin's clothing was pushed up until it completely covered her neck, which was found to have ''multiple horizontal red wounds'' across it.

LEAD: Doug Single, the athletic director at Southern Methodist University, is continuing to interview candidates for the job of head football coach, and the latest one is Bill McCartney, the coach at the University of Colorado. ''I visited with the proper authorities at S.M.U. and was able to get an idea of the direction their program will take and the facilities that are available there,'' McCartney told The Dallas Times Herald.

LEAD: The Fairness Doctrine is dead but won't stay buried. President Reagan vetoed an attempt to make it statutory law in June and the Federal Communications Commission struck it from its regulations in August.

LEAD: U.S. Gloom on Haiti Washington now appears powerless as its efforts to lead the military Government away from dictatorship seem to be exhausted. Page 2. Bush and Iran Affair Vice President Bush, in a campaign debate, was on the defensive over the Iran-contra affair. He is expected to be interviewed under oath about the affair on Monday.
LEAD: Government and ruling party leaders agreed today to seek legal changes that would enable Japan to absorb a larger share of the costs of stationing United States troops here.
LEAD: A display of more than 1,000 new boats and marine accessories has turned the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan into a winter monument to summer days.
LEAD: Virginia Haviland, an author and retired director of the Children's Literature Center at the Library of Congress, died of a stroke at her home in Washington on Wednesday. She was 76 years old.

LEAD: IN Chicago years ago, there was a coach from my high school named Ralph Margolis, a barrel-chested fellow and a storyteller of wide repute. He once told of playing baseball for the University of Illinois, where, he said, he beat out Red Grange for right field.

LEAD: Logic and interest argue powerfully for a Soviet withdrawal in 1988 of its 115,000 troops in Afghanistan. But it can't be done without military and political cost. Is Mikhail Gorbachev wise and strong enough to pull out anyway?

LEAD: Prices fell less on the Tokyo Stock Exchange than in other major markets of the world when stocks collapsed in October. Some analysts, trying to explain why, have cited Tokyo's curbs on price movements.

LEAD: ''The Chosen,'' a musical adaptation by Chaim Potok of his novel, with music by Phillip Springer and lyrics by Mitchell Bernard, will close after the evening performance on Sunday at the Second Avenue Theater. The play, directed by Mitchell Maxwell and starring George Hearn, will have run for six regular performances and 52 previews.

LEAD: Unemployment in the New York region fell last year to its lowest level since the early 1970's, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday, attributing the decline to an economy that expanded through most of the year.
LEAD: Prices of Government securities fell sharply yesterday after the release of a better-than-expected report on the nationwide unemployment rate.

LEAD: An eagle crashed into the cockpit of an Ethiopian Airlines jetliner Tuesday, breaking the co-pilot's leg and forcing the plane to make an emergency landing in Khartoum, an airline spokesman said Thursday.

LEAD: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.
LEAD: The dollar fell yesterday, ending a tumultuous week on an uncertain note.
LEAD: A feud within the City Bar Association in New York over who has the authority to speak for it on the qualifications of United States Supreme Court nominees has spilled over into the courts.

LEAD: Consumer prices in Mexico soared by a record 159.2 percent last year, the Bank of Mexico announced. The bank said on Thursday that consumer prices rose by 14.8 percent in December alone, the highest one-month increase since the Government began collecting such statistics in 1968. Consumer prices rose 105.7 percent in 1986, which had been the previous record level.

LEAD: Pat Cash of Australia, who last year defeated Ivan Lendl in the semifinal round of the Australian Open and in the final at Wimbledon, has been seeded fourth in the draw for this year's Australian championships and would meet top-seeded Lendl in the semifinal round again, if both players get that far.
LEAD: A United States Supreme Court Justice was asked today to block the State Department's planned return to Zimbabwe of a 9-year-old diplomat's son who was said to have been beaten by his father.

LEAD: Vice President Bush is expected to be placed under oath Monday during an interview with representatives of the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, Reagan Administration officials said today.

LEAD: When the temperature drops outside, Charlene Turner, a resident of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, south wing lower level, wraps a matted blanket around her thin shoulders, and turns up the latest episode of her favorite soap opera on her five-inch television set.

LEAD: Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri and local leaders met with the owner of the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday in a last-ditch attempt to keep him from moving the National Football League franchise out of town. William Bidwill, the team's owner, reportedly was ''leaning heavily'' toward moving his team to the Phoenix-Tempe area in Arizona.

LEAD: A drug counseling group's proposal to give addicts clean needles to help prevent the spread of AIDS drew strong reactions yesterday from Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch, and the group itself moderated its position.
LEAD: South Africa provided tanks, trucks, troops, jeeps and mortars for the filming of an American adventure movie scheduled for release next summer, South-West African publications have reported.
LEAD: A 16-year-old girl whose former boyfriend admitted strangling her mother will stand trial as an accessory to the killing, a judge ruled yesterday.

LEAD: ''Le Doulous'' (''The Informer''), a 1962 French film noir written and directed by Jean-Pierre Melville, is being shown through Thursday at Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street. The film, based on a detective novel, features Jean-Paul Belmondo in the leading role. Screenings this weekend are at 2, 4, 6, 8 and 10 P.M.

LEAD: Long after Suzanne Semanick and Scott Gregory had won the dance title at the United States figure skating championships late Thursday night, the afterglow of Brian Boitano's remarkable effort in the men's short program was still illuminating McNichols Sports Arena.

LEAD: Al Barabas, the Columbia halfback who scored the game's only touchdown in the famous 7-0 upset of Stanford in the 1934 Rose Bowl, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Rockville, Md. He was 77 years old. LEAD: Harald Norvik, an economist in private industry since 1981 and a Socialist Government official for 10 years before that, will be the next managing director of Statoil, the state-owned company announced Thursday.

LEAD: Chris Mullin is expected to be released as early as Monday from the California hospital where he is undergoing treatment for alcohol dependency, a source close to the Mullin family said yesterday. The source said that after his release, Mullin plans to continue therapy and will rejoin the Warriors when he thinks he is ready to play again.

LEAD: James D. Landis, who heads his own imprint at William Morrow & Company, was named publisher and editor in chief of Morrow yesterday. He replaces Sherry W. Arden, who was named head of a new Morrow imprint, Silver Arrow Books.
LEAD: Is there warmth without down? After years as the unrivaled cold weather insulator, down is facing growing competition from dozens of new synthetic insulators.

LEAD: The Devils called up three forwards, Anders Carlsson, Chris Cichocki and Al Stewart from Utica of the American Hockey League yesterday. They are expected to be in the lineup when the Devils play the North Stars in Minnesota tonight. Carlsson, 27 years old, is being recalled for the third time this season.

LEAD: Literature celebrates the equalizing aspect of the weather: John Huston's film of ''The Dead'' ends with James Joyce's mesmerizing report that snow ''was general all over Ireland''; it was ''falling upon all the living and the dead.''

LEAD: Texaco Inc. will take charges of $4.9 billion against its fourth-quarter after-tax earnings in order to finance its bankruptcy reorganization, the company said yesterday. The charges are among the largest ever taken by an American company.

LEAD: Frederick Hammond Kelley Jr., a retired partner in the accounting firm of Peat Marwick Main & Company, died of emphysema Wednesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Savannah, Ga. He was 69 years old and lived in Hilton Head, S.C.

LEAD: Hours after the first anti-Chinese riots broke out last fall in Lhasa, the distant capital of Tibet, this normally quiet community of Tibetan refugees in the Himalayan foothills of India came to life.

LEAD: Gary Hart says he lost his confidence for a while after ''the business last May,'' as he calls the episode with a Miami model that detoured his Presidential campaign. But now he says he may be stronger personally and politically because of it.
LEAD: A judge refused today to grant amnesty to five national guardsmen convicted of murdering four American churchwomen in 1980, a court official said.

LEAD: Two days from the possible end of his 13th and final season with the Chicago Bears - or three weeks from the completion he would prefer, in Super Bowl XXII -the football career of Walter Payton has room for one last fantasy.

LEAD: Joyce L. Lynch and her husband, Richard, in the custody of state police officers in Hazletville after they were arrested in connection with the Christmas Eve murder of a Delaware couple and the abduction of their nine-day-old son. Joseph and Beverly Gibson were found shot to death early Christmas Day in their home near Wyoming, Del.; their two older children were unhurt, having slept through the shooting.

LEAD: David R. Waters, president of the specialty store operations of General Mills Inc., resigned yesterday after the company announced on Thursday that it would seek to sell its Talbots and Eddie Bauer retail chains.

LEAD: The police have issued a warrant for the arrest of Dino Ciccarelli, the Minnesota North Star right wing, on a charge of assault from a stick-swinging incident during a game here last Wednesday, officials said today.

LEAD: Duff & Phelps Inc., a Chicago-based credit-rating agency, said this week that it had released the first public long-term credit rating of a commercial bank loan.

LEAD: A handful of the nation's largest money management firms, using two types of computerized trading, were mostly responsible for the October stock market collapse, a Presidential task force said in a report today.

LEAD: If you're thinking about winter travel, it's time to check batteries for the appliances you may need. Manufacturers usually specify the size, from AAA to D, but there are different types to choose from. Zinc carbon batteries: Least expensive; most cost effective when used in gadgets that require little power.

LEAD: The Boston Celtics answered their need for a backup center yesterday by signing the 7-foot-2-inch Artis Gilmore, a 17-year veteran who was released by the Chicago Bulls last month at the age of 38. Gilmore, who averaged at least 11 points and seven rebounds a game in each of his pro seasons, averaged 15.5 minutes, 4.2 points and 2.6 rebounds with the Bulls this season.

LEAD: ONE of the fastest-growing ''investment'' products available is single-premium whole life insurance. Its appeal comes primarily from the tax advantages it retained after the Tax Reform Act of 1986 took effect last Jan. 1.
LEAD: These are the spiritual descendants of Gibbon and Michelet, two of the world's greatest historians, one chronicling the end of the Roman Empire and the other the history of France.

LEAD: A Federal employment rights commission ignored 900 grievances concerning age discrimination for more than two years, preventing most people who filed the complaints from taking legal action, the agency's chief said Thursday.

LEAD: Michael N. Taylor, director of Indian education programs for the Association of American Indian Affairs, died of pnuemonia Tuesday at the Washington Adventist Hospital in Tacoma, Md. He was 47 years old and lived on Staten Island.
LEAD: A dispute between roommates at a midtown Y.M.C.A. ended yesterday with a fatal stabbing, the police said.

LEAD: A West Orange surgeon, called a slumlord by Mayor Sharpe James, has been charged with 11 counts of contempt of court for leaving 62 tenants without heat, hot water and other services, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: Homer Smith, an outstanding running back for Princeton in the early 1950's and head football coach at Army from 1974 through 1978, was named offensive coordinator yesterday for the University of Alabama football team by Coach Bill Curry. Smith, 56, spent 28 years coaching at the college level before serving with the Kansas City Chiefs as offensive coordinator last season.

LEAD: Two days after they signed a major hitter, the Yankees lost a major pitcher last night when Bill Gullickson said no to their final offer and headed for Japan, where he is expected to sign a two-year contract Monday for $3.3 million with the Tokyo Giants.

LEAD: This year's National Conference for Conductors will interrupt classes and meetings at Columbia University today to give its Theodore Thomas Award to Max Rudolf, a man whose Central European training and professionalism has had a strong influence on American symphonic life over the last half-century.

LEAD: The Tandon Corporation, a disk drive maker in Chatsworth, Calif., said it had agreed in principle to the settlement of class action suits filed last July by shareholders charging Tandon had violated Federal securities and state laws in statements and public reports made in 1983 and 1984.

LEAD: The idea that less than 10 large financial institutions could bring the financial system to its knees through their unrelenting selling of stocks and financial instruments that set off the selling of stocks is a terrifying prospect. But that in essence is what the Presidential commission on the stock collapse concluded.

LEAD: The Holly Sugar Corporation rejected a last-ditch, $92.50-a-share buyout proposal from Plum Associates and paid the New York-based investor group a $900,000 fee for calling off the deal in favor of an offer from the Imperial Sugar Company.
LEAD: A member of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission has resigned, calling the agency's efforts to register the city's nonmedallion vehicles ineffective.
LEAD: A new biological method that can detect tiny amounts of the AIDS virus may be a powerful tool for testing the effectiveness of experimental drugs against the disease, researchers say.

LEAD: While economists debate whether another bout of inflation is on the way, Louis R. Cooper, the manager and part owner of Cooper Plumbing and Heating in Ottsville, Pa., thinks it has already arrived.

LEAD: For the last decade, Clifford Jordan has quietly and consistently been making brilliant music with his tenor saxophone. At 56, with 30-odd years of professional experience behind him, Mr. Jordan's profound mastery allows him to wrap each note of his solos in its own texture. In the midst of his unhurried improvisations, he'll convert a low note into a crying moan, slide it up through a silky blue haze to a new pitch and end the phrase with a gently swaying vibrato.

LEAD: Tandem Computer Inc.'s shares lost a quarter of their value yesterday after the company, which makes business computer systems, said revenues for the quarter just ended would not meet its expectations.
LEAD: The snowfall that hit New York yesterday wiped out thoroughbred and harness-racing programs at three tracks in the region and postponed basketball and hockey games in West Point, N.Y.
LEAD: The onset of the $7 movie ticket seems to have aroused some anger in New York, if not much resistance at the box office. This may puzzle an out-of-towner buying tickets for a Broadway show.

LEAD: A senior White House policy group has agreed in principle that the Government should back a private plan for construction of a small, inexpensive space station that would fly into orbit years ahead of NASA's multibillion-dollar space outpost, Federal officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Olivier Messiaen's ''Turangalila'' Symphony is only 40 years old, but it belongs to an age other than ours. Its vastness contradicts modern science's assertions that man is small and the universe infinite. Extravagance such as this bespeaks a confidence in our powers ultimately to control the world around us.

LEAD: A Pennsylvania meat processor has has expanded a voluntary recall of products to include about 3,000 boneless prosciutto hams suspected of being contaminated by salmonella, the Agriculture Department has reported.
LEAD: Brett Hull scored twice and assisted on two other goals tonight as the Calgary Flames defeated the Islanders, 7-4.

LEAD: Striding languidly into the large, brightly colored Bedouin tent with his flowing brown cape swept over his arm, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi declared to the two dozen West German sportswriters that he had watched an ice hockey game on videotape and approved of it. It is not a violent game, he declared, but a mass sport that people like.

LEAD: Thursday's editorial on Margaret Thatcher erred in asserting that the Prime Minister's Conservatives failed in the June 1987 election to capture any Scottish seats. Her party holds 10 of 72 seats from Scotland.

LEAD: Anna Sokolow's Players' Project offered two suites of choreographic images and a little sketch of a dance on Thursday night in Buttenwieser Hall of the 92d Street Y. Because of the fragmentary nature of the proceedings, watching Ms. Sokolow's choreography was like browsing through someone's scrapbook.

LEAD: Dan J. Bradley, a former president of the Legal Services Corporation who later became a leading advocate for gay rights, died of AIDS today at Doctors Hospital in Coral Gables, Fla., He was 47 years old and lived in Miami.

LEAD: One of three polyps removed from Gov. William A. O'Neill's colon this week contained a cluster of cancer cells, his doctors said today. But because the polyp has been taken out, he faces no risk of recurrence, they said.

LEAD: Frank E. Vandiver, the president of Texas A&M University, said Thursday that he would resign his post to establish a national defense research organization at the university. Mr. Vandiver, a military historian, said he hoped to relinquish the presidency Sept. 1 but would stay until his successor was named.

LEAD: The economy continued to create jobs at a rapid pace last month, the Labor Department reported today. The unemployment rate fell one-tenth of a percentage point, to 5.7 percent, the lowest level since mid-1979.
LEAD: The stoic Yankees who live in the small towns nestled in the Litchfield Hills are renowned for their sense of tradition and their resistance to new ideas.

LEAD: The report issued today by the Presidential Task Force on Market Mechanisms was largely the product of a 42-member staff drawn from universities and Wall Street.

LEAD: College Basketball Fifth-Ranked Wyoming Loses: In El Paso last night, Tim Hardaway scored 18 points and Chris Sandle added 16 as Texas-El Paso (12-2) rallied for a 68-62 victory over fifth-ranked Wyoming (11-1) in the Western Athletic Conference opener for both teams. Sandle, who covered Fennis Dembo for much of the night, held the Wyoming star to 9 points.

LEAD: Diego Maradona, the Argentine soccer star who has played in Naples since 1984, said yesterday in an television interview in Milan that when his contract with Napoli (which he recently extended by four years) expires in 1993, he will return to Argentina. ''After nine years in Naples, I will return home and join Boca Juniors to fulfill my mother's dream that I and my brothers, Hugo and Lalo, would play together for at least one year,'' he said.

LEAD: The Cuomo administration plans to propose major changes in housing regulations, including making leases permanent in rent-stabilized apartments and ending the need for their renewals. It would also eliminate rent surcharges for fuel costs and stiffen some penalties against landlords who do not properly maintain apartments.

LEAD: Mayor Tom Bradley today proposed a plan to spend more than $2 billion over the next 20 years to build more low-income housing and provide more services for the city's fast-growing homeless population.
LEAD: For the first time, the American Contract Bridge League will this year use the same formula for selecting the two United States squads.
LEAD: Pat Robertson has lost a bid to postpone the trial of his libel suit against a former Congressman who questioned the Republican Presidential candidate's Korean War record.

LEAD: Mental health and social workers are looking for thousands of mentally disabled people in New York City, many of them homeless, who may be due Social Security benefits that were cut off several years ago in what the courts said was an illegal policy. Some people may get tens of thousands of dollars.

LEAD: On his first visit to a Western country responsible for the security of Berlin, Erich Honecker, the East German leader, met polite but firm disagreement here today on human rights and arms control.

LEAD: An inmate who escaped last April from a Virginia state prison where he was serving a 135-year term for rape and sodomy was captured here Thursday night, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. The inmate, Rafael Rogel Acosta, was four years into his sentence when he walked out of the prison dressed as a corrections officer.

LEAD: Simone de Beauvoir, the French writer and scholar, is being honored today with a daylong program of readings and interviews on WNYC radio, 830 AM and 93.9 FM. The tribute, beginning at 10 A.M., falls on the 80th anniversary of her birth; Miss de Beauvoir, author her birth; Miss de Beauvoir, author of ''The Second Sex,'' among other works, died in 1986.

LEAD: A 38-year-old man wanted in the shotgun killing of his former companion Thursday on a crowded platform in the Grand Central subway station was arrested yesterday outside his brother's home in New Jersey, the police said.
LEAD: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said today that it was studying a wide range of changes in its operations and regulatory role in response to the October market collapse.
LEAD: A near-record number of feature-length films from 1987 qualified for Academy Awards consideration, missing the 1974 mark by a single entry, academy officials said today.

LEAD: To the Editor: The Nov. 1 Q & A column provided information about weather conditions for travelers. Since March of last year, American Express has provided Accu-Weather forecasts to card members through our Global Assist Hotline. The forecasts, updated twice daily, are available for 220 cities in the United States and throughout the world.

LEAD: THE PIOUS DANCE: The Adventure Story of a Young Man. By Klaus Mann. Translated by Laurence Senelick. (PAJ Publications, $15.95.) In this 1925 novel, written when its author (Thomas Mann's son) was 19 years old, everything - carnivals, despair, erotic love, bug bites - is experienced with the solemn rhapsodic intensity of romantic youth, a mood reminiscent of Rimbaud that is skillfully captured in Laurence Senelick's translation.

LEAD: A jet carrying 1,500 pounds of packages for Federal Express crashed before dawn Friday on its approach to an airport here, apparently killing both pilots. One pilot's body was found, and divers searched the Ouachita River for the other, a spokesman for the local sheriff said. The names of the pilots were not immediately released.

LEAD: WHAT to call ''Blood Brothers''? Is it a musical melodrama, a musical tragedy or, more singularly, a ''modern ballad opera brushed with legend,'' as one London reviewer described it.

LEAD: Announcement of the engagement of Gretchen Van Lear Richter to Paul J. Massey Jr. has been made by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Stewart A. Richter of Short Hills, N.J. A May wedding is planned.
LEAD: India has replaced a senior military commander in northern Sri Lanka after months of speculation that New Delhi had been dissatified about his handling of the Indian peacekeeping force there.

LEAD: THINGS CHANGE ALL THE time in Hollywood. Stars come and stars go. Raunchy teen-age comedies clogged the theaters like cholesterol in aging arteries for six years, then disappeared overnight, to be replaced in the fall of 1987 by courtroom melodramas and steamy love stories. Three months ago, the stock market crash put upstart companies at risk, those fragile new movie makers dependent on stock sales and one hit movie.
LEAD: ON a national television program last week, a caller from Connecticut told Gary Hart that she was ''sick of hearing about your sleeping habits.''

LEAD: IN winter I could eat soup every day. For lunch, I like nothing better than a bowl of hot soup and a sandwich. I also like seasonal winter soups for dinner, thick vegetable soups that are almost like stews, with additions of lentils, beans, pasta, rice or potatoes. I like to serve them in large deep bowls, along with some fresh French bread, with cheese and salad to follow.

LEAD: THE holidays are over, you've just finished your semiannual roll of film, and you're waiting for the prints to come back from the processor. You wait and wait. Weeks pass. Could it be that your most treasured memories have vanished without a trace?

LEAD: To the Editor: It was delightful to read ''Marquesas by Freighter'' by Robert Gordon (Travel, Dec. 6). My friend and I took that trip last March and the best part of it was that there are no age limitations on the passengers. She and I are both 80, and while it's true that one must be in good health since there's no doctor on board, we found no difficulty in making all the shore excursions and being tossed by muscular sailors into and out of the whaleboats on to the shore or back at the ship for the ascent up the ladder.

LEAD: SEVEN years into an epidemic that is expected to kill more than 179,000 Americans by the end of 1991, Federal financing to fight AIDS is approaching the amount spent in the war on cancer. Budget documents show that President Reagan plans to ask Congress for $1.3 billion in the next fiscal year to help the Public Health Service combat the epidemic, an increase of 37 percent over appropriations for the current year.

LEAD: THE winged-keel concept that in 1983 helped Alan Bond's marauding Australians lift the America's Cup from its longtime resting place at the New York Yacht Club did more than set the world of sailboat racing on its ear. Once the Australian yacht designer Ben Lexcen had proved the concept on the race course, manufacturers of production sailboats could see the benefits for family cruisers.

LEAD: Melvin H. Worth Sr., retired president and chairman of Cosmopolitan Mutual Insurance Company, died of cancer of the colon Thursday in Staten Island Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Deerfield Beach, Fla.

LEAD: Chris Mullin is Bill Bradley reincarnate: a team player in constant motion who has a very good shot when he is open. Just like Trent Tucker. Based on Pitino's pitiful progress in getting his players to set picks and screens for Tucker, Mullin would fare no better. KEN ROSENBERG New York

LEAD: PENN STATE'S leading rusher, Blair Thomas, who missed the Citrus Bowl after hurting his knee, will undergo surgery tomorrow. If he has not fully recovered by the fall, Thomas has said he might sit out a year. . . . Cris Carter, the Philadelphia Eagles' wide receiver, underwent surgery on his right foot and will be in a cast for six weeks.

LEAD: Though Waterfront Invest once won an award for historic preservation, the group's current Jersey City project certainly does not fit that category. ''We have taken an extremely ugly, black-looking building and turned it into something quite nice,'' said Robert Fioretti, Waterfront's managing partner for Riverview Terrace.

LEAD: WITH the America's Cup competition returning to its big-boat format, Dennis Conner, who won the cup for the San Diego Yacht Club with his 12-meter Stars & Stripes last winter, must have been wondering if there was any future for the little boats. Now Conner has come up with a way to keep a couple of 12-Meter craft in the public eye during Super Bowl week in San Diego.

LEAD: My recollections as an obstetrics-gynecology practitioner in the early 1970's, at the time the Dalkon Shield was marketed, may be of interest. Patients who had been on the pill were so persuaded by articles in feminist magazines extolling the virtues of the shield that they would demand the shield and threaten to leave my practice if I did not oblige them.

LEAD: BLUEFISH have been abundant along the Atlantic coast for more than 10 years, so abundant that they have become the backbone of a multimillion-dollar marine sport fishing industry from Cape Cod to Cape May, N.J. And now a Federal-state plan, aimed at insuring that the species is not overharvested by recreational or commercial interests, is nearing completion.

LEAD: THE last Christmas concert of this season is coming up next Sunday, when the Ossining Choral Society begins its 51st year with Bach's ''Christmas Oratorio.'' The 3 P.M. performance at the high school also serves to introduce the choir's new maestro, Thomas Filo.

LEAD: Two shots in 1987 will go down among the most memorable in golf history -Larry Mize's chip into the second extra hole to beat Greg Norman for the Masters title and Lee Trevino's hole-in-one at the Skins Game in November. Those who saw them on television or in person should remember them - they probably won't be repeated any time soon.

LEAD: ''Sorry I am late,'' Sophie Gluck of Brooklyn wrote in a note, along with her gift of $15 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. She requested that her contribution go to a needy older person.

He was headed not for Nicaragua's rugged mountains or lush tropical rain forests, where combatants stalk one another, but for Washington, where he believes the contra war will ultimately be won or lost.

Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: IT is two and a half hours after midnight, Tanzanian time. In the light of the full moon lighting our climb, we can look down on the lofty peaks of Kenya's mountains poking up through layered clouds in the far distance. We are more than three miles into the sky, almost as high as jet liners cruise, and higher at that moment than any of the millions of people on the African continent.

LEAD: A FEW DECADES AGO, THE term ''early music'' carried the implication of quaintness, oddity and distance, and described a vast literature that ran from medieval troubador songs to the dawn of the Classical symphony. As musicologists supplied theories about ancient performing practices, established a hierarchy among medieval, Renaissance and Baroque composers, and fleshed out the lists of those composers' works, ensembles specializing in subdivisions within the genre flourished.

LEAD: Skiing Zurbriggen Takes First of Season: Pirmin Zurbriggen, after two second-place finishes, won his first World Cup downhill race of the season yesterday at Val d'Isere, France. Zurbriggen, the Swiss skier who was the overall World Cup winner last year, posted the fastest time ever on the Oreiller-Killy course: 1 minute 57.10 seconds.

LEAD: Dispersed and fragmented Long Island needs more than leaders who take a hand in community affairs, as John Racanelli urged recently [ ''Countering the Hysteria on Economic Growth,'' Opinion Page ] . LEAD: The sooner we face the undeniable fact that disposing of garbage costs a lot of money, the quicker we'll be able to solve our environmental difficulties. I had hoped that the plight of the garbage barge would have raised our waste consciousness. After all, it probably cost over $1,000 per ton to transport, inspect, incinerate and finally dispose of the garbage back on Long Island.
