LEAD: Opponents and some supporters of Gov. Evan Mecham are urging that he consider stepping down while he responds to his indictment on charges of fraud, perjury and filing a false campaign financial report.

LEAD: The picture of Tamil fighters looking over the bodies of Indian soldiers vividly portrays the tragedy of conflicts inspired by mistaken ethnic pride (''Sri Lanka: A Nation Disintegrates,'' by Steven R. Weisman, Dec. 13). The young Tamils stare in disbelief at what they have done. There is neither joy nor celebration of victory; just plain shock and a pall of gloom descending on the blood bath.

LEAD: It's hard not to envy Harvey Weiss, an archeologist at Yale who is hot on the trail of an intriguing correspondence. It's between the king of Shubat Enlil and his son, the governor of Mari. Those were two once-great cities on the plains of Mesopotamia, where urban civilization began some 5,000 years ago.
LEAD: ''I don't have to comply with George Bush. Why doesn't he release what we're all trying to find out about, the Iran-contra thing?'' - Senator Bob Dole. [ 22:1. ]

LEAD: If I were a homeless person in Westchester, I would immediately sign up to be a resident of the proposed Central Westchester Humane Society Shelter, where dogs and cats will live in a brand-new architect-designed $4 million edifice [ Westchester Journal, Dec. 6 ] . It's wonderful to know where our priorities are in Westchester County and that many corporations will be solicited and surely donate to the needy animals in our area.

LEAD: OF all the Christmas gifts exchanged on Capitol Hill last month, few attracted more interest than the biodegradable plastic bags Senator Tom Harkin included in the baskets of Iowa farm products that he delivered to colleagues. The bags, which are designed to decompose after a year or two, are at the head of a growing list of industrial products made with corn, the nation's largest and most important crop.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH the state's professional theaters reflect a repertory of extraordinary variety - from the new year's first opening (a Shakespearean tragedy, as interpreted by a leading and much-lauded experimental troupe) to the season's windup (the reworking of a failed, but, for many, a favorite Jerry Herman musical) - it appears that the current attention-getters are three artistic directors.

LEAD: LISTENING to Friday night's concert by the Brooklyn Philharmonic made one wonder whether music is American by virtue of a special identity or by the lack of same. Two pieces on the program at the Academy of Music seemed to argue the question in different directions.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frank Blanchfield Heller of Bedford, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Holland Heller, to John Robert Hewitt, the son of Donald Birch Hewitt of San Diego and the late Edith Marie Hewitt.

LEAD: FOUR days after Black Monday, CJI Industries, a maker of coin and currency handling products, announced plans to merge with Triangle Industries, the nation's biggest packaging manufacturer and a company whose stock had been battered in the Oct. 19 market plunge.
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Gary Hart are two of the 10 men most admired by Americans, the latest Gallup Poll says.

LEAD: MICHAEL J. FOX HAS BEEN dragged by the collar, thrashing and yelling, down the length of a fashion-show runway and tossed out the door several times. Now, resting between takes on the set of ''Bright Lights, Big City,'' he's sitting in the second-floor foyer of the Parsons School of Design in Manhattan, joking with his real-life bodyguard, who plays the fashion-show bouncer on screen, and talking to Jay McInerney.
LEAD: On their painted, icy field, the Cleveland Browns disposed of one bad memory and one real obstacle today by beating the Indianapolis Colts in their American Conference semifinal playoff game.

LEAD: THIS is the time of year when northern grandmasters peruse travel folders of balmier climes in the effort to align comfort with a reasonable competition to play in. Since sponsors pick up air tickets and, indeed, the entire stay, it does not matter how long the journey may be.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WITH THE SPEED AND glitz of the art world, the need for the installation as a self-contained work of art, in which visitors can be totally immersed, is not likely to diminish. Installations are made for a particular place and time. After their run, they are dismantled. Most are never reassembled. At best, they are at the same time immediate and slow.

LEAD: AS a kid, I ate corn mush for breakfast and tomato-soup gravy for dinner, but I learned tough from hard-nosed card games like euchre and pinochle. These were Midwestern card games that set brother against brother, parent against child.
LEAD: TRAIN passengers to Wilmington used to arrive at a rundown railroad station in an equally shabby neighborhood.

LEAD: With regard to the article by R. C. Casey, ''Cooking for One, Forever'' [ Opinion page, Nov. 15 ] , I, too, live alone and am a survivor. My husband also needed a special diet and special enticements while he underwent chemotherapy.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE GROUNDING OF MODERN FEMINISM By Nancy F. Cott. Illustrated. 372 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95.

LEAD: DURING last year's tumultuous legislative session, traditional party alliances often seemed to break down into personality conflicts, with the new Speaker of the Democratic-controlled State Assembly, Mel Miller, more at odds with the state's Democratic Governor than with the majority leader of the Republican-controlled State Senate.

LEAD: Tania Aebi, the 21-year-old sailor who recently circumnavigated the globe alone on a 26-foot sailboat, is scheduled to appear at the New York National Boat Show today and next Saturday and Sunday from noon to 4 P.M. Her boat, the sailing sloop Varuna, will be on display throughout the show, along with a pictorial display of
LEAD: IN the high-stakes game of trade war, Japan's strong hand does not insure victory.

LEAD: A recent prediction in this space (with the wish admittedly father to the thought) that Representative Jack Kemp would upset conventional wisdom and emerge as the Republican nominee has drawn the expected hoots of derision.

LEAD: ''VENUS AND ADONIS,'' a ''masque for the entertainment of the King'' by John Blow, is an endearing trifle, but the beginnings of English opera were so sparse and tentative that it can plausibly be called a landmark among them. The king was Charles II; we do not know precisely when he was entertained by this brief retelling, with dance and diversions, of the Greek tale.

LEAD: ''It's hard to argue with success,'' Dr. Frank Napier Jr., superintendent of schools in Paterson, N.J., said in 1983, speaking of Joe Clark's first year as principal of Paterson's Eastside High School. Hard, maybe, but last week the Paterson Board of Education started an argument that could result in Mr.

LEAD: Ralph Waldo Emerson warns us, in his essay ''Self-Reliance,'' not to drag about ''the corpse of memory.'' But Michael Norman drags his memory of childhood loneliness through all the phases of his maturation, calling it the road to self-reliance. Romanticizing is dangerous. All the current psychobabble -being your own person, not needing anyone, doing your own thing - boils down to being lonely.

LEAD: In fulfillment of President Reagan's campaign pledges, the Mine Safety and Health Administration, known to coal men by the awkward acronym ''EM-sha,'' joined many other regulatory agencies in emphasizing cooperation with industry, rather than being its adversary. Republicans and Democrats in Congress, the United Mine Workers union and now a number of the agency's top career safety engineers have accused it of going too far - of calculated laxity in enforcing safety standards in what has long been the most hazardous of all industrial workplaces.

LEAD: AS the 140-point plunge of the Dow Jones industrial average on Friday reminded Republican optimists, it would hardly be prudent to be smug. What with the unknowable courses of things like the stock market, oil prices and the trade and budget deficits, a sour economy could rout the party from the White
LEAD: THE KINGDOM IN THE COUNTRY By James Conaway. 293 pp. Boston: A Richard Todd Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

LEAD: In percent Tax-Exempt Bonds 7.83 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index Money Market Funds 7.03 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield Bank Money Market Accounts 5.82 Bank Rate Monitor Home Mortgage 11.07 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum fixed rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 14.50 Continental Illinois, Chicago 14.00 Bank of America, San Francisco 18.25
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: Last year, Ivan F. Boesky paid a record $100 million civil penalty for insider trading. In March, he will begin serving a three-year prison sentence for conspiracy. Clearly, he needs less office space.

LEAD: New dances by five choreographers with live music and commissioned scores are featured on the programs offered by Moving Sound Concert, Thursday through next Sunday nights at St. Mark's Church (Second Avenue at 10th Street). ''Elliot's Wave,'' choreographed by Michele Elliman to music by Dalton Portella, concerns greed and the stock market.

LEAD: RAMPAL, FLUTE AND BATON Jean-Pierre Rampal, the virtuoso flutist, will perform with, as well as conduct, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra next weekend in Englewood, Red Bank, Trenton and Elizabeth. On the program will be Weber's Overture to Oberon, Mozart's Flute Concerto No. 2 in D, K. 314, and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No.

LEAD: The big weekend snow that covered the Northeast would have caused mighty traffic problems all by itself. But in many residential sections of New York City, it came on top of the thick ice still left from last Sunday night's fall. With cars now swathed in snow and cemented in ice, some streets may not be cleared till the forsythia blossoms.

LEAD: THE protest in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip has forced the issue of Israel and the Palestinians back to the top of the Arab world's agenda. It has done so, however, at a time when the Arabs, increasingly focused on the hazards in the Persian Gulf war and the rivalries among themselves because of it, seem least prepared - or willing - to respond to the unrest.

LEAD: Alex Roberts scored a career-high 33 points and Chuck Veterano had all 6 of his points in the second overtime today as St. Peter's beat Iona, 81-76, in a Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference game.

LEAD: To the Editor: In the article on the hazards of Bermuda's mopeds (Practical Traveler, Nov. 15) no mention was made of the fact that these auxiliary cycles apparently are not required to have rear-view mirrors on their handlebars. Last summer, I was on both Block Island (where all mopeds seem to have such mirrors) and Bermuda (where only scooters seem to have them).

LEAD: MITCH BUONAGURO, the men's varsity basketball coach at Fairfield University, did a double-take when he spotted 6-foot-10-inch Alex Forbes shooting baskets last September at the school's recreational complex during the freshmen orientation weekend.

LEAD: BROWNSTONE FACADE. By Catherine M. Rae. (Joan Kahn/St. Martin's, $13.95.) Catherine M. Rae has concocted a leisurely mystery-romance in her first novel that fairly cries out for a long train ride during which to read it. She presents New York City in the winter of 1920 through a frame of more recent years: In 1981, a middle-aged man comes upon a disturbing memoir purportedly penned by his late aunt two decades before.

LEAD: BY NOW, EVERYONE KNOWS THAT A HEALTHY TAN IS A contradiction in terms. The gap between knowledge and behavior, however, is big enough to hold all the cocoa butter in Florida. People like the all-over toasted look. Accordingly, tanning parlors, born in the early 1970's, now dot street corners across the country, holding out the promise of the impossible: a safe tan.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a front-page article last Sunday about the new immigration law incorrectly described the number of aliens whose applications have been approved for lawful status. About 1.2 million aliens have applied so far, and fewer than a quarter of their applications have been fully reviewed.

Growth Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in percent 4.3 2.5 2.79 Corporate After-Tax Profits III Q'87 II Q'87 Year Ago In billions, annual rate $141.9 $134.5 $130.2

LEAD: Hauling the Nothingness What does a congregation of poets remind you of? This is Lyubomir Nikolov, a Bulgarian writer, describing ''The Poets of Iowa'' in ''The World Comes to Iowa: Iowa International Anthology'' (Iowa State University), edited by Paul Engle, Rowena Torrevillas and Hualing Nieh
LEAD: RECENTLY I read two articles whose juxtaposition had an impact on me. The first was entitled ''Is Fashion Destiny? Ask Cinderella,'' by Janice Gordon [ Opinion Page ] .

LEAD: THE reviewers agree that Tom Wolfe's ''Bonfire of the Vanities'' is the New York City novel -but not much has been said about what kind of New York City Mr. Wolfe offers us. He is generally considered to be a brilliant reporter - yet no one seems to be reading past his headlines, past the scandal.

LEAD: While Boston's City Hall is certainly bigger than a breadbox, many municipal employees say that it is far less watertight and useful. And at least one worker there, David Scondras, a City Council member, would like to see the building sold.
LEAD: Dr. Randolph K. Byers, a Milton, Mass., pediatrician and child neurologist, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday. He was 91 years old.
LEAD: MYSTERIOUSLY, one in every five children was being poisoned by lead in the poorest section of the town of Thompson in northeastern Connecticut.

LEAD: IN what is likely to be the first test of a newly elected Southampton Town Supervisor's campaign pledge to give government back to the people, Mardythe DiPirro said recently she will pursue a six-month moratorium on commercial development in the hamlet of Water Mill.

LEAD: A major study of the monitoring of radiation at nuclear power plants has concluded that better equipment and procedures are needed in the plants and in nearby areas to achieve safe operations and inspire public confidence.

LEAD: AMERICANS ARE cruel to their journalists. They say we would rather take cyanide than confess error. Nonsense. I am no different from the next journalist, and I am always eager to retract and apologize if I make an error.

LEAD: More than one ''knowledgeable'' person has asked me why WGLI-AM agreed to continue to be member station of the Lilco emergency broadcast system [ ''Emergency Broadcast Plan Decided,'' Dec. 13 ] .
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: >The marriage of Arielle Nadine Bienenstock, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harry Bienenstock of Belle Harbor, Queens, to Dr. David Kauver, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham J. Kauver of Denver, took place yesterday at Temple Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbis Jacob Reiner and Bennett Rackman performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Congress has forestalled the State Department budget crisis for at least a year by quietly appropriating additional funding in the final days of its last session.
LEAD: ''Nothing fundamentally has changed, but you don't find as many bears in the woods as you used to.''

LEAD: FOR most of the Reagan years, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration has been a punching bag. It was hammered not only by labor unions and other groups seeking safer workplaces, who accused it of internal disarray and lax enforcement, but also by conservatives demanding that it stop stifling American industry with petty rules.

LEAD: To the Editor: In his piece on the Scots' hogmanay (Travel, Nov. 29), Israel Shenker has resurrected an impressive list of folklore and folk customs about welcoming the New Year in Scotland. Much of that applied, if it ever did, only to previous generations.

LEAD: JACK COHAN, the director of the Jorgensen Auditorium at the University of Connecticut, faces the challenge each season of assembling a schedule that ''contains something for everyone.'' This time, he said, ''I think we've succeeded.''

LEAD: Leaders of the N.A.A.C.P. in New York yesterday criticized the lawyer Alton H. Maddox Jr. and other black lawyers and clergymen for ''whooping and hollering'' rather than working methodically to fight discrimination and violence against blacks.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WHEN I SEE CALORIE counts listed on a menu, I cringe. Although the threat of extra pounds is constant, the idea of being reminded of this when I'm out to enjoy myself is no fun at all. Paying dearly for diet food is only further insult.
LEAD: KICKED A MACHINE lately? Among music lovers, you're not alone.
LEAD: One of New York State's rare moose has died, the victim of either a gunshot wound or a collision with a car, according to state wildlife experts.
LEAD: A review of ''Mexican Churches'' Dec. 20 inadvertently omitted the name of the translator. The review, by Octavio Paz, was translated by Robert Pegada.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 7 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts creates nightmares in a Maine village. 2 2 12 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel.

LEAD: THE Thai restaurant wave that seems to be flowing throughout the United States is rippling into Fairfield County. First there was Bangkok in Danbury. Now we have a new entry, Siam-o-cha, in Westport. Tucked away in the largely unchanged upstairs premises formerly occupied by Chez Bach, Siam-o-cha (whose name means delicious Siam), is a happy addition to Westport's expanding ethnic dining scene.

LEAD: Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the United States Supreme Court barred the State Department yesterday from returning a 9-year-old Zimbawean boy to his country until the court reviews the Government's arguments against legal attempts to block the boy's return.
LEAD: AS the elected directors of a co-op corporation, board members have long had the right to make management decisions without disclosing their reasons to the shareholders.

LEAD: BUILDING A BALLET COMPANY demands more than the training of dancers. It also requires assembling a repertory. But that is no easy task. Repertory-building is a challenge shared by the artistic directors of ballet companies everywhere.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Scalera of Beaver, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Marie Scalera, to Donald Cameron Findlay 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Findlay Jr. of Elkhart, Ind. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: Within months of his acquittal on Federal charges of conspiring to organize a prisoner escape and rob armored cars, Roger Wareham, one of a group of black revolutionaries known as the New York Eight, landed a job at the Center for Law and Social Justice, where he helped establish a 24-hour hot line to monitor reports of police brutality.
LEAD: THE SILVER DESOTO By Patty Lou Floyd. 257 pp. Austin: Council Oak Books/ Texas Monthly Press. $14.95.

LEAD: Martin Brech wrote in the Dec. 13 Westchester letters section that wolves and coyotes might be a solution to the deer problem in Westchester. This is ridiculous. Whereas I have never heard of a wolf attack on human, the coyotes have been noted in California for taking a small child in a suburban neighborhood encroaching in the Sierras.

LEAD: The engagement of Juliet Jean Pennington to James Jude Matte, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Matte of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Gloria Pennington of Hastings-on-Hudson and Bruce Pennington of New York. Miss Pennington, a reporter for The Sun Chronicle in Attleboro, Mass., and her fiance, a copy editor at The Boston Herald, plan to marry in May.
LEAD: The prospects for peace in Central America appear bleak as the region's leaders prepare to meet next week to judge the results of the peace plan they signed five months ago.

LEAD: Girl Scouts Gorge In Mechanicsburg IT'S time to sell Girl Scout cookies and so, to honor the tradition and work up some enthusiasm, the scouts of Mechanicsburg, Pa., held a cookie eating contest.

LEAD: DESIGNATING religious properties as landmarks is a sensitive subject. Churches have opposed such designation, fearing a loss of not only religious freedom but the flexibility to deal with property that often is difficult to maintain.

LEAD: IT is not easy being a Realist these days. Something - the massive art-education program of the last 30 years, the long shadow that Abstract Expressionism still casts, end-of-the-century blues - has made it very difficult for artists to tackle observable reality without a game plan or without seeming to put their efforts in quotes.
LEAD: ALMOST HUMAN A Journey into the World of Baboons. By Shirley C. Strum. Drawings by Deborah Ross. Photographs. 294 pp. New York: Random House. $22.50.

LEAD: United Press International is planning to reduce its coverage of local news and instead concentrate on major news events in an effort to put the company back on a solid financial footing, a U.P.I. spokesman said today.

LEAD: The engagement of Victoria Stillman Rockefeller to Peter Sandys Philip has been announced by Mrs. John Philip Fisher of Toronto and Andrew Carnegie Rockefeller of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Van Ness Philip of Bedford, N.Y. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: The Earl of St. Andrews married a Canadian scholar, Sylvana Tomaselli, today and became the first member of the royal family to wed in a civil ceremony in Britain. Lord St. Andrews, 25 years old, is the son of the Duke of Kent, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II. The bride, 30, a Roman Catholic and divorced, is a history research fellow at Cambridge University, where she met the Earl.
LEAD: The Clinton community board has unanimously approved a zoning change to end a ban on redevelopment of local apartment buildings in which tenants have been harassed by landlords.

LEAD: To the Editor: Not to diminish Lesley Hazelton's fine endorsement of mountain ascents, ''Because It's There'' (Travel, Nov. 29), a slight correction is in order. Mount Monadnock is such an approachable and adoptable peak precisely because it is not above the tree line. Its summit is artificially bare, devastated by fire.

LEAD: QUIETLY, WITHOUT FAN-fare, there has been a resurgence of Off Broadway, with plays as well as musicals developing into long-run successes. This theatrical arena has once again become a healthy commercial territory at the same time that it is providing the theater with new and rewarding work. The plays include Alfred Uhry's ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' Terrence McNally's ''Frankie and Johnny in the Claire de Lune,'' Robert Harling's ''Steel Magnolias,'' Barbara Lebow's ''Shayna Maidel'' and Tom Griffin's ''Boys Next Door.

LEAD: The Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Sarah Elizabeth Thornton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Thornton of Bronxville, N.Y., to Joseph Dominic John Downing, a son of Gertrude Martin Downing of Pittsfield, Mass., and the late John F.

LEAD: Michael Norman makes some interesting observations in his article ''The Road to Self-Reliance'' (About Men, Dec. 13). It's true that ''society forces [ isolation ] on men.'' But it strikes me as misguided to put aside or deny the anger and pain this causes and to speak of how ''the loneliness . . .
LEAD: THE BINGHAMS OF LOUISVILLE The Dark History Behind One of America's Great Fortunes. By David Leon Chandler with Mary Voelz Chandler. Illustrated. 292 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $17.95.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Jacoby of Bronxville, N.Y., of the engagement of Mr. Jacoby's daughter, Tracy Lynne Jacoby, to John Wells Stevens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Stevens of New Canaan, Conn., and South Londonderry, Vt.
LEAD: NOW, the 64,000-shekel question: What is the impact on Israeli party politics of the recent Palestinian protests in the occupied territories? Answer: Virtually none - so far.

LEAD: Preservation Concert Jan. 10 - Pete Seeger will be the lead performer at a 4 P.M. benefit concert for Save the Village, a preservation group that is seeking to establish a historic waterfront district adjacent to Greenwich Village. The concert, with refreshments at intermission, will be held at the chapel of St.
LEAD: Chris Mullin may not be the missing link to make the Knicks a contender, but his unselfish style and excellent passing and shooting will contribute greatly. ROGER L. GILDE New York
LEAD: MENTION THE NAME Moira Shearer and movie buffs will instantly smile and say:

LEAD: A COMPUTER chip factory appears to be the epitome of cleanliness and safety. Workers don white ''bunny'' suits, gloves and goggles and pass through an air shower before entering the production area, known as a ''clean room.''
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: FORBIDDEN JOURNEY The Life of Alexandra David-Neel. By Barbara M. Foster and Michael Foster. Illustrated. 363 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $21.95.

LEAD: ANIMATION IN NORWALK Eighteen prize-winning animated films are featured in the 20th Tourney of Animation to be shown at 7:30 P.M. Friday through Jan. 18 at the SoNo Cinema, 15 Washington Street, South Norwalk. A 5 P.M. matinee is scheduled on Saturday.
LEAD: Street Smart Starring Christopher Reeve, Morgan Freeman. Directed by Jerry Schatzberg. 1987. Media Home Entertainment. 97 minutes. $79.95.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Wick of Watertown, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Lee Wick, to Robert Michael McLean, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin B. McLean of Potomac, Md., and Rehoboth Beach, Del. The couple plan to marry in June.
LEAD: WHEN Larry Puckridge began driving a rig in 1973, ''dirty old truck stops that sold greasy food and fuel'' gave him little incentive to stop while he crisscrossed the country, he said.

LEAD: DETERMINING the difference between a children's book and a book for adults is often tricky business. After all, many people once considered ''Huckleberry Finn'' - that bible of individualism, perhaps the most delightfully subversive, antiauthoritarian work in American literature - to be a charming children's story.

LEAD: In a fresh move to guard the increasingly shopworn secrets of its intelligence services, the British Government is trying to suppress yet another book describing the services as riddled with would-be traitors and homosexuals.

LEAD: OVERTIME: A Twentieth Century Sports Odyssey. By Peter Schwed. (Beaufort, $15.95.) Many young sports fans know the joy of settling onto a grandfatherly lap and listening to colorful tales from someone who professes to have seen Babe Ruth swing a bat or experienced the patriotic euphoria created by Jesse Owens in 1936.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Roberts of Old Bethpage, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Patricia Lynne Roberts, to Dr. Michael Stuart Rosenblatt, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Rosenblatt of Margate, N.J. A summer wedding is planned.

LEAD: PERU, by Gordon Lish. (Scribners, $8.95.) A violent television newscast from Peru and a bump on the head jar a 50-year-old man into a remorseless recollection of a murder he committed as a child. Told in an obsessively circular manner, the novel ''increases speed to a kind of frenzy,'' Stephen Dobyns said in The Book Review in 1986.

LEAD: Howard Goldberg remembers the first tour he led of Roosevelt Island in 1963. Student firemen leaped from buildings set ablaze as part of their graduation ceremony. The training center is no longer on the East River island; neither are the almshouse, the prison and the New York City Lunatic Asylum.

LEAD: James V. Siena, a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense and an executive at the American Institute of Architects, died of cancer last Sunday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 55 years old and lived in Washington.

LEAD: To the Editor: How disappointing that ''Venezuela's Island in the Caribbean'' (Travel, Nov. 15) focused on overpriced, overcrowded Margarita Island when Puerto La Cruz lies only 40 minutes from Caracas. Five minutes after we arrived the Doral Beach Hotel staff had us happily in our rooms. We were surrounded by tennis, volleyball and basketball courts, a long private beach and free shuttles to the shops and sights of Puerto La Cruz.

LEAD: A plan to use a decommissioned British troop barge to house 700 New York State prison inmates, announced with fanfare by the Cuomo administration last June, has run into trouble and now appears unlikely to be carried out.

LEAD: LAST FALL, JORGE BOLET PLAYED A lovely run of performances of the Grieg Piano Concerto with the New York Philharmonic. But what made them lovely was not just the pianist's own brand of commanding, diffident elegance. It was also the orchestral accompaniment - forthright on its own; properly subservient yet never self-effacing in partnership with the pianist.

LEAD: AFTER 16 years, I am at last a stay-home mother. The only thing is, the children are no longer there. I timed my transition from corporate executive to budding author to coincide (was it coincidental?) with the high school graduation and departure for college of my younger daughter, Sarah.

LEAD: The engagement of Heidi-Rachel Webb to Dr. Andrew Millard Singer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Singer of Stamford, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. Gertrude Mikels Webb and J. Chester Webb of Waltham, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: Zaire's Permanent Mission to the United Nations owes landlords and companies in the New York region more than $150,000 in rent and other bills, with many of those debts outstanding for more than half a year, according to complaints filed with various official United States bodies by Zaire's creditors.

LEAD: The Houston Astros' pitching staff is intact, Charlie Leibrandt has completed Kansas City's starting rotation, Detroit has Jack Morris and Frank Tanana back and California held onto Mike Witt. Then there are the Yankees.
LEAD: CVJ Nicknames of Maitre D's & Other Excerpts From Life. By Julian Schnabel. Illustrated. 222 pp. New York: Random House. $75.

LEAD: In a move that was could bring new violence in Haiti, the electoral council appointed by the military-led Government announced tonight that it had rejected 10 of 11 former associates of the deposed Duvalier dicatorship as candidates for president in an election Jan. 17.

LEAD: AS Dr. Tomas Koppany and his wife, Kornelia Nagy, tell it, they gave up prosperous jobs as lawyers in Hungary, a desirable apartment in Budapest, a summer cottage in a lake resort and a sizable bank account -not because they prefer poverty.
LEAD: THROUGHOUT MEXICO, across much of the rest of Latin America and among more than 12 million Mexican-Americans in the United States, she is known simply as La Reina - The Queen.
LEAD: LOVING ROGER By Tim Parks. 151 pp. New York: Grove Press. $15.95.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: In reading Gwen Davis's article ''The Private Pain of Infertility'' (Dec. 6), I was struck by the many similarities to my own situation, and a few major differences.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A NEW Yonkers government began work on an uncertain note last week, appointing an interim city manager while beginning the search for a full-time administrator and seeking a unified stand on the divisive housing desegregation issue.

LEAD: AFTER Robert F. Wagner Jr. disclosed last week that he had threatened to resign as president of New York City's Board of Education unless Sandra Feldman relaxed her grip on the process of selecting the next schools chancellor, she said, ''It was my pleasure to be able to save Bobby Wagner's job and get an excellent chancellor in the process.

LEAD: IF there's anything boat owners love more than their boats, it's the gear and the accessories that they bring aboard. Sailors, fishermen and powerboat operators are all inveterate tinkerers and gadgeteers. The more space, time and energy that an instrument saves, the likelier that it will find a home aboard a well-found vessel.
LEAD: A. M. Rosenthal, a columnist and former executive editor of The New York Times, has been named editor at large at G. P. Putnam, the publishing house announced yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Starr of Old Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Robin Starr to Neal Jason Berman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Berman of Needham, Mass.

LEAD: THE MEN WHO LIVE ON MY ONE-BLOCK street are a banker, a lawyer, a television ad writer, an obstetrician, a librarian, a retired ophthalmologist and another college prof like me. On mornings after a big snow, three or four of us will be out there at more or less the same time, shoveling the stuff out of our driveways and off our walks.
LEAD: A FORKED pier on the edge of downtown Boston will soon be the site of a condominium complex to be known as Burroughs Wharf.
LEAD: Helen L. Buttenwieser, a legendary figure in New York legal circles, felt a bit of trepidation about what lay ahead Friday night.
LEAD: FOR Floyd Vivino, laughter makes the world go round, and although he has not taken the career leaps that other New Jersey comedians have, his followers have kept his zany humor alive.

LEAD: The marriage of Jill Elizabeth Buzzi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Buzzi of Colonia, N.J., to Michael Alan Tanenbaum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Tanenbaum of Short Hills, N.J., took place last evening at the Essex County Country Club in West Orange, N.J. Judge John E. Keefe, presiding judge in the chancery division of the Superior Court of New Jersey, Middlesex

LEAD: Most builders in New York City's northern suburbs are making two mistakes, according to Anthony J. Amicucci. Either they overestimate how many people can afford high-priced, Westchester County houses, or they underestimate what customers will pay for homes farther north.

LEAD: STOCK options took a bath in the October stock plunge, forcing corporate boards to wrestle with two problems: First, should they make up the losses for executives whose profits from options were wiped out by the collapse? Second, given the market's volatility, how could options be tailored to provide a buffer against a repeat performance?

LEAD: IT is no secret that forecasts of the economy are fallible. As a nonexperimental social science, economics cannot achieve the degree of precision that physicists attain in measuring the speed of light or even the lower degree achieved by meteorologists in predicting tomorrow's precipitation. It is less widely understood that, despite several notable mistakes, economic forecasters have been able to predict some, though not all, important economic variables better than simple rules of thumb and that their accuracy seems to have increased over time.
LEAD: Mark Jackson, the Knicks' rookie playmaker, has had so many outstanding games, it is difficult to pinpoint his best one.

LEAD: To the Editor: In his interesting article about Austin, Tex. (Travel, Nov. 8), Peter H. Lewis says that often in the morning the Hill Country is covered with a purple haze. Those two words, like magic, immediately called to mind pleasant but hitherto long-dormant memories from my teen-age years when I first read one of the many exciting Western novels by Zane Grey, namely, ''Riders of the Purple Sage,'' with the cowboy mystery man, Lassiter, dressed in black.

LEAD: The history of the world is littered with the debris of collisions between art and politics. And so, to Philadelphians who like to call their city the birthplace of both American art and American politics, a current uproar over art exhibits in City Hall comes as no surprise.

LEAD: A day after Vice President Bush challenged Senator Bob Dole to make his tax returns public, the Bush campaign began sending reporters copies of an article in a small Kansas newspaper that raised questions about a real estate transaction by a blind trust belonging to the Senator's wife, Elizabeth Hanford
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Mark L. Chapman of Norwood, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Stacey Ann Chapman to Adam Saravay, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Saravay of Roslyn Heights, L.I.

LEAD: A year after Congress toughened a 1980 law for cleaning up toxic waste sites, the Environmental Protection Agency is struggling to do the job Congress intended, caught between critics who say its efforts are not adequate and those who question whether the cleanup is the best use of the agency's resources.
LEAD: ALL IN A LIFETIME An Autobiography. By Ruth K. Westheimer with Ben Yagoda. Illustrated. 225 pp. New York: Warner Books. $17.95.

LEAD: UNDERHILL, Belknap, Stillwell and Elliott are all names of Yonkers streets today, but 100 years ago they belonged to a far-sighted group of Yonkers families who organized the Yonkers Building and Loan Association, the first savings and loan association in the county.

LEAD: If you remember high school - or even if you have forgotten high school - you should enjoy ''Oil City Symphony'' (at Circle-in-the-Square Downtown, 159 Bleecker Street), a grand spoof of old times, good times and those who compulsively return for reunions. Four musically inclined graduates of Oil City High come together in concert to honor a former teacher, toasting her with a garland of nostalgic and amusing tunes.

LEAD: At the Duke University Chapel in Durham, N.C., Dr. Pamela Preston Reynolds, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Reynolds of Akron, Ohio, was married yesterday to Dr. John Robert Ball, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Ball Jr. of Auburn, Ala. The Rev. Noel Calhoun, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: FOR AVID skiers, downhill or cross-country, there is no such thing as a bad snowstorm. Oblivious to wind and cold, they pursue their ideal: fresh powder.

LEAD: AS sharp and as cold as a knife blade that had been left overnight on the ice along the Lake Erie shore, the wind sliced through the 78,586 customers pounding their mittens together on the slopes of Cleveland Stadium's tundra. This was pro football the way it always is here during the Super Bowl playoffs.

LEAD: JOHN H. GUTFREUND, the chief executive of Salomon, Inc., took a $2 million voluntary pay cut in 1987. Merrill Lynch & Company is cutting brokers' compensation by 6 percent, and analysts say other brokerages mayfollow that lead.
LEAD: Contrary to some speculation, Gary Hart's latest caper may turn out to be a valuable gift to the Democratic Party. He may turn out to be his party's deliverer in the coming electoral season.
LEAD: Several life-size statues, thought to have been smashed nearly 2,000 years ago to eradicate traces of the Roman Emperor Caligula's family, have been restored and put on display.

LEAD: THE New York National Boat Show, coming at the onset of a new year, is viewed by the marine industry as the bellwether for its coming season. In 1988, eyes are peeled for a glitch in the boating market that might be traced to the stock market's Black Monday in October. But few really expect such a ripple.

LEAD: Egypt said today that it had arrested an Iranian agent who was setting up a sabotage group and attempting to recruit adherents from among Moslem fundamentalists. The announcement came a few days after Bahrain reported the arrests of members of what it called a terrorist network directed by Iran.

LEAD: A Sunday television highlight listing and a front-page picture caption today in The Guide, section 2A, misstate Mike Nichols's connection with the ABC comedy series ''The Thorns.'' He is the executive producer.

LEAD: I would like to urge every car owner who qualifies to seek redress under the New York State Lemon Law and not through Autocap or the Better Business Bureau [ ''Car Buyers Get a Referee in Disputes With Dealers,'' Dec. 13 ] .

LEAD: Frank Pace Jr., a former Secretary of the Army and the first chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, died of a heart attack Friday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Greenwich.
LEAD: John Hill, executive chef at the White House, resigned Friday, just four months after taking the job.

LEAD: A 17-year-old, described by the police as a crack addict, was charged yesterday with killing five people and wounding six others in a series of robberies in East Harlem that began on New Year's Day.
LEAD: The Minnesota Vikings had the poorest record (8-7) of the 10 teams that started the National Football League playoffs last Sunday. Now they are one game away from reaching the Super Bowl.

LEAD: THERE is a barn behind my great-grandfather's house in Stony Brook. I suppose now I should say my grandfather's, for it is he who inherited the house and lives there now, but to me it will always be Poppy's house. Even after all the new paint, soft carpets and beautiful unfamiliar furniture, I still like it better the old way, the way it used to be.

LEAD: TRAIN passengers to Wilmington used to arrive at a rundown railroad station in an equally shabby neighborhood. Now the station has changed and so has the neighborhood.

LEAD: YING RUOCHENG IS FAMILIAR to American audiences as the prison warden in Bernardo Bertolucci's new film ''The Last Emperor.'' However, in China, he is now primarily known not for his acting ability, but as the nation's Vice Minister of Culture. In this powerful post he is presently at work on a broad reform of the performing arts.

LEAD: BLOWGUNS, FEATHER ORNAMENTS, shrunken heads: artifacts from past and present cultures of Amazonia, the tropical rain forest area of northern South America, are being assembled in the Hall of South American Peoples, which New York's Museum of Natural History is to open in October. Complementing an exhibit of Andean archeology, the hall's ethnographic display includes 1,000 Amazonian artifacts that were selected, over two years, from more than 15,000 in the museum's collection by Robert L.
LEAD: The Knicks don't need a slow, and possibly chemically dependent shooting guard. The Knicks should continue to build through the draft. BRITT BURR New York

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Julian M. Kien of Manhattan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauri Allison Kien, to Eric Kotcher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Kotcher of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: DESPITE opposition in some communities, Connecticut is pushing ahead with a record $300 million construction program to add 3,000 new prison beds in the next five years to keep pace with a steadily rising inmate population.

LEAD: FIVE special prosecuting units for drug cases are being created in Connecticut this month, working with local police departments to insure that investigations withstand court tests and to target cases for speedy prosecution. The units will be part of what state officials call Connecticut's most ambitious effort to step up drug enforcement.

LEAD: THAI HORSE. By William Diehl. (Villard, $18.95.) Christian Hatcher is the kind of guy you wouldn't mind having at your side when trouble lurks around the corner. This ex-naval officer, amateur boxer, cat burglar, linguist, expert lover and former operative for some shadowy government agency is your perfect adventure hero.

LEAD: MY FATHER, A soft-spoken, hard-working, heavy-smoking, meat-and-potatoes alcoholic, died the classic death of the mid-1950's. Shortly after his 48th birthday, complaining of pain in his stomach, he spent a day in bed. By afternoon, his heart, not his stomach, had stopped working. The doctor explained that his coronary arteries had become ''filled with crud'' and so he had a fatal heart attack.

LEAD: In an experiment intended to cut through red tape and create a new management model for large urban school districts, the Dade County Public Schools have turned the running of 32 schools over to teams that include teachers and parents.

LEAD: HE was edged out for the Heisman Trophy, but Don McPherson has been doing just fine in the awards department since then. LEAD: YOU may well ask - her family certainly did - what Joan Hamburg was doing in her kitchen last week, in the middle of the night, cooking and baking. Particularly as this occurred after the holidays, when she was not expecting company and there was absolutely no need for all that chopping and stirring.

LEAD: For all that Americans have learned about South Africa in recent years, we remain largely unfamiliar with the mechanisms of white control. How does a government representing a small minority of the population actually exercise totalitarian dominion over the vast majority?

LEAD: BILL McCARTNEY, the head football coach at Colorado, changed his mind at the last minute last night about taking the Southern Methodist coaching job after consulting with his family, Colorado's athletic director, Bill Marolt, and the Colorado president, Gordon Gee, according to Doug Single, the S.M.U.

LEAD: The Education Department said Thursday that John L. Sam had been named director of its $66 million Indian education programs. Mr. Sam, a 43-year-old member of the Cherokee Tribe, has been a Federal education official for the past decade and formerly taught in the Sand Springs, Okla., public schools.

LEAD: The key recommendations for reordering the regulation of the nation's financial markets included in the report of a Presidential commission are likely to be tied up in Congressional debate and may never be acted on, lawmakers and regulatory experts said today.

LEAD: JOHN PORTMAN is perhaps the best-known hotel architect in the world. His Hyatt Regency in Atlanta, completed in 1967, was the first postwar hotel with a central atrium, and it changed the nature of hotels everywhere, replacing the banal boxes of the Hiltons and Sheratons with the Portman trademarks of vast atrium spaces, fountains and glass-enclosed elevators.

LEAD: SHELDON R. GAWISER, 38 years old, owns a consulting concern in Westport that specializes in helping businesses collect and manage information. He is also a recognized expert on polls, which the public will be seeing a lot of in the coming months of the Presidential campaign.

LEAD: JUST about the minute Bob Horton arrived in town two years ago as the new chairman of the Standard Oil Company, he slashed the budget for the big bash the company was planning to celebrate the opening of its new headquarters on Public Square here. They still had the party, but it was not nearly as much fun.

LEAD: In the first session of the 100th Congress, most members took part in an overwhelming percentage of House and Senate votes. Some who were running for President, however, participated in fewer than half the votes. Here are the 5 northeastern senators and 10 northeastern representatives who had that best voting attendance records in 1987.

LEAD: Marion B. Reith, who founded the English in Action program, died of pneumonia Dec. 21 at Pomona (Calif.) Valley Community Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived in Claremont, Calif.

LEAD: The dollar got strong support from central bankers in both words and deeds. When the week's trading began in Tokyo the dollar resumed its slide to record lows, but central banks of several countries, including the United States, moved vigorously to prop it up, buying billions of dollars in the currency markets.

LEAD: THE recent upheaval in the stock market proves once again how unpredictable the world is. Few forecasters had spotted the timing and extent of the fall; fewer still had foreseen the prolonged rise.

LEAD: AT the rate the length of player contracts is shrinking, the players and the owners will soon be back to the days before free agents - the time of the one-year contract - or they will be immersed in a labor dispute that could severely intrude on the 1990 season.

LEAD: IN my life, the two points between which I must routinely travel are Union Station in Washington, D.C., and Penn Station in Manhattan. If I am feeling rushed, I pay a bit more for the Metroliner, which gets me back and forth a little faster. Otherwise I take the regular train that stops for more pilgrims in its progress along the way.

LEAD: SINCE at least the 14th century, when English common law called it ''malice a prepense,'' judges and juries have struggled with the concept and the consequences of trying to gauge a killer's state of mind at the moment of killing.

LEAD: WHAT everyone in business needs is a good crystal ball. But to be of value, forecasts must be accurate, and a Chappaqua consulting group, Levy Economic Forecasts, has compiled one of the best records in the country for predicting turning points of the business cycle in the United States for the last 40 years.

LEAD: Most days of this sharp, cool winter - as in previous winters - a thick, dirty blue haze settles across much of the Indian capital, causing an increase in sore throats, colds and other respiratory ailments.

LEAD: TEN years ago Shatin was a quiet patch of farmland in Hong Kong's New Territories, with water buffalo pulling plows through geometric acres of rice paddies and fishermen's cottages along the Shing Mun River. It was an evocation of rural China, even though it was only 10 miles north of the teeming city of Kowloon, separated from Hong Kong's busiest district by the steep Lion Rock

LEAD: WHEN parents of a disabled child draw up an estate plan, they face a concern that other parents do not. While other adult children may be fully independent and in no need of a legacy, a disabled child may be left more vulnerable than ever by a parent's death.

LEAD: THE term ''lockset'' is used to describe collectively all door hardware (except hinges) that permit the door to be opened, closed and locked. Usually a lockset consists of a lock with keys, a latch bolt, doorknobs and a strike plate, which is installed in the door jamb to receive the end of the latch bolt and hold the door shut.
LEAD: The recently released Fairfield 2000 Report now takes its place alongside Westchester 2000. With it comes the recognition of just how many problems in the two counties are intertwined.

LEAD: Announcement of the engagement of Claudia Rose Thompson to William Jay Iselin has been made by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. John B. Thompson of Winchester, Hampshire, England. Mr. Iselin is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Jay Iselin of New York, and Vinalhaven, Me. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: The front-runners for the Republican Presidential nomination, Vice President Bush and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, attacked each other sharply today, each accusing the other of having something to hide.

LEAD: SEARCH FOR A SUPERTHEORY: From Atoms to Superstrings. By Barry Parker. (Plenum Press, $21.95.) On the way to the Grand Unified Theory (GUT) charted in this book, we confront hoards of electrons, protons, neutrons, mesons and their discoverers, rushing by like billiard players burdened with eight-balls, positively and negatively charged.

LEAD: SKIRT lengths may be all over the lot these days, but coat lengths - especially fur-coat lengths - remain decidedly long. And who can argue the logic? Furs are supposed to keep one warm (in much of the nation recently one has needed all the warmth one can get), and fur coats can't serve that function adequately if they're cut off at the knees.
LEAD: The Vermont Supreme Court has rejected a request by lawyers for John A. Zaccaro Jr. to dismiss cocaine charges against him.

LEAD: THE Compaq Deskpro 386-20 personal computer is the most powerful PC an executive can buy. It is certainly the fastest one I've ever used - and the most expensive, too. Both its speed and price are likely to take your breath away.

LEAD: The Soviet economy stagnates and it's clear that Mikhail Gorbachev is willing to undo a half-century of Stalinist central planning to get it moving again. What's not clear is whether a successful fix would serve American interests.
LEAD: ONE OF the state's most varied and valuable horse-carriage collections is about to be broken up.

LEAD: IN THE FIRST PART OF STEVEN Spielberg's sprawling new epic, ''Empire of the Sun,'' a boy dressed in a party costume discovers a derelict fighter plane in a field near Shanghai. The adventurer, resembling Aladdin, instantly climbs into the rusted cockpit and gleefully imagines he is stalking enemy aircraft.

LEAD: East Berlin Question: To make the most of a day visiting East Berlin, do you recommend a guided tour or going on my own? What costs are involved? -B. B. R., Cleveland Heights, Ohio Answer: Travelers who feel they will be satisfied by a four-hour excursion to East Berlin should consider taking a bus tour arranged by a West Berlin travel agency.

LEAD: PRINCETON UNIVERSITY has revised its plans for a Center for Jewish Life, which were put on hold at the end of 1986 because the major contributor, Ivan Boesky, had run into trouble with the Securities and Exchange Commission and withdrawn his $750,000 pledge.

LEAD: IN two fashion collections presented last week, models wore their hair pulled back severely from the face, the better to show off earrings and sunglassses. ''The clothes are frilly and feminine, the earrings are elaborate, so the hair must be smooth,'' said Charles Nicholas, who was responsible for the coiffures at the Adolfo spring and summer show.

LEAD: YOUR PLACE . . . OR MINE, in Williston Park, is not a yuppie watering hole where the gang can go for buffalo wings. Nor is it a dark roadhouse rendezvous with dewy-eyed couples holding hands in the corners. It's a startlingly attractive restaurant serving well-prepared, eclectic food.
LEAD: Iran resumed artillery attacks on Iraq's second-largest city and the two sides fought a naval battle in the northern Persian Gulf, reports from Baghdad and Teheran said today.

LEAD: There is no one in the N.B.A. that can make more of an impact for the Knicks than Chris Mullin. He has the intellect that can help solidify the defense and a jump shot that would rock the Garden. BOB LEE Roslyn Heights, L.I.

LEAD: IN sentencing Cheryl Pierson to six months in jail, the judge at her manslaughter hearing said that the 18-year-old Selden girl had had alternatives short of arranging her father's killing. But many professionals who deal with such incest cases warn that had the teen-age victim turned to Suffolk County for help, she might have been frustrated and might even have ended up dead herself.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Nov. 29 article from Concord, Mass., about efforts to ban swimming in Walden Pond in Concord, Mass., misstated the status of a concrete pier. The pier was removed in 1983.

LEAD: WHEN GENERAL Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev brushed off charges of human-rights violations in the Soviet Union with the question, ''What about the wetbacks?'', Americans cringed - not at the crude attempt of moral equivalency, but at the use of a term now regarded as a slur. A wetback - from the condition of a Mexican swimming across the Rio Grande to enter the United States - later become known as an illegal alien, and when that became onerous, the name was changed to undocumented person, now applied to persons of any nationality who enter the country without a visa.

LEAD: The figure-skating team that will represent the United States next month in the Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta, emerged today, after a hectic 24-hour period in which 12 of the 16 team members were determined and several judging decisions were questioned.

LEAD: Russell O. Blosser, senior vice president of the National Council of the Paper Industry for Air and Stream Improvement, died of a heart attack Dec. 29 in Denver. He was 63 years old and lived in Norwalk, Conn.

LEAD: LOUIS CRECHETTI is not your average pig farmer. He spends his day teaching engineering at the University of Hartford. But, come dusk, you'll find him in his Granby barn, tending his pigs and sheep.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 21 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: REAL ESTATE brokers are warning that this city, the financial center of the Pacific Northwest, is about to experience a jump in office vacancy rates because the pace of downtown construction shows no signs of slowing.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH the American Nobel Committee has no official connection with the Nobel Institutes in Norway and Sweden, we reflect the interests of some 100 American Nobel Laureates. There are more Nobelists in the United States than the rest of the world combined.

LEAD: When New York was selected last month as one of eight finalists in the national competition to become home state for the superconducting supercollider - the biggest and costliest tool for science research ever built - state officials expressed satisfaction.

LEAD: 'They used, when I first came in, to talk about us in terms of the British disease. Now they talk about us and say, ''Look, Britain has got the cure. Come to Britain to see how Britain has done it.'' That is an enormous turn-round. And it has brought hope to others as well.' Margaret Thatcher in an interview last week on the occasion of her becoming Britain's longest-serving Prime Minister of the 20th century.

LEAD: FOR youthful travelers, vacation can mean a welcome hiatus from classrooms, books and study; for another, often older group it means the opposite, an opportunity to spend two or three weeks rediscovering the pleasures of learning, in many cases through seminars, lectures or research projects. A wide array of programs sponsored by academic institutions, museums and nonprofit organizations offers the opportunity to combine travel and education.

LEAD: I WAS standing at the head of the players' ramp just before game time, having small talk with Dennis D'Agostino, one of the Knicks' publicists. The tipoff against the Phoenix Suns last Tuesday night was just a few minutes away and the Garden was about two-thirds full. D'Agostino suddenly looked at his watch and then peered up at the game clock, which had counted down to zero.
LEAD: It is a tricky business figuring just what message the Houston Oilers' coach, Jerry Glanville, is sending to the Rocky Mountains.

LEAD: THE public safety authorities in Pennsylvania are investigating why a storage tank failed last weekend, contaminating water supplies with enough oil to heat almost 1,000 single-family houses for a year. If the accident prompts officials elsewhere to check the soundness of tanks in their jurisdictions, however, they are likely to find that knocking on the cold steel shell produces an unexpected sound - a hollow ring.
LEAD: DIZZY AND McKEE
LEAD: Two men were shot by the police in Brooklyn and the South Bronx - 20 minutes apart - early yesterday, and one of them remained in critical condition last night, the police reported.

LEAD: THUMBS UP: The Life and Courageous Comeback of White House Press Secretary Jim Brady. By Mollie Dickenson. (Morrow, $19.95.) Most of us are familiar with the tragic and heroic story of Jim Brady, the White House press secretary; now, Mollie Dickenson, a journalist, has given us a more complete portrait of the man.

LEAD: Lieut. Col. Beverly Ann Belew of the Army Nurse Corps and Col. Michael Richard Antopol, commander of the Brooke Army Medical Center at Fort Sam Houston in Texas, plan to be married Feb. 14, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Jerry B. Belew of Andrews, Tex., have announced.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Julius B. Schack of Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Gail Schack to Alan Michael Forrest, a son of Joyce Forrest of New York and the late Milton Forrest. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: An article on page 9 of the Travel section today about the Portman hotel in San Francisco identifies the hotel management incorrectly. The property is managed by the Portman Hotel Company of Atlanta, which has affiliated with the Peninsula Group of Hong Kong for marketing purposes only.

LEAD: In explaining why he chooses not to hunt, gentle Hervie Haufler [ ''Three-Generation Perspective of Hunting and Killing,'' Opinion page, Dec. 13 ] shows he has bought two of the most powerful myths, both promoted by game agencies, that perpetuate the notions that hunting is necessary to reduce deer overpopulation and that the legendary conservationist John James Audubon is the prototype for combining kindness and killing No data support the overpopulation contention.
LEAD: When asked today on a campaign stop here whether he had ever used drugs, Gary Hart told reporters, ''None of your business.''

LEAD: To the Editor: I was interested in the feature on Austin, Tex., and the lack of any mention of the Austin Symphony Orchestra under the ''Music'' heading. Mr. Lewis should be aware of the symphony. Symphony Square, which is owned by the symphony, is a fascinating center for music activities, concerts and galas and has a fine restaurant.

LEAD: MY DAUGHTER, aside from being a connoisseur of feminine attire, also knows a great deal about submarine sandwiches. You have to admit that this is an unusual duo of interests.

LEAD: A wide range of social services will soon be available in 29 New Jersey school districts in what state officials say is the first program in the country intended to deal comprehensively with crippling problems faced by teen-agers.

LEAD: Gwen Davis's article brought back all of the grievous memories of my five years of infertility treatments. Her depiction of an in vitro fertilization cycle - in which couples gamble $5,000 and all of their hopes on a 10 percent long shot - is accurate.

LEAD: ''I'M a fellow in English here at Cambridge,'' the young man presiding over our class told us, ''and I shall be the literature half of your course on Tudor kingship. My history colleague will handle the historical material and we hope our different approaches, intellectual prejudices and convictions will crossfertilize the subject and give you the chance to explore it in considerable depth.

LEAD: THE cacti, dwarf trees and small farm plots that dot the vast plateau of the Mexican state of Oaxaca create subtle harmonies of green and ocher right up to the jagged gray profile of the Sierra Madre. As the Pan American Highway traces an unswerving black line across this alto plano, or high plane, a blue signpost overhead indicates, by a pattern of white lines symbolizing interwoven threads, the turnoff for Teotitlan del Valle.

LEAD: President Hosni Mubarak, left, of Egypt with King Fahd in Riyadh, Saudi Araabia. It was the first visit by an Egyptian head of state to Saudi Arabia since Egypt's 1979 peace treaty with Israel. Page 3. (Reuters)

LEAD: ONCE UPON A TIME IN THE Ukraine, there were Cossacks and Tartars, tambourines and magic boots, and the kind of impromptu dance competitions that Miroslav Vantukh watched years ago on summer evenings in the villages around Lvov.

LEAD: A NEW Yonkers police program scheduled to take effect this month will give the police the right to stop any car between the hours of 1 A.M. and 5 A.M. that displays a special decal. The decal allows the police to operate under the ''reasonable suspicion'' that the car is being stolen.

LEAD: Where and When: The New York National Boat Show is located at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, at 11th and 12th avenues between 34th and 39th streets. LEAD: It was surprising that Steven Weisman's article made no mention of an interesting and important personality in the recent history of Ceylon/Sri Lanka, Sirimavo Bandaranaike, who became the world's first female prime minister, in 1960. Her husband, Solomon West Ridgeway Dias Bandaranaike, had been assassinated the year before, and she was persuaded to take over the reins of his party, which won the general election the following year.

LEAD: Philip B. Schwab's formal job description could be, and often is, president of any one of several construction, demolition or heavy equipment companies based in the New York City area. But to hear his creditors tell it, sometimes in court testimony, he is in the bamboozle business - has been for years.

LEAD: THE return to the Ballroom, at 253 West 28th Street, of Judith Cohen, one of the most popular figures in the 1970's cabaret revival, is a reminder of how, even in a milieu that treasures nostalgia, styles come and go.

LEAD: At Temple Ohr Torah in North Woodmere, L.I., Karyn Susan Stiefel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Stiefel of West Hempstead, L.I., was married yesterday to Asher Ansel Blass, a son of Lorell Blass of Herzliya, Israel, and the late Dr. Judd Blass. LEAD: At the Bronx High School of Science, one of New York City's premier public schools, more than 300 windows have been shattered since last summer. LEAD: Declaring population growth to be India's most serious problem, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi doubled expenditures for health and family planning services in the last two years. But the country's own experts say they have been disappointed by the results so far.

LEAD: WITH its new production of ''Das Rheingold,'' the Metropolitan Opera has created a series of visual effects befitting the grandeur of Wagner's mythic tale. LEAD: One year after a fire at the Dupont Plaza hotel killed 97 people, Puerto Rican tourism is thriving and leaders of the industry are painting a bright future for travel to the island.

LEAD: Tennis Shriver Wins in New South Wales Open: Top-seeded Pam Shriver scored an impressive 6-2, 6-3 victory over second-seeded Helena Sukova in the New South Wales Open at White City outside Sydney, Australia, yesterday. In the men's final, John Fitzgerald of Australia, seeded fifth, posted a 6-3, 6-4 victory over third-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union.

LEAD: There are some minor disadvantages to becoming a Presidential candidate at 39. When Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee, who was born in 1948, was asked at a recent news conference in Tallahassee whether he was interested in becoming the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee this year, he offered a low opinion of the post and its historic significance.

LEAD: QUESTION: Did Paul (Bear) Bryant coach the most Heisman Trophy winners? In a head-coaching career that spanned 38 years at four colleges from 1945 to 1982 and resulted in 323 victories, Bryant saw only one of his players voted the Heisman Trophy, and it wasn't even a player at Alabama, where Bryant coached for 25 years.

LEAD: Some $1.5 billion in international aid available to the Philippines is stuck in the pipeline awaiting decisions on how it should be spent, according to officials of the State Department, Pentagon and Agency for International Development.

LEAD: Environmental concerns and other problems that have defied legislative remedies will be the most pressing issues when the New Jersey Legislature convenes on Tuesday to close the book on its 202d session and open its 203d.

LEAD: CONFRONTING the disease of anti-Semitism, ''Evil in Clear River'' gets the symptoms right but is curiously vague about the root causes. On Channel 7 at 9 this evening, the television movie is, according to a press release, ''a fictionalized drama suggested by real events.'' The fictionalizing seems to have left reality decidedly fudged.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The white clapboard bungalow, four rooms, kitchen, bath and carport, seems better suited to Levittown than to Lublin.

LEAD: Three gunmen entered an apartment in the Bronx early yesterday, forced the occupants to remove their clothes and then shot them repeatedly, killing three men and wounding two others, the police said.

LEAD: In a city with a distinguished political tradition of grudges and vendettas, some people are asking what is really behind Senator Edward M. Kennedy's hot battle with the publisher Rupert Murdoch.

LEAD: THE death last week of the retired professional basketball player Pete Maravich offers a sober lesson for anyone who exercises or is thinking of exercising. Maravich, who was 40 years old, collapsed and died of sudden cardiac arrest while playing basketball with friends in a church gymnasium in Pasadena,
LEAD: HE GOT HUNGRY AND FORGOT HIS MANNERS. A Fable. By Jimmy Breslin. 275 pages. Ticknor & Fields/Houghton Mifflin. $17.95.

LEAD: WHEN the game ended and the Bears had lost, when he knew he would never play football again, Walter Payton sat on the Bears bench with his head in his hands for perhaps five minutes. In the chill - it felt as if it was 23 degrees below zero - his teammates had hurried off Soldier Field to the warmth of their locker room.

LEAD: The police suspect that a West Berlin woman working for Palestinian terrorists planted the bomb that killed two American soldiers and a Turkish woman and wounded 229 people in a West Berlin discotheque in April 1986, the authorities said today.

LEAD: A startling features of the report by the Presidential panel on the stock market collapse is its conclusion that several major systems that had been expected to protect the market or keep it in balance instead contributed to its near disintegration last October.

LEAD: They are still tiny but, by the time they are chosen to bolster some message of love on St. Valentine's Day, they will have traveled several thousand miles and matured into beautiful long-stemmed red roses.
LEAD: Edward V. Hickey Jr., chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission since 1985, died unexpectedly of heart failure on Saturday at his home in Falls Church, Va. He was 52 years old.

LEAD: THE songs of Jimmy Webb, whose hits for Glen Campbell, the Fifth Dimension and Richard Harris made him the ranking wunderkind of West Coast songwriters in late 1960's, are defined by an unblushingly effulgent romanticism. From early hits like ''Up Up and Away'' and ''MacArthur Park'' to recent songs like the lovely ballad ''Skywriter,'' which he performed at Jan Wallman's on Friday, his music strains against the conventional boundaries of pop form toward an operatic breadth and expressiveness.
LEAD: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega returned today from an unexpected weekend visit to the Dominican Republic, ending speculation that his trip might be a flight into exile.

LEAD: WHEN a lawyer for a major financial underwriter refused last month to produce a company executive at a trial in San Diego, the Federal District Court judge supervising the case decided he had heard enough.

LEAD: With sunny skies and crisp temperatures providing near perfect conditions for sledding, Shay Coe pulled Gidon Shocken up a small hill in Washington Square Park. At Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, Betty Oleaga, a park ranger, gave a lesson in cross-country skiing. For those planning for the outdoors in warmer weather, there was the Boat Show at the Jacob K.

LEAD: When Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, Chief of the Soviet General Staff, called on the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff during the Washington summit meeting last month, he was invited into their sanctum sanctorum, a place rarely visited by any outsiders, much less Communist military men.
LEAD: Sometimes State Senator Nancy Larraine Hoffmann likens the State Legislature to a soap opera. ''It's like 'General Hospital,' '' she says, ''except it's called, 'State Capitol.' ''

LEAD: Judith L. Trossman, an editor in the communications department at the accounting firm of Peat Marwick Main & Company in Montvale, N.J., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Dr. Alvin Ruthenberg, a dentist in Brooklyn. Rabbi Andre Unger officiated at the Village Green. The bride is the daughter of Shirley Newman of Schenectady, N.Y., and Sanford Lindy of West Hartford, Conn.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''Virginia Woolf read it, was fascinated by it, and told me to scrap it. So I did. She said that nobody should publish before the age of 30.''

LEAD: Appalled at how little the play of his team in the first period resembled its performances of the last three weeks, Coach Michel Bergeron proceeded to tinker with its cast tonight. Thus reorganized, the Rangers for two periods struggled to act in concert. They wound up, however, producing only an old and disturbingly familiar encore.
LEAD: The state grand jury that has indicted Gov. Evan Mecham on six felony counts will take a few weeks off but has not concluded its investigation of him, Attorney General Bob Corbin said today.

LEAD: In a combined drive against corruption and racketeering in New York City's construction industry, state and city officials say they are assembling a unit of more than 100 prosecutors, investigators, auditors and other personnel.
LEAD: Desperate for a victory after four losses in their previous five games, the Milwaukee Bucks found the perfect solution today: the Nets.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: This is one of the few cities in the world where Preston Robert Tisch could feel poor. Not that Mr. Tisch lacks money. He can't tell you exactly how much he has, but he estimates his fortune as just under $1 billion.
LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association must stop trying to legislate integrity, its executive director, Dick Schultz, said today in remarks opening the 82d annual convention.
LEAD: Democrats have always relished political brawling. The Republicans say they prefer campaigns run according to the rules of engagement laid down by Emily Post.

LEAD: RALPH Vaughan Williams's ''Sir John in Love'' is probably the closest approach before Britten's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' to a satisfactory Shakespeare opera in English. The Bronx Opera Company opened its 20th-anniversary season with a new production of the piece (which it first revived in 1978) Saturday evening at the Lehman College Theater, in the Bronx.

LEAD: The United States, the world's leading grower of grain, also is a major importer. The reason, according to farmers and policy makers, lies in the conflicting goals of the Federal farm program, and in global competition.
