LEAD: The city's relationship with Broadway theater is to be the subject of talks this morning between Mayor Koch and a panel that has accused him in the past of ignoring its suggestions: his Theater Advisory Council.

LEAD: Major banks are reported to be unenthusiastic about the novel debt-relief scheme cooked up by Mexico and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. The reluctance of other big players may limit the scheme's effectiveness. But the Mexican arrangement still could open a promising new chapter in the third world's crisis of overborrowing.

LEAD: ''CONSERVING AMERICA'' is refreshing; it's about ordinary people as much as it's about the environment. Ordinary people may fight to protect marshes, swamps and prairie potholes not so much because wetlands are consecrated as because people like them. Documentaries about the environmental movement sometimes forget people; ''Conserving America,'' on

LEAD: Amid a heightened sensitivity about development in New York City, a range of officials - from Mayor Koch to some of his sharpest critics - are calling for a reassessment of the widespread practice of trading zoning variances for promises of public amenities.

LEAD: Frustrated by the slow pace of the fledgling recycling efforts in New York City, 16 City Council members are backing legislation that would make recycling mandatory citywide and set a four-year goal of reusing a fourth of the city's garbage.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The guidance systems used for aiming MX missiles are continuing to fail in tests at an alarming rate, the House Armed Services Committee reported today.
LEAD: Two homeless men were found dead in Manhattan yesterday morning, the police said, and both appeared to have died of natural causes.
LEAD: John Cade, the political strategist who masterminded the 1979 campaign that made Dave Treen Louisiana's first Republican Governor since Reconstruction, died Friday at the age of 59.

LEAD: Although Vietnam and the United States have no diplomatic relations, three Congressional delegations are visiting Hanoi over the next two weeks. So are an American humanitarian aid mission and a technical team looking for missing servicemen.

LEAD: Jury selection is scheduled to begin Monday in the trial of Lyn Nofziger, the former top political adviser to President Reagan who is accused of capitalizing on his relationship with the President in violation of Federal ethics law.

LEAD: With an exceedingly flowery memo, Burton Manning, chairman and chief executive of the British-owned J. Walter Thompson Company, notified his people that two members of Don Johnston's management team would be leaving the agency - as Mr. Johnston, the former chief executive, quietly did himself late last year.
LEAD: A picture caption Saturday with an article about the play ''Half Deserted Streets'' misidentified the actor at right. He was Michael Imperioli.

LEAD: The Brooklyn Philharmonic under the direction of Lukas Foss will give four concerts this season in its ''Meet the Moderns'' series, with programs including seven world premieres, three United States premieres and five New York City premieres.

LEAD: Influenced by political, economic and meteorological trends that have converged in recent weeks, the global demand for American farm products is stronger than at any time since 1984, and exports are climbing, according to the Department of Agriculture.
LEAD: As Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita departs for his first state meeting with President Reagan, Japan may be in its strongest position in years to turn aside American criticism.

LEAD: The unresolved issue of North Korea's participation in the Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea, could place Cuba in the uncomfortable position of either supporting an ally or satisfying its own considerable sports appetite, according to senior Olympic officials in the United States and elsewhere.

LEAD: Judith Clark, a former member of the Weather Underground, has spent the last six years behind bars for her part in a 1981 robbery that resulted in the death of two policemen and an armored truck guard. Last month, she was suddenly transferred from New York State's penitentiary for women in Westchester County to a Federal facility in Tucson, Ariz.

LEAD: THE much-talked-about merger by Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi of its Ted Bates Worldwide and Backer & Spielvogel, forming Backer Spielvogel Bates, was completed Oct. 1. Now, three months later, G. Robert Holmen, who is chairman and chief executive domestically, is on the verge of calling the merger a success.

LEAD: Losing patience with price discounting by other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Saudi Arabia has introduced a discount plan to insure it will hold on to its major American customers, a respected trade journal and industry experts said.

LEAD: For a dozen years, general retailers and apparel and textile manufacturers have envied the supermarket industry's black-and-white bar code, which has helped speed customers through checkouts. But the vast number of general merchandise items -in many different sizes and shapes -had seemed to be an obstacle to wider use of bar-code scanners.

LEAD: A man ventured to Vermont on a recent weekend seeking the tranquillity of mountain vistas. It turned out to be one of the busiest weekends of the season and skiing was more of an urban experience: brief periods of skiing and long periods of standing in line.

LEAD: Joe Clark, the Paterson, N.J., high school principal whose tough actions have led to conflict with the local school board, has been offered a post in the Reagan Administration, a White House official said yesterday.
LEAD: Demoralized by corruption and virtually paralyzed by fear, Colombia's courts have signaled their unwillingness to continue fighting this country's powerful drug barons.
LEAD: In his hotel suite overlooking this snow-draped city, Alexander M. Haig Jr. finishes his morning coffee and prepares, once more, to bundle up and shake hands at a factory gate.

LEAD: An eight-inch snowstorm that caused an official closing of the Federal Government on Friday was no match for the two main participants in one of Washington's longest-running public forums. It was the 101st monthly appearance by Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Janet L. Norwood, before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress to explain the latest employment figures.

LEAD: IN the beginning, men ran and women didn't, and running came between them. Seduced by the many health benefits of running and its combination of play and competition, the born-again athletes of the 1970's became obsessed, to the detriment of relationships. Men even took perverse pride in their addictive behavior, flaunting their excesses as a kind of emancipation from the traditional needs of work, family and romance.

LEAD: A battered white Peugeot pulled up to the roadblock the Palestinians had thrown across the main highway through the Gaza Strip, and the driver opened the trunk to reveal his cargo: eggplant, tomatoes, scallions and potatoes.

LEAD: The Emhart Corporation announced yesterday that it would make a $577 million unsolicited bid for Stanadyne Inc., which makes precision metal parts.

LEAD: Do states have a right to set their own speed limits? Of course. The national 55-mile-an-hour limit was imposed by the need to conserve oil. That's no longer so urgent a national concern. Last April's highway bill properly relaxed the Federal rule; the continuing resolution just passed relaxes it a bit more.
LEAD: The Cleveland Browns won't play in the American Conference championship game until next Sunday, but along with their fans they've been playing the game for the past year.

LEAD: Two youths were wounded, one of them critically, in a shooting yesterday afternoon outside a popular roller skating rink in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, the police said.

LEAD: The report by a Presidential panel agreed with what some stock market participants have suspected for months: portfolio insurance managers were among the major villains in the frenetic five-day stock market drama of October 1987.

LEAD: A USAir jetliner made an unscheduled stop in Kansas City early Saturday to discharge an intoxicated passenger who tried unsuccessfully to open the cockpit door and an outer door during the flight, officials said. LEAD: THE discovery in 1986 of a new class of substances called high-temperature superconductors has galvanized research in chemistry and physics, spurred a global race for industrial and military applications and led two scientists to a Nobel Prize. LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts has named Francis O'Brien, a man of some renown in press and political circles, to the position of senior press adviser.

LEAD: The troubled Governor of Arizona, Evan Mecham, opened the state's legislative session today by acknowledging ''I have made mistakes'' and extending a conciliatory hand to legislators he had largely ignored in his first year in office.

LEAD: THE central character in Richard Foreman's ''Symphony of Rats'' (at the Performing Garage) is the President of the United States, but his residence is more a labyrinthine fun house than anything remotely resembling the White House. LEAD: A wide range of new programs to help New Jersey businesses sell their goods overseas will be proposed by Governor Kean in his State of the State Message to the Legislature on Tuesday.

LEAD: * Allegheny International, Pittsburgh, said it had called a meeting of the holders of its $11.25 cumulative preferred stock for March 2 in Pittsburgh to elect two additional directors to the company's board as requested by a shareholder, Spear, Leeds & Kellogg.
LEAD: ''Here's the total picture of Pat Robertson.''
LEAD: Laura Chapman, a former dean of the School of Nursing at Rutgers University, died of leukemia Jan. 1, at Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. She was 78 years old and lived in Piscataway, N.J.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article from Washington yesterday about a commission on American military strategy misstated Zbigniew Brzezinski's former title. He was national security adviser, not Secretary of State.

LEAD: In a move to close down several major distributors of pornography, the Justice Department plans to seek a series of racketeering indictments this year designed to seize tens of millions of dollars from the distribution and sale of sexually explicit material.

LEAD: Michel LaChance, one of seven harness drivers suspended by the State Racing and Wagering Board in connection with a Nov. 14 race at Yonkers Raceway, told the board yesterday that ''I tried everything I knew to win.''
LEAD: The chief economist for Sears, Roebuck & Company predicted yesterday that sales of general merchandise would increase 5.8 percent in 1988, compared with a 5.2 percent rise last year.

LEAD: Stylish wearing of any kind of clothing has little to do with common sense but everything to do with the fashion of the moment. Right now, of course, the short skirt has surpassed every other silhouette. Even recently, with the temperature in the teens, it has prevailed at see-and-be-seen restaurants.

LEAD: The father of a boy whose body was found in a ditch two years ago pleaded guilty today to misdemeanor charges of abandoning a body and concealing a death. The man, Eli Stutzman, was sentenced to 18 months in prison after he entered the pleas in Thayer County Court. Mr. Stutzman testified that he and his 9-year-old son, Danny, were driving from Wyoming to Ohio on Route 81 in December 1985 when the boy died.

LEAD: Give Alf Burtleson a mountain, and he'll give you a cave. In California's Napa Valley, about 45 miles north of San Francisco, no one is more in demand these days than Mr. Burtleson, who calls himself a cave man. He digs caves. But not ordinary caves. Burrowing into hillsides, he creates spacious and elegant caverns in the earth that wine makers fill with barrels and bottles of aging wine.

LEAD: The prices of crude oil and oil-related futures crumbled further yesterday as more traders questioned OPEC's ability to maintain the production and pricing levels to which its members agreed at a meeting last month.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Representative Jim Bunning, the Kentucky Republican who won 224 games in his career as a major-league pitcher, and Willie Stargell, whose name appears on the ballot for the first time, are considered the leading candidates to gain admittance to the baseball Hall of Fame when the results are announced tonight.
LEAD: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia scored a 6-3, 7-6, 6-2 first-round victory over Bryan Roe tonight in the Australian Open.

LEAD: The United Nations said today that it had revised downward its forecast for worldwide economic growth in 1988. The United Nations is now predicting growth of 3 percent, instead of the 3.5 percent rate reported two weeks before the Oct. 19 stock market plunge.

LEAD: Sterling Drug Inc., the object of a $4.2 billion takeover offer from F. LEAD: The deep freeze of the last week has set many cloth-coat wearers to thinking about furs. And now is the time to buy. Between fears about the economy and concern over hemlines, fewer coats were sold earlier in the season than furriers had anticipated. As a result, fur salons, stores and manufacturers are marking down furs anywhere from 20 to 50 percent.

LEAD: ''Teddy and Alice,'' a musical with a book by Jerome Alden and music by John Philip Sousa, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Minskoff Theater. Directed by John Driver and starring Len Cariou, it will have run for 77 regular performances and 11 previews.

LEAD: The Presidential panel's report on the stock market crash has run into a cool reception from some in the White House and heavy criticism from some in Congress and on Wall Street for its proposed reforms of the financial system. Already there have been predictions that the proposals will never be enacted.

LEAD: THE sports divisions at the major television networks are huge operations, making and spending hundreds of millions of dollars each year. They pay their broadcasters astronomical salaries, and provide them with excellent working conditions and a national audience that religious leaders might covet.

LEAD: Mayor Koch, asserting that New York City cabdrivers frequently refuse to accept black passengers, proposed yesterday that cab owners be punished if their drivers refuse service to potential passengers.

LEAD: WORKING with a drug tried unsuccessfully against malaria in the 1960's, scientists have developed a new class of antibiotics that promises to have a profound effect on the treatment of important infectious diseases. Many patients who in the past have been hospitalized for weeks in order to receive intravenous antibiotics can now be discharged to take the new drugs orally at home.

LEAD: The president of Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium, today threatened to bring trade actions against America's leading aircraft makers if they file trade suits against his company.

LEAD: For 16 years Ida Nudel was denied permission to leave the Soviet Union, and she was banished to Siberia for four years after she hung a banner from her apartment balcony that read: ''K.G.B., give me my visa to Israel.''

LEAD: A grand jury in Opelika, Ala., yesterday indicted Jim Abernethy, a former Atlanta sports agent who has said he paid performance bonuses to the Auburn defensive back, Kevin Porter. Don Siegelman, the Alabama attorney general, said that the panel returned misdemeanor counts of tampering with a sports event, violating the deceptive practices act and commercial bribery.

LEAD: Companies in Britain, West Germany and Japan have an advantage in acquiring American companies because of how laws regarding good will payments are handled by their countries, a Congressional report says.

LEAD: BETWEEN periods of turbulence, fashion often simmers down. Despite the prevalence of lace boleros, fluffy skirts paved in ruched ruffles and the glitter of gold-colored metal, the Adolfo collection for spring and summer actually reflects a moderate mood. It contrasts with the boisterousness of his last collection, giving women as well as the designer a chance to catch a breath.

LEAD: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita of Japan will tell President Reagan this week that he is ready for negotiations to open some public works projects to foreign construction companies, Japanese officials said today.

LEAD: With an unemployment rate down to 3.6 percent and jobs increasing by 100,000 a year, New Jersey appears on an economic upswing. But Governor Kean, in his State of the State Message yesterday, wisely spent less time crowing about the boom than assessing how to prolong it. He's concerned with those it leaves behind, particularly the homeless.

LEAD: The Yankees' search for pitching help remains at a standstill, just five weeks before pitchers and catchers have to report for spring training. Lou Piniella, the team's general manager, said yesterday that he was conducting talks with several teams, but that there was little chance a deal would be made soon.

LEAD: IT is amusing to think that when French chefs were passing out names for dishes in the days of Escoffier, they often named the simplest of dishes ''a l'anglaise,'' meaning in the English style. The term was used for foods that were simply boiled in water or stock, like mutton or chicken or potatoes.

LEAD: The first Air Force Titan 4, the United States' most powerful unmanned space rocket, arrived here today to be prepared for a launching with a military payload in October. The 204-foot booster was brought here by a C5A cargo plane from a plant near Denver. In addition to the Air Force's plans to launch two of the rockets annually from here, the space agency is considering using the Titan 4 for scientific payloads, and its manufacturer, Martin Marietta, wants to market it for commercial customers.

LEAD: SOME artists work with oils, some in watercolors. But Sylvia Weinstock and Colette Peters prefer butter cream, a moist, tender cake and icing. Although the two women work independently they share the same idea of what a cake should be: an edible extravaganza.

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission moved today to penalize a television station in Kansas City, Mo., saying it appeared to have violated rules against broadcasting indecent programming at a time when children were likely to be in the viewing audience.

LEAD: In an unexpected reversal, a group of black Baptist clergy members voted to invite Mayor Koch to attend its annual memorial service for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the president of the group said yesterday.

LEAD: The Grand Union Company, a unit of Generale Occidentale of Paris, said that a management group, led by its chairman, Floyd Hall, had organized a leveraged buyout for all the assets of the supermarket company, based in Elmwood Park, N.J. Terms were not disclosed. The transaction is scheduled to close March 1.

LEAD: The United States' two members of the International Olympic Committee and a senior State Department official said yesterday that the presence of many allies of North Korea, including the Soviet Union, would serve as a deterrent to the possibility of disruptive actions by North Korea during the Seoul Olympic

LEAD: The Federal trial of a reputed Mafia ''capo'' and nine other defendants took an unusual turn yesterday when the judge disclosed that he had privately questioned one or more jurors. The disclosure came amid indications that he was inquiring into possible tampering.

LEAD: When public television broadcasts a three-part performance of Eugene O'Neill's ''Strange Interlude'' next week, blind and vision-impaired people in nine areas may be able to enjoy the show more than in the past, since an oral description of the visual portions will be broadcast at the same time.
LEAD: The Singer Company said yesterday that its directors had called a special meeting today to consider a $1 billion takeover bid from Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor.

LEAD: THE CONSOLATION OF NATURE AND OTHER STORIES. By Valerie Martin. 147 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $16.95.

LEAD: The first major tournament of 1988 for players in the New York metropolitan area, the Tri-State Regional, begins today at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y. This is the schedule: Today - Men's pairs and women's pairs, 1:30 and 8 P.M.

LEAD: The selection of a new Federal prosecutor in Manhattan has touched off a major behind-the-scenes confrontation between Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, according to Republicans close to both men.

LEAD: John J. Williams, a Republican Senator from Delaware for 24 years, died of heart and respiratory failure Monday night in a hospital in Lewes, Del. He was 83 years old and had been in poor health for some time.

LEAD: ''SWORD OF ISLAM'' explores the world of Moslem fundamentalists. The view is not always attractive. Many of the fundamentalists seem to be in love with death. Political fanatacism and sexual repression join. The 90-minute documentary, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, is compelling.

LEAD: The new year has started with democracy in retreat in several countries, yet the Reagan Administration, quick to claim credit when there's good news, now prefers to ignore, or disguise, the bad.

LEAD: John H. Johnson, who presided over the nation's 176 minor-league teams as president of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, died of chest cancer yesterday at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 66 years old.
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it was negotiating the possible sale of a stake in its Venezuelian operations to the Mendoza Group, a local conglomerate.
LEAD: TWO Wall Street analysts took on hundreds of retailers yesterday and showed them no mercy.
LEAD: In an improved performance over last year, students at New York City public high schools have won more than one-third of the semifinal places in the national Westinghouse Science Talent Search.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation, seeking to revitalize sluggish sales of mid-sized computers, said today that it would recruit more independent companies to sell those machines. The program is aimed at reaching the 4.5 million businesses that have fewer than 5,000 employees. Even I.B.M.
LEAD: Richard L. Huber, formerly an executive in Citicorp's investment bank, has joined the Chase Manhattan Corporation as sector executive for capital markets and foreign exchange.

LEAD: Donald P. Kelly, chairman of E-II Holdings Inc., a Chicago-based offshoot of the Beatrice Companies, will meet today with William J. Alley, chairman of American Brands Inc., to discuss ideas to improve American Brands' stock price, both companies said yesterday.

LEAD: Sensational shootings often draw more attention, but to many people here there is something deeply troubling in the numbing frequency of incidents like the one Monday that left 14-year-old Aaron Fultz critically wounded.

LEAD: Mayor Koch called yesterday for a curb on the deal-making powers of the Board of Estimate, of which he is a member, by limiting the board to a simple yes or no vote on land-use issues before it.

LEAD: Cecil Cooper, the Milwaukee Brewers' career leader in batting and runs batted in who did not play after the All-Star break last season, was waived yesterday for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. Cooper, 38 years old, played 11 of his 14 major-league seasons with the Brewers. The five-time All-Star had one year remaining on a contract that called for a reported $700,000 in 1988, not including a deferred payment of $840,000.
LEAD: Sir Con O'Neill, who led the intricate negotiations that took Britain into the European Economic Community, died Monday, his family said. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: Iowans besieged by politicians and their electronic messages since before 1988 began, are growing weary of the prolonged Presidential campaign. In Texas, voters are still trying to sort out just who is running for the White House.

LEAD: Leslie Koerner was having his cheeseburger with a slice of onion and a Dr. Brown's black cherry soda at Big Nick's on Broadway when his beeper went off and he leaped out the door to find a pay phone. He was just saying, ''a lot of times people are antagonistic because of the price - they feel they're being ripped off even if they're not,'' when he was summoned.

LEAD: Members of a Congressional delegation visiting Nicaragua said today that they warned the Government here that Congress may approve more aid for rebels if the Sandinistas do not reverse their position and agree to begin direct cease-fire talks with the contras.

LEAD: A proposed national championship football playoff was overwhelmingly rejected today by the nation's major football schools.
LEAD: In a state where growth has been one of the most divisive issues, Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin today outlined a set of sweeping proposals that could shape Vermont for years to come.

LEAD: Gov. Arch Moore, the silver-haired patriarch of West Virginia's Republican Party, has announced that he will seek a fourth four-year term. The announcement Monday by the 74-year-old Governor ended months of speculation that he would run for the United States Senate.Mr. Moore won his first of two consecutive terms in 1968, then stepped down.

LEAD: ONE of the first terms of art you learn in the newspaper business is that there is something called the silly season, which used to occur around August. That was the time of the year when news had ground to a dead halt, when the Mayor was at the beach, the kids were out of school and public relations people called up promoting things like the Madonna look-alike contest.
LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices were unchanged to slightly lower yesterday in aimless trading that reflected a widespread lack of conviction about the future course of interest rates.
LEAD: Jessica McClure fell into an abandoned well as a result of inadequate supervision by her mother and an aunt, a state official says in a letter.

LEAD: Franchising World, the year-old publication of the Washington-based International Franchise Association, is making itself available to the public on a limited number of newsstands and bookstores beginning with its January-February issue.

LEAD: The President's national security adviser has warned the leaders of four Central American countries that they could face serious economic and political consequences if Congress lets the contras collapse, according to senior Administration officials and diplomats familiar with the discussions.

LEAD: Pakistan's two senior leaders have concluded that some members of the pro-Moscow Government in Afghanistan must be allowed to take part in a successor government as a condition for the withdrawal of Soviet troops.

LEAD: The broadest Soviet-American accord on scientific cooperation in almost a decade was signed here today by the heads of the two countries' top scientific academies, paving the way for greater joint efforts in fields ranging from AIDS research to nuclear reactor safety.

LEAD: Bill Gullickson, who spurned a Yankee offer last week, signed a one-year contract today with the Yomiuri Giants. Gullickson will receive $1.1 million for 1988 plus a contract signing bonus of $400,000 and at least $150,000 in expenses. ''I will try my best for the Giants as I did in the major leagues,'' Gullickson said at a news conference in Tokyo.

LEAD: David P. Bloom, a 23-year-old New Yorker with an unregistered investment business, collected $10 million in the last two years from 100 friends and associates to play the stock market. Instead, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission, he bought himself an art collection, a beach house on Long Island and a reputation as a philanthropist.

LEAD: Texas Republican officials say the names of all six of their party's Presidential contenders will remain on the March 8 primary ballot despite questions about the validity of some signatures on petitions submitted by four of the candidates.

LEAD: THE title of ''The Joy of More Sextets'' - a recent violin and piano work by Milton Babbitt that had its first local performance Sunday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall - refers to a work of 20 years ago entitled simply ''Sextets.'' Neither involves a sextet in the conventional sense of six instruments; the term refers to numerical groupings that govern the pitches and other events in the 20-minute work.

LEAD: For months, betting against the dollar seemed a sure thing to the global army of traders who ply the $200 billion-a-day currency market. Going into the new year, most foreign-exchange traders expected the United States currency to fall even more.

LEAD: The nations of the world spent about $930 billion on their military forces last year, an increase of $50 billion over 1986, and the United States ranked first in such spending, a military and social researcher reported nan annual study made public this week.

LEAD: DINNER included salad with vanilla vinaigrette, vanilla-glazed beef kebabs and vanilla cream seltzer. For professional reasons, the diners dutifully consumed eight vanilla custards, or at least took a thoughtful taste; each was made with a different vanilla extract or bean. Organizers of this unusual vanilla dinner, a gathering of the San Francisco Professional Food Society, had hoped to decide which vanilla was best.

LEAD: IF one had to name the two great pioneering folk dance ensembles from the Soviet Union that became the model for all other professional folk companies in the world, they would have to be the companies founded separately by two choreographers, Igor Moiseyev and Pavel Virsky.

LEAD: Senators returning from recess later this month might not notice the new tile floor that is being installed in one of the main lobbies on the first floor of the Senate wing of the Capitol. Their oversight would be understandable, because the new floor looks exactly like the old tile floor that has been in place since it was installed in the 1850's.

LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation expects its exports will be down for the third con-secutive year, its president, Shoichiro Toyoda, said. A higher Japanese yen and changes in the American tax sys-tem can be blamed for sluggish ex-ports, he said. Toyota's exports num-bered 1.77 million cars in 1987, down 6 percent from 1.88 million in 1986.

LEAD: Elderly twin brothers who lived as recluses in a house filled with trash were beaten to death and the house set afire, the authorities said today. ''The fire was used to cover the crime,'' said Fire Chief Tom Anderson. ''The motive at this time is unknown.'' The bodies of the victims, Roy and Irl McNutt, 79 years old, were found Saturday in their living room.

LEAD: COMPLAINT plays an important part in almost every gardener's life. We complain about problems we can solve with a little work, like chickweed or crabgrass in the flower beds. We also complain about matters beyond our control, mainly the weather. Chief among these meteorological complaints are those concerning the plants we cannot grow because we live in a climate they find too taxing or unfriendly.

LEAD: PETER LINK'S new musical, ''The River,'' is a collage of rock, rap and pop gospel, extolling water in spiritual and metaphorical terms. In Mr. Link's lyrics water falls, tumbles, rains and rushes in streams, rivers and oceans. By the end of the show, which opened last night at the Promenade Theater, one has been inundated by images of liquidity.

LEAD: Senator Albert Gore Jr. has a peculiar advantage in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination. His state, Tennessee, borders on eight other states, all of which hold their primaries on March 8, the day politicians call Super Tuesday. Day after day, Senator Gore has told neighboring state audiences how happy he was to be in a state that borders on his own and remarked on how much the neighboring states have in common.

LEAD: In the continuing controversy about how much hard-driving ''Type A'' behavior may affect the risk of developing and dying of heart disease, a new study has found that men who were considered Type A were less likely to die after a heart attack than their more placid Type B counterparts.
LEAD: Katherine Guy Fenimore Cooper, a horticulturist and member of the boards of many charitable groups, died Friday at her home in Cooperstown, N.Y. She was 92 years old.
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. is expected to announce Friday that it will enter into a joint development agreement with the Digital Equipment Corporation.

LEAD: COLIN QUINN, a comedian whose reputation for New York Irish streetwise humor has been described as Joycean, is a performer who relies more heavily than most comics on electrical communication with individual members of the audience.

LEAD: President Reagan said he felt ''pretty good'' today after being up much of the night with an upset stomach and nausea. In what was called a coincidence, he will enter the hospital Friday for a six-month checkup to guard against a recurrence of colon cancer.

LEAD: A Soviet monthly has begun publishing installments of Boris Pasternak's ''Doctor Zhivago,'' which had been banned since Mr. Pasternak won the 1958 Nobel Prize for literature.

LEAD: Three days before the deadline, China announced today that it would send a team to the Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea.

LEAD: CAN it really be a quarter of a century since a 16-year-old pianist named Andre Watts made his spectacular debut with the New York Philharmonic as the substitute for an ailing Glenn Gould? LEAD: In a capital in constant flux, the White House staff is one of the least permanent institutions of all, shifting kaleidoscopically with elections, Presidential whims, Government scandals and intramural political coups.
LEAD: THE European American Bank, which was doing its own advertising, felt that its name didn't go with the image it wanted. It doesn't really sound like Long Island's leading bank.

LEAD: When Congress approved a Federal holiday to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., many who had fought for passage of the bill privately feared it might produce no more than another three-day weekend. Backers of the holiday also believed it would take years to become widely accepted.

LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service's pending claim against Texaco appears to be similar to those it filed in recent years against other multinational companies, including the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company, former Government tax officials said today.

LEAD: PARRILLADA is the Spanish term for mixed grill, which in the Argentine tradition ususally means a mini-charcoal barbecue presented at the table and heaped with T-bone steak, marinated skirt steak, morcilla (blood sausage), sweetbreads, kidneys, calf's liver and sausage. At La Fusta, a popular neighborhood Argentine restaurant in Elmhurst, Queens, the lusty and well-cooked parrillada (sans kidneys and liver) comes with a jar of chimichurri, a piquant sauce made with garlic, parsley and olive oil.

LEAD: The Rev. Paul E. McKeever, professor of moral theology at St. John's University and a former editor of The Long Island Catholic, died of cardiac arrest Sunday at the Seminary of the Immaculate Conception in Huntington, L.I., where he lived. He was 64 years old.

LEAD: ''EL SUR'' (''The South''), opening today at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema, is the second feature by Victor Erice, the Spanish director whose first film, ''The Spirit of the Beehive,'' was one of the critical hits of 1976.
LEAD: Jose Zacarias Arza, former president of Paraguay's ruling Colorado Party, died Tuesday. He was 93 years old.

LEAD: Despite Japanese-American progress in steadying the dollar, higher United States interest rates are needed ''to make the dollar an attractive currency,'' a high-level representative of the International Monetary Fund said today.

LEAD: MUSIC was the controlling impulse behind George Balanchine's choreography and two of his works at the New York City Ballet Wednesday night typified how wide-ranging that specific focus could be.

LEAD: Ducks seemed oblivious to the single-digit temperatures yesterday in Central Park as they swam in one of the few unfrozen ponds. The thermometer dipped to 5 degrees, the lowest this winter. Today should be warmer, with the temperature rising into the mid-20's. (NYT/Neal Boenzi)

LEAD: With the United States abstaining, the Security Council adopted a second resolution today calling on Israel to cancel plans to deport Palestinians from the occupied territories and allow those already deported to return home. All 14 other Council members voted in favor of the resolution.
LEAD: The State Department has found a new tool to combat terrorists: a dishwasher-size explosives detector called the EGIS Mark II that will be installed in all United States embassies next fall.

LEAD: The nation's retail sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in December over the November level, the best performance in four months, spurred in great part by higher auto sales, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

LEAD: ANYONE who has seen the movie ''Broadcast News'' is not likely to forget a nutty cameo featuring a pair of eager-beaver jingle writers auditioning their John Williams-ish ''evening news'' theme for a major network news department. Congress has at last decreed that the agency should also consider supporting a much smaller, privately operated space station that costs a mere $700 million and can do many of the same things.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it had extended its buyer incentive program, which it began in late October, for another month. It has added the Aerostar van with a $500 rebate, and certain Mustang car models, with a $400 rebate, to an enhanced program that runs through March 8.
LEAD: Senator Bob Dole said today that if he was elected President he would propose a one-year spending freeze that would save $150 billion over three years and slash the Federal budget deficit.

LEAD: BILLY REGIS (Chris Mulkey) is a ladies' man who likes to boast about his exploits, and Eddie (John Jenkins) is the friend who has heard it all. So when the two of them embark on an all-night drive to visit a girlfriend of Billy's in ''Patti Rocks,'' it's a very long journey indeed. Billy describes his sexual adventures in rude, graphic detail; meanwhile, the more sensitive Eddie laments the breakup of his marriage.

LEAD: Only four months after a crash nearly ended his life, Roberto Guerrero was back in a race car yesterday, feeling ''100 percent.'' He spent more than two weeks in a coma after the accident.

LEAD: The Supreme Court has upheld in broadest terms the power of public school authorities to control the content of high school newspapers. Now just about any educational reason will justify heavy editing and outright exclusion of student articles. The Court reaffirms its 1969 decision that students may not be punished for non-disruptive political expression, like wearing black armbands in school to protest the Vietnam War.

LEAD: One woman was killed, six people were injured and 27 families were forced to leave their homes when a four-alarm fire blazed through a city-owned building yesterday at 583 Franklin Street in Prospect Heights. LEAD: ''MEDIA POST MEDIA'' is the latest exhibition organized by the independent curators Tricia Collins and Richard Milazzo. The duo's shows usually manage to indicate important directions in new art while remaining somewhat inconsistent and presenting a number of artists whose prominence will probably not exceed the proverbial 15 minutes.

LEAD: A Travel Advisory report on Dec. 27 about Hertz rental cars omitted mention of some national car-rental companies that hold renters responsible not only for collision damage but also for vandalism, theft and other loss of the car. Besides Value Rent-a-Car and Hertz, they are Alamo and Thrifty. In some copies, the headline characterized Hertz's new policy inaccurately.

LEAD: KIDDUSH HASHEM Jewish Religious and Cultural Life in Poland During the Holocaust. By Shimon Huberband. Translated by David E. Fishman. Edited by Jeffrey S. Gurock and Robert S. Hirt. 474 pp. New Jersey/New York: KTAV Publishing House/ Yeshiva University Press. $35.
LEAD: NOTHING could take away from the success of East Hampton's innovative recycling project last fall - except perhaps a partisan squabble over a garbage bill.

LEAD: Nearly one-fifth of the obstetricians in Massachusetts who responded to a survey have quit their practices since 1984, a result of increasing malpractice insurance rates and a rising number of lawsuits.
LEAD: OUR friend Alan gets the shakes every time he thinks of how close he and Ellen came to a divorce after 38 years of marriage.

LEAD: AS we remember Dr. Martin Luther King's achievements, we readily focus upon his courageous crusades that attained extensive desegregation and contributed to the passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act and the 1965 Voting Rights Act. But what were the sources of the philosophy of nonviolence that directed his crusades?

LEAD: THE 1988 battle over the New York State budget, which began formally last week with Governor Cuomo's presentation of his spending plan, will probably be not so much about how to spend the money as about how much money there is to spend.

LEAD: JUST beyond the senior prom and the soft-spoken words ''I will'' is a wonderful creature called a wife. Joke all you want about them, wives are the best things that happen to men. They come in all heights and weights, with straight or wavy hair, with green or blue or brown eyes, with freckles and without, but somehow the one you have is the nicest combination of all.
LEAD: Cliff Robinson made a foul shot with two seconds remaining tonight and Connecticut upset Syracuse, 51-50, in a Big East Conference game.

LEAD: FINDING SOLUTIONS TO PROBLEMS may be difficult enough these days without someone like Steve Richardson, whose active trade is obfuscation. He's the owner of Stave Puzzles in Norwich, Vt., an enterprise dedicated to state-of-the-art vexatiousness. Stave's hand-painted and custom-cut wooden jigsaw puzzles go beyond the ruses that other puzzlemakers have long employed as tools of confusion - monochromatic designs, say, or pieces painted back and front.

LEAD: The engagement of Dawn Renee Greenspan to Charles Heller Brownman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Brownman of Watchung, N.J., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Greenspan of Beaumont, Tex. A September wedding is planned.
LEAD: A 69-year-old woman was killed yesterday evening when fire broke out in her room at the Martha Washington Hotel on the East Side of Manhattan, fire officials said.

LEAD: Three months after the stock market collapse, an army of highly educated, highly paid executives, people used to sitting at the center of corporate power, are scrambling to salvage their careers, professional reputations and affluent styles of life.

LEAD: I DON'T know about anyone else, but I'm very impressed with all the information we get from the Government in Washington. I'm especially impressed with statistics about the Gross National Product, the percentage of unemployment, the trade deficit, personal income and the like. Just think about the amount of work it takes to compile those figures and the number of people who must be involved.

LEAD: THOMAS LETIS'S candy apple-red motorcycle is often the subject of intense stares as he drives along streets and highways. It isn't the machine's color that attracts attention - it's the scores of scrolls and hand-engraved dragons and flowers.
LEAD: IT was to be the narrowest - and perhaps most notorious - of the sliver buildings, 33 stories on an 18-foot-wide lot at 1451 Lexington Avenue, between East 94th and 95th Streets.

Raymond Mummery of Coral Gables, Fla., and Kathleen Osborne of Stamford, Conn. Jean S. Kotkin, a leader of the American Ethical Union, performed the ceremony at the Burden Mansion in Manhattan.

Built in 1785 by Benjamin Weed, a soldier in the Revolutionary War, the 33- by 35-foot dwelling is listed on the State Register of Historic Places and has been undergoing extensive structural restoration since last July by the Connecticut Trust for Historic
LEAD: A Taiwanese court today imposed long prison terms on two dissidents who were convicted of sedition for advocating Taiwan's independence from China.

LEAD: To the Editor: I have followed with interest the graph you printed each week comparing the crashes of 1929 and 1989. But to put the post-crash periods in proper perspective, I think it mandatory that you graph the 50 or so trading days before the crashes. Doing that will allow readers to see longer-term similarities and differences between the two events, and thus help us to evaluate the post-crash period.
LEAD: Ryoko Sato of Japan shopping in San Francisco. Foreigners are finding bargains here because dollars are cheaper. Page 22. (The New York Times/Terrence Mccarthy)

LEAD: A senior Reagan Administration official said today that Nicaragua's reported agreement to open direct talks with the contra rebels ''would be an important step'' if it led to serious negotiations.

LEAD: Over the last two years a 23-year-old New York investor named David Bloom collected $10 million from 100 friends and associates to play the stock market. But last week authorities charged that Mr. Bloom's favorite investment was himself. They said he spent most of the money on such things as an art collection, a beach house, a condo, an Aston Martin and contributions to Duke University, his alma mater.

LEAD: FOR MOST OF MY LIFE, I trusted the system, especially the economic system, to serve as an engine not only of prosperity but of equality and freedom and individual rights under the law. I fully believed that once principles of law were at stake, all Americans were equal.

LEAD: Between them, the Washington Redskins and the surprising Minnesota Vikings have four starting quarterbacks, two big-play receivers who have emerged from the shadows, two strong defensive lines and one cornerback with a pain in the ribs.

LEAD: WHILE the number of hunters reached a record high during the fall wild turkey season, the success rate dropped to a record low, the State Department of Environmental Protection reported last week.

LEAD: THE Sony Walkman helped usher in a new category known as ''personal audio'' products, which allow people to take high quality music with them anywhere. Now, electronics companies hope to repeat their success with ''personal video.'' They are combining tiny television sets and video cassette recorders into miniature units that would allow people to take their favorite movies with them anywhere.

Today,'' was dismissed a day after making controversial comments about blacks in sports. Section 5. Unifying Force in Cambodia Many of the 61,000 Cambodians in border refugee camps controlled by the Communist Khmer Rouge look to Prince Sihanouk, the non-Communist opposition leader, as a sort of liberator.
LEAD: Cuba's decision not to attend the 1988 Seoul Olympics could result in its loss of the 1991 Pan American Games, which were awarded to Havana two years ago.

LEAD: The Guggenheim Museum of Art has appointed a man described as ''the Clint Eastwood of the art museum director's world'' to direct its expansionist fortunes.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH deer are beautiful to watch as they bound across open fields with their white tails raised, many homeowners, nurserymen, farmers and orchardists are changing their views about them. Once supportive, they are now part of the so-called anti-Bambi lobby.
LEAD: BY next weekend, the concert calendar will have returned to its busy preholiday pace, and choices will have to be made from among orchestral concerts, chamber recitals or folk music.
LEAD: WHAT is the right moment to terminate a game, whether by resigning or by offering a draw?

LEAD: Lakshmi Kant Jha, one of India's most distinguished economists and an architect of the country's recent economic liberalization, died of kidney failure today. He was 74 years old.

LEAD: Parents cannot be held liable for all their children's actions, a magistrate said Tuesday in rejecting a misdemeanor charge against a woman whose teen-age son was charged with allowing minors to drink at a party at their house while she was away.

LEAD: Mrs. Edward James Dore Jr. of Bloomfield Hills and Glen Arbor, Mich., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Ann Dore, to David James O'Connell of Bronxville, N.Y., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarence O'Connell. Ms. Dore, the daughter also of the late Mr. Dore, is an institutional equities saleswoman with Morgan Stanley & Company in New York.

LEAD: IT IS UNUSUAL FOR A DEALER TO put together an exhibition on a modern master that seems indispensable. Yet Sidney Janis has done just that. The 44 paintings, drawings and gouaches at the Sidney Janis gallery through Feb. 13 focus on the early figurative work and the ideas and feelings that Piet Mondrian wanted to distill and synthesize in his abstraction.
LEAD: DAVID S. RUDER was tapped to be a good caretaker.

LEAD: Of all the Cambodians whose future will be discussed in coming talks on a political compromise, perhaps none have so much to gain or lose as the tens of thousands of civilians still living under the control of Communists who run several refugee camps along the Thai-Cambodian border.

LEAD: IN PROSPECT, VISITING THE NA-tional Theater to see ''Entertaining Strangers'' seemed rather like going to the Ritz for bran and apple juice. According to pre-opening publicity, it was a ''community play,'' a history of 19th-century Dorchester painstakingly researched by the townspeople themselves and originally presented in a local church.

LEAD: HITCHCOCK AND SELZNICK The Rich and Strange Collaboration of Alfred Hitchcock and David O. Selznick in Hollywood. By Leonard J. Leff. Illustrated. 383 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $22.50.
LEAD: WHAT the longbow was to English yeomen and the V-2 rocket was to the Germans in World War II, the Stinger antiaircraft missile is to today's American-backed guerrilla fighters.

LEAD: Engineers and transportation officials, seeking to determine the future of the aging Williamsburg Bridge, uncovered the bridge's most corroded cable yesterday and pronounced it not as badly damaged as they had feared.

LEAD: A crowd stood on a corner at West 84th Street and Broadway yesterday, gawking at the enormous hole left by an aged water main that broke and spewed thousands of gallons of water onto the streets early Friday morning.

LEAD: It was a thrill to see our son's article on the About Men page. It was also a source of perverse satisfaction to me, as I well remember that he, too, was a colicky baby who drove us to distraction for a time, as we paced the floor with that same feeling of helplessness. There is some justice in the world.

LEAD: I AM a member of the ''sandwich'' generation. I am a parent who has suddenly found herself caring for own parent. Sometimes I feel as if I am trapped in the middle, like the cream of the Oreo cookie, with no way out of a situation for which I was totally unprepared.

LEAD: OUT OF FRUSTRATION WITH A HISTORICAL clock that insists on moving at its own measured pace, some dedicated propagandists for new music come to sound like the generals who insisted that the only way to save Vietnamese villages was to bomb them out of existence. Only by ruthlessly dismantling the repertory built up over previous centuries, it is suggested, can room be made for the 20th century's own candidates for survival.

Marie, Ontario, Canada, before, during and after World War II. In ''Fountain Pen'' we were introduced to the Yanover family, whose 10-year-old son, Irving Yanover, has a passion for eating bacon.

LEAD: Q. We recently installed a brass-framed glass door over the opening to our brick fireplace. Because the brass frame is very straight and the brick against which it fits is rough and bumpy, there are gaps where smoke seeps out into the room. We stuffed small strips of fiberglass insulation into these cracks, but some smoke still gets through and bits of fiberglass keep falling out.

LEAD: I fail to see how the uncovering of Jackson Pollock's studio floor reveals evidence of his working process [ ''Studio Floor Yields a New Look at Polock's Art,'' Dec. 20 ] . The real revelation coming from Pollock's studio floor is the fact that he was a very messy painter who liked to walk around in wet paint.

LEAD: WHAT SNAKE OIL was to folk medicine in the last century, the word ''digital'' is to home electronics in our era. Like the reptilian elixir, or traditional incantations of ''abracadabra,'' that word is deemed to possess miraculous powers. Anything to which the term digital can be attached is supposed to be either perfect already or getting there fast.

LEAD: After playing 42 holes over three days with 15 birdies, 27 pars and no bogeys, Steve Pate took a double bogey on his 43d hole, his seventh hole in today's round. He then took three bogeys on the back nine of LaCosta Country Club's course. But he also had seven birdies for the round, and that helped him keep the lead he has held from the first day of the 36th annual MONY Tournament of Champions.

LEAD: On the eve of Haiti's second attempt at presidential elections in seven weeks, a general strike brought the usually teeming capital to a virtual standstill today.

LEAD: THEY are not numerous, but they are out there, traveling along woodland trails, across meadows and beaches, up and down hillsides and around backyards. They are the people who fasten frames of ash or aluminum to their feet and go snowshoeing.

LEAD: SINCE Mussolini's fall in 1943, anti-Fascism has been a national creed in Italy, extolled, institutionalized and politically manipulated. Only recently has anyone argued that it is obsolete. The debate has raged since Italy's most prominent historian of the Fascist period, Prof. Renzo De Felice, said in a newspaper interview last month that ''the great alternative'' between Fascism and anti-Fascism ''no longer makes any sense either in the public conscience or in the reality of everyday political struggles.
LEAD: The police in Managua have arrested five opposition leaders who recently met with the contras, and were seeking six others, according to the Interior Ministry.

LEAD: Let no reader of Dan Wakefield's troubling article be misled into thinking that the decline of ''orthodox'' Freudian analysis has made the couch a safer place.

LEAD: THE persistent failure of the cheaper dollar to significantly improve the United States trade balance not only signals problems for Administration economic policy. It is a puzzle - and increasingly an embarrassment - for an economics profession that predicted almost unanimously that a cheap dollar would bring dramatic trade improvement.

LEAD: WHEN RICHARD L. ARMITAGE, an Assistant Secretary of Defense, embarked on a secret mission to Panama two weeks ago, he carried a harsh message. In a lengthy meeting, he told Gen. Antonio Manuel Noriega, the de facto leader of the military-controlled regime, to get out of politics within three months so that the country could have a cushion of civilian rule before elections next year.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The list of possible successors to Rudolph W. Giuliani as United States Attorney in Manhattan is like an accordion - for a variety of reasons, it expands and contracts in the hands of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and his aides.

LEAD: THE debate rages clear out to Montauk. Where is Long Island going and what will it look like when it gets there? The economy, our government, education, transportation and taxation are just a handful of the issues that keep popping up like targets on a pistol range.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: LATE ON AN UNUSUALLY WARM June 1 afternoon last year in East Baltimore, Jewel Foster Lyles, 25 years old, was walking down East Federal Street, which was littered with empty liquor bottles and food wrappers. Mrs. Lyles, a dark, statuesque woman with a broad forehead and a vibrant smile, was two weeks past term with her second child.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH just-in-time systems were once used exclusively by large manufacturers, a wide range of non-manufacturing companies are beginning to use such systems successfully to increase their competitiveness and extend their geographic reach. In my judgment, just-in-time techniques applied to retailing and services offer benefits for small and large companies as dramatic as those they offer manufacturing.

LEAD: IF there was one hot catch-phrase at this year's show, it was the ''home office.'' By one estimate, there are 13 million proprietors running businesses from their homes, and many of these people have high incomes, making them attractive targets for vendors.

LEAD: Hosea Williams, with bullhorn, an Atlanta City Councilman, leading a march yesterday near Atlanta. The 200 demonstrators retraced the steps of a brotherhood march in mostly white Forsyth County that was disrupted by violence a year ago. Mr. Williams led the march last year and another a week later with more than 20,000 demonstrators.

LEAD: YOU DIDN'T NEED TO KNOW A time step from a soft shoe when you watched Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire. LEAD: NIGHTS AT THE ALEXANDRA. By William Trevor. Illustrated by Paul Hogarth. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) ''I am a 58-year-old provincial,'' writes the narrator of William Trevor's slim novella, the latest in the Harper Short Novel series. ''I have no children. I have never married.'' The person responsible for this state of affairs is Frau Messinger, an Englishwoman who finds refuge from World War II with her elderly German husband near the Irish town of Cloverhill.

LEAD: The engagement of Mary Eileen Shelley to Dr. John Daniel Morrissey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morrissey of Pelham Manor, N.Y., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Shelley Jr. of New Rochelle, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in August.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN ''THE FAMILY,'' WHICH opened on Friday at the Cinema Studio, Ettore Scola offers up a two-hour crash course in 80 years of European history, without ever leaving the rambling apartment which is both haven and prison for five generations of a comfortable Roman clan. Just outside the family's field of vision - and the audience's - World War I rages, Mussolini waxes and wanes, threadbare liberation is followed by a burgeoning postwar boom, post-'68 malaise segues into the uneasy reconciliations of the 1980's.

LEAD: ISRAEL struck back with a variety of strong measures last week in new efforts to quell Palestinian demonstrations in the occupied territories. But the violence continued and more deaths and injuries were reported.

LEAD: A trial judge should have discharged a juror who said after deliberations began that she could not ignore her own prejudice against Hispanic people in a case with a Hispanic defendant, the state's highest court has ruled.
LEAD: An officer who was dismissed for running a British container ship aground stabbed his captain and threw him overboard today, the Coast Guard reported.

LEAD: An article by The Associated Press last Sunday about United Press International misstated the number of people dismissed from U.P.I. in the last two months. Christopher Smith, a U.P.I. spokesman, said that while as many as 100 employees had left the news agency in the period, only 33 were laid off.

LEAD: BEFORE the Democratic candidates for President gathered in debate here last week, people figured they knew what would be said about the deficit and arms control and welfare reform. What people were wondering was, would any one in the pack go after Gary Hart on the character issue?

Nunn performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Donna Karan said she did not show longer skirts in her summer collection Friday just to provide the customer with options. She said she did so because ''I think they look great, and they look new.''

LEAD: WALKING THROUGH MILFORD, A NEW England town turned small city turned New York suburb, I think of my parishioners and can't help but feel a little envy. It's not that I am jealous of their cars (which are nice) or their boats (beautiful) or their homes (expensive). Rather, I am envious of the ways that their careers reward them.

LEAD: ON a windy, bitterly cold day last week, Robert P. Rittereiser sat in his eerily still office on the 28th floor of E. F. Hutton & Company's year-old headquarters. In the plush offices all around him, the telephones were silent. Sunlight poured in on dozens of empty, tufted-leather chairs. Everything was clean, orderly, an office seemingly poised for an important meeting of Wall Street dealmakers.

LEAD: EVERY evening after dinner, George Papineau goes to a nearby Friendly Ice Cream Shop for a snack. When he gets his check, he fishes a small card from his wallet and scans the numerical tables to find the correct amount for the 15 percent tip.
LEAD: CHADHA The Story of an Epic Constitutional Struggle. By Barbara Hinkson Craig. Illustrated. 262 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

LEAD: Palestinian protests over the last five weeks have brought about at least one profound change in Israeli thinking. People no longer believe that it will be easy to go on occupying the West Bank and Gaza.

LEAD: Shearling coats, which have seen their wearers through some cold times, are getting the chance to do so again this frigid winter. Simple, honest, rugged - these are the words that come to mind in describing the sturdy and functional shearling. They still apply to this hardy perrennial, but now some new descriptions can be added to the shearling coat lexicon, such as sophisticated and fashionable.

LEAD: Your essay on ''Hip Graphics'' (Works in Progress, Dec. 13), with the images in sequential rotation of the human hip, recalls a similar revolutionary image of the human body 76 years ago -Marcel Duchamp's ''Nude Descending a Staircase, No. 2.'' The painting caused quite a stir at the Armory Show of 1913 in New York, owing to the liberties it took with the human form.

LEAD: The Yankees signed the wrong Jack. What they need is pitching, and Steinbrenner should have signed Jack Morris. Besides, as a right-handed power hitter, Clark will not have an easy time hitting homers in Yankee Stadium. JOSEPH A. LEVY Rego Park, Queens

LEAD: IT'S a scene I see almost every time I go into a camera store. Harry, the hapless customer, walks up to the counter and asks for a roll of film. ''What kind?'' the clerk queries. ''I dunno, the kind that makes color prints,'' Harry replies, acting as if he's on an errand for his wife.

LEAD: Stefan Batory Question: I understand the Polish Ocean Lines' Stefan Batory is to be retired. Is there to be a replacement for this wonderful ship, which my family has enjoyed the past three summers? - W. B. R., New Paltz, N.Y. Answer: Polish Ocean Lines is seeking a more modern ship to replace the Stefan Batory, which is to be taken out of service in March.

LEAD: Drug trafficking is again emerging as a source of tension between the United States and Mexico, after an interlude of nearly a year in which both sides played down their differences on what each should be doing to combat it.

LEAD: THE WASHINGTON Post was bewailing the reluctance of candidates to mention the dread word taxes. ''They've been Mondaled,'' the editorialist wrote, making a verb out of the name of the last candidate to suggest that a rise in taxes was inevitable, ''you say the T-word and you die.''

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Verner Reed Jr. of New York and Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Serena Reed to Paul B. K. Kusserow, a son of Suzanne Kusserow of Underhill Center, Vt., and the late Dr. Berthold Kusserow. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: The annual census of bald and golden eagles has counted 36 birds in the Quabbin Reservoir so far and at least six others elsewhere in the state, according to Massachusetts wildlife officials. Bird counters said this week that this year's total was slightly below those of the past two winters, when more than 50 birds were counted.

LEAD: THE mood on Wall Street was glum; only 2,000 shares changed hands that Tuesday. Retail sales took a beating; a B. Altman's store saw only one costumer all day. Food prices soared; milk went from 2 cents to more than 10 cents a quart within three days.

LEAD: WHILE household gardeners, with spring in mind, have begun poring over seed catalogues, farmers and others for whom the land provides a livelihood have been preparing to gather in Atlantic City Tuesday for the annual New Jersey Vegetable Meeting, a three-day conference said to be the largest of its kind on the East

LEAD: The next round of United Nations-sponsored peace talks on Afghanistan will open in Geneva in February and appear likely to produce agreement on a timetable for the withdrawal of Soviet forces, according to United Nations officials and diplomats here.

LEAD: The United States Olympic hockey team, testing itself against tougher competition after an idyllic schedule in which it routed collegiate squads, today lost its second consecutive game to Canada's Olympic team. Sean Burke of Canada made 50 saves in a 5-1 Canadian victory at the Joe Louis Arena.

LEAD: NO GATHERING OF ANTIQUES is more eagerly anticipated in New York than the Winter Antiques Show, which opens with a series of preview parties on Friday and runs through Jan. 31 at the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and 67th Street. Now in its 34th year, it is one of the city's smartest social charities (proceeds benefit the East Side House Settlement in the South

LEAD: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., actually Jan. 15, will be observed tomorrow. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only; offices are open in Manhattan at 25 Broadway, 90 Church St., 909 3d Ave., Grand Central Terminal, 33d St.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Wingate of Hamden, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Joy Wingate, to Joel M. Hausman, the son of Mrs. Irving Hausman of San Francisco and the late Rabbi Hausman. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: THIS month, Frank D. Gawle begins his official duties as the Connecticut Teacher of the Year. He is also marking his 30th year as a teacher, 28 of which he has spent teaching social studies at Enfield High School.

LEAD: W. James Oelsner, the mayor of Centre Island from 1975 to 1977, is selling Harbour Point, the Oelsner family's Centre Island estate since 1946. The 25.4-acre tract, which faces Cold Spring Harbor on the north shore of Long Island, is composed of 12 land parcels assembled over the years around Seacroft, the family's Mediterranean-style mansion.
LEAD: Residents face an average property-tax increase of 12 percent this year, most of it attributable to sharply higher costs for garbage disposal, Mayor Sharpe James announced this week.

LEAD: THERE is tension on Canada's medal-conscious Olympic hockey team as the calendar draws closer to that time Coach Dave King calls ''the point of no return.'' But the anxieties don't extend to the team's impromptu goaltending duo. The coincidence of King's ending up with a pair of first-string goalies could provide the edge his club of modest scorers will need against more talented Olympic opponents.
LEAD: Larry Garrett is mild-mannered and friendly, traits reflected in his son Jimmy, who is paralyzed from the waist down because of a 1985 car accident.

LEAD: The marriage of Naomi R. Haber, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Haber of New York, to Joel Barry Rudin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Rudin of Bayside, Queens, took place last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Lavey Derby officiated.
LEAD: I want to love you As long as the world is a world, Oh, Fiorenza, Until the stones go flying away.

LEAD: ''PREPARE yourself for unexpected twists and turns,'' the audience is forewarned. It is the audience that determines some of those surprises - by applauding, by hissing, by a show of hands - in the second act of ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood.''

LEAD: The United States Postal Service said Friday night that post offices around the country would shorten their lobby hours by an average of half a day a week to absorb budget cuts required by Congress.

LEAD: THOUGH its clapboard facade has changed a few times, the Cudner-Hyatt House has stood near the corner of the White Plains Post Road and Boulevard for 254 years. The Quaker Meeting House next door, another wood building, is a comparative newcomer, having been removed from its original site on Griffen

Rabbi Charles Lippman and the Rev. Raynar W. Hesse, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Fenway Country

LEAD: SHOULD developers be allowed extra stories on their high-priced buildings if they promise, in exchange, to construct day care centers or esplanades as well? And in any case, who should have the power to make such a concession and what role should the local community board play?

LEAD: RECOGNIZING that they were losing their ability to compete in domestic and world markets, many American manufacturers have been engaged in years of globe-trotting, seeking cheap offshore labor to bring their manufacturing costs down. Now, a handful of companies, including I.B.M., Emerson Electric and Swank, are returning production to our home shores.

LEAD: ADVERTISEMENTS for the Music-Theater Group's ''Cinderella/ Cendrillon'' at St. Clement's Church on Thursday night were enough to chill the opera lover's spine. A ''retelling'' of the Cinderella story with ''a modern sensibility,'' they promised. (''Retelling'' plus ''modern'' in small American opera companies usually means ''vulgarization.
LEAD: UNTIL now P.I.P. has hardly made a squeak. But that could change soon.
