LEAD: EVERY TIME WE SAY GOODBYE Starring Tom Hanks and Cristina Marsillach (both in photo). Directed by Moshe Mizrahi. 1987. Lightning Video. 97 minutes. $79.98.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE rush to fill vacant nursing and teaching positions is resulting in what critics contend are policies and proposals that will lower the licensing standards for people entering the fields.

LEAD: IT'S always been an early harbinger of spring around our house: the first mail of the new year brings a letter from a Connecticut university congratulating me for once again having been appointed an adjunct professor for the spring semester. It's a little extra cash, but that's not why I do it; call it teaching for the joy of it.

LEAD: Isn't progress wonderful (''Foreign Money, U.S. Fears,'' by Martin and Susan Tolchin, Dec. 13)? In just a little over 200 years we have progressed from being a colony whose economic and political life was governed from across the ocean, to an expanding free nation, to the world's greatest political and economic power and the world's largest creditor nation, and, in the last six Reagan years, to being the world's largest debtor nation, with an economy increasingly owned and controlled by foreign investors from across two oceans.

LEAD: The marriage of Anne Wing Sommers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Feldher Sommers of Chevy Chase, Md., to Robert Orris Blake Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Blake of Washington, took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in the Georgetown section of Washington. The Rev. George L. Peabody performed the ceremony.

LEAD: GEORGE PERLE'S Second Sonata for Solo Violin is, at its best, a work of expressive vigor, overlong by just a bit maybe, but calling for a performer who can project dissonant lines of urgent, nervous energy. The 20-minute piece from 1963 found a worthy exponent in the person of Sylvia Rosenberg, who gave the belated local premiere of Mr.
LEAD: You just betcha. Who needs more pitchers? These bats will take care of those arms. MINNI WALKER New York

LEAD: FOR three seasons, Anthony Carter felt more like a status symbol than an integral part of the Minnesota Vikings' offense. He was the family heirloom that the Vikings were reluctant to remove from its display case. Whether a wide receiver relies on speed or moves, or both, he must be elusive. And here was Carter, sensing constraints, as if he were running his pass patterns in a ball and chain.
LEAD: CONCERT FOR DR. KING
LEAD: Throughout Eastern Europe, an economic crisis is placing increasingly heavy strains on the region's already difficult relations with foreign creditors.

LEAD: While the New York Stock Exchange scrambles to tame the exaggerations of computerized program trading, President Reagan's task force report looks elsewhere for the causes of the October crash. Traditional markets for stocks, and the newer markets for stock futures and options, the commission argues, are now inextricably linked.

LEAD: THE mood on Wall Street was glum. Just 2,000 shares changed hands that Tuesday. Retail sales took a beating. The B. Altman store had only one customer all day. Food prices soared. Milk went from 2 cents to more than 10 cents a quart within three days.

LEAD: A NUMBER of other eye-popping items were displayed at the show. Toshiba showed a three-dimensional video camera. Available in early summer for $2,850, it will require viewers to wear special glasses attached by a cable to an electronic adapter. . . Panasonic showed off its automatic bread baker, already a hot item in Japan.

LEAD: WORDS, WORDS, words, said Hamlet, when Polonius asked him what was in the book he was reading. But sometimes books contain pictures, too; and sometimes, just sometimes, the pictures revolve or jiggle around or spring to attention.

LEAD: Rick Pitino, searching for a new way to win, revived an old concept last night: starting Patrick Ewing and Bill Cartwright together on the front line. It was only the second time this season that the Knick coach had started his two 7-footers together in hopes of controlling the boards and the tempo of the game.
LEAD: LAW-ENFORCEMENT officials are trying to combat a new form of cocaine that they say is deadlier, more addictive and cheaper than crack.
LEAD: West Germany has pledged to explore new economic aid to Poland, a move that evidently reflects growing concern in Bonn that economic turmoil could produce social instability in Eastern Europe.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William J. O'Herron of Westfield, N.J., and Peru, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Coughlin O'Herron, to Robert Haldane Swindell 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Swindell Jr. of Baltimore and Damariscotta, Me. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: It would be unfortunate if Dan Wakefield's experience of ''strict Freudian psychoanalysis'' in the 1950's were considered representative of psychoanalysis today (''My Six Years on the Couch,'' Dec. 20). That he was not helped despite considerable expenditure of time and money, and that he felt traumatized is obvious from his bitter account.

LEAD: RYAN McDONNELL, 7 years old, got the bad news nearly a year after he collided with a municipal truck while riding his bicycle and was hurt slightly in San Carlos, Calif. The city was suing him for $13,000.

LEAD: THIS IS A STORY OF A GOOD piece of architecture that some people think is in the wrong place - or perhaps it is better described as the story of how, in New York, you can never win. The building is the new headquarters of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., the communications conglomerate, and the place is the neighborhood of West 66th and West 67th Streets off Central Park West, just north of Lincoln Center.

LEAD: With regard to Dan Wakefield's article, I am enclosing a poem I wrote some time ago, which I think you will find appropriate. I told him my anxieties, Confessed some improprieties, Revealed a dozen vices too (Well, at these prices, wouldn't you?) I thought that he'd have prodded me, He didn't even nod at me, He never showed a mild concern, Yet meekly, weekly, I'd return.

LEAD: Deborah Parnelle Burks and Michael John Southwick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Southwick Jr. of Princeton, N.J., plan to marry in August, the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. William P. Burks of Princeton, have announced.
LEAD: As smoke from a fire in the historic Mirror Lake Inn hung above this village Monday morning, the inn's owners, Edwin and Lisa Weibrecht, arranged an unusual shopping expedition.

LEAD: THE pitcher who has saved more Boston Red Sox games than anyone else, Bob Stanley, was hoping that doctors at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester had saved the day for him after four hours of surgery on his pitching hand Friday. Stanley, a right-hander with 123 saves in his 11 years with the Red Sox, was listed in good condition yesterday following the surgery on his hand to repair tendons and digital nerves that were cut when he fell while taking out the trash at his home

LEAD: ONE certain thing about the reflection in the mirror - it's sort of a shock, a picture that would surprise, maybe even stun, an awful lot of your friends. Is it really you - you, who only a few hours ago, were an example of good grooming and put-togetherness, the epitome of big city chic?

LEAD: The foreign trade deficit may have shrunk by more than $4 billion in November, as the Commerce Department reported, but statisticians know that raw monthly totals can be off by as much as $2 billion. They will eventually refine the figures. For overall world trade statistics, however, a much larger error defies refinement.

LEAD: The engagement of Patricia Ann Aycock to Christopher Stephen Baker, a son of Linda Baker of Point Lookout, L.I., and the late James E. Baker, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. William G. Aycock of Mebane, N.C.

LEAD: WITH two leviathans from the past (Larry Holmes and George Foreman) once again rumbling round a boxing ring, I've been keeping a good idea on the back burner. However, if Mike Tyson readily dispatches ex-champion Holmes in Atlantic City Friday night, things will be put into proper perspective and we can go ahead as planned.
LEAD: LOVE IN THE TEMPERATE ZONE By L. R. Wright. 280 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.
LEAD: Prosecutors last week disputed defense arguments that the verdict in the Howard Beach trial of four white teen-agers requires the dismissal of a key charge pending against seven other youths.
LEAD: Tom Garrick and Carlton Owens combined for 40 of 58 second-half points for Rhode Island today as the Rams defeated Rutgers, 84-71. The loss was the seventh straight for Rutgers.

LEAD: Eliza Ordway Webb and Craig Robert Faulks, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Faulks of Rocky River, Ohio, plan to marry in May, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. William J. Gaynor Webb of New Canaan, Conn., have announced.
LEAD: CHATTERTON By Peter Ackroyd. 234 pp. New York: Grove Press. $17.95.

LEAD: A bitter legal dispute between Indian tribal leaders and the Martha's Vineyard town of Gay Head ended this week with the signing of a final piece of legislation needed under a settlement that allows the tribe to buy some of the land it has long wanted. But few of the Indians are rejoicing.

LEAD: Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I., was the setting last evening for the wedding of Heidi Dina Cheven, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Cheven of Sands Point, L.I., to Michael David Jaffe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Jaffe of Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Gilbert S. Rosenthal officiated. The bride, a graduate of Adelphi University and the St.
LEAD: A new Federal law dramatically strengthens the protection of patients' rights by imposing dozens of new requirements on nursing homes and home health agencies.

LEAD: FOR Jeanne Kardos, director of employee benefits at the Southern New England Telecommunications Company, the numbers were alarming. Last year, she estimated, her company spent almost $40 million on medical expenses for its employees, up 14 percent in one year and more than double its spending five years ago.

LEAD: A NEW wariness has crept into the relationship between the United States and each of the two South Asian rivals, India and Pakistan, but there is also opportunity for Washington to extend its authority. Both the wariness and the opportunity are a result of deepening American involvement in an area that often receives less attention than the neighboring Persian Gulf but may be no less critical to Washington's interests.

LEAD: NEW JERSEY has closed a loophole in its 1977 Casino Control Act that had allowed companies operated by reputed organized-crime figures to reap more than $800,000 from casino construction projects in Atlantic City.

LEAD: Fred C. Ikle, the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, said today that he was resigning from the top-level Pentagon post, essentially completing a realignment of senior military officials under the new Secretary of Defense, Frank C. Carlucci.

LEAD: Four Republican members of Arizona's Congressional delegation called for Gov. Evan Mecham to resign today, saying the legal and political turmoil surrounding him had virtually paralyzed the state.
LEAD: IMAGINE casting Jack Gilford, Jack Weston, Ellie Greenwich and David Essex in ''We Bombed in New Haven.''

LEAD: THINGS might have taken a turn for the better for LaMarr Hoyt, the former Cy Young Award winner whose pitching career came to a sad end last January when he was released by the San Diego Padres after a succession of drug arrests in 1986.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson holding 8-year old Nick Aldrich on his lap on a visit yesterday to the farm of Terry Hoy, right, in Adel, about 20 miles west of Des Moines. The Democratic Presidential candidate was there to talk with a group of local farmers about his farm policy proposals. (NYT/Jim Wilson)
LEAD: Devils' Jack O'Callahan, left, battling Bryan Trottier for puck. In Montreal, the Rangers lost, 4-3. (The New York Times/Ray Stubblebine) Page 4.

LEAD: LIKE SO MANY FILMS OF THE 1980'S, THE GOLDIE Hawn comedy ''Overboard'' offers something for everyone. To begin with, it presents the amusing spectacle of Miss Hawn impersonating a viciously bad-tempered heiress, striking terror into everyone she meets. After this satirical high-life phase, the film moves into its low-rent period, with an amnesiac Miss Hawn trapped in the squalid home of a carpenter (played by Kurt Russell), who intends to teach her a lesson.
LEAD: The Islanders' Kelly Hrudey put a goaltending tip to good use this evening. But he was not ready to divulge the key to his success.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bernstein of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Rachel Bernstein to Ian O. Lesser, the son of Mortimer Lesser of New York and the stepson of Henrietta Lesser. The couple plan to marry in June.
LEAD: To The Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A man who pleaded guilty to conspiring to overthrow the United States Government as a member of a radical group accused of nearly 20 bombings has been sentenced to seven years in prison and fined $20,000.
LEAD: WEBSTERS' FIRST NEW INTERGALACTIC WICKEDARY OF THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE By Mary Daly with Jane Caputi. Illustrated. 310 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $35.

LEAD: Compatible improvisers who stick together, year after year, develop camaraderie and quick reflexes that can't be built any other way. A long-running band doesn't need conventions or formulas; like family members who can finish one another's sentences, they can skip the basics and get down to deeper communications.
LEAD: DR. GRUBER'S DAUGHTER By Janice Elliott. 159 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.: Hodder & Stoughton/ David & Charles. $18.95.

LEAD: I FIRST saw the Grand Canyon by the light of a winter moon. A handful of the canyon's snow-topped buttes shimmered under its gaze; ethereal and serene, they seemed to float above the darkened canyon floor. Under a blanket of snow, the Grand Canyon lay mysteriously, almost terrifyingly, still.

LEAD: For a first novel, PUSH, MEET SHOVE by Peter Barthelme (St. Martin's, $14.95) moves with unusual confidence. The writing is assured and relaxed, with snappy, sophisticated dialogue and convincing characterizations. Mr. Barthelme is also on secure ground, in that he is an advertising man in Texas writing about an advertising man in
LEAD: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency is pressing New York City and several sewage authorities in New Jersey to find alternatives to dumping sewage sludge in the Atlantic Ocean.

LEAD: The Army has asked Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci to authorize continued development of a new tactical helicopter in exchange for delaying similar work on a model for transporting troops, Pentagon sources say.

LEAD: THEY look like overgrown calculators, but they do much more than math. A variety of handheld electronic devices can now do everything from keeping track of appointments to choosing lottery numbers.

LEAD: Like a general marking his victories, Francis T. Vaughan pointed to the map of New York State hanging on the wall of his office in downtown Tokyo. It was covered with red dots - several clustered on Long Island, two near Elmira, others scattered throughout the state.
LEAD: Irving Hochstadter, a chemical engineer who founded Hochstadter Laboratories Inc., died Jan. 8 at the Valley Nursing Home in Westwood, N.J., where he lived. He was 100 years old.

LEAD: The poetic and the rowdy will be celebrated at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) this week when Jazzdance: The Danny Buraczeski Dance Company performs in a program of new and recent work. Over the past decade, Mr. Buraczeski has set himself the task of exploring and mining jazz dance, and he has stretched the boundaries of that seemingly limited form of dance with contagious wonder and good cheer.

LEAD: After a week of controversy about his financial affairs, Senator Bob Dole today made public 21 years of Federal tax returns along with the details of a blind trust belonging to his wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole.

LEAD: Former Gov. Pete du Pont of Delaware asked today that his name be pulled off the ballot for the Republican Presidential primary in Texas, saying his campaign was a victim of ''a nasty fraud'' involving forged signatures on petitions.

LEAD: A 144-foot clipper believed to the nation's last working square rigger of her size sank Thursday night while docked for maintenance work, officials said Friday. The 80-year-old Regina Maris was undergoing routine maintenance at the Boston Marine Works when she sank in about 30 feet of water, said Dusty Rhodes, a spokeswoman for Quincy's Marina Bay, where the vessel was usually docked.

LEAD: ''BUTTERFLY heaven,'' exults Donald Perry from his mobile perch above the jungle roof. The first sunny morning all week and the butterflies are out; a dozen varieties, a dozen different color swatches, flit by within half an hour.

LEAD: FEW investors who bought new stock offerings from companies in 1987 will look back with pleasure. The frothy pre-October market enabled Wall Street's underwriters to sell a record volume of initial public offerings - $24.2 billion worth, up 8 percent from a year earlier, according to Going Public, a service that tracks the new-issue market.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Dan Wakefield's article leaves readers with the impression that his hallucinatory psychotic illness resulted from the analysis and his doctor's mismanagement. There is no question in my mind that Mr. Wakefield was suffering from alcohol-induced hallucinations. The explanation offered by his analyst that they had entered the ''heartland'' of analysis is pure nonsense.

LEAD: Joel C. Berman's description of his daughter's colic and his reactions to her distress has an important message for all of us (About Men: ''A Case of Colic,'' Nov. 29). Patients will hear a sensitive physician admitting his frailties and will admire his expressions of camaraderie with those who turn to health-care providers for help.
LEAD: Alysheba, winner of the Eclipse Award as the top 3-year-old last year, will head a field of eight entered in the $200,000-added San Fernando Stakes Sunday at Santa Anita.

LEAD: THE show now at Art/Place, the co-operative at the Southport railroad station, is ''Gallery Artists Choose Other Artists.'' Twenty guests are present - presumably one per member - although the observer has no way of knowing who chose whom.
LEAD: ''EACH man has his own design for wedded bliss.'' So says Arnolphe, a would-be husband determined not to be duped, in ''The School for Wives'' at the Whole Theatre.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Solow of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Renee Solow, to Marvin Dubin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Dubin of Howard Beach, Queens.
LEAD: More than 10 percent of the nation's employers provide specific benefits or services to help their workers arrange for child care, the Labor Department said Friday.

LEAD: NOT long before he was gunned down on the balcony of a motel in Memphis, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. observed that it did no good to be allowed to eat in a restaurant if you had no money to pay for a hamburger. Dr. King, whose birthday will be commemorated tomorrow, died 20 years ago this year, an anniversary that is provoking deep reflection.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 37 food establishments cited for violating the health code.
LEAD: In an evening of Big East Conference upsets, Seton Hall came close to doing what it had not managed in many years: beating St. John's on its home court.
LEAD: To the Editor: It's nice to be remembered. Especially at Christmastime. And that's what Virginia Van der Veer Hamilton did in her article ''Leaving Home for Christmas'' (Travel, Dec. 13).

LEAD: TWO years have gone by since my husband died, and I have just realized that I no longer wince when I refer to myself as a widow. Looking back now, I see there have been other changes in my feelings during my difficult adjustment to a new life. I've experienced shock, anger, grief, depression, guilt, doubt, pain, regrets and loneliness.

LEAD: STANDING before a rally the other night in an airport hangar in Ottumwa, Iowa, Senator Bob Dole began speaking at length about the differences between himself and Vice President Bush. ''I don't want to get into class, but all of us have different backgrounds,'' he said. ''I didn't start at the top and stay at the top.

LEAD: STUDY seed and nursery catalogues and place orders promptly to be sure of getting first choices. Stock bird feeders daily. Bring in a pot of hardy bulbs from the coldframe, water gradually and place in sunlight to force flowers. Study pruning manuals to brush up on methods for trimming back grapevines, fruit trees and other dormant plants, weather permitting.
LEAD: IN 1969, the Supreme Court ruled that students ''do not shed their constitutional rights to freedom of speech or expression at the schoolhouse gate.''

LEAD: The Brady report called for changes in the financial markets. Among other things, the commission recommended unified margin requirements, better clearing mechanisms, a coordination of existing ''circuit breakers'' and the establishment of a market coordination agency. But what kind of future does the Brady Plan have, and can it really fix the market?

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Purcell of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Louise Mary Purcell to Glenn Edward Hemmerle, the son of Mrs. John Hemmerle of Rocky Mount, N.C., and the late Mr. Hemmerle. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: It is worth noting that Dan Wakefield was strongly advised by his analyst not to marry a woman he thought he loved. I can testify that a very similar episode took place in my own analysis. When, years later, the analyst began to have second thoughts about his earlier judgment, he brushed the matter off.
LEAD: American cities are awash in a tidal wave of hulks - abandoned cars. They could be reducing the tide and making money in the process. Instead, notably in New York, they are sinking.
LEAD: CBS Sports dismissed Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder yesterday, a day after the veteran commentator made derogatory racial comments about athletes.

LEAD: More than most Shakespearean plays, ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' freely lends itself to reinterpretation and transplantation, or - to use the word applied to Bottom - to ''translation.'' Although the play takes place in Athens and the forest beyond, it is an Athens of the mind, and the fairies can be relocated to almost any fictive environment - in contrast to the histories, which, by definition, are so rooted in specificity.

LEAD: Frosty the Snowman joined an increasingly interesting lineup of Florida Derby prospects by winning his third start without a defeat at Gulfstream Park today.

LEAD: Iran has set aside funds in this year's budget for the production of chemical weapons, according to a summary of the budget published here.

LEAD: The Yanks will be favorites when they have a starting rotation to match the Blue Jays. Adding John Candelaria (still a big 'if') still leaves them a quality pitcher short. JEFF MARINER New Hyde Park, L.I.

LEAD: The first town-house development in Palisades Park, N.J., is under construction at the corner of Grand Avenue and Roosevelt Place. Upon completion next fall, the six buildings of the 26-unit complex will join the area's mostly one-family homes and garden apartments. The $4 million project's first building, with three units, will be ready for occupancy next month, said the developer, Alfred Haber.
LEAD: Abe Waters, a textile executive, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Lauderhill, Fla. He was 77 years old.

LEAD: Q. We recently installed a brass-framed glass door over the opening to our brick fireplace. Because the brass frame is very straight and the brick against which it fits is rough and bumpy, there are gaps where smoke seeps out into the room. We stuffed small strips of fiberglass insulation into these cracks, but some smoke still gets through and bits of fiberglass keep falling out.

LEAD: AFTER a decade of failed efforts to restrain New York City landlords who generate profits off electricity, the Koch administration hopes to cajole them into trimming their revenues as middlemen between Con Edison and commercial tenants.

LEAD: GOVERNOR KEAN touched nearly all the bases in his State of the State address last week, but omitted tax and spending reforms, probably because the working script for those items is being written by others.
LEAD: THERE is much more to celebrate in busy and sensuous Rio de Janeiro than generous beaches, exotic night life and the string of luminous baccanalia that climax with Carnival.

LEAD: AS the Andalusian Express wends its way through the southern Spanish province for which it is named, the beauty and splendor of the region unfold as if the pages of a photo album of the American South and West were being slowly turned.

LEAD: THE MOST COMPREHEN-sive collection of comic-character toys ever exhibited - Mickey Mouse, Popeye, Donald Duck, Little Orphan Annie, Felix the Cat and Betty Boop - will be on view through Saturday at the Alexander Gallery, 996 Madison Avenue (at 77th Street). The 400 outrageously colorful and boldly graphic windup, push-pull, squeezeable and noisemaking toys were produced mostly between 1920 and 1940.

The elongated lapels or lower openings suggest that her neck is admirably longer.

LEAD: NEAR the end of the last century Edward Bellamy wrote ''Looking Backward'' - a ''fanciful romance,'' as he called it - in which he risked daring predictions about life at the end of our own century. We are still reading his durable classic, but time has revealed to us what it hid from him: the appalling implications of his prophecies.

LEAD: ROSCOE MITCHELL'S ''FLOW of Things'' (Black Saint, LP and cassette) and ''Four Compositions'' (Lovely Music Ltd., compact disk only) present contrasting views of a complex and frequently misunderstood musical sensibility. On ''The Flow of Things,'' Mr. Mitchell, a saxophonist and founder of the Art Ensemble of Chicago, is backed by a trio of piano, bass and drums; the album is a probing exploration of musical processes pioneered by the late John

LEAD: THE MAJOR NOVELS OF OLIVIA Manning, written in the 1960's and 1970's and collected in two volumes called ''The Balkan Trilogy'' and ''The Levant Trilogy,'' have at long last made it to television. They are dramatized in a BBC production entitled ''Fortunes of War,'' a mini-series that begins on WNET at 9 this evening as a ''Masterpiece
LEAD: SHOSHONE MIKE By Frank Bergon. 290 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

LEAD: THE New York Chamber Ensemble has undertaken an appealing four-concert series this season at Alice Tully Hall. Entitled ''Music of the Verein Revisited,'' it offers music once heard on the programs of Arnold Schoenberg's Society for Private Musical Performances in Vienna between 1917 and 1921.

LEAD: The store's unofficial motto is: ''If you're going to Loehmann's, you better not go with someone your size.'' Famous for offering designer women's clothing - sans label - at discount prices and infamous for provoking fights among aggressive bargain hunters, the 80-store chain, a division of May Department Store Companies, plans to open a new outlet in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx in March.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: RICHARD ARTSCHWAGER'S IS A strange sculptural world, like an ordinary home whose furnishings - the tables and chairs, the windows, the floorboards, the medicine chest, everything - have all gone slightly mad. His work called ''Handle,'' for instance, is a handsomely crafted piece of polished oak that resembles a length of bannister, but it hangs on the wall and is not a handle to anything.
LEAD: EVEN though the rents of well over a million apartments in New York City are governed by rent control or rent stabilization, hundreds of apartments do not have to abide by those regulations.

LEAD: IN choosing to end his career as a Federal judge with a blast at his critics and a vow to seek vindication off the bench, Robert H. Bork validated both the admiration of his supporters and the worst fears of those who succeeded in blocking his elevation to the Supreme Court four months ago.
LEAD: MENTION plans for a radioactive waste dump, and most communities recoil in horror. Not Needles, Baker and Trona, three small towns in the Mojave Desert of California.

LEAD: Texaco might face a $6.5 billion bill for back taxes relating to the pricing of Saudi Arabian oil from 1979 to 1981. The Internal Revenue Service would not comment, but Texaco said it was possible such a claim would be filed in the company's bankruptcy proceedings. Texaco's effort to get out of bankruptcy was already facing enormous expenses, principally a $3 billion payment to Pennzoil to settle their celebrated legal dispute.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: HOW far can a rubber band stretch before it snaps?

LEAD: A senior United Nations official, sent to investigate conditions in Palestinian refugee districts, was caught up in a hail of rubber bullets and tear gas today as the Israeli Army chased youthful protesters.
LEAD: PETER constantly reminds me that I'm the first line of defense against the forest. It's been that way since we moved here.
LEAD: Thomas A. Pappas, a prominent Republican who was Ambassador to Greece during the Eisenhower Administration, died at his home here after a long illness. He was 89 years old.
LEAD: The preacher's words sounded like something from the Book of Revelation as they thundered through the old pine pews of the Macedonia Baptist Church.
LEAD: LITERAL MADNESS Three Novels: Kathy Goes to Haiti. My Death My Life by Pier Paolo Pasolini. Florida. By Kathy Acker. 410 pp. New York: Grove Press. $19.95.

LEAD: IT was just a year ago that Yonkers officials were saying they hoped the city's new Kawasaki rail car plant, which was making subway cars for New York and New Jersey, would someday be manufacturing them for railroad and subway systems around the world.

LEAD: Achievers and Royal Gala Honoring Role Models Jan. 19 - Arthur Ashe and Marilyn Horne are among well-known achievers who came up the hard way and who will be honored as role models at the ninth annual Sidewalks of New York fund-raising dinner of Big Brothers of New York City in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

LEAD: The last round in the tangled 21-year legal battle of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter may have ended last week when the United States Supreme Court refused to reinstate triple-murder charges against the onetime contender for the middleweight boxing championship. Mr. Carter, now 50, and John Artis, 41, were convicted in two trials, in 1967 and in 1976, of the fatal shootings of two men and a woman at a bar in Paterson, N.J., in 1966.
LEAD: Sure . . . just as much as Andre Dawson, the National League's most valuable player in 1987, made the Chicago Cubs the favorites. KARL HAMILTON West Point, N.Y.
LEAD: WEARING NIKE RUNNING shoes and an expression of casual glee, Clint Eastwood stepped into 1943.

LEAD: THE National Football League has named Shane Conlan of the Buffalo Bills rookie of the year. Conlan was a first-round draft pick from Penn State, where he helped the Nittany Lions win the 1986 national championship. . . . Tamara McKinney, the United States' best hope for an Olympic medal in skiing, has progressed to gate training in her comeback from a fractured ankle.

LEAD: Mitsuko Shirai, a mezzo-soprano, will sing songs by Mendelssohn, Liszt and Wolf, and Karol Szymanowski's settings of James Joyce poems, tonight at 8 in Alice Tully Hall. Her accompanist will be Harmut Holl. Tickets are $10. Information: 874-6770.

LEAD: FOR A DECADE NOW, THE GREAT point of reference for the songs of Francis Poulenc has been the rich edition integrale, lovingly and carefully produced for EMI with Dalton Baldwin (who early in his career was close to Poulenc's artistic circle) at the piano. The singers are Elly Ameling, Nicolai Gedda, Michel Senechal, William Parker and Gerard Souzay: important talents all.

LEAD: Tornado deaths rose to 59 in the United States last year, nearly quadruple the toll of a year earlier, the National Weather Service says. While tornado-related deaths rebounded from the record low of 15 posted in 1986, last year's total still fell short of the long-term average of 90 fatalities, the agency said Thursday.

LEAD: The Supreme Court, as Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote in dissent, taught ''young men and women'' the wrong civics lesson when it upheld the right of a principal to impose prior restraint on a student newspaper. So it did, and that damaging lesson may well be absorbed far beyond the corridors of high school.

LEAD: THE nation's top-ranking investment advisers of 1987 began raising cash well before the stock market collapsed on Oct. 19. But, unlike many other money managers, they also had the fortitude to jump back into the market on the heels of the record 508-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average.

LEAD: James F. Macandrew, a pioneer in educational broadcasting who helped build New York City's public radio and television systems, died of a heart attack Friday at Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.
LEAD: A House panel is planning to investigate the phenomenon of ''hate crimes,'' including the racial incident in Howard Beach, Queens.

LEAD: The New York City Ballet will celebrate the music of American composers with its American Music Festival at the New York State Theater. The festival, which features such guest artists as Ray Charles, begins April 26 with a gala opening of the company's spring season, and continues through May 15. Over 35 ballets are scheduled, 19 of them world premieres.

LEAD: The Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, executive minister of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, delivering his sermon yesterday at Riverside Church during a service honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)
LEAD: Voters here approved a $2.57 billion transit improvement program Saturday that includes a 20-mile rail system to connect downtown with other business areas.

LEAD: Jan Davidsz de Heem's depiction of a banquet table from 1642 - the largest and most lavish still life ever painted by this artist - brought $6.6 million Friday in a sale at Christie's. The price was the highest ever paid at auction in the United States for an Old Master painting. The previous record was set Thursday at Sotheby's, with the sale of another

LEAD: Maxime A. Faget, a leading figure in the development of NASA's manned space program, now runs a six-year-old company called Space Industries. He and his colleagues at the Houston-based concern think they can build and operate a small, low-cost space station that would be rented to commercial and Government researchers.

LEAD: With 4 minutes 17 seconds remaining in Saturday night's game against the Boston Celtics at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, Mike Gminski hit a 13-foot jumper over Dennis Johnson that tied the score at 91-91 - it was to be the 6-foot-11-inch center's last basket as a Net.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about Morris Giloni, a stockbroker and board member of the Jewish National Fund of America, described the fund incorrectly. It represents not only the Herut Zionists but other Jewish groups as well.

LEAD: From the age of 12, John Edwards had wanted to go to the United States Military Academy, and he made it the hard way, first enlisting in the Army and then distinguishing himself in military intelligence and language studies.
LEAD: The stack of income tax returns and other financial documents released by Senator Bob Dole this weekend contained no major surprises, according to those familiar with the matter.

LEAD: A Congressional delegation has returned from Vietnam convinced that Hanoi is embarking on a campaign to regain some of the international understanding it lost by invading and occupying Cambodia nine years ago.

LEAD: In fiction rooted in history, a novelist uses but transcends fact. This is what happens in a hefty new novel (size: 824 pages; number of real and fictional characters: 107) that has already arrived in the bookstores, ahead of its Jan. 29 publication date, preceded by trumpets of critical acclaim.

LEAD: MODESTY and lack of assumption are virtues that seem increasingly rare in the theater these days. But they were refreshingly present in a program by Laurie De Vito's She-Bops and Scats company on Friday at Marymount Manhattan Theater, at 221 East 71st Street. Ms. De Vito, a noted Manhattan jazz-dance teacher, seemed to be aiming for simplicity, freshness and an entertaining and even inventive evening of jazz dance performed by a well-rehearsed company of strong and personable dancers.

LEAD: A circuit judge has ordered a 17-year-old robber to pay $100 a month for the next five years to a 102-year-old man he attacked outside a grocery store. Judge Frank Eppes issued the order to Darrel Burrel in sentencing him to 10 years in prison, suspended to probation for five years.
LEAD: If an athlete tests positive for use of a banned substance, and it is his first offense, should he alone bear the responsibility of sanction?
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Long-simmering hopes that interest rates will decline boiled over Friday after Government statistics showed a large drop in the nation's trade deficit and lower-than-expected inflation.

LEAD: The marriage of Jessica Wolfe, a public affairs specialist at the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation in Washington, to Jonathan Bernstein, the assistant press secretary and a legislative assistant to Senator Quentin N. Burdick, Democrat of North Dakota, took place yesterday in New York. Rabbi Marshall Hurwitz performed the ceremony at 24 Fifth
LEAD: QUESTION: Mel Allen, among many others, has called Don Mattingly the best Yankee first baseman since Lou Gehrig? How about it?

LEAD: An explosion ripped through a Mormon church Saturday. Hours later law-enforcement officers surrounded the house of a woman whose husband had feuded with the Mormon leadership before he was shot to death by the police nine years ago.

LEAD: Despite widespread skepticism and strong opposition from West Germany, the Finance Minister of France, Edouard Balladur, has been talking up the idea of forming a European central bank, in the hope of putting the matter on Western Europe's economic and political agenda.
LEAD: Computers have long been used for generating tournament deals, and more recently for scoring. They now have an impact on the type of event being played.

LEAD: Ricky Nattiel of the Broncos after scoring during Denver's 38-33 victory over the Browns. At right, the Vikings' Wade Wilson being sacked by Dave Butz and Dexter Manley (72) of the Redskins. Washington won, 17-10. Super Bowl is Jan. 31. SportsMonday, page C1. (AP)
LEAD: Some of Gary Hart's old friends did not turn out to see him this weekend when he came back to his hometown.

LEAD: ''WHAT PRICE VICTORY'' has no question mark; it has no story, either. Mostly it has cliches: big-time college football has no soul; it chews up and spits out good old country boys. Actually, this makes the two-hour movie, on ABC at 9 o'clock tonight, sound more interesting than it is. Cliches can work fine, but in this movie they are particularly barren.

LEAD: HIGH atop the scoreboard at Mile High Stadium a big white fiberglass bronco is rearing on his hind legs, his front legs pawing the rarefied Rocky Mountain air. It's as if the bronco had been startled yesterday by all the points that kept going up beneath him like bursts from six-shooters when John Elway and Bernie Kosar had a shootout on the dusty main street of the

LEAD: The Redskins won the National Conference championship and a berth in the Super Bowl today, though they made it harder than it should have been. But in the last quarter, they stopped the Minnesota Vikings once on the 1-foot line and, with 52 seconds to go, stopped them near the end zone again to save a 17-10 victory.

LEAD: Mayor Koch, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and John Cardinal O'Connor were among 1,500 people who attended a ''Save The Post'' rally yesterday outside The New York Post building in lower Manhattan.
LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, left, talking with Senator Albert Gore Jr. before the Democratic Presidential candidates appeared on ABC News's ''This Week.''
LEAD: As if there were not enough uncertainties in this presidential election year, French television is in a state of upheaval.

LEAD: The Cleveland Browns were going to score. The orange-clad fans stacked to the top of Mile High Stadium were going to have to endure an overtime period with a spot in the Super Bowl resting on the outcome. The script said so, and the Denver Broncos thought so.

LEAD: BIG DIPPER and Dumptruck, two big attactions on the college rock circuit, brought a near-overdose level of earnestness to CBGB Saturday night. Both groups are from the Boston area, and they both present rock as anti-spectacle. Band members wear the same T-shirts and jeans offstage as they do on, both groups stand there, calmly delivering their songs with the idea that the words take priority over entertainment - rock as literature.

LEAD: It is a vast subterranean network, a whooshing, gurgling 6,000-mile iron snake under the streets of New York City, and it is unseen and largely ignored until it erupts like a monster, flooding basements, streets, subways and utility lines as it did twice last week.

LEAD: Allen Churchill, a social historian who wrote sprightly books on subjects ranging from the bohemian culture of Greenwich Village to the unsolved disappearances of several famous missing persons, died of pancreatic cancer on Saturday at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: When Clara Watson dropped by Fort Worth Bank and Trust in 1973 to pick up an application for a job as a teller, she said, the chilly reception almost ended her dream of working at the bank.
LEAD: After a particularly bad 1987, Harvey Herman Associates is seeking to improve its economic health with a pair of new health care clients.
LEAD: If any company has positioned itself well for the commercialization of space, it is Space Industries.

LEAD: Israel's consumer price index rose 16.1 percent in 1987, the lowest annual inflation rate in 15 years, the Central Bureau of Statistics announced Friday. The improvement reflected a sweeping austerity program begun in July 1985. It included a freeze on prices and wages and helped to reduce inflation from a record 444.9 percent in 1984 to 19.7 percent in 1986.

LEAD: WHEN The Daily News announced Friday that it would include Vista, the Hispanic Magazine, in its Sunday issue once a month beginning March 6, it concluded a three-year effort by Arturo Villar, Vista's publisher, to crack the country's second-biggest Spanish-speaking market.
LEAD: IN his office, 26 floors above Fifth Avenue, there are models of buildings that Donald Trump has in the works or on his mind.

LEAD: David L. Eyles, chief credit officer for the Chemical Bank, is leaving to become a vice chairman of the Mellon Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh, Mellon announced Friday. Mr. Eyles, 48 years old, will also be chairman of Mellon's credit policy committee and the senior credit committee. Chemical, a subsidiary of the
LEAD: The dollar rose sharply in trading in Tokyo this morning, on the heels of an improvement in United States trade figures announced Friday. Stock prices also rallied, traders said.
LEAD: It is the wedding season in this wealthy and powerful city - as in many other parts of India -and ballrooms and community centers are booked for months.
LEAD: A series of upsets and close finishes last week might lead to questions whether the talent pool in the Big East is half full or half empty.
LEAD: A picture caption in some editions on Jan. 7 about a hockey game between the Rangers and the Canucks misidentified the Rangers' defenseman. He was David Shaw.
LEAD: MOST northeastern anglers will be casting for nothing but memories until spring, and one way to enliven this winter-imposed idleness is to begin putting gear into shape for the coming season.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Greta Bernard, a rabbinical student at the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York, and Robert S. Brown, a student at the New York University School of Law, were married yesterday at Congregation Beth Shalom in Southfield, Mich. Rabbis Robert Abramson and Robert Nelson officiated.

LEAD: A highlight film of the Vikings' season will not be necessary. All that splicing and editing would not capture the year in review any better than today's National Conference championship game against the Redskins. Steve Jordan, the tight end, called it a bumpy road, much like the one the Vikings have traveled since September.

LEAD: Today was a normal wintertime Sunday in Washington for Jack Kent Cooke. LEAD: Caren Lisa Grossbard, a fourth-year student at the Harvard Medical School, was married yesterday to Dr. Scott David Solomon, a resident in medicine at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. Rabbi Hyman Krantz performed the ceremony at the Terrace Restaurant Atop Butler Hall in New York.
LEAD: A year later, the Browns fell nine feet short of creating their own heroics in the American Conference championship game. The Broncos again toppled them and once more will go to the Super Bowl.
LEAD: Anne Minter, cheered by a hometown crowd, stunned fourth-seeded Pam Shriver, 6-2, 6-4, today to advance to the quarterfinals of the Australian Open.

LEAD: A $25 billion plan to overhaul the Government's outdated telephone system has fallen almost a year behind schedule and could experience substantial additional delays because of a bidding dispute that has led to several criminal investigations.
LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, arrived in Bonn today for a three-day visit, the first by a senior Soviet official under Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

LEAD: Martha Graham, the 93-year-old modern-dance choreographer, is in the hospital to undergo tests, according to Ron Protas, associate director of the Martha Graham Dance Company. Mr. Protas said last night that Miss Graham had experienced dizziness in the afternoon and that they had made the decision together for her to enter the hospital.

LEAD: Since the Democratic National Convention of 1968, when tensions within the Democratic Party exploded into riots on the streets of Chicago, American political parties have been tinkering with the methods by which they choose their Presidential nominees, attempting to make the process more responsive to the views of the average voter.

LEAD: Haiti's army-dominated Government held its presidential elections today, but voting appeared to be light, and irregularities, from multiple voting to voting by youths under the minimum age of 18, appeared widespread.
LEAD: Donald G. Fiordelisi of Princeton, N.J., contributed $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in honor of his father, Peter, who died on Thanksgiving Day.

LEAD: A memorial service for Leo Steiner, co-owner of the Carnegie Deli, will be held 12:30 P.M. Feb. 1 at the Sutton Place Synagogue at 225 East 51st Street. Mr. Steiner died of complications of a brain tumor Dec. 31 at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 48 years old.

LEAD: Reagan Administration officials considered and rejected a military option to intercept ships carrying Silkworm missiles to Iran in recent weeks, deciding the idea was probably illegal and diplomatically unwise, according to several officials.

LEAD: Lech Walesa, left, and Elie Wiesel, right, winners of the Nobel Peace Prize, during a visit yesterday to the Auschwitz Nazi death camp in Oswiecim, Poland. They and five other Nobel laureates took part in a ceremony marking the liberation of the camp by Soviet troops in 1945. Mr. Wiesel was a prisoner at Auschwitz and witnessed the killing there of his father and one of his sisters.

LEAD: THE names of the basic tennis strokes, forehand and backhand, should tell you something about the role of your hands in shot-making. The adage is that the racquet should feel like an extension of your hand. You should meet the ball on the forehand side as if you were striking it with your open palm, and on the backhand side as if you were hitting it with the back of your hand.
LEAD: Frank V. Schwinn, who developed the independent dealership network for his family's bicycle company, died unexpectedly at home last Tuesday. He was 67 years old.

LEAD: Bregman Partners, an investment group led by the Bregman and Belzberg families of Canada, has met with the International Multifoods Corporation to discuss buying ''certain operating divisions'' of the food processing company, based in Minneapolis. In a Securities and Exchange

LEAD: As Tsai Yo-chuan and Hsu Tsao-teh saw it, all they had done was to exercise free speech when they organized a political group with a charter calling for Taiwan's independence from China. But to the Government, what they did constituted an act of sedition, and this weekend Mr. Tsai and Mr. Hsu were sentenced to up to 11 years in prison.
LEAD: Senator David Karnes, Republican of Nebraska, is calling on the Federal Department of Agriculture to change the way it interprets the definition of a ''person.''

LEAD: After four years of robust demand that kept construction of new homes at annual levels of more than 1.7 million units, the housing industry has entered a slower period that is likely to extend into the mid-1990's.
LEAD: Four people, including three children, died in two fires here over the weekend and 27 other people were left homeless, fire officials reported today.

LEAD: YESTERDAY'S experiment is today's curiosity. That's one easy conclusion, certainly, to be drawn from Eugene O'Neill's ''Strange Interlude,'' an award-winning sensation when it was unveiled in 1928 and now a decidedly odd but still powerful period piece in a four-and-one-half-hour production made for television.
LEAD: * Air Midwest Inc., Wichita, Kan., elected as chairman Gary M. Adamson. Robert L. Priddy was named to succeed Mr. Adamson as president and chief executive.

LEAD: The Nicaraguan Government's last-minute offer Saturday to suspend its state of emergency and begin direct talks with the rebels opens a volatile period of political maneuvering, with high stakes that could determine the future course of not only the Sandinista revolution but also of Central America.

LEAD: One disgruntled author got so angry in 1979 at his publisher, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, because he thought his book had been mishandled that he rented an airplane and buzzed the house's mid-Manhattan headquarters.

LEAD: Bruce Babbitt was the first, accusing IBP Inc., the giant meatpacking company that operates four plants in Iowa, of being a ''corporate outlaw'' because of recurrent labor problems and a history of unsafe working conditions.

LEAD: After Venezuela nationalized 14 American and other foreign oil companies in 1976, it came to recognize that much of the industry - the business of refining and marketing oil abroad - was in fact still in foreign hands.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Judge Edward Weinfeld, one of the nation's most respected Federal judges, died of cancer at his home in Manhattan yesterday at the age of 86.

LEAD: The marriage of Judith Goldberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Goldberg of New York, to Stuart Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Lewis of Blauvelt, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Hotel Inter-Continental in New York. Rabbi Martin Zion officiated.

LEAD: Missing financial documents that may have been shredded or removed have hampered a Federal investigation of Jim Bakker, the former leader of the PTL ministry, and his top aides, a newspaper reported today.

LEAD: Bill Baird, right, an abortion rights advocate, and Jozef Mlot-Mroz, an anti-abortion activist, as their paths crossed yesterday at Faneuil Hall in Boston. Groups supporting both sides of the abortion issue demonstrated there to mark the 15th anniversary of the Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion.
LEAD: It was not the schedule of a complacent candidate, confident of the affections of his neighbors.

LEAD: ''If you like a man but you can't stand his wife, that tempers your judgment about whether you invite him to dinner.'' - Linda Denning, an Iowa voter, explaining how disillusionment with President Reagan hurts George Bush. [ A13:4. ]

LEAD: After weeks of negotiations, the leadership of the New York City Council has crafted a compromise bill on the Koch administration's proposal for public financing of municipal election campaigns and says it has the votes to pass the measure.

LEAD: ''St. Elsewhere,'' NBC's award-winning medical drama, is to cease production in March and its crew is to move to a new series, although NBC is still discussing ways to keep the show alive, officials said today.

LEAD: THE large oak desk that seemed so formidable 15 months ago has been moved from the south wall to the west wall, where it supports stacks of papers and an engraved nameplate that reads: Robert P. Wade.
LEAD: On the surface, the daily routine at the Manhattan headquarters of the Pan Am Corporation looks like business as usual.

LEAD: Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, who has been serving as a mediator in Nicaragua's civil conflict, said today that political concessions made by the Sandinista Government this weekend were encouraging but insufficient.

LEAD: Eugene Sawyer, the Acting Mayor, announced today that he would run in a 1989 election to complete the last two years of the four-year term vacated by the death of Mayor Harold Washington. ''I'm the Mayor, the man in the chair,'' Mr. Sawyer said in an interview on the radio station WBMX. ''I'm going to remain the Mayor.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a sen-tence in an article by Kosta Tsipis on Jan. 11 implied that canceling further production of the MX missile and the Trident submarine would save $2 bil-lion. It should have said ''as much as $2 billion per submarine.''
LEAD: THE Ramzi El-Edlibi Dance Company offered a panorama of Middle Eastern dances on Saturday night at the Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University.

LEAD: Twenty-five international ballet stars, including current Soviet dancers and an expatriate, joined here today in an AIDS gala benefit.

LEAD: A playbill issued by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts contains a passage that conflicts with the frequently-declared policy toward Yugoslavia of the center's sponsor, the United States Government.

LEAD: A dynasty ended in Taiwan when President Chiang Ching-kuo died last week, but change had already begun. While faithful to the myths of Chiang Kai-shek's rule, the generalissimo's son was a realist who had recently set course toward liberalization and democracy. The challenge to Taiwan's new president is to keep that course, tackle economic problems and yet not upset the delicate balance that maintains calm in the Formosa
LEAD: Can a son of Mr. Prospector win the Kentucky Derby?
LEAD: A report in the Business Digest on Friday about the reassignment of a General Services Administration official misstated A.T.&T.'s allegations on the Government bidding process.

LEAD: The Sunday Express quoted a Moslem cleric as saying in an interview that kidnappers holding foreign hostages in Lebanon will not consider terms for their release until President Reagan leaves office, but the cleric said in Beirut today that the report was ''fabricated.''

LEAD: Fifteen years ago, when A. J. Antoon directed ''Much Ado About Nothing'' to the accompaniment of ragtime music, an oompah band, and the antics of Keystone Kops, President Nixon saw the play and said wonderingly, ''I didn't know they could do it that way.''

LEAD: It is cold, very cold and the pond is frozen solid. The neighborhood children push aside the snow, someone builds a fire and soon the ice is covered with skaters gliding to and fro, their faces reddened from the cold and exertion.

LEAD: One woman goes to the Women's Medical Pavilion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., because she is determined to have no more children. Another is there because she has been unable to conceive. If all goes well, the second woman will become pregnant with an egg contributed by the first, who is then to be sterilized.
LEAD: Three people died, including two Canadians, in a three-car accident early this morning.
LEAD: A new Japanese Prime Minister, Noboru Takeshita, has just visited Washington talking of his country's greater willingness to shoulder global economic responsibilities.
LEAD: Scott Arniel scored twice in the third period tonight as the Buffalo Sabres beat the Islanders, 5-2.

LEAD: The General Accident Corporation of America said Friday that it had bought 20 percent of the United Fire and Casualty Company for $20.2 million from the Reliance Insurance Company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, General Accident said the purchase was for investment. General Accident, a unit of the Scottish Insurance Corporation of Perth, Scotland, also said it might seek seats on the board of the insurance company, based in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.
LEAD: EVEN Mozart wrote a ballet score, and last year Peter Martins became the latest choreographer to be attracted by it, creating one of his best works in the process.

LEAD: FIFTY years to the day after Benny Goodman's orchestra played the first complete jazz concert ever held in Carnegie Hall, on Jan. 16, 1938, the program was repeated on Saturday evening by an orchestra led by the clarinetist Bob Wilber.

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency says it will permit dinoseb, one of only three pesticides ever subjected to an emergency ban, to be used in the Pacific Northwest for the next two years as long as inventories last.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Arizona House will begin impeachment hearings this week against Gov. Evan Mecham, the House Speaker said today.
LEAD: Management at the Stop and Shop Companies is a family affair. Avram J. Goldberg is chairman and chief executive; his wife, Carol R. Goldberg, is president and chief operating officer.

LEAD: Col. Rodolfo Aguinaldo, jungle fighter, mutineer and now candidate for governor of Cagayan Province, sat over a breakfast of rice, eggs and marinated beef the other day discussing his campaign strategy.

LEAD: THE season's final ''Fledermaus'' at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night brought together several cast members who had gone into the show at one time or another since the return of the production last month. Thomas Allen was an excellent Eisenstein; he delivered the spoken dialogue with more verve and class than anyone else, and his ringing, juicy baritone was a pleasure to hear.
LEAD: Arthur M. Hettich, editor in chief of Family Circle magazine, has been named senior vice president, magazine development, of The New York Times Company Magazine Group.

LEAD: Jack Brooks is a Congressman who loves a good fight, and sometimes he goes looking for one. Such is the case now as he takes the lead in bashing Japan on its trade policy with the United States.

LEAD: The American Rocket Company has always been a fun kind of place. In one of his previous professional incarnations, George Koopman, Amroc's president, designed the spectacular stunt and car-chase scenes in the movie ''The Blues Brothers.'' And when it came to naming Amroc's first two test engines, they naturally became Jake and

LEAD: In life, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. fought to put an end to segregation, discrimination and, hardest to root out, bigotry. On the anniversary of his birth, many now claim to wear his mantle, to walk in his footsteps.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration will push plans to ask Congress for new military aid for Nicaraguan rebels despite a pledge by the Nicaraguan President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, to hold direct talks with rebel leaders and suspend a state of emergency in Nicaragua, senior White House and State Department officials said today.
LEAD: The caption of a Reuters picture in some copies on Thursday about a hockey game between the Winnipeg Jets and Vancouver Canucks misidentified the Winnipeg player. He was Ray Neufeld.
LEAD: The next American Ambassador to East Germany will be Richard C. Barkley, according to State Department insiders.

LEAD: A police sergeant who had investigated the death of Jennifer Levin in Central Park was testifying in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. Mr. Chambers's lead defense lawyer, Jack T. Litman, was doing exactly what most defense lawyers avoid - putting his client at the scene of the crime.

LEAD: As a baseball scout for more than 25 years, Pete Smith, who started with Houston and has been with the Mets since 1971, has seen his share of high school and college players with major-league potential.
LEAD: For some firefighters in Engine Company No. 45 on Tremont Avenue in the Bronx, the daily routine provides enough excitement. The firehouse has been among the busiest in the city for years.

LEAD: In an interview here today, the man almost certain to become Mexico's President later this year said repayment of his country's $105 billion foreign debt must be linked to the achievement of ''sustainable economic growth'' and urged the United States to seek a more ''dignified'' and realistic relationship with Mexico.
LEAD: Troops loyal to the civilian Government encircled a northern army compound today after a rebel officer and about 100 sympathizers had seized control of the compound's regimental headquarters.

LEAD: The rigid plastic ski boot became an institution in downhill skiing after its introduction in the mid-1960's. Along with it have come improvements in the way bindings anchor the boot to the ski.
LEAD: Bill Southwick is George Bush's nightmare.

LEAD: David P. Bloom has finally stopped telling everyone he meets about how much money he has. Instead, the 23-year-old Duke University graduate with an eye for American art and, according to the Government, a knack for selling bogus investment services stood before Federal Magistrate James C. Francis 4th in

LEAD: While the Supreme Court awaits a ninth justice,tie votes of 4-to-4 have blocked decisions in some instances. But not when the Court grinds out orders that send condemned prisoners to the executioner. An anomaly in the Court's rules, coupled with the determination of four justices to get on with executions, is producing death decrees from a deadlocked tribunal.

LEAD: Like the roar of an El train, thunderous and urgent and get-out-of-my-way powerful, the sound bursts out through the walls of the Checkerboard Lounge and escapes down the streets of the South Side.

LEAD: A young entrepreneur who started a carpet-cleaning business in his parents' garage and turned it into a million-dollar enterprise was charged Friday along with 11 other people in a 54-count Federal indictment that includes accusations of securities fraud and embezzlement.

LEAD: The Israeli Army kept more than 250,000 Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip sealed up in their refugee centers today in what is emerging as the Government's major tactic against the rioting in which at least 38 Palestinians have been shot dead.

LEAD: Concerned that insider trading and other crimes are going unpunished, the Justice Department and several regulatory agencies are planning a task force that will seek out securities fraud cases across the country, concentrating on several large cities outside New York.
LEAD: Leslie G. McCraw has been named president of the Fluor Corporation, putting him in line to head the international construction and engineering company based in Irvine, Calif.

LEAD: Katherine S. Brod and Milton H. Lehrer were married yesterday in New York by Rabbi David M. Posner, who performed the ceremony in his study at Temple Emanu-El. The bride, the widow of Melvin D. Brod, an architect and engineer, is a painter in oils and acrylics. The bridegroom is an administrative law judge and arbitrator.

LEAD: Amid the national uproar over whether to release living, genetically altered bacteria into the environment, one vital development seems to have gone virtually unnoticed: a biotechnology experiment that began last year in California seems to have worked.
LEAD: While some legislators and others in the Government vilify Japan over economic issues, one tiny Federal agency struggles on to bring the two countries closer together.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Justice Department has withdrawn the arrest warrant it issued two years ago for Mohammed Abbas, who also uses the name Abul Abbas, in connection with the hijacking in 1985 of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro and the murder of an American passenger, a department spokesman said today.

LEAD: Steve Pate became the winner of the 36th MONY Tournament of Champions today when a Pacific storm with 40-mile-an-hour winds and heavy rains washed out the final round of the year's first PGA Tour event.

LEAD: As the Minnesota Vikings lined up with a minute to go, just 6 yards from a touchdown that could have tied the game, and even less than that for a first down that could have given them another chance, Coach Joe Gibbs of the Washington Redskins dropped to his knees on the sideline.
LEAD: HALFWAY through a trial in Lexington, Miss., lawyers representing the survivors of a cigarette smoker are convinced that they have made the strongest case yet against the tobacco industry.
LEAD: The subjects that had bedeviled CBS Sports for two days - Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder and his racial comments - were reduced to a mere oblique mention on the network's pre-game show yesterday.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Friday about troubles at the New York Mercantile Exchange misstated the employment record of Kevin Conway, most recently the exchange's vice president of compliance. He has never worked for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
LEAD: By and large, an executive budget briefing is about as funny as a tax form.

LEAD: Skiing Tomba Wins Slalom: Alberto Tomba of Italy scored his fourth victory of the season yesterday in a slalom race at Bad Kleinkirchheim, Austria, increasing his overall lead in the World Cup standing. Two Austrians, Thomas Stangassinger and Bernhard Gstrein, finished second and third.

LEAD: On Aug. 31, 1983, the Soviet Union shot down a Boeing 747 with the loss of 269 lives, having failed to identify it as a civilian airliner. Moscow deserved the universal obloquy it incurred. But the Reagan Administration added a savage twist, sometimes implying and sometimes saying outright that the Soviet Union knew it was attacking a civilian plane.
LEAD: The only Treasury auctions scheduled this week are today's regular sales of three- and six-month bills.

LEAD: At the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York, Barbara Zinn, the daughter of Eve Zinn of New York and the late Victor Zinn, was married yesterday to Stephen Stout-Kerr, a son of the late Cantor and Mrs. Aron Stoutzker of London. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler officiated.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The choir finishes the hymn and the minister ascends the pulpit. Across the congregation, even before the preacher has opened his mouth, eyelids begin to feel heavy.
LEAD: THERE are moments when the elements of time and place and improbable coincidence converge to make for dramatic events. This afternoon was one of those moments.

LEAD: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said it was withdrawing its proposal to consolidate its gas service in the Sacramento, Calif., area with the electricity operations of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District. P.G.&E., which had proposed in September to take over the struggling utility and scrap its nonfunctioning nuclear power plant, said it was dropping the offer because of the Sacramento utility's failure to give it serious consideration.

LEAD: Browsers crowding a table yesterday at an outdoor flea market at the Avenue of the Americas and 26th Street as the temperature soared to 44 degrees. Today should be even warmer, with a high of about 46, but periods of rain are expected. (NYT/Dith Pran)

LEAD: PSYCHEDELIC-ERA nostalgia arrived Friday when the Dinosaurs, a group of San Francisco rockers with a 1960's pedigree, headlined an evening of music, lights and reminiscences. It was the first Psychedelic Daze Revue at the Saint, the discotheque that replaced the Fillmore East Auditorium at 105 Second Avenue, at Sixth Street; the next revue, with the Chambers Brothers, is scheduled for Jan.
LEAD: It was one day after Andrew Young resigned under fire as the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, and Zehdi Labib Terzi was worried.

LEAD: LISTENING to Alan Mandel play piano music by Charles Ives and Elie Siegmeister Friday night was to reverse the usual musical practice of tension and release. Mr. Siegmeister was in attendance at Weill Recital Hall, and surrounded by colleagues, he spent the first half of the evening listening to Ives's cheerful iconoclasm - ''Five Takeoffs,'' eight Studies and five other pieces including ''Baseball Takeoff'' and a march on ''Here's to Good Old Yale.

LEAD: Efforts to improve how America elects a President have had unexpected side effects such as Michigan's confusing caucus process. First article of a series, page A12. Mexican Debt Condition The man almost certain to be Mexico's next President said foreign debt repayments must be linked to ''sustainable economic growth.

LEAD: The New York City Ballet will present its annual ''Family Matinee'' on Jan. 31 at 1 P.M. at the New York State Theater. The company will perform ''Symphony in C'' and ''The Four Temperaments,'' both by George Balanchine, and ''Brahms/ Handel,'' a collaboration by Jerome Robbins and Twyla Tharp. During intermissions, company members will be on hand to answer questions and demonstrate such activities as the preparation of toe shoes, pre-performance warm-ups and applying stage makeup.

LEAD: At the Douglass Memorial Children's School, four elections officials sat on the front terrace grimly surveying the courtyard from behind large gray ballot boxes as they waited in the rising midmorning heat for voters to appear.

LEAD: Several weeks ago, the finance chairmen of the Democratic National Committee sent out invitations to a $500-per-person ''intimate birthday dinner'' honoring Paul G. Kirk Jr., the national chairman, on Jan. 20, two days after his official 50th birthday.

LEAD: New military aid for the contras will be sought by the Reagan Administration despite a pledge by the Nicaraguan President to hold direct talks with rebel leaders and suspend a state of emergency in Nicaragua, officials said. Page A1
LEAD: Meets on southern Lebanon at 11:30 A.M. Economic and Social Council COMMISSION ON INTERGOVERNMENTAL STRUCTURE AND FUNCTIONS IN ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL FIELDS - 10 A.M.
LEAD: Percy Qoboza, an award-winning black journalist who was editor of several leading anti-apartheid publications, died today. He was 50 years old.

LEAD: THE latest installment in the Town Hall series of ''Russian Nights'' was an estimable and sometimes exciting recital by the cellist Karine Georgian. ''Russian Nights'' is a misnomer, though doubtless more salable than ''Soviet Nights'' would be, since both Miss Georgian and her accompanist, Sahan Arzruni, are Armenian.
LEAD: A sellout crowd at Madison Square Garden last night prepared to jeer the return of Dave Brown of the Flyers but got a double disappoinment.

LEAD: THE scenery dances along with the human performers in Carol Fonda's ''Pieces of Glass,'' thereby creating much of the magic of the two-act work that Carol Fonda and Company presented Friday night at the Triplex Theater of Borough of Manhattan Community College.

LEAD: The marriage of Jane Aaron to Skip Blumberg took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sam Aaron of New York. Justice Betty Weinberg Ellerin of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Irving Hochstadter, a chemical engineer who founded Hochstadter Laboratories Inc., died Jan. 8 at the Valley Nursing Home in Westwood, N.J., where he lived. He was 100 years old.
LEAD: THE TRIAL OF SOCRATES. By I. F. Stone. 282 pages. Little, Brown. $18.95.

LEAD: In a major change of strategy, the Cuomo administration plans to create a new category of highly trained workers to manage the lives - from psychiatric care to welfare benefits - of the 25,000 people who are most difficult to treat among the state's mentally ill.

LEAD: With George Foreman's boxing comeback, Don King has come down with a mild case of nostalgia, remembering Foreman's part in what amounted to something of a role reversal between the two men: Foreman losing his crown and King gaining a new career.
LEAD: Neoax Inc. said yesterday that it had increased its tender offer for the IU Corporation by $1.50 a share, to $19, or about $589 million.

LEAD: Pat Robertson campaigned from border to border across Iowa today, stopping his specially equipped bus at small towns, preaching his message of moral values and trying to energize Iowans to support him in the state's Republican Presidential caucuses three weeks from today.

LEAD: President Reagan's dream of a tax system in which most people would not have to file returns apparently is not to be.

LEAD: About 200 pounds of a low-level radioactive powder leaked early today from a rooftop vent at a federally owned uranium-processing plant, officials said. Contamination from the uranium powder appeared limited to the immediate area and no trace was detected outside the 1,050-acre plant site, said Pete Kelley of the Westinghouse Materials Company of Ohio.

LEAD: The Yankees may have bolstered their corps of starting pitchers yesterday by adding John Candelaria to their staff. General Manager Lou Piniella immediately pronounced Candelaria the team's third starter, but questions existed over how effective the left-hander might be.

LEAD: In contrast to the elaborate, official ceremonies marking the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., some of New York's poorest children gathered yesterday at the welfare hotel where they live and voiced their feelings about a man who inspired millions before they were born.

LEAD: Seeking public office in New York City has traditionally meant paying obeisance to real estate developers, brokerage houses and others who offer big contributions in hopes that the favor will be repaid once the beneficiary takes office.

LEAD: Candidates seeking the Presidential nomination make dozens of speeches in their campaigns. Some address a particular issue or audience in a particular way. But more often the candidate uses a ''basic speech.'' It summarizes, with little variation from one occasion to the next, how the candidate wants to present himself to the voters.
LEAD: A DEVICE designed by West German aerospace engineers to pulverize kidney stones with shock waves is now being explored as a promising treatment for a far more common condition: gallstones.

LEAD: The Home Group Inc., a New York insurance company, and Carteret Bancorp Inc., which owns the Carteret Savings Bank of Morristown, N.J., said they had amended the takeover agreement that was reached last August. Under the revised deal, Home Group's offer price was reduced to $19 a share in cash, or about $232 million, from $22.50 a share, or about $320 million.

LEAD: OFTEN dabbling in sensitive subjects, the kind that fit easily into tidy object lessons, programs for younger viewers can occasionally topple over into heavy-handed theatrics. Take for instance ''Things My Mother Told Me,'' tomorrow's ''Afterschool Special'' on ABC at 4 o'clock. Eager to insure that viewers don't miss the point, the little drama is exaggerated to the point of possibly inducing hives.

LEAD: The desegregation case that has preoccupied three city administrations at a cost of $10 million is entering its eighth year with a hint of settlement, but also with many here still asking, why Yonkers?

LEAD: American industry is showing an unusual reluctance to build new factories - even though a growing number of companies are hard pressed to meet a rising demand for their products at home and abroad, according to economists and Commerce Department statistics.

LEAD: C-SPAN, the cable television network that brings Senate and House floor sessions live into your living room, has 43 percent more viewers than it did three years ago. The public affairs network reports that a national poll by the Maryland Survey Research Center, taken in the final three months of 1987, showed 10.9 million households or a potential audience of 27.3 million people watching C-SPAN, an increase of 43 percent from the 1984 estimates of 7.6 million households and 19 million people.

LEAD: Scientists in Japan have found evidence that hereditary predisposition to cancer of the colon and rectum may be a result of a highly complex process involving loss of protective genes on any of several different chromosomes.

LEAD: Q. There are cracks in a ceiling of our 1867 house. One contractor says the plaster has separated from the lath and recommends that the entire ceiling be taken down and replastered. A second contractor says that the plaster may have separated only in some areas, and that if he tapes the cracks, smooths out the plaster and inserts long screws into the beams, the ceiling will hold.
LEAD: Sexism plays a role even in divorces, with the parents of sons less likely to separate than the parents of daughters, according to a new study.

LEAD: Ten people died when a Taiwan Airlines commuter plane crashed into a mountain on Orchard Island, 170 miles southeast of Taipei, the Government said today. One man survived. The British-built Britten-Norman 2, a propeller-driven plane, had taken off Tuesday morning from the fishing port of Taitung, 160 miles south of Taipei, for a 20-minute flight to Orchid Island.

LEAD: THE question seems to come up at dinners among architects just when the fish course is being served: can the Los Angeles architect Frank Gehry really be designing a high-rise office tower in the shape of a fish to be built on the present Madison Square Garden site?

LEAD: Why is everybody paying so much attention to Iowa? Things are looking up for Babbitt in Iowa . . . Dole's lead in the Iowa polls is widening . . . Hart looked rattled on TV in Iowa. LEAD: Consumer prices for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose slightly in December, ending 1987 on a ''welcome quiet note'' after a 12-month increase of 5.9 percent, the largest in six years, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of labor statistics, said yesterday.

LEAD: ''THE Summer Face Woman,'' Dave Hunsaker's meditation on Aleut history and mythology, begins with a nifty nugget of musical humor, as six of its cast members gather to sing a rock-and-roll version of Johnny Horton's 1960 hit, ''North to Alaska.'' The sight of a group of actor-singers who include several Alaska natives joining together in a tune that celebrates Alaskan territory as a new American frontier ripe for conquest, sets us up for a bracing indictment of marauding exploitation.

LEAD: Despite the certainty of a legal challenge, President Reagan will soon announce rules prohibiting abortions and abortion counseling by family planning programs that receive Federal funds, White House officials said today.

LEAD: WHEN ''Woza Albert!,'' the acclaimed two-man South African play, was first presented in New York several years ago, high-powered political South African ''township'' theater was a something of a novelty. Since then, Lincoln Center's Woza Africa Theater Festival and its production of ''Sarafina!'' have familiarized us with an emotionally charged genre of spare, confrontational theater that transfuses political anger into ritualistic communal affirmation.

LEAD: President Oscar Arias Sanchez strongly criticized Nicaragua's ruling Sandinista Party on Tuesday night for arresting opposition political leaders. The Costa Rican leader said the arrests were not in accord with the pledges Nicaragua made in the Central American peace treaty.

LEAD: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said yesterday that he ''would have no objection'' to extending Rupert Murdoch's March 6 deadline on selling The New York Post if such an extension is needed ''to complete the sale.''

LEAD: The Hartford Insurance Group has laid off 400 people and indicated that more cuts might be necessary as the company tries to reduce its costs. Hartford Insurance employs 9,000 people in Connecticut and 20,000 nationwide. Donald R. Frahm, its president, said he hoped attrition might offset the need for future layoffs.

LEAD: When the Rev. Al Sharpton was being besieged Wednesday by reporters for his response to a newspaper report that he was a Federal informant, he chose to speak first to a reporter from WLIB, a New York City radio station that he calls ''the heartbeat of the black community.''

LEAD: A municipal judge ordered Glenn C. Loury, a professor at John F. Kennedy School of Government of Harvard University who was charged with posssessing drugs, to continue a program for drug treatment that he has entered since his arrest and to pay $115 in court costs and other fines.
LEAD: The board of directors of Knight-Ridder Inc. voted today to close The Detroit Free Press if a joint operating agreement with The Detroit News is not approved by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.

LEAD: To prevent the collapse of the agency that insures more than half of New Jersey's 4 million motorists, all drivers will have to pay a surcharge averaging $66 for each car they own when they renew their insurance policies, the state's Insurance Commissioner said today.

LEAD: Twenty-seven pit bull dogs seized in a raid last month were put to death today after a judge ruled they had been trained for violence. The dogs belonged to a couple who face cocaine-trafficking charges. Judge William Green said he issued the order because ''these animals have been bred and trained for no purpose other than to viciously attack other animals.

LEAD: The Stop and Shop Companies, responding to an $834 million cash offer from the Dart Group Corporation, was noncommittal yesterday but said it would review the proposal. The Haft family of Landover, Md., which controls Dart, has long been rumored to be interested in acquiring Stop and Shop, and the Boston-based retailer has taken defensive measures.
